articles.content:
Largest observed flare from a black hole unleashes the light of 10 trillion suns 
       
  By Ashley Strickland, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        7:39 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Astronomers have spotted the largest and most distant flare ever observed from a supermassive black hole. Nicknamed ‚ÄúSuperman,‚Äù the flare originated 10 billion light-years from Earth, and at its peak, the light emitted shone with the brightness of 10 trillion suns.
 

   
  The source of the flare is an active galactic nucleus, or AGN ‚Äî a bright, compact region at the center of a galaxy ‚Äî and it‚Äôs powered by a supermassive black hole that is actively feeding on material. Gas and dust fall into a rotating disk around the black hole, and as the debris spirals more rapidly, it becomes superheated, releasing intense radiation.
 

   
  Researchers pondered what the gargantuan black hole consumed to release such a powerful flare. They concluded it likely gobbled up a massive star that would have otherwise been destined to end its life by exploding.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAbout 1 in 10,000 AGN show some sort of flaring activity but this is so extreme that it puts it into its own category (which is roughly a 1 in a million event),‚Äù Matthew Graham, a research professor of astronomy at the California Institute of Technology, said in an email. Graham is the lead author of a study about the unprecedented phenomenon that published Tuesday in the journal  Nature Astronomy .
 

   
  The flare suggests there are unknown populations of giant stars near the centers of large galaxies, which also host supermassive black holes ‚Äî and sheds light on the complicated interactions between two behemoths.
 

   
    A massive stellar feast
 

   
  Superman   was first detected by the Catalina Real-Time Transient Survey and the Zwicky Transient Facility at the Palomar Observatory in Southern California in November 2018. Zwicky, which scans the night sky with a wide-field camera, has a reputation of enabling astronomers to discover transients or fleeting cosmic phenomena, such as quickly flaring supernovae.
 

   
  At first, the object didn‚Äôt seem unusual, only bright, Graham said. The team of astronomers thought it was a blazar, or a supermassive black hole that launches energetic jets of material across the cosmos.
 

   
  Five years later, they revisited early data gathered by the Zwicky survey and noticed one signal, previously thought to be a blazar, which had steadily changed in brightness. The team captured follow-up observations with other telescopes such as the W. M. Keck Observatory in Hawaii, which revealed that the source of light was more luminous and energetic than initially thought.
 

   
  The light ,  they realized, came from an active galactic nucleus estimated to be 500 million times more massive than our sun.
 

   
  The astronomers considered several possible reasons why the flare is so bright, such as a massive star exploding within the disk of material around the black hole, before determining that the most likely cause is a tidal disruption event ‚Äî when a star draws too near a black hole and gets torn apart.
 

   
  The flare is ongoing,  meaning that the black hole is still actively consuming the star, like ‚Äúa fish only halfway down the whale‚Äôs gullet,‚Äù Graham said.
 

   
  Superman peaked at a brightness that was 30 times more luminous than any other known black hole flare, and the star being consumed by the black hole has a mass at least 30 times greater than that of the sun. The previous record for a tidal disruption event   was set by ZTF20abrbeie, nicknamed ‚ÄúScary Barbie,‚Äù which was caused when a black hole gobbled up a star between three and 10 times the size of our sun.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is probably the most massive star ever seen shredded by a supermassive black hole,‚Äù study coauthor K.E. Saavik Ford, an astronomy professor at the Borough of Manhattan Community College and a research associate in the department of astrophysics at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, said in a statement. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs exciting because it tells us that massive stars must live in and around gas disks around super-massive black holes.‚Äù
 

   
    Peering inside the hearts of galaxies
 

   
  The team continues to monitor the flare as it fades over time ‚Äî although time passes differently near a black hole compared with how it‚Äôs experienced on Earth, Graham said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a phenomenon called cosmological time dilation due to stretching of space and time. As the light travels across expanding space to reach us, its wavelength stretches as does time itself,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSeven years here is two years there. We are watching the event play back at quarter speed.‚Äù
 

   
  Since the flare occurred 10 billion light-years away, it‚Äôs taken 10 billion years for the light to reach Earth. A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, which is  5.88 trillion miles  (9.46 trillion kilometers).
 

   
  By combing through Zwicky‚Äôs data and using new telescopes, such as the Vera C. Rubin Observatory in Chile, it may be possible to identify more of these rare events, which showcase that supermassive black holes have dynamic environments and are far more than big sinkholes surrounded by swirling material, Graham said.
 

   
  Flares such as this one reveal the presence of incredibly large stars near the hearts of galaxies and shed light on the very structure of galaxies, Ford said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúUnderstanding the stars in the centers of galaxies (how many are there, what are they like) at such early times in the universe gives us a new way of investigating galaxy assembly over all,‚Äù she noted.
 

   
  The discovery represents an astonishing leap in our understanding of the universe‚Äôs most powerful events, said Dr. Danny Milisavljevic, associate professor of physics and astronomy at Purdue University. Milisavljevic was not involved in the new study but previously researched the ‚ÄúScary Barbie‚Äù event.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe once thought ‚ÄòScary Barbie‚Äô was a bizarre, one-of-a-kind anomaly, but this new flare is even more extreme, releasing as much energy as if the entire Sun were converted completely into electromagnetic radiation,‚Äù he wrote in an email.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt belongs to a newly emerging class of extreme nuclear transients (ENTs), a poorly understood phenomenon that is challenging our current models of how black holes and stars interact.‚Äù
 

   
  The flare reveals insights into the growth of black holes, how they rip apart nearby stars and how their immense energy can shape the galaxies around them, said Alex Filippenko, distinguished professor of astronomy at the University of California, Berkeley. Filippenko did not participate in the new research, but his work has established a strong foundation for active galactic nuclei physics.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhen a supermassive black hole suddenly erupts in a brilliant flare, it gives astronomers a front-row seat to some of the most extreme physics in the Universe,‚Äù he wrote in an email. ‚ÄúBy catching this record-breaking brightening, astronomers have opened a new window into the extreme physics of galactic centers, where stars, gas, and gravity collide in the Universe‚Äôs most violent laboratories.‚Äù

articles.content:
What Elon Musk could buy with $1 trillion 
       
  Analysis by Allison Morrow, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        6:07 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  As expected, Tesla shareholders did a truly unprecedented thing, approving a pay package for Elon Musk that could, over the next decade, turn the CEO into the world‚Äôs first trillionaire.
 

   
  First, some important caveats: Tesla and Musk need to hit certain milestones, including raising its already lofty market capitalization by 466%. Is it possible? Sure. Probable?  Depends on whom you ask . But since there‚Äôs a not-zero chance Musk pulls it off, it‚Äôs worth exploring what we talk about when we talk about a ‚Äútrillion.‚Äù
 

   
  A lot of tech and financial media have been tossing the T-word around lately as if it means something. The thing is, it doesn‚Äôt. You know how I know that? Quick, think of a trillion ‚Ä¶ anything. A trillion dollar bills. A trillion grains of sand. A trillion puppies. Whatever you‚Äôre imagining that number to look like, you‚Äôre way off. One trillion is so much comically larger than anything we can wrap our heads around, it‚Äôs practically meaningless.
 

   
  And that is, in part, why Tesla, in its pivot to become an AI and robotics company, is leaning into hyperbole. If I‚Äôd told you that Tesla just approved an eleventy-gazillion-jillion-dollar package, it wouldn‚Äôt make much of a difference. Musk already has a $475 billion fortune ‚Äî more money than any one person anywhere, ever, in the history of the world, and needless to say more money than any person could ever spend.
 

   
  Consider the example cited by  KRWG columnist Jerry Pacheco  in 2020: If you spent $40 per second, around the clock, it would take you 289 days to exhaust a  billion  dollars. If you did the same thing with a trillion dollars, it would take you 792.5 years to go broke.
 

   
  Just for kicks, though, let‚Äôs explore what happens when a 1 is followed by 12 zeros. What could you buy? What would it look like?
 

   
  For a trillion bucks, you could acquire:
 

   
  - 1,428 peak Shohei Ohtanis.  Ohtani, possibly the greatest baseball player ever, secured a $700 million contract over 10 years with the Dodgers. A measly 0.07% of a trillion.
 

   
  - Every single car sold in the United States this year.  Terrible investment, though ‚Äî those things start losing value the moment you drive them off the lot.
 

   
   -10,000 CEOs of Starbucks.  Brian Niccol, the coffee chain boss, is paid a pauper‚Äôs sum of nearly $100 million.
 

   
  - 333 supertall skyscrapers.  If you‚Äôre in the New York area you might have glimpsed the new JPMorgan Chase headquarters on Park Ave and thought, ‚Äúwow, that probably cost a fortune.‚Äù And you‚Äôd be right:  It cost $3 billion ! That is a fortune. But you‚Äôd have to build it roughly 333 more times to hit $1 trillion.
 

   
  - 2,000 Jeff Bezos yachts.  Though you‚Äôll need to budget about  $25 million per boat , each year, for maintenance.
 

   
   - 465  Icon of the Seas.   If you want more of a party-boat vibe, you could buy Royal Caribbean‚Äôs   Icon of the Seas , the world‚Äôs largest cruise ship. You could buy 465 of them, in fact. And that‚Äôs also about as many ships as are in the US Navy, which is a fine size for your own personal fleet.
 

   
   -The entire Ivy League, five times over.  Collectively, the endowments of the eight most elite American universities come out to about $200 billion. You can‚Äôt put a price on education, of course, but for a fifth of a trillion, the Ivy League is steal.
 

   
  - A $2,923 bonus for every single person in the United States.  Look at you, being so charitable! (Beware the inflation, though ‚Äî we‚Äôve  been down this path before .)
 

   
  - Switzerland.  OK, honestly, not sure if you can buy a  country,  but the landlocked Alpine nation‚Äôs nominal annual GDP came in at just under $900 billion last year. A flipper‚Äôs dream!
 

   
   -Every house in Hawaii.  There are 572,781 households in Hawaii, and according to Zillow they go for only $826,575, on average.  Eat your heart out, Larry Ellison .
 

   
   -Coca-Cola, plus a Coke for everyone on the planet.  Drop a cool $300 billion on the corporation, and you‚Äôll still have plenty left over to buy all 8.2 billion   humans a 12-pack of Coke.
 

   
   -Toyota, Volkswagen, Stellantis, Hyundai, Ford, and GM.  If you want to compete against Tesla, you‚Äôre gonna need scale.
 

   
   -ExxonMobil, Chevron, and ConocoPhillips.  Who knows, maybe the whole electric car thing doesn‚Äôt work out, and Tesla decides to get into the internal combustion business. Buying the top three largest American oil companies could help there, too.
 

   
   Bottom line:  For better or worse, we‚Äôre entering an era in which companies and their CEOs can amass wealth in numbers so large, our brains actually don‚Äôt know how to understand them. The wealth at the top is incomprehensible ‚Äî orders of magnitude beyond the numbers most of us glean from our own bank statements. One quasi-upside? Understanding the absurdity of one trillion anything makes the $38 trillion US national debt that economists have been blathering on about for years look almost sensible. Our giant national debt is just 38 potential Elon Musks? Just 7.5 Nvidias? Eh, I‚Äôm sure we can manage that.
 

   
   ‚ÄîCNN‚Äôs Chris Isidore contributed to this article.

articles.title: NTSB Investigates UPS Plane Crash Near Louisville After Engine Detachment During Takeoff
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A UPS MD-11 cargo plane crashed near Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on November 5, 2025, after a left engine detached during takeoff, killing at least 13 people and causing widespread destruction. More than 20 NTSB officials are on site examining wreckage, including the black boxes, engine, and fan blades. Investigators are focusing on the engine detachment, recent maintenance records from San Antonio, and flight data from the black boxes. The crash site spanned half a mile, with significant damage and trapped individuals. The NTSB will release a preliminary report in 30 days, with a full investigation expected to take 18 to 24 months. The incident has deeply affected the local community, with families seeking answers about how such a tragedy could have occurred.
keyTakeAways: A UPS MD-11 cargo plane crashed near Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on November 5, 2025, after a left engine detached during takeoff.
The crash resulted in at least 13 fatalities, including three UPS crew members and nine community members believed to be in the area at the time of the crash.
More than 20 NTSB officials are on site examining the wreckage, including the black boxes, a detached engine, and multiple engine fan blades.
The NTSB will analyze the crash site, engine condition, maintenance records, and flight data from the black boxes to determine the cause of the disaster.
The plane's engine detached prematurely, as shown in airport surveillance footage, and the engine rupture likely caused a fuel tank failure and subsequent explosion.
Investigators are reviewing recent maintenance in San Antonio, which temporarily grounded the aircraft for six weeks, to assess if any mechanical issues contributed to the crash.
The black boxes have provided 63 hours of flight data and two hours of cockpit audio, which may reveal critical moments leading up to the crash.
The debris field was extensive, stretching over half a mile, with significant damage to nearby businesses and homes; some individuals were trapped for up to 90 minutes due to high fencing.
Air quality monitoring was conducted post-crash due to the intense fire and explosion, though no hazardous cargo was involved.
Family members of victims are seeking answers to understand how such a catastrophic event could have occurred.

articles.content:
These are the key factors investigators will examine to determine the cause of the Louisville UPS plane crash 
       
  By Lauren Mascarenhas, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:42 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  More than two dozen officials with the National Transportation and Safety Board are on site and have begun sifting through the  mangled remnants  of a UPS cargo plane that crashed after an engine detached during takeoff near Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport.
 

   
  They‚Äôll try to determine what led to the disaster that killed  at least 13 people  while  destroying nearby businesses  and buildings.
 

   
  Investigators on the ground have started collecting parts of the plane ‚Äì including its black boxes, an engine and multiple pieces of engine fan blades ‚Äì which will be transported to a safe location for further examination, the NTSB said Thursday.
 

   
  The NTSB will release a preliminary report within 30 days, but it could be 18 to 24 months before the investigation concludes, according to  Jim Brauchle , an aviation attorney with law firm Motley Rice and former US Air Force navigator.
 

   
  In the wake of Tuesday‚Äôs tragedy, family members of the crash victims will be waiting for the answers investigators are working to uncover, Brauchle told CNN. In addition to the three UPS crew members identified from the plane, nine community members have been reported missing and were believed to be in the area at the time of the crash, Louisville Mayor Craig Greenberg said Thursday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe one thing that all these family members, based on my experience, want to know is: How this could have happened?‚Äù Brauchle said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not something that happens every day, but I see it a lot. It‚Äôs more than grief.‚Äù
 

   
  Here are some of theÔªø   factors aviation experts say will be key to the investigation.
 

   
    The crash site
 

   
  The crash left a half-mile-long  debris field , and the first priority is dealing with rescue and recovery, said Mary Schiavo, CNN aviation analyst and former Department of Transportation inspector general.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCrash investigators have scoured miles of Scottish countryside ( PanAm flight 103 ), miles of ocean floor ( TWA flight 800 ), and the southern Indian Ocean ( Malaysia Airlines flight 370 ),‚Äù she said, referencing previous plane crashes. ‚ÄúThey carefully map where pieces are recovered. There are great software programs that help you do this as you work a debris field.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúLouisville looked apocalyptic,‚Äù Rep. Morgan McGarvey  said  at a news conference Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe images of smoke coming over our city, of debris falling in every neighborhood, people trapped in their homes.‚Äù
 

   
  Two employees of Kentucky Truck Parts and Service, whose shop is located on the edge of the debris field,  told CNN affiliate WLKY  they were knocked back by the explosion.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe flames were so bad. You can feel the heat,‚Äù said one of the men. ‚ÄúWe made a decision: run for our lives.‚Äù
 

   
  High fencing blocked their escape and the men remained trapped for around 90 minutes until police arrived with bolt cutters.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much debris there, there‚Äôs so much charred, mangled metal, that not all the bodies may have been located underneath certain things,‚Äù Greenberg said Thursday on the search for more possible victims. ‚ÄúGoing through the various layers (of) debris on the field, that will begin now. Everything to date has been just looking at what can be seen without moving debris.‚Äù
 

   
  Though the plane was not carrying any hazardous cargo that would ‚Äúcreate an environmental issue,‚Äù Beshear said, officials monitored Louisville‚Äôs  air quality  in the wake of the crash, according to the mayor.
 

   
    The engine
 

   
  The left engine of the plane detached during takeoff, NSTB member Todd Inman said Wednesday, citing  airport surveillance footage  viewed by the agency.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBoth the condition of the engine and the location of the engine will be of paramount importance to the NTSB,‚Äù Schiavo said. ‚ÄúThe most recent maintenance will give a pretty good idea of the health of the engines.‚Äù
 

   
  It‚Äôs possible pieces flying off of one failing engine could have impacted other key parts of the plane, and the engine likely ruptured the wing fuel tank when it ripped from the plane, she said.
 

   
  The MD-11 is equipped with three engines: one on each wing and one on the tail.
 

   
  Investigators ‚Äúfound multiple pieces of engine fan blades along with the main component of the engine of the number one engine, which is on the left side of the aircraft,‚Äù Inman said Thursday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf this engine did indeed come off prematurely, as it appears it did, then you‚Äôre going to be looking for the engine mounts. You‚Äôre going to be looking at the bolts themselves. All of those pieces need to be recovered and brought back in,‚Äù Soucie said.
 

   
  The NTSB is asking people to report any debris found in surrounding areas, which could help provide investigators with some of the answers they‚Äôre searching for.
 

   
    The black boxes
 

   
  NTSB investigators have recovered the plane‚Äôs so-called  black boxes  ‚Äì the cockpit voice recorder and the flight data recorder ‚Äì which could hold crucial information about the moments before the disaster.
 

   
  Officials were able to extract 63 hours of flight data and two hours of audio from the black boxes, NTSB member Chihoon Shin said Thursday.
 

   
  Black box recovery is critical,  experts say , because the technology can point to what pilots were saying before a crash.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs suffered some heat, not intrusion, but heat around it. These recorders are built for that,‚Äù Inman said Wednesday.
 

   
  The agency will know more about what the black boxes contain once they are transported back to Washington, DC, Inman said.
 

   
  Black boxes can survive a fire ‚Äì but not always, Schiavo said.
 

   
    Recent plane maintenance
 

   
  NTSB investigators always look at three things when dealing with a crash: ‚ÄúThey look into the environment. They look into the pilots. They look at the airplane,‚Äù CNN correspondent  Pete Muntean , who is also a pilot and flight instructor, said Wednesday.
 

   
  Since the weather was pretty fair at the time of the crash and the NTSB had few initial takeaways about the environment, the airplane itself will be key, Muntean said.
 

   
  The plane went through some previous maintenance in San Antonio that put it out of commission for six weeks, Inman said Thursday. All service records all being pulled for investigators to review, he added.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe maintenance will be the big issue ‚Äî what exactly was done to the aircraft, who did it, what parts were replaced, what procedures were followed, and who inspected the work,‚Äù Schiavo said.
 

   
  It‚Äôs too soon to know for sure whether any maintenance issues impacted the crash, Muntean stressed on Wednesday. Some of the initial videos and images from the crash are revealing, though, Schiavo said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe most telling photo is the one where the engine is separated from the rest of the wreckage, showing it separated from the plane before the final crash and explosion. This reveals the pilots were left with no ability to control this plane,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe fire on takeoff shows that something was wrong right from the start.‚Äù
 

   
  The plane‚Äôs takeoff was not delayed, and no maintenance work was done immediately before the crash, according to UPS, Inman said. NTSB investigators will independently verify that and ‚Äúwill be going back and looking at every aspect of maintenance that was done on this plane,‚Äù he added.

articles.title: Facing a spike in deadly bear attacks, Japan turns to the military and drones that bark
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Japan is facing a record surge in deadly bear attacks, primarily in northern and central prefectures like Akita and Gifu, driven by climate change, habitat loss, and population shifts. A poor acorn harvest and warmer winters are disrupting bear food sources and seasonal patterns, leading to increased foraging in human-populated areas. Despite legal restrictions on culling, local authorities have requested military and police assistance for logistical support, such as transporting bear carcasses and setting traps. The Self-Defense Forces and National Police Agency are stepping in without killing bears, while local governments experiment with drones that play dog barks and fireworks to deter them. Conservation groups oppose lethal measures, advocating for habitat restoration. The crisis reflects a broader cultural tension between reverence for nature and the urgent need for public safety, with international attention drawn by the UK‚Äôs travel advisory warning.
keyTakeAways: Japan is experiencing a record number of bear attacks due to climate change, habitat loss, and population shifts.
The bear population, especially brown and Asiatic black bears, has increased significantly over the past 30 years due to environmental protections.
Climate change is disrupting natural cycles, such as food availability (e.g., poor acorn harvests), leading to bears foraging farther and more frequently into human areas.
Japan‚Äôs aging rural population and abandoned farmland have created more accessible pathways for bears to move into towns and villages.
Military and national police forces are being deployed for logistical support, not culling, due to legal restrictions on killing bears.
Local authorities are experimenting with non-lethal deterrents such as drones that play dog barks and fireworks to scare bears away.
Cultural tensions exist between the reverence of bears as mountain deities in Shinto and Buddhist traditions and the need for public safety.
Conservation groups are actively opposing culling, advocating for habitat restoration and non-lethal solutions to address the root causes of the problem.
The British government has issued a bear warning for Japan, indicating the issue has global implications for international travel safety.

articles.content:
Facing a spike in deadly bear attacks, Japan turns to the military and drones that bark 
       
  By Jessie Yeung, Junko Ogura, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        7:58 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  When Japanese soldiers arrived in the northern prefecture of Akita on Thursday, they prepared to face a new kind of threat ‚Äì one with fuzzy ears and up to 220 pounds of mass.
 

   
  This mountainous region is known for its lush forests, lakes and valleys ‚Äì and for being a hotspot for this year‚Äôs deadly bear attacks in  Japan .
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe situation has already surpassed what the prefecture and municipalities can handle on their own, and exhaustion on the ground is reaching its limit,‚Äù said Akita Gov. Kenta Suzuki in an Instagram post last month.
 

   
  It‚Äôs a national problem, fueled by the climate crisis and habitat change. Across Japan, at least 13 people have killed and more than 100 injured since April this year, according to government figures ‚Äì the highest numbers since records began in 2006.
 

   
  In October alone, shoppers were attacked in a  supermarket , a Spanish tourist was scratched by a cub at a heritage site, and a trail runner was forced to  wrestle a bear  in the woods before sprinting to safety. The problem has become so bad that the British government  added a bear warning  in its travel advisory for Japan.
 

   
  In Akita, local authorities requested formal military assistance from Japan‚Äôs Self-Defense Forces, saying their existing measures ‚Äì including box traps and bear repellant sprays ‚Äì weren‚Äôt enough.
 

   
  But the troops won‚Äôt be culling the bears ‚Äì they‚Äôre not allowed to under Japanese law. Instead, they‚Äôll provide logistical support, like setting up traps and transporting carcasses shot by hunters.
 

   
  The actual culling is reserved for licensed hunters and local hunting associations, some of whom do it recreationally or as a part-time job. But this group is shrinking and  aging rapidly  amid Japan‚Äôs demographic crisis, Reuters reported last year ‚Äì prompting fears that they alone can‚Äôt handle the scope of the problem.
 

   
  The federal government has acknowledged these limitations. ‚ÄúLocal governments and hunting associations, who work together as wildlife control teams, are now severely exhausted,‚Äù Defense Minister Shinjiro Koizumi said at a news conference in October. ‚ÄúI believe it is only natural to consider what can be done in response to requests from local governors.‚Äù
 

   
  The National Police Agency announced Thursday riot police would be authorized to shoot the animals in residential areas of Akita and Iwate prefectures, when hunters can‚Äôt respond in time.
 

   
  Local authorities also considering more tech-based countermeasures, such as AI-equipped surveillance cameras and drone-based alert systems, said Suzuki. Similarly, in central Gifu prefecture, the government is  experimenting  with drones that play the sound of dogs barking and fireworks, in a bid to scare bears away.
 

   
  Meanwhile, residents and officials remain on edge. Far fewer people are  going camping,  a popular activity in the cool fall weather; in some cities, staff are  handing out flyers  warning picnic-goers not to leave food lying around, NHK reported.
 

   
  Some Akita residents, afraid they could stumble upon a bear at any moment, have taken to loudly rattling their door handles before leaving the house,  the defense minister said,  adding: ‚ÄúThat is the level of anxiety residents are now living in every day.‚Äù
 

   
    Climate change and blurring boundaries
 

   
  Though this year marks a record surge in attacks, the number of bear-human incidents has been steadily rising for several years.
 

   
  Experts say this is partly because bears are increasingly venturing out of their traditional habitats and into urban areas in search of food. Some suggest this is because climate change is interfering with the flowering and pollination of some of the animals‚Äô traditional sources of food.
 

   
  The Ministry of Environment blamed this year‚Äôs surge on  a poor acorn harvest  ‚Äì which drove a similar  spate of attacks in 2023. 
 

   
  Climate change could also be changing their seasonal patterns; warmer winters could lead to delayed hibernation, which could increase encounters with humans, some studies suggest.
 

   
  Another factor may be Japan‚Äôs demographic shift, experts say. For years, younger generations have flocked to big cities for better job opportunities, leaving a dwindling elderly population in rural villages. That means more abandoned farmland, overgrown bushes and fruit trees, and fewer people along the borders of these towns ‚Äì making it easier for bears to cross into inhabited areas.
 

   
  There are also just more bears these days. Bears were once hunted so much in Japan that their population dropped precipitously ‚Äì but environmental protections were introduced in the 1990s, allowing the bear population to recover.
 

   
  Brown bears, mostly seen in Japan‚Äôs northernmost Hokkaido Island, more than  doubled in 30 years , according to government estimates ‚Äì reaching 12,000 today. The number of Asiatic black bears, seen on Japan‚Äôs largest Honshu Island, also rose by 1.4 times between 2003 and 2018 ‚Äì now reaching  more than 42,000. 
 

   
  It has strained the relationship between the mammals and Japanese communities ‚Äì with government efforts swinging back and forth between conservation and targeted culling over the years.
 

   
  Culturally, Shinto and Buddhist traditions emphasize respect for life and nature, which are deeply valued in Japan; in Nagano and Gifu prefectures, black bears are sometimes revered as mountain deities, researchers wrote  in a paper  this summer. But at the same time, bears are a very real danger that can damage property and harm humans ‚Äì causing a ‚Äúdeep-seated cultural tension,‚Äù wrote the researchers.
 

   
  That tension is evident, with some people protesting proposals for expanded culling and hunting. The conservation group  Kumamori,  which claims to have 21,000 members, has urged the government to seek non-lethal measures and to regrow damaged habitats so bears can return to the mountains instead.   ‚ÄúTwo years ago, the number of incidents dropped sharply once we entered November,‚Äù Suzuki said on Instagram, referencing the 2023 spike. ‚ÄúWe are determined to make it through the peak of this autumn season as well.‚Äù

articles.content:
Tesla shareholders approve Elon Musk‚Äôs $1 trillion pay package 
       
  By Chris Isidore, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:34 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Tesla shareholders approved a pay package on Thursday that could make CEO Elon Musk, already the world‚Äôs richest person, the world‚Äôs first trillionaire.
 

   
  Tesla announced that more than 75% of shares voted in favor of the pay package during the company‚Äôs annual shareholder meeting. The vote didn‚Äôt include the 15% of the company that Musk already owns.
 

   
  The crowd at the meeting broke into cheers and chants when the results were announced. Musk thanked the shareholders and the Tesla board soon after. ‚ÄúI super appreciate it,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Musk doesn‚Äôt take any salary, but the approved pay package comes in the form of a stock grant that would give him as much as 423.7 million additional Tesla shares over the next 10 years.
 

   
  Those shares could be worth about $1 trillion, assuming the company reaches the $8.5 trillion market cap needed to have Musk qualify for the full potential payout. In addition, Tesla needs to achieve a series of either operational or financial targets for him to get the full number of shares, which would be distributed in 12 equal blocks.
 

   
  Getting all the shares available under this package over the next 10 years would be the equivalent of earning $275 million a day, dwarfing any other executive pay package in history.
 

   
    Lofty targets for stock growth
 

   
  For Tesla to reach the $8.5 trillion in market value needed, shares need to jump 466% from today‚Äôs stock price. That‚Äôs also about 70% higher than the world‚Äôs most valuable company, Nvidia, which hit a record  $5 trillion market cap  last week.
 

   
  Musk is already worth an estimated $473 billion according to  Bloomberg‚Äôs billionaire tracker , most due to his holdings in Tesla, as well as the other companies he controls, including SpaceX and xAI.
 

   
  A vote to reject the pay package Thursday could have meant his exit from Tesla‚Äôs CEO office. Tesla‚Äôs board said in a filing that Musk had raised the possibility of leaving the company if he didn‚Äôt get the assurances of control that the pay package could grant him.
 

   
  However, the company has had a rocky year. Sales and profits plunged in the first half and Tesla faces potential billions in lost revenue due to reduced US government support for electric vehicles.
 

   
    A future bet on robots and AI
 

   
  But Musk and Tesla executives dismiss those problems, saying Tesla is shifting focus from merely selling EVs to selling self-driving cars, including a fleet of ‚Äúrobotaxis,‚Äù as well as humanoid robots.
 

   
  In his remarks to shareholders, Musk spoke more about robots, which have yet to go on sale, than he did about the company‚Äôs cars. Most of his references to cars were about its so-called full self-driving (FSD), a driver assistance feature that still requires drivers to stay alert and ready to take control of the cars.
 

   
  But Musk said the robots will be bigger than the company‚Äôs car business - or any other business, even.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs going to be the biggest product of all time by far,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo like bigger than cell phones, bigger than anything. I guess a way to think about it is that every human on Earth is going to want to have their own personal R2D2 or C3PO.‚Äù
 

   
  He even predicted Tesla‚Äôs robots could replace surgeons, lead to the end of global poverty and re-shape the global economic order. He claims they could be produced for $20,000 each, allowing the company to sell them for about the price of a car.
 

   
  Still, those products and concepts are still under development and haven‚Äôt gone on sale. That means even with the passage of the pay package, it‚Äôs not certain that Musk will ever see any of its potential hundreds of millions of shares. He will need to straighten out the company‚Äôs current problems and then live up to the big promises that he‚Äôs made for the future.
 

   
  Musk has insisted he needs the additional shares to have more control over the company, not because he wants so much more wealth.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like I‚Äôm going to go spend the money,‚Äù Musk said on a call with investors last month. ‚ÄúThere needs to be enough voting control to give (me) a strong influence ‚Äì but not so much that I can‚Äôt be fired if I go insane.‚Äù
 

   
   This story has been updated with additional reporting and context.

Weapons cache believed linked to Hamas found in Vienna by Austria‚Äôs intelligence service 
       
  Story by Associated Press
 

       
Updated: 
        4:19 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: AP
 
   
   Austria‚Äôs domestic intelligence service has uncovered a weapons cache in Vienna that is believed to be linked to the Palestinian militant group Hamas for use in ‚Äúpossible terrorist attacks in Europe,‚Äù the government said Thursday.
 

   
  A 39-year-old unidentified British citizen allegedly ‚Äúhaving close ties to the weapons cache‚Äù was arrested in London on Monday, the interior ministry statement said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAccording to the current state of the investigation, Israeli or Jewish institutions in Europe were likely to be the targets of these attacks,‚Äù it added.
 

   
  The weapons cache and the suspect were part of an internationally coordinated investigation by the country‚Äôs Directorate for State Security and Intelligence service, or DSN, ‚Äúinto a global terrorist organization with ties to Hamas.‚Äù
 

   
  In the course of the investigations, the ministry said its intelligence service found ‚Äúsuspicion that a group has brought weapons into Austria to use in possible terrorist attacks in Europe.‚Äù
 

   
  Germany‚Äôs federal prosecutor‚Äôs office later on Thursday identified the suspect as Mohammed A. in line with German privacy lines. It said in a statement that he met up twice with Abdel Al G.  who was arrested in Germany last month  on suspicion of plotting attacks on Israeli or Jewish institutions in Germany.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOn these occasions, Mohammed A. took over five handguns and ammunition from Abed Al G. He then transported the weapons to Austria and stored them in Vienna,‚Äù the prosecutor‚Äôs statement said. ‚ÄúThese actions served to prepare terrorist attacks on Israeli or Jewish facilities in Germany.‚Äù
 

   
  The statement said that ‚Äúafter his extradition from Great Britain,‚Äù the suspect will be brought before an investigating judge at the Federal Court of Justice in Germany.
 

   
  In a statement at the time, Hamas denied having any connection to the suspects arrested in Germany last month, describing the allegations of a link to the group as baseless. The group has carried out hundreds of attacks against Israeli civilians over the years but has rarely operated outside Israel and the Palestinian territories.
 

   
  The weapons cache, which is thought to belong to unspecified foreign operations linked to Hamas, was discovered in a suitcase in a rented storage room in Vienna and contained five handguns and 10 accompanying magazines.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe current case shows once again that the Directorate for State Security and Intelligence has an excellent international network and takes consistent action against all forms of extremism,‚Äù Austrian Interior Minister Gerhard Karner said. ‚ÄúThe mission is clear: zero tolerance for terrorists.‚Äù
 

   
  Britain‚Äôs National Crime Agency confirmed on Thursday that a 39-year-old was arrested in central London on Monday by specialist officers from the NCA‚Äôs National Extradition Unit. He is being held in custody until his next appearance at Westminster Magistrates‚Äô Court on Monday.

articles.title: Hundreds of US Flights Cut Amid Ongoing Government Shutdown
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The ongoing government shutdown, which began on October 1, 2025, has led to a significant reduction in US flights as the Trump administration orders a 10% cut in flight volume at 40 major airports, including the 'Core 30' high-traffic hubs and 10 additional locations. This includes major cities like New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston, and Atlanta. Airlines such as Delta, United, American, and Southwest have canceled hundreds of flights, with reductions increasing by 1% daily. The reductions are driven by staffing shortages‚Äîover 400 air traffic controllers have resigned or are working without pay‚Äîraising safety concerns. However, the FAA and NTSB argue that reducing flight volume improves safety by reducing controller workload. Travelers are advised to book backup tickets, avoid layovers, and use direct airline bookings to mitigate risks. No compensation is currently offered for stranded travelers, and airlines state that disruptions beyond their control are not eligible for reimbursement.
keyTakeAways: Hundreds of US flights are being canceled starting Friday due to the ongoing government shutdown.

The FAA has identified 40 airports‚Äîcomprising the 'Core 30' high-traffic hubs and 10 additional sites‚Äîfor flight reductions, including major cities like New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Atlanta, and Houston.

A 10% reduction in flight volume is targeted, though it's unclear whether this applies to the 40 airports or all US flights. Airline schedules are being cut by 4% starting Friday, increasing by 1% daily.

Major airlines such as Delta, United, American, and Southwest have canceled hundreds of flights, with Delta canceling ~170 flights, United ~200, and American and Southwest canceling around 220 per day.
Airline officials and travelers are advised to book backup tickets and avoid layovers to reduce risk of being stranded.
The shutdown has caused over 400 staffing shortages in FAA facilities, with air traffic controllers resigning daily due to unpaid wages, raising safety concerns.

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has stated that low staffing and mandatory overtime directly impact aviation safety, supporting the decision to reduce flight volume as a safety measure.
No compensation is currently available for travelers stranded due to flight cancellations, as most airlines state that disruptions beyond their control are not eligible for reimbursement.
The Trump administration and FAA are implementing flight reductions to maintain safety, despite the lack of immediate compensation for affected passengers.

articles.content:
Hundreds of US flights are getting slashed Friday as the shutdown continues. Here‚Äôs what to know if you‚Äôre about to fly 
       
  By Holly Yan, Pete Muntean, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        6:18 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Millions of Americans expecting to fly this month could have their plans grounded if the  government shutdown  drags on.
 

   
  Starting Friday, the Trump administration will  reduce flights at 40 airports nationwide  if the shutdown continues.
 

   
  The Federal Aviation Administration‚Äôs ‚ÄúCore 30‚Äù airports are among those on a preliminary list of sites expected to be impacted, an FAA source with direct knowledge of the situation told CNN.
 

   
  Several major airlines have preemptively canceled hundreds of flights scheduled for Friday. The cancellations will impact airlines like a busy weather day, one airline official told CNN. Unlike a storm, however, they will be spread across multiple cities as opposed to a geographic region.
 

   
  Here‚Äôs what to know if the travel nightmare turns into reality Friday:
 

   
     Which 40 airports will lose flights?  
 

   
   The ‚ÄúCore 30‚Äù high-traffic airports  include New York City‚Äôs three major hubs and large airports in Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Denver, Honolulu, Houston, Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Miami, Phoenix, Seattle and Washington, DC, the source said.
 

   
   Another 10 airports  across the country are expected to be impacted, including ones in Anchorage, Alaska; Indianapolis; Portland, Oregon; and Ontario, California. Some smaller airports in the ‚ÄúCore 30‚Äù cities are also on the list.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAs we start to implement this drawdown in service, it will be restricted to these 40 high-volume traffic markets,‚Äù FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to ask the airlines to work with us collaboratively to reduce their schedules.‚Äù
 

   
    How many flights will be cut?
 

   
  Flight volume will be reduced by 10%, Secretary of Transportation Sean Duffy said Thursday. But he did not say whether that‚Äôs 10% of the flight volume at the 40 impacted airports, or 10% of all US flights ‚Äì which would be significantly more.
 

   
  Either way, a 10% reduction could result in thousands of canceled flights a day ‚Äì an unprecedented cut.
 

   
  Airline officials said they were told Thursday to cut 4% of flights at those airports starting Friday, increasing by 1% each day the shutdown drags on.
 

   
    Which airlines have canceled flights on Friday?
 

   
  While most major airlines said the impact would be limited or that they‚Äôre evaluating the potential impact, the four largest US airlines have preemptively canceled hundreds of flights scheduled for Friday.
 

   
  Delta Air Lines has canceled around 170 regional and mainline flights that were scheduled on Friday, and more regional flights will be canceled, a spokesperson for the carrier told CNN.   
 

   
  United Airlines told CNN it will preemptively cancel about 200 flights starting Friday, roughly 4% of the airline‚Äôs Friday schedule and comprising mostly regional flights. It will cancel about 4% again on Saturday and Sunday, the airline said.
 

   
  American Airlines said it expects the ‚Äúvast majority‚Äù of its customers‚Äô flights would not be affected and long-haul international service will remain as scheduled.
 

   
  American has reduced flight schedules by 4% at 40 airports Friday through Monday, amounting to about 220 flights canceled each day, citing the FAA‚Äôs requirement, according to airline spokesperson Sarah Jantz. ‚ÄúEven with these cancellations, we plan to operate around 6,000 daily flights,‚Äù Jantz told CNN.
 

   
  Around 100 Southwest Airlines flights will be canceled Friday, the airline said. A Southwest spokesperson urged Congress to ‚Äúimmediately resolve its impasse‚Äù and said the airline is determining the schedule adjustments needed to meet the FAA‚Äôs flight reductions.
 

   
    I have travel plans in the coming days. What should I do?
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf you are flying Friday or in the next ten days and need to be there or don‚Äôt want to be stranded I highly recommend booking a backup ticket on another carrier,‚Äù Frontier Airlines CEO Barry Biffle  posted  on Instagram.
 

   
  ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt book a basic ticket. For example, book Economy on Frontier so you can reuse the ticket value as changes are free or you can get a credit,‚Äù Biffle wrote. ‚ÄúIf your flight is cancelled your chances of being stranded are high so I would simply have a backup ticket on another airline.‚Äù
 

   
  American, Delta, Southwest, United and Frontier are all offering waivers to allow passengers who do not want to fly to change their tickets without fees.
 

   
  It‚Äôs also helpful to book directly with an airline instead of through a third-party website. That‚Äôs because if your flight gets canceled, you might have to deal with another party to resolve the problem.
 

   
  And try to avoid booking flights with layovers, the  US Public Interest Research Group  says. The more planes you have to get on to reach your destination, the more chances you have for a flight to be delayed or canceled.
 

   
    What if I‚Äôm stuck at another airport and my flight gets canceled? Will anyone pay for a hotel?
 

   
  The Department of Transportation has not said what compensation ‚Äì if any ‚Äì would be given to travelers who lose their connecting flights or are otherwise stuck in another city due to the shutdown.
 

   
   Delta Air Lines  said compensation isn‚Äôt available for disruptions that the company can‚Äôt control, a common rule at most airlines.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPlease note that expense reimbursements are not available for flights that are delayed or canceled due to adverse weather events or other circumstances outside of Delta‚Äôs control, including without limitation for hotels, rental cars, meals, ground transportation and other pre-paid expenses,‚Äù Delta said in a statement.
 

   
    Why is all this happening?
 

   
  The government shutdown, which started on October 1, has prevented many federal employees from getting paid.
 

   
  Air traffic controllers and Transportation Security Administration screeners are considered essential employees during the shutdown and are expected to go to work. But they‚Äôre not getting paid, and some have needed to find other sources of income to pay the bills.
 

   
  ‚ÄúControllers are resigning every day now because of the prolonged nature of the shutdown,‚Äù said Nick Daniels, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre also 400 controllers short ‚Äî shorter than we were in the 2019 shutdown.‚Äù
 

   
  More than 400 staffing shortages have been reported at FAA facilities since the shutdown began, according to a CNN analysis.
 

   
    If airports are short-staffed, is it still safe to fly?
 

   
  The longer the shutdown drags on, the more risks could emerge ‚Äì especially as controllers go longer without pay, the union leader said earlier this week. But federal officials say reducing the number of flights will improve safety.
 

   
  ‚ÄúEvery single day that this goes on, tomorrow is now less safe than today,‚Äù Daniels  told CNN  earlier this week.
 

   
  But the newly announced flight cuts will help maintain safety, the head of the National Transportation Safety Board said Thursday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúTHIS is safety management, the very foundation of our aviation system, and it‚Äôs the right thing to do,‚Äù National Transportation Safety Board Chair Jennifer Homendy  posted  on X.
 

   
  ‚ÄúNTSB has repeatedly stated low air traffic control staffing levels, mandatory overtime, and six-day work weeks have a direct impact on  #safety .‚Äù
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Alexandra Skores, Forrest Brown, Aaron Cooper, Tori B. Powell and David Williams contributed to this report.

The administration aims to improve access to weight-loss treatments, reduce chronic disease, and make healthcare more affordable by aligning drug pricing with international standards through Most Favored Nation pricing. These changes are expected to benefit about 10% of Medicare enrollees and are set to take effect from mid-2026 onward, with consumer pricing details available on the TrumpRx website by early 2026.

articles.content:
Certain obesity drugs will cost as little as $149 and Medicare will start covering them under White House deals 
       
  By Tami Luhby, Meg Tirrell, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:12 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Certain blockbuster obesity drugs will be available for as little as $149 per month and more Medicare enrollees will have access to them under two deals announced Thursday by the Trump administration.
 

   
  The arrangements with drugmakers Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk, which President Donald Trump  foreshadowed in remarks  last month, are the latest in the administration‚Äôs efforts to lower drug prices. As part of the new deals, the drugmakers have also agreed to match prices to the lowest paid in peer nations for all their drugs in Medicaid as well as for the list prices when their medications first hit the market. They will also offer primary care medicines directly to consumers at discounted prices.
 

   
  In exchange, the drugmakers are getting breaks on tariffs on imported pharmaceutical products and a dramatically expedited regulatory review for certain medicines.
 

   
  The prices consumers pay under the deals, however, will vary based on their coverage and how they purchase the medications, among other factors. The current list price of the drugs ranges from roughly $1,000 to $1,350, though the ultimate cost for consumers depends on their insurance and on discounts.
 

   
  Under the deal, those buying injectable GLP-1 medications directly from the companies will pay an average of $350 per month to start, though the drugmakers have committed to reducing the price to about $250 over the next two years, according to senior administration officials. If oral GLP-1 tablets are approved by the US Food and Drug Administration, the lowest dose will cost $149.
 

   
  These prices will be available when TrumpRx, the administration‚Äôs direct-to-consumer website, launches in early 2026 ‚Äì though consumers will be able to see the medications‚Äô costs before the year‚Äôs end, said Dr. Mehmet Oz, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services‚Äô administrator.
 

   
  Novo Nordisk currently offers a direct-to-consumer option for those willing to pay cash for Ozempic and Wegovy at $499 a month. Lilly also offers cash-pay options for its weight-loss drug Zepbound that start at $349 a month.
 

   
  Eligible Medicare enrollees, meanwhile, will have a $50 copay for certain GLP-1 medications approved for both obesity and diabetes. The drugmakers will reduce the prices Medicare pays to $245, which will help pay for expanded coverage of weight loss drugs. The prices will take effect in mid-2026.
 

   
  As part of the deal, the Trump administration is broadening access to obesity drugs for Medicare enrollees with certain medical conditions. Medicare, by law, is not allowed to cover medications for weight loss, but the Biden administration last year  proposed  reinterpreting the statute to allow coverage for the treatment of obesity as a chronic disease.
 

   
  Trump officials  halted  that effort. The administration noted in a call with reporters Thursday that it achieved price reductions, which will make the expansion cost-neutral, while the Biden administration did not include price cuts. The Biden proposal was estimated to cost Medicare $25 billion over a decade.
 

   
  Under the new arrangement, consumers who are overweight and have prediabetes or who have had a stroke or other cardiovascular disease will be eligible, as will those who have obesity and diabetes or uncontrolled high blood pressure and severe obesity.
 

   
  About 10% of Medicare enrollees would be eligible for expanded access under the deals, senior administration officials said. Medicare  already covers  certain weight loss drugs if they are also approved to treat certain medical conditions.
 

   
  Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk have also agreed to provide the GLP-1 medications at lower prices to state Medicaid programs, though the timing will depend on negotiations with each state. Some 13 states covered the costly drugs for weight loss as of August 2024, according to a KFF survey, though North Carolina recently announced it would no longer do so.
 

   
  The deals were described by several administration officials as helping make Americans healthier by using the medications to address their obesity, along with lifestyle changes, including more exercise and healthier eating, which should lead to a reduction in chronic disease.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is a tool in the toolkit. It is not a silver bullet,‚Äù said US Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has long  opposed  obesity drugs but moderated his views once he joined the administration. ‚ÄúIt will allow a lot of people who are locked into high-risk obesity to finally lose weight, to reset and then start doing the kind of things that will address the root causes of obesity.‚Äù
 

   
    Most Favored Nation pricing
 

   
  In his second term, Trump has revived a controversial initiative to base drug prices in the US on those in other developed countries, so-called Most Favored Nation pricing. His current efforts focus on getting drugmakers to voluntarily agree to reduce their prices in exchange for various incentives.
 

   
  Trump has fixated in particular on striking a deal for GLP-1 medications that have exploded in popularity in recent years for helping with weight loss and a range of chronic conditions. The president has referred to them in both public and private as the ‚Äúfat-loss drug.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to be paying, instead of $1,300, you‚Äôll be paying about $150,‚Äù Trump said of the GLP-1 drugs during a mid-October event highlighting a separate drug price deal, prompting Oz to jump in and emphasize that the negotiations were still ongoing.
 

   
  Notably, Ozempic and Wegovy were selected in January for a second round of  Medicare drug price negotiations , which is expected to result in savings for the program and, possibly, for enrollees depending on their drug coverage.
 

   
    Varying costs
 

   
  People who pay for a Zepbound multidose pen with cash through Eli Lilly‚Äôs direct-to-consumer channel will pay $299 for the lowest dose and $449 for additional doses, the drugmaker said in a news release Thursday. The latter is a $50 discount from the current self-pay option and similar to the prices in Europe.
 

   
  Patients who refill their multidose pens through LillyDirect will not pay more than $449.
 

   
  Meanwhile, Eli Lilly‚Äôs weight-loss tablet, which is still awaiting FDA approval, will be priced starting at $149 for the lowest dose.
 

   
  Starting as early as April 1, Medicare enrollees will pay no more than $50 a month for Zepbound‚Äôs multidose pen and for the obesity pill, provided both are approved, Eli Lilly said.
 

   
  Novo Nordisk will offer its Wegovy pill for $149, if it is approved, in its direct-to-consumer channel, the company said in a statement. It said it will also lower its prices for the injectable medicines, including Wegovy and Ozempic, for Medicare, Medicaid and direct-to-consumer patients, but it did not provide details.
 

   
  The company said it will update its self-pay offers for the two medications in coming weeks.
 

   
  Both weight-loss tablets ‚Äî Novo Nordisk‚Äôs Wegovy pill and Lilly‚Äôs orforglipron ‚Äî were  named  by the FDA Thursday as drugs that would get an expedited regulatory review. Called the  Commissioner‚Äôs National Priority Voucher pilot program , it aims to shorten FDA reviews of promising new medicines to one to two months, from as many as ten to 12.
 

   
    Doctors and patients are watching
 

   
  Trump‚Äôs announcement came as thousands of obesity clinicians and researchers gathered in Atlanta for the annual ObesityWeek conference. When news of the deals began to spread Thursday, some doctors said they were hopeful but eager to see more details ‚Äî and what their patients actually experience.
 

   
  Dr. Kimberly Gudzune, the chief medical officer for the American Board of Obesity Medicine Foundation, said it has been demoralizing to dangle the carrot of effective weight loss medicines in front of patients only for them to learn the drugs aren‚Äôt affordable. Slowly, she‚Äôs seeing changes that could have an impact, especially on people with lower incomes.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think that will open it up to people who ‚Ä¶ had dismissed the thought that they might ever be able to afford it, so it‚Äôs a potentially very exciting time,‚Äù Gudzune said.
 

   
  Michele Rouse, the program coordinator for the Healthful Eating, Activity and Weight Program at Johns Hopkins Medicine, said she has lost 70 pounds on Wegovy over three years. Insurance has always covered the medication for her, she said, but she works with patients for whom cost is a barrier.
 

   
  When insurance won‚Äôt cover the medication, ‚Äúit‚Äôs deflating, because ‚Ä¶ they‚Äôre really motivated to start this journey and start this process, and then it‚Äôs almost like they‚Äôre starting again at step one,‚Äù Rouse said from ObesityWeek.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis would be a lifesaver for so many patients who are desperate to get to the point where they can get this weight under control,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt would be awesome for these patients. It really would be.‚Äù
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Brenda Goodman and Adam Cancryn contributed to this report.

articles.title: Stunning map of ancient roads will give you a good reason to think about the Roman Empire more often
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A new digital map called Itiner-e, developed by international researchers including Dr. Pau de Soto from the Autonomous University of Barcelona and Dr. Tom Brughmans from Aarhus University, reconstructs over 100,000 kilometers of ancient Roman roads, with a focus on the empire‚Äôs peak around AD 150. Using historical records, satellite imagery, and topographic data, the team identified routes that span over 300,000 kilometers‚Äîenough to circle Earth more than seven times‚Äîhighlighting the Roman Empire‚Äôs vast reach and logistical sophistication. Despite this scale, only 2.7% of the roads are precisely located, revealing significant gaps in archaeological knowledge. The map is not only a scientific tool for studying historical connectivity, migration, and disease transmission but also a resource for writers, filmmakers, and travelers seeking to envision ancient Roman travel. The project is evolving, with future additions planned to include waterways and longitudinal changes in road networks over time. The study, published in the journal *Scientific Data*, underscores the Roman Empire as the first large-scale integrated political and economic system with a revolutionary transport infrastructure.
keyTakeAways: A new visualization tool, called Itiner-e, maps over 100,000 kilometers (62,000 miles) of ancient Roman roads, revealing a network that spans over 300,000 kilometers‚Äîenough to circle Earth more than seven times.

The map combines historical records, satellite imagery, and aerial photos to reconstruct the road system, with researchers identifying roads even hidden under modern lakes using historical satellite images.
Only 2.7% of the roads are located with certainty; about 90% are less precisely known, and 7% are hypothesized, indicating significant gaps in current archaeological knowledge.
The Roman road system enabled movement of goods, spread of diseases, migration, and dissemination of ideas‚Äîkey factors in understanding Roman expansion and societal dynamics.
The map is an evolving project, with plans to include maritime and river transport and to explore changes in road networks over time.
Experts note the Roman Empire was the first example of large-scale integrated transport infrastructure, surpassing earlier systems and influencing future global transportation developments.

Stunning map of ancient roads will give you a good reason to think about the Roman Empire more often 
       
  By Taylor Nicioli, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:03 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  How often do you  think about the Roman Empire ?
 

   
  For a team of international researchers who went all in and mapped the ancient Roman road system, the answer ‚Äî truly   ‚Äî is every day. And now, anyone can dive into the  newly created visualization tool , which includes 100,000 kilometers (about 62,000 miles) of freshly identified routes, and virtually explore how ancient Romans traveled.
 

   
  At its peak, the Roman Empire stretched from modern-day Britain to Egypt and Syria, and its impressive network of roads contributed to its successful expansion. The astonishing map, which lays out the Roman road system around AD 150, spans over 300,000 kilometers (about 186,000 miles) ‚Äî enough to circle Earth more than seven times, Dr. Pau de Soto, coauthor of the study describing the tool, said in an email. He is a professor in the department of ancient and medieval history at the Autonomous University of Barcelona in Spain.
 

   
  The expansive map can help support future research that explores the influence Roman roads had on connectivity and migration as well as disease transmission, and the long-term effects these events had on the empire, experts say.
 

   
    Travel as an ancient Roman
 

   
  Those living during the Roman Empire had many different modes of transportation: Egyptians mainly relied on camels, while people in other areas of the empire rode horseback or traveled via carts and pack mules. Sometimes they used chariots or simply walked, said Dr. Catherine Fletcher, a professor of history at Manchester Metropolitan University in the UK and author of the book ‚ÄúThe Roads to Rome: A History of Imperial Expansion.‚Äù
 

   
  In some areas, the roads were paved, while away from civilization they were topped with a layer of small stones. It‚Äôs still possible to walk down some of these roads, such as the  Appian Way  leading into Rome, she added.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis dataset brings together a huge range of research to give a bigger and more comprehensive picture of the Roman road network than we‚Äôve had before. It also shows just how much we still don‚Äôt know about the roads, despite their fame,‚Äù said Fletcher, who was not involved with the new study.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe visualisations will be a great help for writers or filmmakers looking to imagine how trips across the Roman Empire might have looked, and it‚Äôll be fun for anyone who wants to explore a Roman road in their own locality or when they‚Äôre on vacation,‚Äù she added in an email.
 

   
  The map is an evolving project, de Soto said, and additions are still being made to it. The authors hope to add maritime and river connections soon and to explore the chronological evolutions of the roads, he added.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe Roman (Empire) was the earliest example of a continental scale integrated political and economic unit,‚Äù said study coauthor Tom Brughmans, an associate professor of classical archaeology at Aarhus University in Denmark. ‚ÄúThis period fundamentally restructured transport infrastructure in the region, in a scale unseen until the industrial revolution in the 19th century, and we now have the dataset that allows us to study how terrestrial mobility changed over (2,000) years.‚Äù
 

   
    Mapping ancient Roman roads
 

   
  Laying the groundwork for the map, named Itiner-e, required the researchers to cross-reference many historical records as well as satellite imagery, historical aerial photographs and other data. The map offers the ability to calculate journey times between different locations and helps to highlight gaps that remain missing in scientists‚Äô knowledge of the ancient roads.
 

   
  Putting together 200 years of research on the Roman roads to create the visualization was like ‚Äúa giant game of connecting the dots,‚Äù Brughmans said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe know hundreds of thousands of ancient places like cities and villas where the Romans lived and worked,‚Äù Brughmans added in an email. ‚ÄúBut roads are long linear features cutting through a landscape that are hard to excavate in their entirety.‚Äù
 

   
  The authors found traces of these ancient roads by comparing historical evidence ‚Äî such as items found during excavation or in historical travel records ‚Äî with satellite imagery and topographic maps that show a time before dense urbanization. They even uncovered roads that are currently hidden under dam lakes by using historical satellite images that reveal what the area once looked like, Brughmans said.
 

   
  However, while the map adds to scientists‚Äô understanding of the ancient travel network, the authors noted that only 2.7% of roads are certain to have an exact location. About 90% of the map is less precisely known, and the remaining 7% are only hypothesized roads.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis was a huge surprise and a sobering realisation: roads are one of the most enigmatic topics in Roman archaeology and history, they were all over the place, we have proverbs like ‚Äòall roads lead to Rome,‚Äô‚Äù Brughmans said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHow can it be that we only know the location of 3% with certainty?‚Äù he added.
 

   
  That question serves as a call to action for researchers to map other less-known parts of the ancient empire, such as ‚Äúareas where we know the road data is not very representative because there are many ancient places with no roads leading to them,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  For now, the map provides visual data for understanding how the civilization moved and evolved, helping to identify routes for the dispersion of goods, the circulation of diseases or the spread of ideas, de Soto said.
 

   
  The researchers reported the findings Thursday in the  journal Scientific Data .

articles.content:
Federal judge says border patrol chief admitted he lied, in ruling limiting federal agents‚Äô use of force in Chicago 
       
  By Bill Kirkos, Priscilla Alvarez, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        3:32 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction restricting the use of force by federal agents in Chicago, finding the Trump administration‚Äôs version of recent events involving agents was not credible.
 

   
  One of the incidents in question was a confrontation between federal agents and protestors, where  Gregory Bovino , a top Border Patrol official charged with the immigration crackdown in Chicago deployed tear gas.
 

   
  Judge Ellis found that Bovino wasn‚Äôt hit in the head with a rock  prior to deploying tear gas  despite claims from the Department of Homeland Security justifying the use of force. ‚ÄúDefendant Bovino admitted that he lied,‚Äù she said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúVideo evidence ultimately disproved this,‚Äù said Ellis, who is presiding over a case concerning the heavy-handed tactics used by federal agents in Chicago. Bovino, who sat for an hours-long deposition, said he was hit after the tear gas was thrown, Ellis said. The top Border Patrol official has started wearing his body-camera, according to attorneys for the government, after revealing in court last month that he did not have one.
 

   
  During Thursday‚Äôs hearing, Ellis slammed the Trump administration, saying that the government‚Äôs portrayal of Chicago ‚Äúis untrue.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI find the defendant‚Äôs evidence simply not credible,‚Äù Ellis said. ‚ÄúI watched the defendants‚Äô videos,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúThis, and hours and hours and hours of bodycam video and video from helicopters was the best they could provide. ‚Äù
 

   
  Ellis also found that that the plaintiffs in the case, who accuse federal agents of aggressive behavior against peaceful protesters, were ‚Äúthreatened and harmed for exercising their constitutional rights.‚Äù
 

   
  In citing the government‚Äôs concern over micromanaging by the court, Judge Ellis said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing no such thing with this injunction.‚Äù
 

   
  Ellis said she is not telling the government how to handle their operations. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not telling defendants who to hire,‚Äù Ellis added.
 

   
  Federal agents must give at least two separate warnings before issues riot control weapons with ‚Äúreasonable opportunity‚Äù for people to comply, Ellis ruled.
 

   
  The judge also said she will not issue a stay of the injunction pending appeal and will issue a written order later on Thursday.
 

   
  As the hearing came to a close, plaintiffs‚Äô attorney Steve Art thanked the judge saying, ‚ÄúWe appreciate you protecting this community.‚Äù

The United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) reported the strikes occurred in villages like Tayr Dibbah, Taibe, and Ayta al Jabal, calling them violations of Security Council Resolution 1701 and warning of civilian endangerment. Hezbollah accused Israel of violating the November 2024 ceasefire and of using political blackmail to force negotiations. The US Special Envoy Tom Barack criticized Lebanon‚Äôs inability to disarm Hezbollah, noting that such a move would risk civil war. articles.content:
Israeli military launches strikes across southern Lebanon against what it says are Hezbollah targets 
       
  By Dana Karni, Tal Shalev, Nadeen Ebrahim, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:07 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The Israeli military carried out a series of strikes across southern Lebanon on Thursday, saying it was targeting Hezbollah in response to what it described as the militant group‚Äôs attempts to rebuild operations in the region.
 

   
  The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said the strikes targeted weapons storage facilities belonging to Hezbollah‚Äôs elite Radwan Force. It claimed the group was working to ‚Äúreestablish terrorist infrastructure‚Äù in southern Lebanon.
 

   
  However, Lebanon‚Äôs President Joseph Aoun claimed the strikes had violated international humanitarian law by targeting civilians and forcing them to flee their homes. He denounced the action as a ‚Äúfully fledged crime.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe more Lebanon expresses its openness to the path of peaceful negotiation to resolve outstanding issues with Israel, the more Israel intensifies its aggression against Lebanese sovereignty,‚Äù Aoun wrote on X.
 

   
  Prior to the strikes, the IDF‚Äôs Arabic language spokesperson Avichay Adraee had issued multiple warnings to residents of several villages.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYou are located in a building used by Hezbollah. For your safety, you are requested to evacuate immediately to a distance of at least 500 meters from the building. Remaining in the vicinity of these structures endangers your lives,‚Äù Adraee said in one of three evacuation notices given Thursday afternoon.
 

   
  Later Thursday, the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) said it had observed several strikes within its area of operations in southern Lebanon, including in Tayr Dibbah, Taibe, and Ayta al Jabal, and warned the action threatened the safety of civilians.
 

   
  UNIFIL called on Israel to stop the attacks, which it said constituted ‚Äúclear violations‚Äù of  Security Council resolution 1701 , a measure that was adopted to end a 34-day war between Israel and Lebanon in 2006 and which called for a full cessation of hostilities between Israel and Hezbollah.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAny military action, especially on such a destructive scale, threatens the safety of civilians and undermines the progress being made toward a political and diplomatic solution,‚Äù the statement continued.
 

   
  Fighting between Israel and Hezbollah ramped up a day after the October 7, 2023, Hamas terror attack on Israel, when the Lebanese militant organization launched attacks on Israeli positions in what it said was an act of solidarity. In October 2024, Israel launched what it described as a ‚Äúa limited ground operation‚Äù in southern Lebanon targeting Hezbollah.
 

   
  In November 2024, a US-brokered ceasefire agreement between Lebanon and Israel went into effect, under which Israel was to halt offensive operations and gradually withdraw from positions inside southern Lebanon, while Hezbollah was to pull back heavy weaponry north of the Litani River. However, Israel has continued to strike targets in Lebanon, citing Hezbollah violations of the truce, claims the group has denied.
 

   
  The Lebanese Army said in a short statement Thursday that despite the Israeli strikes, ‚Äúit remains in close coordination‚Äù with UNIFIL and insisted that their partnership still functions on a ‚Äúhigh level of trust and cooperation.‚Äù
 

   
  The Israeli security cabinet was expected to convene Thursday evening, according to two Israeli officials. One of the officials told CNN that Lebanon would be among the topics discussed.
 

   
  The officials said Israel has been warning in recent weeks against what they described as ‚ÄúHezbollah attempts to rearm and reestablish its offensive capabilities.‚Äù
 

   
  Last week Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu convened security consultations with some cabinet ministers to discuss Israeli reactions. According to an Israeli source with knowledge of the discussion, the military recommended launching a wide scale operation against Hezbollah‚Äôs alleged rearming attempts.
 

   
  Foreign Minister Gideon Sa‚Äôar also said last week that Israel ‚Äúcannot bury its head in the sand‚Äù as Hezbollah ‚Äúcontinues to intensify its efforts to rebuild and rearm.‚Äù
 

   
  The Lebanese president made headlines in recent days after suggesting that his country had ‚Äúno choice‚Äù but to negotiate with Israel directly.
 

   
  ‚ÄúLebanon has no choice but negotiation, because in politics there are three fields of action: diplomacy, economy and war. When war leads to no result, what else can be done?,‚Äù he was cited as saying by  local media , widely believed to be referring to Israel.
 

   
  In a statement on Thursday, Hezbollah accused Israel of repeatedly violating the ceasefire reached in November 2024, and of ‚Äúblackmailing‚Äù the Lebanese government into recognizing Israel.
 

   
  ‚Äú(Lebanon) is absolutely not interested in succumbing to aggressive blackmail or being drawn into political negotiations with the Zionist enemy. Such negotiations serve no national interest and pose existential risks to the Lebanese entity and its sovereignty,‚Äù it said, affirming the group‚Äôs ‚Äúlegitimate right to resist occupation and aggression.‚Äù
 

   
  Israel‚Äôs military action comes days after US Special Envoy Tom Barack said Lebanon was a ‚Äúfailed state‚Äù run by ‚Äúdinosaurs.‚Äù Barrack voiced doubts about whether authorities will be able to disarm Hezbollah, which he said had more vastly more weapons than Lebanon‚Äôs armed forces.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIn our opinion, it‚Äôs not reasonable to tell Lebanon, ‚ÄòForcibly disarm one of your political parties.‚Äô Everybody‚Äôs scared to death to go into civil war. The idea is: What can you do to have Hezbollah not utilize those rockets and missiles,‚Äù he said.
