articles.content:
DC sandwich thrower found not guilty of assault 
       
  By Holmes Lybrand, Casey Gannon, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        3:58 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The man who threw a Subway sandwich at a federal officer in the early days of the Trump administration‚Äôs law enforcement surge in Washington, DC, earlier this summer has been found not guilty of assault.
 

   
  The incident quickly became a symbol ‚Äì somewhat in jest ‚Äì for resistance in DC against the Trump takeover of law enforcement and ramp up in deportation efforts, with spray painted posters and internet jokes spreading as an homage to the incident popping up in its wake.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAs always, we accept a jury‚Äôs verdict; that is the system within which we function. However, law enforcement should never be subjected to assault, no matter how ‚Äòminor,‚Äô DC US Attorney Jeanine Pirro told CNN in a statement after the verdict.
 

   
  ‚ÄúEven children know when they are angry, they are not allowed to throw objects at one another,‚Äù she added.
 

   
  During the trial, federal jurors were shown several videos of the man, Sean Dunn, yelling at officers before throwing a subway sandwich at one Customs and Border Protection agent before running away and being detained shortly thereafter.
 

   
  In one video taken from a police officer‚Äôs body-worn camera, Dunn told the officer, ‚ÄúI was trying to draw them away from where they were. I succeeded.‚Äù
 

   
  After the verdict was read, Dunn told reporters that he was ‚Äúrelieved and looking forward to moving on with my life.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI would like to thank family and friends and strangers for all of their support, whether it was emotional or spiritual or artistic or financial,‚Äù Dunn said outside the courthouse.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThat night I believed that I was protecting the rights of immigrants,‚Äù Dunn said. ‚ÄúAnd let us not forget that the great seal of the United States says ‚ÄòE pluribus unum.‚Äô That means ‚Äòfrom many, one.‚Äô Every life matters no matter where you came from. No matter how you got here, no matter how you identify, you have the right to live a life that is free.‚Äù
 

   
  Dunn‚Äôs legal team could be heard loudly celebrating behind closed doors. The US Attorney‚Äôs Office didn‚Äôt immediately comment on the acquittal.
 

   
  Jurors had deliberated for roughly 7 hours on the single charge.
 

   
  Dunn‚Äôs attorneys did not argue over the facts of the case, but rather focused on whether the sandwich throw was enough to constitute an assault of an officer. The officer who was hit with the sandwich, Greg Lairmore, told jurors that colleagues had given him gag gifts after the incident, including a toy sandwich and a patch with the words ‚Äúfelony footlong.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThey all think it‚Äôs funny,‚Äù Dunn‚Äôs attorney, Sabrina Shroff said of the officers in closing arguments Wednesday, citing the gag gifts that Lairmore said he put on a shelf at work.
 

   
  While the officer claimed the sandwich ‚Äúexploded‚Äù on his chest and left smells ‚Äúof onions and mustard,‚Äù defense counsel showed a photo of the sandwich after the throw, noting that it was still in its Subway wrapping.
 

   
  ‚ÄúA footlong from Subway could not and certainly did not inflict bodily harm,‚Äù Shroff added Wednesday, arguing that the legal requirements for the assault charge had not been met by the sandwich throw.
 

   
  One juror told reporters after the verdict that she didn‚Äôt think the officer felt threatened by the sandwich and laughed when asked if she felt the sub ‚Äúexploded‚Äù as the officer claimed.
 

   
  Shroff said Dunn worried that night, ‚Äúright or wrong,‚Äù that the large groups of federal immigration officers that had gathered were going to conduct a raid on a Latin LGBTQ nightclub he had just left.
 

   
  Dunn shortly lost his job at the Justice Department following the incident, a public firing that was announced by the attorney general herself.
 

   
  The trial, which lasted just shy of two days, highlighted how the US Attorney for DC, Jeanine Pirro, is willing to bring assault cases to federal court, despite how weak they may be. Also highlighted is the continued resistance DC residents have shown to these cases, including by a grand jury first declining to bring a harsher charge against Dunn earlier this year.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere are a lot of people who sit on juries, and they live in Georgetown or in Northwest or in some of these better areas and they don‚Äôt see the reality of crime that is occurring,‚Äù Pirro told Fox News in late August when asked about the grand jury declining to bring charges against Dunn.

articles.content:
Dow stumbles and tech stocks slide as volatility picks up on Wall Street 
       
  By John Towfighi, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:15 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  US stocks closed lower Thursday as concerns mounted about expensive tech stocks, and a risk-off sentiment spread through markets after new data showed a bleak outlook for the job market.
 

   
  The Dow closed lower by 399 points, or 0.84%, after briefly falling as much 524 points earlier. The broader S&P 500 fell 1.12%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite slid 1.9%.
 

   
  A wide range of tech and AI stocks fell, continuing a recent patch of volatility amid concerns about elevated valuations and nerves about a bubble.
 

   
  Chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices ( AMD ) slid 7.27%. Palantir ( PLTR ) fell 6.84%. Nvidia ( NVDA ) fell 3.65%.
 

   
  Wall Street‚Äôs fear gauge, the VIX, jumped 9%.  CNN‚Äôs Fear and Greed index  hovered in between ‚Äúextreme fear‚Äù and ‚Äúfear.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúLarge cap tech stocks have been on an unstoppable run over the past six months, with particular strength over the past two months, and a pullback has been long overdue,‚Äù Robert Edwards, chief investment officer at Edwards Asset Management, said in an email.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBig tech stocks have their hands on their knees, dripping with a bit of sweat and gulping for air ‚Äî that‚Äôs a natural response after a monster run over the past few months,‚Äù Edwards said.
 

   
  Meanwhile, investors rushed in to government bonds, pushing yields lower, after data showed an acceleration in layoff announcements last month. The number of announced jobs cuts in October was  the highest increase  for that month since 2003, according to data from Challenger, Gray & Christmas.
 

   
  US Treasury bonds are considered safe bets when there are signs of a slowdown in the economy. A weakening labor market can also bolster arguments for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. Investors tend to buy Treasuries when the Fed is expected to cut rates in order to lock in current yields.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWith yields still attractive and likely to fall, we continue to believe that quality fixed income offers an appealing combination of income and the potential to perform well in the event of slowing economic activity and further rate cuts,‚Äù Ulrike Hoffmann-Burchardi, global head of equities at UBS Global Wealth Management, said in a note.
 

   
  JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon said Thursday that there are ‚Äúa lot of things taking place today, and there‚Äôs a lot of turbulence out there.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThat creates a little more uncertainty that you should be prepared for,‚Äù Dimon said at the America Business Forum in Miami. ‚ÄúAnd, hopefully, you know, we‚Äôll continue to have the soft landing [taming inflation while avoiding high unemployment], but it may not happen. We just don‚Äôt know.‚Äù
 

   
  Wall Street this week was also attuned to the  Supreme Court‚Äôs deliberations  and oral arguments about the legality of President Donald Trump‚Äôs sweeping global tariff regime that relies on an emergency powers law.
 

   
  Investors in recent months have looked past concerns about tariffs, while the revenue collected has helped assuage bond investors‚Äô nerves about enormous US deficits. While a decision on the tariffs is not immediately expected, it could prove to be a thorny issue for investors if the tariffs are struck down ‚Äî despite the headache they caused earlier this year.
 

   
    ‚ÄòExtreme valuations‚Äô
 

   
  Stocks had been coming off a monthslong hot streak. The Dow rose every month from April through October, posting its best monthly winning streak since the end of 2017.
 

   
  Legendary investor Warren Buffett‚Äôs  favorite market indicator , which compares a measure of the total value of the US stock market to the value of US economic growth, is also flashing a warning sign. The Buffett Indicator is at a record high above 217%, signaling the stock market might be strongly overvalued.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe S&P 500 today is at historically extreme valuations,‚Äù Torsten Slok, chief economist at Apollo Global Management, said in a note.
 

   
  Stocks have climbed higher this year on strong corporate earnings and enthusiasm about AI. Yet concerns also linger that the market‚Äôs gains are increasingly reliant on tech companies.
 

   
  Wall Street‚Äôs bar for positive surprises is also rising, analysts say. Some companies that have reported third quarter earnings have beaten analysts‚Äô estimates but are still seeing their shares slide. Shares in Duolingo ( DUOL ), the language learning company, plunged 25.49% on Thursday and had their worst day on record after the company‚Äôs outlook and guidance underwhelmed investors.
 

   
  Meanwhile, bitcoin slid almost 3% and hovered around $100,650 in a sign of risk-off sentiment. The cryptocurrency has fallen roughly 20% since reaching an all-time high above $126,000 one month ago.

articles.title: Trump Administration to Reduce Traffic at 40 Airports if Shutdown Continues
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration, through the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), announced a plan to reduce air traffic at 40 of the nation‚Äôs busiest airports, including major hubs in New York, Washington, D.C., Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas, Phoenix, and Seattle, beginning Friday, November 7, 2025. The reduction is set to start with a 4% cut in flights and increase over the weekend, targeting regional and domestic routes, while long-haul international flights remain unaffected. This action is prompted by severe staffing shortages among air traffic controllers and TSA screeners‚Äîmany of whom are not being paid during the ongoing government shutdown‚Äîleading to growing safety risks. The FAA described the measures as 'prescriptive' and 'surgical' to maintain airspace safety. Airlines including Frontier, United, Delta, American, and Southwest have responded with preemptive flight cancellations and customer flexibility policies, such as free refunds and rebooking options. The move is viewed as a necessary but disruptive response to a systemic crisis in federal operations, and it underscores the broader impact of political dysfunction on critical infrastructure like aviation.
keyTakeAways: The Trump administration, via the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), will reduce air traffic at 40 major U.S. airports if a shutdown resolution is not reached.
The reduction will affect 10% of air traffic, with initial cuts at 4% starting Friday and increasing over the following days.
The core 30 airports ‚Äî including New York City, Washington, DC, Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas, Phoenix, and Seattle ‚Äî are among those most affected.
Airline responses include preemptive cancellations of regional and domestic mainline flights, with no impact on long-haul international routes.
Passengers are being advised to have backup tickets, as cancellations and delays are expected to increase.
Frontier, United, Delta, American, and Southwest all issued passenger flexibility policies allowing free changes or refunds.
The plan is described as 'prescriptive' and 'surgical' by FAA officials, with the goal of maintaining airspace safety amid staffing shortages.
Over 400 staffing shortages have been reported at FAA facilities since the shutdown began, with controllers not being paid for missing their second paycheck.
The FAA and airlines are working collaboratively, though airlines were notified only an hour before the announcement.
The measures also include restrictions on space launches and small aircraft traffic in certain markets.

articles.content:
Trump administration will reduce traffic at 40 airports across the US starting Friday if shutdown continues 
       
  By Alexandra Skores, Pete Muntean, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:37 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The Federal Aviation Administration will reduce flights at dozens of major airports as early as Friday if no  shutdown deal  is reached, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy announced at a news conference Wednesday.
 

   
  Ten percent of air traffic at 40 busy airports would be cut, potentially impacting thousands of flights, though the details of how many flights   was not announced.
 

   
  The nation‚Äôs ‚Äúcore 30‚Äù airports ‚Äì including New York City‚Äôs three big hubs, plus major airports in Washington, DC, Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas, and across the West from Phoenix to Seattle ‚Äì are among those on a preliminary list of sites expected to be impacted by the drawdown, an FAA source with direct knowledge of the situation told CNN.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAs we start to implement this drawdown in service. It will be restricted to these 40 high volume traffic markets,‚Äù FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to ask the airlines to work with us collaboratively to reduce their schedules.‚Äù
 

   
  The drawdown is ‚Äúthe right thing to do,‚Äù National Transportation Safety Board Chairperson Jennifer Homendy  posted  early Thursday on X, adding, ‚Äúpressures are building in the system.‚Äù
 

   
  The announcement comes as  air traffic controller staffing shortages  during the shutdown are delaying an increasing number of flights throughout the country. Controllers will miss their second full paycheck next week and some are taking second jobs to make ends meet or calling in sick in protest.
 

   
  Controllers, like Transportation Security Administration screeners, are considered essential employees and must work during the shutdown, but are not being paid.
 

   
  ‚ÄúControllers are dedicated safety professionals,‚Äù Homendy posted. Duffy ‚Äúcan‚Äôt just ignore it; he took action to mitigate risk and ensure safety. THIS is safety management, the very foundation of our aviation system, and it‚Äôs the right thing to do.‚Äù
 

   
  The FAA was scheduled to meet Wednesday night with airlines to discuss implementation of the new plan. The change is ‚Äúprescriptive‚Äù and ‚Äúsurgical,‚Äù Bedford called.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe are going to proactively make decisions that keep the airspace safe,‚Äù Duffy said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe have asked (air traffic controllers) to show up for work, but I‚Äôm not naive to understand that they‚Äôre trying to figure out how they meet their daily obligations,‚Äù Duffy said. ‚ÄúBecause of that, we have seen staffing pressures throughout our airspace. Those who travel will see that we‚Äôve had more delays. We‚Äôve had more cancelations.‚Äù
 

   
  More than 400 staffing shortages have been reported at FAA facilities since the start of the shutdown, according to a CNN analysis. The number is more than four times what was seen on the same days last year.
 

   
  The airlines were notified of the plan only about an hour before it was announced, an airline source told CNN.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe are working with the federal government to understand all details of the new reduction mandate and will strive to mitigate impacts to passengers and shippers,‚Äù Airlines for America, the industry trade group, said in a statement.
 

   
  Schedule reductions will begin Friday and gradually increase throughout the weekend and into next week, a source with knowledge of airline plans told CNN.
 

   
  Airlines are being told to cut 4% of flights starting Friday multiple airline officials told CNN. However, others caution that plans are preliminary and things could change.
 

   
  Bedford said the new measures would also go beyond commercial airspace and include restrictions on space launches and small aircraft traffic in certain markets.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI want to applaud the controllers who continue to come to work on a daily basis keeping our system safe,‚Äù Bedford said. ‚ÄúBut I also want to recognize the fact that the data is telling us we need to do more.‚Äù
 

   
    Airlines prepare for cuts
 

   
  Most major airlines said the impact would be limited or said they‚Äôre evaluating the potential impact.
 

   
  Multiple airline officials told CNN they are treating the government-mandated scaling back of their flight schedules like they would deal with mass cancelations due to a snow storm.
 

   
   The no-frills carrier Frontier warned passengers to book a backup ticket or risk ‚Äúbeing stranded.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf your flight is cancelled your chances of being stranded are high so I would simply have a backup ticket on another airline,‚Äù Frontier Airlines CEO Barry Biffle wrote in a statement. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry this is happening. Hopefully the shutdown is over soon.‚Äù
 

   
  Frontier said in a statement that passengers with a canceled or 3-hour or more delayed domestic flight (or six for international) will be able to rebook or request a refund online. A flexible travel policy has also been issued for any traveler wanting to change their plans.
 

   
  United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby said in a memo to employees that its ‚Äúlong-haul international flying‚Äù and ‚Äúhub-to-hub flying‚Äù wouldn‚Äôt be affected. The airline will focus cuts on regional flights and domestic mainline flights that don‚Äôt travel between hubs.
 

   
  United Airlines will preemptively cancel less than 200 flights starting tomorrow, the airline told CNN. That‚Äôs roughly 4% of United‚Äôs Friday schedule and is comprised of mostly regional flights. United says it will cancel about 4% again on Saturday and Sunday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs important to maintain the integrity of our network, give impacted customers as many options as possible to resume their trip, and sustain our crew pairing systems,‚Äù he wrote.
 

   
  All passengers with flights during this period are eligible for a refund, even for nonrefundable tickets, Kirby wrote.
 

   
  Delta Air Lines tells CNN it is preemptively canceling roughly 170 mainline and regional flights on Friday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe are providing additional flexibility to all of our customers during the impacted travel period to change, cancel or refund their flights, including our basic economy fares, without penalty,‚Äù Delta said in a statement.
 

   
  American Airlines said it expects that the ‚Äúvast majority‚Äù of its customers‚Äô fights would not be affected and long-haul international service will remain as scheduled.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIn the meantime, we continue to urge leaders in Washington, DC, to reach an immediate resolution to end the shutdown,‚Äù the airline said in  a statement.  
 

   
  Travelers flying American whose flights are cancelled for any reason or who choose not to travel will be able to change their flight or request a refund, without any penalty, the airline said.
 

   
  A Southwest Airlines spokesperson urged Congress to ‚Äúimmediately resolve its impasse‚Äù and said the airline is determining the schedule adjustments needed to meet the FAA flight reductions. Around 100 Southwest flights will be canceled Friday, according to airline.
 

   
  Southwest said all travel booked through Nov. 14 can be adjusted at no cost or receive a refund, regardless if the passenger was affected by the cuts.

articles.content:
Outback‚Äôs parent company abruptly closed 21 restaurants 
       
  By Jordan Valinsky, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        3:27 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Outback Steakhouse‚Äôs parent company abruptly closed 21 restaurants in October as it begins a ‚Äúcomprehensive turnaround strategy‚Äù to keep up with its  trendier competitors .
 

   
   Bloomin‚Äô Brands , Outback‚Äôs parent company, disclosed in its earnings report Thursday that in addition to those closures, an additional 22 locations across its three brands ‚Äî which also includes Carrabba‚Äôs Italian Grill and Bonefish Grill ‚Äî will not have their leases renewed and will shutter over the next four years.
 

   
  A company spokesperson wouldn‚Äôt reveal how many Outback locations it specifically closed.
 

   
  Outback has 670 US locations remaining, according to its website. That‚Äôs roughly 10% fewer than a decade ago, when it had about  750 locations .
 

   
  Bloomin‚Äô Brands also announced that it will take a $33 million impairment charge for the closures and suspended its shareholder dividend to help pay for the turnaround plan.
 

   
  The company revealed more details in a call with analysts Thursday morning, saying it‚Äôs investing $75 million in the Outback turnaround plan over the next three years. Guests will soon see new menus highlighting the improved steaks the chain is selling. It is also increasing value offers and reducing the number of tables waiters serve from six to four to improve the dining experience.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOutback Steakhouse has incredible brand equity,‚Äù said CEO Mike Spanos. ‚ÄúIt is the pioneer of the casual steakhouse industry. We have strong brand awareness and a tremendous opportunity to convert that awareness into restaurant visits.‚Äù
 

   
  All of its remaining restaurants will be renovated by the end of 2028. The  redesign  has brighter interiors with a newly designed bar and seats as well as smaller kitchens and expanded areas for pickup.
 

   
  Outback has been struggling for the past two years and hasn‚Äôt posted same-store sales until this quarter, when sales rose a meager 0.4%.
 

   
  Meanwhile,  Darden-owned LongHorn Steakhouse  posted a 5.5% rise and Texas Roadhouse generate a 5.8% jump in sales in their most recent earnings reports.
 

   
  Diners are becoming choosier with their dollars when going out, and are not spending money at chains that they don‚Äôt perceive as good value. That‚Äôs helped Outback‚Äôs rivals, which serve heaping portions; and other chains, like Chili‚Äôs and Applebee‚Äôs that are  focused on value and deals .
 

   
  Bloomin‚Äô Brands ( BLMN ) stock has lost 40% of its value since the beginning of the year.
 

   
   This story has been updated to clarify the number of closures.

articles.title: Canadian court dismisses farm‚Äôs attempt to save ostrich flock despite efforts by RFK Jr.
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Canada‚Äôs Supreme Court has dismissed a legal appeal by Universal Ostrich Farms in British Columbia to save a flock of 330 ostriches, paving the way for their culling under the CFIA‚Äôs 'stamping out' policy due to the detection of highly pathogenic avian influenza. The farm claims the ostriches can produce disease-fighting antibodies, but the CFIA has rejected these claims, stating there is no evidence of such research. The case gained international attention when U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. publicly advocated for preserving the flock, and Republican businessman John Catsimatidis financially supported the legal effort. Despite protests from supporters and emotional appeals from farm spokespersons, the Canadian government maintains that culling is necessary to protect the nation‚Äôs $7 billion poultry industry, especially given that British Columbia has been the hardest-hit province in Canada due to avian flu outbreaks.
keyTakeAways: The Canadian Supreme Court dismissed an appeal to save a flock of 330 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms in Edgewood, British Columbia, allowing the culling to proceed under CFIA‚Äôs 'stamping out' policy.
The CFIA cited concerns over the spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza and the potential damage to Canada‚Äôs $7 billion poultry industry as justification for the culling.
Universal Ostrich Farms claims the ostriches have unique disease-fighting antibody-producing capabilities, but the CFIA has stated there is no evidence supporting such research claims.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr., US Health Secretary and figurehead of the 'Make America Healthy Again' movement, expressed support for preserving the flock and wrote to CFIA urging reconsideration.
Republican supermarket magnate John Catsimatidis supported the farm‚Äôs legal efforts and bankrolled its representation, calling the outcome 'government overreach'.
The case has drawn international attention, highlighting tensions between animal welfare, scientific research, and public health regulations.
British Columbia has been the hardest-hit province in Canada due to avian flu, with over 11.4 million birds affected, outpacing other provinces like Alberta.

articles.content:
Canadian court dismisses farm‚Äôs attempt to save ostrich flock despite efforts by RFK Jr. 
       
  By Max Saltman, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        3:07 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
   Canada ‚Äôs Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal on the proposed culling of a British Columbia ostrich herd,   in a case that has attracted the attention of US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his ‚ÄúMake America Healthy Again‚Äù movement . 
 

   
  The court‚Äôs  dismissal  paves the way for the flock of around 330 ostriches to be culled. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) had ordered the birds to be euthanized after detecting  highly pathogenic avian influenza  on the farm in late December 2024.
 

   
  In a statement published Thursday, the CFIA confirmed that it would move forward with euthanizing the ostriches under its ‚Äústamping out‚Äù policy, in which infected or exposed animals are killed in the event of a disease outbreak. The statement did not provide a timeline.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is the saddest day in Canadian history,‚Äù Katie Pasitney, the spokesperson for Universal Ostrich Farms and the daughter of one of its co-owners, told CNN shortly after the court made its announcement.
 

   
  Universal Ostrich Farms in Edgewood, British Columbia says it is raising the animals to study their ability to produce disease-fighting antibodies. The farm has been embroiled in a legal battle with the CFIA for nearly a year over the matter.
 

   
  The CFIA has  called   the farm‚Äôs research claims ‚Äúunsubstantiated,‚Äù saying that the agency ‚Äúhas not received any evidence of research activities‚Äù on the ostrich farm, nor ‚Äúany research to show the flock of ostriches currently under quarantine has a unique capacity to produce eggs with antibodies.‚Äù
 

   
  The farm‚Äôs plea to save the ostriches from culling was heard by Trump administration officials like Kennedy.
 

   
  After meeting with Canadian officials in May, Kennedy  wrote a letter  to the CFIA asking it to ‚Äúconsider not culling the entire flock of ostriches,‚Äù writing that the animals could be used to study the ‚Äúantibody levels and cellular immunity‚Äù to develop cures for disease.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe believe there is significant value in studying this population,‚Äù Kennedy added.
 

   
  CNN has reached out to Kennedy‚Äôs office for comment on the court‚Äôs decision.
 

   
  Pasitney told CNN that she connected with Kennedy through Republican supermarket magnate and lifelong New Yorker John Catsimatidis, who had taken up her Canadian farm‚Äôs cause.
 

   
  Catsimatidis bankrolled the farm‚Äôs legal representation and called Thursday‚Äôs outcome an example of ‚Äúgovernment overreach,‚Äù according to a spokesman for the businessman speaking to CNN‚Äôs broadcast partner CBC.
 

   
  CNN has reached out to Catsimatidis for comment.
 

   
    Province struggling with bird flu
 

   
  An expert in avian virology told CNN that the Canadian government‚Äôs order to cull the entire flock is in line with standard avian flu mitigation efforts.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhenever there‚Äôs a foreign animal disease affecting a country, it could be Newcastle disease or avian influenza, the first thing is to stop the dissemination of the disease,‚Äù Rodrigo Gallardo, a professor of poultry medicine at UC Davis School of Veterinary Medicine, said. ‚ÄúAnd in order to do that, you euthanize flocks that have been infected.‚Äù
 

   
  The Canadian government took control of the ostrich farm and its animals in September. Numerous people continued to protest outside the farm‚Äôs fences, and CFIA has warned the farm‚Äôs supporters from hindering government operations, or flying drones over the site.
 

   
  On Thursday, an emotional Pasitney told CNN that around 100 supporters had gathered at the farm to protest the decision. ‚ÄúThese animals don‚Äôt deserve to die,‚Äù Pasitney said. ‚ÄúThey are our family members.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe CFIA has respected all orders and decisions of the courts throughout the legal process,‚Äù the agency said on Thursday, ‚Äúand expects the ostrich farm owners and supporters to do the same now that the Supreme Court of Canada has issued its judgment.‚Äù
 

   
  In ordering the culling, CFIA repeatedly cited the need to prevent damage to the country‚Äôs nearly  $7 billion poultry industry .
 

   
  British Columbia has struggled more with bird flu than any other Canadian province, according to  CFIA‚Äôs statistics , with an estimated 11,439,000 birds affected as of October 28. The next-closest ranked province, Alberta, has an estimated two million birds impacted.

articles.title: Jury awards $10 million to Virginia teacher shot by 6-year-old student
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A jury awarded $10 million to former Virginia teacher Abby Zwerner, who was shot in the chest and hand by a 6-year-old student at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News in January 2023. The civil trial centered on former assistant principal Ebony Parker, who is accused of failing to act on warnings about the student having a gun. The verdict suggests that school administrators have a duty to prioritize safety and investigate threats involving firearms. The case may set a precedent for accountability in school shootings involving children with guns. Parker is set to face eight felony counts of child neglect in a criminal trial next month, and the civil trial is notable for proceeding before the criminal one, a rare legal order that allows defense attorneys to assess key evidence. The incident, part of a broader national crisis with 64 school shootings reported in the U.S. this year, highlights tensions over school safety, institutional responsibility, and the limits of foreseeability in preventing violence.
keyTakeAways: A jury awarded $10 million to Abby Zwerner, a former Virginia teacher, after she was shot by a 6-year-old student in January 2023 at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News.
The civil trial centered on former assistant principal Ebony Parker, who is accused of failing to act on warnings about the student possessing a gun.
The verdict implies that school administrators have a duty to prioritize safety and investigate threats involving guns on campus.
The case may set a precedent for determining liability in school shootings involving children with access to firearms.
Parker faces eight felony counts of child neglect in a criminal trial, with evidence from the civil trial likely to be used in that proceeding.

Attorneys argued that Parker failed to take appropriate action, such as inspecting the student‚Äôs backpack or investigating the gun, while Parker‚Äôs legal team emphasized that the incident was unforeseeable and that school safety is a shared responsibility.
Zwerner testified that she suffered severe physical and emotional trauma, describing thoughts of death and ongoing difficulties in daily life due to her injuries.
The civil trial was unusual in proceeding before the criminal one, potentially giving defense counsel insight into key facts and potentially influencing the criminal case.
This case is part of a broader national issue with 64 school shootings reported in the U.S. this year, 27 of which occurred on K-12 school grounds.

articles.content:
Jury awards $10 million to Virginia teacher shot by 6-year-old student 
       
  By Chris Boyette, Cindy Von Quednow, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        3:18 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A jury   on Thursday awarded $10 million to Abby Zwerner, the former Virginia teacher who was shot by her 6-year-old student in 2023, in a civil trial that offered a preview of the criminal case to come against the school administrator accused of ignoring warnings about the gun.
 

   
  Zwerner, a now-former teacher at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News,  sued  ex-assistant principal Ebony Parker, alleging Parker failed to act on  concerns  that the student had brought a gun to school in January 2023.
 

   
  Zwerner was shot in the chest and hand while sitting at a reading table in her classroom.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think (the verdict) says that what happened at Richneck Elementary School that day was wrong and is not going to be tolerated,‚Äù Diane Toscano, one of Zwerner‚Äôs lawyers, said outside the courthouse after the verdict was read. ‚ÄúSafety has to be the first concern at schools.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe have to acknowledge within our civil justice system that accountability comes from anyone who‚Äôs contributed to the ultimate outcome ‚Ä¶ so ultimately, it‚Äôs for the jury to decide what‚Äôs right,‚Äù Kevin Biniazan, another attorney for Zwerner, added.
 

   
  Attorneys for Zwerner and Parker will convene Friday morning for post-trial motions. Parker can appeal the verdict after the court enters a final judgment in the case.
 

   
  Parker‚Äôs legal counsel was provided by the Virginia Risk Sharing Association, the school district‚Äôs insurance pool, according to Toscano Law Group, one of the firms representing Zwerner.
 

   
  A spokesperson for VRSA told CNN‚Äôs Jean Casarez that as an insurance company, VRSA would hypothetically pay damages in litigation if awarded.
 

   
  The jury deliberated for approximately 5¬Ω hours.
 

   
    Parker will appear in criminal court
 

   
  The civil verdict against Parker ‚Äî who faces  eight counts  of felony child neglect in a criminal trial next month ‚Äî provides a window into key evidence and arguments that will likely resurface when Parker appears in criminal court.
 

   
  Holding civil cases before criminal ones is ‚Äúreally unusual,‚Äù according to Darryl K. Brown, a law professor at the University of Virginia.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI suspect that defense would want the civil trial to go forward first, because they‚Äôre not going to be able to avoid it, and it gives them a lot of information about what would come in at the criminal trial,‚Äù Brown said.
 

   
  While Zwerner‚Äôs pain and suffering have taken center stage in this trial, the upcoming criminal trial would be more likely to touch on what action Parker failed to take, given her duty to protect children, Brown said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe more important evidence for the prosecution would be from other witnesses and sources that reveal what the defendant knew with respect to the threat the child posed, and whether he had a gun,‚Äù the professor said.
 

   
  The case could set a legal precedent for who shoulders the blame when children have access to guns and carry out school shootings, which continue to plague the country. As of last week, there were  64 US school shootings  this year, 27 of them on K-12 school grounds.
 

   
    What attorneys on both sides argued
 

   
  ‚ÄúDr. Parker‚Äôs job is safety,‚Äù one of Zwerner‚Äôs attorneys said  during closing arguments  Wednesday. And she didn‚Äôt do enough to thwart the shooting after learning of the child having a gun, he argued.
 

   
  ‚ÄúA gun changes everything. You stop and you investigate. You get to the bottom of it,‚Äù Biniazan said. ‚ÄúYou get to the bottom of that backpack. You get to the bottom of his pockets, whatever it is. You get to the bottom of it to know whether that gun is real and on campus.‚Äù
 

   
  Sandra Douglas, one of Parker‚Äôs attorneys, noted during her closing arguments that Zwerner herself did not go to Parker with her concerns over the students, nor did she act on the concerns of others.
 

   
  The attorney reminded the jury of testimony from an expert, who said school safety falls on all school officials, not just one person.
 

   
  Parker did not breach professional standards, violate protocols or act with indifference, Dr. Amy Klinger, an expert in education administration and school safety, testified earlier, saying it would have been difficult for anyone to foresee the incident.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt was a tragedy that, until that day, was unprecedented. It was unthinkable and it was unforeseeable, and I ask that you please not compound that tragedy by blaming Dr. Parker for it,‚Äù Douglas told jurors.
 

   
    ‚ÄòI thought I was dying. I thought I had died,‚Äô injured teacher testifies
 

   
  Zwerner testified she is still enduring the emotional and physical ramifications of the shooting.
 

   
  She said she has become withdrawn and distant with family and finds daily tasks ‚Äì like opening a bottle of water ‚Äì difficult because of her hand injury.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI thought I was dying. I thought I had died,‚Äù Zwerner said with a catch in her voice during her  emotional testimony  earlier in the trial. ‚ÄúI thought I was either on my way to heaven or in heaven.‚Äù
 

   
  During closing arguments and in the trial, Parker‚Äôs attorneys tried to undermine Zwerner‚Äôs testimony by pointing out that the former teacher was able to graduate cosmetology school despite her injuries and attend concerts even though she said she struggled going out in public.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not minimizing what happened to Miss Zwerner. I‚Äôm not doing that ‚Ä¶ I have to bring the truth and the whole story,‚Äù Douglas said.

With Nancy Pelosi retiring, stock traders who copy her investments need to find a new hero 
       
  By Marshall Cohen, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        3:14 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  There‚Äôs a cottage industry of investors who monitor former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs disclosed stock trades, match her every move, and usually make a profit along the way.
 

   
  That trend will now end in 2027. Pelosi announced Thursday that  she is retiring  after a storied four-decade career in Congress, and she won‚Äôt run for re-election in next year‚Äôs midterms. Once she leaves Congress, she won‚Äôt be required to publicly reveal anything about her family‚Äôs stock holdings.
 

   
  The California Democrat is one of the wealthiest members of Congress and one of the best-known investors on Capitol Hill. In the last three years, her disclosed trades had a volume of about $59 million, according to data from  Capitol Trades , which tracks lawmakers from both parties.
 

   
  There is  no prohibition  against members of Congress owning or buying stocks. But federal law requires lawmakers to disclose ‚Äì within 45 days ‚Äì their transactions, and any transactions by their spouse or children, or any stock activity done on their behalf. They report their transactions in value ranges, not exact amounts.
 

   
  Most of the Pelosi-linked trades are done by her husband, Paul Pelosi, as made clear in federal disclosures. A spokesperson from Pelosi‚Äôs office  said  in 2022 that she isn‚Äôt involved in her husband‚Äôs investment decisions.
 

   
  A collection of financial experts, day traders, political junkies and others have closely watched the Pelosis‚Äô trades and matched their investments. A ‚ÄúNancy Pelosi Stock Tracker‚Äù  account  on X, formerly Twitter, has amassed 1.2 million followers.
 

   
  Among those Pelosi-watchers is Dan Weiskopf, a senior portfolio manager at Tidal Financial Group, who oversees an ETF fund whose ticker symbol is  aptly called ‚ÄúNANC.‚Äù  That fund invests in stocks that are bought or sold by not just Pelosi, but all Democratic members of Congress. (He also manages an ETF fund called ‚ÄúGOP,‚Äù which does the same for Republican lawmakers.)
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing ‚Äì when Nancy Pelosi makes a trade, the community immediately hops on it, and it‚Äôll move that market,‚Äù Weiskopf said of the Pelosis‚Äô transactions. ‚ÄúSo many people are following her decision-making. Other members of Congress have less of an impact.‚Äù
 

   
  The NANC fund has about $263 million in net assets, while the GOP fund has about $60 million, according to their website. Both were launched in 2023. Weiskopf said both of his congressional-based portfolios have largely  outperformed  the S&P 500.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wonderful about her trades is that she‚Äôs got such conviction in the way she trades, because she‚Äôs using long-dated options‚Äù that are still active even after the delayed disclosures, Weiskopf said. ‚ÄúShe has done really well, so why wouldn‚Äôt you want to follow her?‚Äù
 

   
  Pelosi has always  denied any wrongdoing,  and has rejected assertions that lawmakers may be using non-public information to gain a financial advantage. Defending her own family‚Äôs trades, she said in 2021, when pressed on her seemingly well-timed trades: ‚ÄúWe are a free market economy, (lawmakers) should be able to participate in that.‚Äù
 

   
  Government ethics groups have been lobbying for years to ban lawmaker stock trading, which is legal as long as trades are disclosed, and it isn‚Äôt isolated to just Pelosi or one political party. Amid public pressure, Pelosi  announced her support  in 2022 for bipartisan efforts to ban congressional stock trading, which have been  slowly gaining steam  throughout the year.
 

   
  There are a handful of proposals being floated in Congress by progressive lawmakers like Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Sen. Elizabeth Warren. But conservatives like Rep. Chip Roy and Sen. Josh Hawley have also signed on to some of these bills.
 

   
  These developments ‚Äì and new support this year from President Donald Trump and the congressional leadership from both parties ‚Äì has given advocates optimism for potential passage through the Republican-led Congress.
 

   
  Pelosi  reaffirmed her support  for a congressional stock-trading ban earlier this year, even after Senate Republicans renamed one of the bills the ‚ÄúPELOSI Act.‚Äù That hasn‚Äôt stopped her family from trading, including a recently disclosed  transfer  of at least $100,000 in Apple stock by her husband on Oct. 22. The shares were donated to a Catholic university in Washington, DC.
 

   
  ‚ÄúShe does impact the markets when her trading is disclosed,‚Äù Weiskopf said. ‚ÄúHer retirement is notable, but there are plenty of other members of Congress who will continue the trend.‚Äù
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Annie Grayer contributed reporting

articles.title: Dallas Cowboys Player Marshawn Kneeland Dies at Age 24, Police Investigate Possible Suicide
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Marshawn Kneeland, a 24-year-old defensive end for the Dallas Cowboys, died by apparent suicide on November 6, 2025, after a traffic pursuit in Frisco, Texas. The incident began when Texas DPS attempted to stop a vehicle for a violation, leading to a pursuit that ended with a crash and Kneeland fleeing on foot. Officers from the Frisco Police Department located him at 1:31 a.m. with a self-inflicted gunshot wound. His girlfriend reported that he had expressed suicidal thoughts and was armed, with a history of mental illness. The NFL and Cowboys issued public statements expressing grief. Kneeland, a second-round 2024 draft pick, made seven appearances with the team and scored his first career touchdown. Coaches and teammates praised his leadership and character. The Collin County Medical Examiner will determine the official cause of death, and the incident has sparked broader conversations about mental health in professional sports.

Kneeland made his professional debut with the Cowboys in 2024, appearing in seven games and scoring a career touchdown, showing promise as a young athlete.

articles.content:
Dallas Cowboys player Marshawn Kneeland dead at age 24. Police investigating possible death by suicide after evading pursuit 
       
  By Kevin Dotson, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:56 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Dallas Cowboys defensive end Marshawn Kneeland died Thursday morning at age 24, the team said in a statement.
 

   
  Police are investigating the incident as apparent death by suicide.
 

   
  The Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) says that at 10:33 p.m. local time Wednesday, troopers attempted to stop a vehicle for a traffic violation, but the driver refused to halt and a pursuit began.
 

   
  The pursuit was quickly terminated after troopers lost sight of the vehicle, Texas DPS said.
 

   
  The Frisco Police Department said Thursday that its officers responded to a call at 10:39 p.m. to assist the Texas DPS in locating the vehicle.
 

   
  A wrecked vehicle was located ‚Äúminutes later,‚Äù crashed on Dallas Parkway in Frisco, Texas, police say. Initial reports indicate that a male subject, later identified as Kneeland, fled the scene on foot.
 

   
  Officers then began searching the area with K-9 and drone units, according to Frisco police.
 

   
  In dispatch audio obtained by CNN from Broadcastify of the local police response, law enforcement can be heard talking about police having been in touch with Kneeland‚Äôs girlfriend.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre talking to the girlfriend. She‚Äôs trying to call his agent but we‚Äôre trying to get her to call him first. But she‚Äôs saying he is armed and has a history of mental illness and her quote was ‚Äòhe will end it all.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  Police in Plano, Texas, where Kneeland resided, say they received a call approximately an hour later to perform a welfare check at ‚Äúan address associated with Mr. Kneeland,‚Äù but made no contact at the residence.
 

   
  Also heard in the dispatch audio was a mention that the NFL had been in touch with authorities while the search for the football player continued. ‚ÄúWe have a lieutenant calling in from Plano advising that the NFL is calling Plano PD and the subject is texting his family goodbye.‚Äù
 

   
  CNN has reached out to the league for comment about the alleged interaction with police.
 

   
  Frisco police say officers were informed that Kneeland ‚Äúhad expressed suicidal ideations‚Äù and ‚Äúwas later located at 1:31 a.m., deceased with what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound.‚Äù
 

   
  The Collin County Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office will determine the official cause of death, per Frisco PD.
 

   
  The Cowboys released a statement Thursday morning which read: ‚ÄúIt is with extreme sadness that the Dallas Cowboys share that Marshawn Kneeland tragically passed away this morning. Marshawn was a beloved teammate and member of our organization. Our thoughts and prayers regarding Marshawn are with his girlfriend Catalina and his family,‚Äù the Cowboys said in a statement.
 

   
  Kneeland appeared in seven games for Dallas this season, making 12 tackles and recording one sack. Kneeland scored his first career touchdown in the Cowboys‚Äô loss to the Arizona Cardinals on Monday night after recovering a blocked punt in the end zone.
 

   
  The second-round draft pick from 2024 was playing in his second season with the Cowboys after playing for Western Michigan University.
 

   
  The school‚Äôs head coach, Lance Taylor, called Kneeland a ‚Äúremarkable young man who meant so much to our program and to me personally.‚Äù
 

   
  Taylor continued: ‚ÄúHis leadership, energy, and smile were infectious, and he left a lasting impact on everyone in our program. Having coached him during my first season here, we developed a special bond that went far beyond football. His passion for life and his teammates were unmatched.‚Äù
 

   
  Kneeland‚Äôs agent, Jonathan Perzley, posted a statement on Instagram stating, ‚ÄúI am shattered to confirm that my client and dearest friend Marshawn Kneeland passed away last night. I watched him fight his way from a hopeful kid at Western Michigan with a dream to being a respected professional for the Dallas Cowboys.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMarshawn poured his heart into every snap, every practice, and every moment on the field. To lose someone with his talent, spirit, and goodness is a pain I can hardly put into words. My heart aches for his family, his teammates, and everyone who loved him, and I hope they feel the support of the entire football community during this unimaginable time. I ask that you please give his loved ones the privacy and compassion they need as they grieve this tremendous loss.‚Äù
 

   
  The NFL said on social media it is ‚Äúdeeply saddened by the tragic news.‚Äù
 

   
   This story has been updated with additional information. 
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Dana O‚ÄôNeil, Taylor Galgano, Caroll Alvarado and David Close contributed to this report.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs historic NYC win, in three maps
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Zohran Mamdani won the 2025 New York City mayoral election, defeating former Governor Andrew Cuomo by nearly 9 percentage points, with over 2 million votes cast and high turnout across key districts. The election marked a significant shift in voter behavior, with Mamdani gaining strong support in traditionally Democratic, Black and Latino-majority areas of Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx, while Cuomo won support in Republican-leaning neighborhoods like Bensonhurst and Flushing, and in Staten Island‚Äîthe only borough that backed Trump in 2024. CNN‚Äôs exit poll showed Mamdani leading 66% to 31% among self-identified Democrats, suggesting consolidation of party base support. The results reflect broader trends of civic engagement and shifting political dynamics in diverse urban enclaves, indicating that the general election outcome diverged from the primary, with voter behavior influenced by both identity and party affiliation.
keyTakeAways: Zohran Mamdani won the New York City mayoral election, defeating former Governor Andrew Cuomo by nearly 9 percentage points in the final vote count.
Turnout reached over 2 million votes, surpassing 2024 presidential election levels in many areas, signaling high civic engagement.
Thirteen districts‚Äîincluding parts of Brooklyn, Lower Manhattan, and the Upper East Side‚Äîexceeded 80% of their 2024 presidential turnout, showing increased voter participation.
Mamdani received over 65% support in five districts and less than 35% in four, indicating a mixed but generally favorable outcome across different neighborhoods.
The election was a rematch of the June Democratic primary, where Mamdani defeated Cuomo, who then ran as an independent, highlighting a shift in voter behavior beyond the primary electorate.
Mamdani gained strong support in traditionally Democratic, Black and Latino-majority areas of Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx, where Cuomo won in the primary.

Cuomo gained support in more Republican-leaning areas such as Bensonhurst and Flushing, which have large Chinese populations, and in Staten Island, the only borough to support Trump in the 2024 presidential election.
Cuomo won 70% of Trump voters citywide, with Mamdani receiving only 9%, suggesting that Trump voters were more likely to support Cuomo in the general election.
CNN‚Äôs exit poll showed that Mamdani led Cuomo 66% to 31% among self-identified Democrats, indicating his success in consolidating Democratic base support.

  Zohran Mamdani  won Tuesday‚Äôs election  for mayor of New York City, leading former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo by nearly 9 percentage points so far. See how Mamdani did in precincts across the city:
 

   
  Turnout surged across the city ‚Äî total votes cast in many areas rivaled the number cast in the 2024 presidential election. With late-arriving mail still to be counted, there have been over 2 million votes cast, about three-quarters of the 2024 turnout.
 

   
  Thirteen districts, spanning Brooklyn, Lower Manhattan, and the Upper East Side, exceeded 80% of their presidential turnout, including one district in Brooklyn that topped its count of 2024 total ballots. These districts varied in their support for Mamdani: He received greater than 65% support in five of the districts and less than 35% in four, with the remaining districts more mixed in their support.
 

   
  The election largely came down to a rematch of the top two candidates in June‚Äôs Democratic primary. Mamdani won that contest to become the Democratic nominee, while Cuomo chose to run as an independent candidate after losing. The electorate in a general election is by nature different from a Democratic primary, which is restricted to registered Democrats only. But shifts in the margin between Mamdani and Cuomo suggest there were changes in support driven by more than just a broader electorate.
 

   
  As the Democratic nominee, Mamdani consolidated the support of self-identified Democrats, leading Cuomo 66% to 31% according to  CNN‚Äôs exit poll . Mamdani‚Äôs largest improvements came from strongly Democratic areas, mostly places with high Black and Latino populations, in Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx that voted for Cuomo in the primary.
 

   
  Cuomo‚Äôs gains came from more Republican areas in Brooklyn, Queens, and Staten Island. These include areas with large Chinese populations, such as Bensonhurst in Brooklyn and Flushing in Queens. Staten Island was the only borough in New York City to support Trump in the 2024 presidential election. CNN‚Äôs exit poll found that Cuomo won 70% of 2024 Trump voters citywide (the Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa received 21% of Trump backers‚Äô votes, and Mamdani received 9%).

Cutting America‚Äôs flights will have huge ramifications for ticket prices and passengers 
       
  By Chris Isidore, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:53 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Airline passengers were already looking at higher fares and packed planes this holiday season. But the holiday headaches might get much worse as the government shutdown causes flight reductions at major airports.
 

   
  The Trump administration will  reduce traffic  at 40 airports across the United States starting Friday if the  shutdown  continues ‚Äî meaning holiday travels could be much more fraught this year. Airlines are already starting to cancel upcoming flights a few days at a time, though it‚Äôs hard to say how long these cutbacks will last.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre doing that because we don‚Äôt know how long this is going to last and they‚Äôre not going to go and take out flights automatically that they don‚Äôt necessarily need to,‚Äù travel industry expert Zach Griff said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs going to cause a lot more stress for travelers, but there really isn‚Äôt a better way to do it. Still, it is not going to be a pleasant experience until this is finished.‚Äù
 

   
  Fares were already forecast to be up 7% to 10% over a year ago during the holiday season, according to data from discount travel site Going.com. Strong travel demand and a pullback on capacity by some low-fare carriers, such as Spirit Airlines, have largely propelled the rise in prices. (Spirit is once again in bankruptcy and was cutting its schedule as a cost-cutting measure before the Federal Aviation Administration-demanded flight restrictions were announced.)
 

   
  Cutting back flights will likely pressure prices higher. Based on flight schedules that have yet to be finalized, aviation analytics firm Cirium estimates that there could be 1,800 fewer flights a day with the anticipated travel restrictions, reducing supply by more than 100,000 seats up to as many as 268,000.
 

   
    Which flights most at risk
 

   
  The flights most at risk of being canceled are feeder routes from smaller regional airports to the airlines‚Äô hubs, as flights between bigger cities are more profitable. So while the nation‚Äôs 40 largest airports are facing the government-mandated flight reduction, travelers at smaller airports are the ones who could be stranded.
 

   
  Passengers with canceled flights were already entitled to a refund if they decide not to take a different flight. But finding another seat can be difficult, especially if this lasts into the holidays, or if bad weather causes flight cancellations elsewhere.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis will be disruptive, and it‚Äôs not good for customers, there‚Äôs no question about that,‚Äù said Griff.
 

   
  The good news, such as it is, for travelers is that the nation‚Äôs three largest airlines ‚Äì American, Delta and United Airlines ‚Äì have all announced they will give refunds to passengers who cancel their flights in advance. Travelers can get a refund from those three airlines, even if their flight isn‚Äôt one of those affected and if they have what would normally be a non-refundable ticket.
 

   
  The hope by some industry observers is that the government shutdown ends and the schedules return to normal before the week of Thanksgiving, which is often the busiest week of the year in terms of flights.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThanksgiving is sort of a nonnegotiable for a lot of travelers,‚Äù said Katy Nastro, spokesperson for Going.com. ‚ÄúFingers crossed that this doesn‚Äôt last well into next week. I would really be shocked if it did, because we‚Äôre in for a whole lot of travel pain if that‚Äôs the case.‚Äù

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In November 2025, Democrats on the U.S. House Oversight Committee formally request an interview with former Prince Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, seeking to investigate his alleged ties to Jeffrey Epstein and sexual abuse allegations made by Virginia Giuffre. The request comes amid Andrew's formal removal of his royal title and eviction from royal estates, and includes allegations that he paid millions to Giuffre under a gag order and attempted to silence her with internet trolls. While the request lacks legal enforcement due to lack of Republican support, it reflects broader global efforts to hold powerful individuals accountable for abuse and cover-ups. Giuffre‚Äôs claims‚Äînow posthumous‚Äîhighlight concerns about victim suppression and the misuse of power, particularly within elite circles. The investigation also includes the Met‚Äôs probe into Andrew‚Äôs 2011 request to dig up dirt on Giuffre, further fueling scrutiny into attempts to intimidate survivors.
keyTakeAways: Democrat-led House Oversight Committee is requesting former Prince Andrew Mountbatten Windsor to appear and be interviewed regarding his alleged connections to Jeffrey Epstein and sexual abuse allegations involving Virginia Giuffre.
Andrew‚Äôs name appears in financial and operational documents tied to Epstein, including notations such as 'massages for Andrew,' raising concerns about his role in Epstein‚Äôs network.
Virginia Giuffre, who died by suicide in April 2022, accused Andrew of sexually abusing her at age 17 and claimed he believed sex with her was his 'birthright'.
Andrew reportedly paid millions in 2022 to settle a civil case with Giuffre, which included a one-year gag order, leading to claims of victim silencing and suppression.
Giuffre alleged that Andrew‚Äôs team hired internet trolls to harass her and that he hid behind the security of Balmoral Castle to avoid legal service.
In 2025, the UK formally stripped Andrew of his royal title and removed him from royal estates; he is being relocated to Sandringham after the Christmas holidays.
The request for an interview lacks legal force due to bipartisan absence‚ÄîCongressional Republicans would be needed to issue a subpoena, and Andrew is expected to decline.
The congressional investigation is focused not only on Epstein‚Äôs crimes but also on efforts to silence or intimidate victims, citing the Metropolitan Police‚Äôs 2025 inquiry as a key justification.
Andrew has denied all allegations, and the request underscores the ongoing global public interest in accountability for powerful figures linked to sexual abuse and cover-ups.

articles.content:
Democrats on US congressional panel request interview with former Prince Andrew on Epstein links 
       
  By Christian Edwards, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:40 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Democrats on the House Oversight Committee are requesting that  Andrew Mountbatten Windsor  come to Washington to be questioned as part of the panel‚Äôs investigation into the convicted sex offender  Jeffrey Epstein  and his accomplices.
 

   
  In a  letter  to Andrew on Thursday ‚Äì published soon after he was formally stripped of his ‚ÄúRoyal Highness‚Äù style and ‚ÄúPrince‚Äù title ‚Äì the lawmakers asked that he submit himself to questioning to ‚Äúprovide insight into the crimes of Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs co-conspirators.‚Äù The lawmakers ask Andrew to sit for a transcribed interview and ask that he provide a response by November 20.
 

   
  ‚ÄúRich and powerful men have evaded justice for far too long,‚Äù said Rep. Robert Garcia, the top Democrat on the committee. ‚ÄúNow, former Prince Andrew has the opportunity to come clean and provide justice for the survivors.‚Äù
 

   
  The request for an interview comes a week after King Charles III began a process to strip his younger brother of his titles and honors and evict him from the royal estate at Windsor, seeming to cap Andrew‚Äôs yearslong fall from grace over the depth of his ties to Epstein.
 

   
  Andrew will likely decline the request from the Republican-controlled committee. Even with bi-partisan support, the committee would struggle to compel Andrew‚Äôs participation. But without Congressional Republicans signing on, the Democrats cannot even take the step of issuing a subpoena ‚Äî which offers legal weight to force a person to appear.
 

   
  Nonetheless, the letter underscores how the removal of Andrew‚Äôs title as prince will do little to deter those on both sides of the Atlantic seeking justice for Epstein‚Äôs alleged victims.
 

   
  Andrew‚Äôs name appears in financial records and documents subpoenaed from Epstein‚Äôs estate and published by the committee, including in notations such as ‚Äúmassages for Andrew,‚Äù which the committee said ‚Äúraise serious questions‚Äù about the nature of his relationship with the billionaire pedophile.
 

   
  He has also been accused by  Virginia Giuffre  ‚Äì who died by suicide in April ‚Äì of sexually abusing her when she was just 17. In her posthumous memoir, Giuffre wrote that Andrew ‚Äúbelieved that having sex with me was his birthright.‚Äù
 

   
  Despite claiming never to have met her, Andrew reportedly paid millions of dollars to Giuffre in 2022 to settle a civil case she brought against him. He has repeatedly denied all allegations against him.
 

   
  In her memoir, published last month, Giuffre wrote that she feared retaliation if she made allegations against Andrew, claiming that the settlement restricted her to a one-year gag order designed to protect the royal family‚Äôs reputation.
 

   
  She also claimed that Andrew‚Äôs ‚Äúteam‚Äù tried to hire ‚Äúinternet trolls‚Äù to hassle her while he hid behind the ‚Äúwell-guarded gates‚Äù of Balmoral Castle to avoid being served court papers by her lawyers.
 

   
  Earlier in October, London‚Äôs Metropolitan Police said it was investigating reports in the British media that Andrew asked his police protection to ‚Äúdig up dirt‚Äù on Giuffre in 2011.
 

   
  As well as investigating alleged abuse committed by Epstein and his circle, the committee said it was also probing efforts to ‚Äúsilence, intimidate, or threaten victims,‚Äù citing the Met‚Äôs investigation as another reason for wanting to question Andrew. It asked that he provide a response to the committee by November 20.
 

   
  Royal sources told CNN that the committee‚Äôs request is a matter for Andrew, for whom Buckingham Palace does not speak or act.
 

   
  Andrew‚Äôs summoning comes a day after the UK‚Äôs official public record  showed  that he has been formally stripped of his ‚ÄúPrince‚Äù title. He is also preparing to leave Royal Lodge, where he has lived since 2003. Royal sources have told CNN that Andrew will be given a house on the King‚Äôs private estate in Sandringham, Norfolk, and that he is expected to move after the Christmas holidays.

articles.title: Trump administration tells Congress it currently lacks legal justification to strike Venezuela
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration has informed Congress that it currently lacks a legal basis under U.S. law to conduct military strikes inside Venezuela, emphasizing that the Justice Department‚Äôs Office of Legal Counsel opinion authorizing lethal operations against suspected drug boats does not extend to land targets. While the administration has launched 16 strikes since September 2025 targeting vessels linked to 24 specific Latin American cartels, it has not yet decided on future land-based operations and is seeking a new legal opinion to justify such actions. The military buildup in the Caribbean‚Äîsuch as the Ford Carrier Strike Group‚Äîis framed as supporting counternarcotic efforts and intelligence gathering, not offensive strikes. Critics including Senators Mark Warner and Gregory Meeks have questioned the legality, transparency, and necessity of using lethal force, arguing that non-lethal interdiction by the Coast Guard would be sufficient. The administration maintains that its actions are constitutionally justified and aligned with the Law of Armed Conflict, but continues to avoid formal congressional approval for military force in the region.
keyTakeAways: The Trump administration has stated it currently lacks legal justification under U.S. law to launch military strikes inside Venezuela.
The Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) opinion authorizing lethal strikes against drug-related vessels does not extend to land targets in Venezuela or any other territory.
The existing 'execute order' for strikes is limited to maritime targets linked to 24 specific cartels or criminal organizations in Latin America and does not authorize attacks on land.
The administration is seeking a new legal opinion from the Justice Department to justify future strikes on land targets without congressional approval.
Military assets such as the Ford Carrier Strike Group are being deployed to the Caribbean primarily for counternarcotic operations and intelligence gathering, not for offensive strikes on Venezuela.
The administration has acknowledged that it often does not know individual identities aboard vessels prior to strikes, relying instead on intelligence linking vessels to cartels.
The U.S. has conducted 16 known strikes since September 2025, resulting in at least 67 deaths, and claims these actions are based on rigorous intelligence tracking and coordination.

Critics, including Sen. Mark Warner and Rep. Gregory Meeks, have questioned the legality and necessity of using lethal force, arguing that interdiction by the Coast Guard would be sufficient and more transparent.
The White House maintains that the actions are consistent with the President‚Äôs constitutional authority and the Law of Armed Conflict, emphasizing protection of Americans from narcoterrorism.

articles.content:
Trump admin tells Congress it currently lacks legal justification to strike Venezuela 
       
  By Natasha Bertrand, Jennifer Hansler, Katie Bo Lillis, Zachary Cohen, Kylie Atwood, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:07 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Trump administration officials told lawmakers on Wednesday that the US is not currently planning to launch strikes inside Venezuela and doesn‚Äôt have a legal justification that would support attacks against any land targets right now, according to sources familiar with the briefing conducted by Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and an official from the White House‚Äôs Office of Legal Counsel.
 

   
  Lawmakers were told during the classified session that the opinion produced by the Justice Department‚Äôs Office of Legal Counsel to justify strikes against suspected drug boats,  first reported by CNN  last month, does not permit strikes inside Venezuela itself or any other territories, four sources said.
 

   
  The ‚Äúexecute order‚Äù that launched the US military campaign against suspected drug boats that began in September also does not extend to land targets, the briefers said, according to the sources.
 

   
  The officials did not rule out any potential future actions, one of the sources said.
 

   
  The existing OLC opinion includes a list of 24 different cartels and criminal organizations based around Latin America it says the administration is authorized to target, according to one of the sources familiar with the document.
 

   
  But the Trump administration is seeking a separate legal opinion from the Justice Department that would provide a justification for launching strikes against land targets without needing to ask Congress to authorize military force, though no decisions have been made yet to move forward with an attack inside the country, a US official said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhat is true one day may very well not be the next,‚Äù said that US official when discussing the current state of the policy, pointing out that Trump has not decided how he will handle Venezuela.
 

   
  The massive buildup of military assets in the Caribbean, which will soon include the Ford Carrier Strike Group, has raised questions about whether the US intends to strike inside Venezuela. But the briefers said the military assets are only moving there to support counternarcotic operations and conduct intelligence gathering, two of the sources said.
 

   
  The administration has to date tried to avoid involving Congress in its military campaign around Latin America. A senior Justice Department official  told Congress last week  that the US military can continue its lethal strikes on alleged drug traffickers without congressional approval and that the administration is not bound by a decades-old war powers law that would mandate working with lawmakers, CNN has reported.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPresident Trump was elected with a resounding mandate to take on the cartels and stop the scourge of narcoterrorism from killing Americans,‚Äù a White House official said in a response to a request for comment from CNN. ‚ÄúThe President continues to take actions consistent with his responsibility to protect Americans and pursuant to his constitutional authority. All actions comply fully with the Law of Armed Conflict.‚Äù
 

   
  The US military has carried out 16 known strikes against boats in the Caribbean and eastern Pacific since September, killing at least 67 people. In  several briefings  to Congress, including the one on Wednesday, administration officials have acknowledged that they do not necessarily know the individual identities of each person on board a vessel before they attack it.
 

   
  Strikes are instead conducted based on intelligence that the vessels are linked to a specific cartel or criminal organization, sources said. Administration officials walked through the process they use to identify and target the vessels and discussed the types of intelligence they had connecting the vessels to cartels during Wednesday‚Äôs briefing, one of the sources said.
 

   
  Democratic Sen. Mark Warner, the ranking member of the Senate Intelligence Committee,  told reporters after the briefing , ‚ÄúI think our intelligence assets are quite good,‚Äù explaining that he believes the administration does have ‚Äúvisibility‚Äù into the transport of illegal drugs.
 

   
  But he questioned why the administration had to use lethal force against the boats instead of interdicting them, as the Coast Guard has routinely done in the past, which could produce evidence of the trafficking.
 

   
  House Foreign Affairs Committee ranking member Rep. Gregory Meeks, however, told CNN after the briefing that he heard ‚Äúnothing‚Äù to convince him of the legality of the strikes. He also said the briefers did not share the evidence that ties the vessels or their passengers to the drug trade.
 

   
  Administration officials have repeatedly said they have intelligence that ties the vessels to the drug trade, but have offered few details publicly.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI can assure you that every one of these strikes involves boats and shipments that were tracked from the very beginning,‚Äù Rubio said in late October. ‚ÄúFrom the moment these things were put together, the moment they were coordinated, we know where they‚Äôre headed. We know what their drop-off points are; we know what organizations they‚Äôre involved in. These things are tracked very carefully.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere are hundreds of boats out there every single day, and there are many strikes that we walk away from and that the Department of War walks away from because it doesn‚Äôt meet the criteria,‚Äù he said in remarks to the press. ‚ÄúThis goes through a very rigorous process.‚Äù

articles.content:
Amazon lakes became ‚Äòsimmering basins‚Äô as temperatures spiked to 105 degrees ‚Äî above recommended limits for hot tubs 
       
  By Laura Paddison, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:00 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Lakes in the Amazon became  hotter than the maximum temperature  recommended for hot tubs as unprecedented heat and drought in 2023 turned them into ‚Äúshallow, simmering basins,‚Äù according to a new study ‚Äî and it proved a death sentence for endangered dolphins.
 

   
  The world‚Äôs lakes are considered sentinels of climate change and are warming dramatically as  global temperatures rise . Research, however, has tended to focus on temperate lakes   rather than those in the tropics, despite their huge vulnerability to intense warming.
 

   
  Scientists in Brazil are trying to fill some of these gaps. They used satellite data to analyze 10 Amazon lakes during a devastating  climate change-driven heat wave  and drought in September and October 2023, which pushed them to the lowest water levels on record at the time.
 

   
  In half the lakes, daytime temperatures were ‚Äúexceptionally high,‚Äù above 37 degrees Celsius (98.6 Fahrenheit), according to the  research  published Thursday. These kinds of temperatures are rare in large bodies of water ‚Äî even in tropical regions. Daytime temperatures in Amazonian lakes are more typically around 30 degrees Celsius (86 Fahrenheit).
 

   
  Lake Tef√©, a roughly 37-mile long lake in northwestern Brazil, endured especially intense heat.
 

   
  Daytime temperatures in the lake spiked to 41 degrees (105.8 Fahrenheit) in October 2023 ‚Äî hotter than the average spa bath, and exceeding  the 104 degrees Fahrenheit limit  the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends for hot tubs.
 

   
  Strikingly, this heat was not just on the surface but was also detected at depths of more than 6 feet, leaving nowhere in the lake for fish and dolphins to take refuge.
 

   
  Such high temperatures to these depths are ‚Äúlikely unprecedented, though, we lack long-term observations‚Äù to understand what happened in the past, said Ayan Fleischmann, a report author and hydrologist at the Mamirau√° Institute for Sustainable Development in Brazil.
 

   
  Many of the lakes also shrunk dramatically. Lake Tef√©‚Äôs surface area decreased by 75%, while another lake, Badaj√≥s, shrunk by 92%.
 

   
  The impacts of the extreme heat were severe. The temperatures went ‚Äúbeyond the thermal tolerance of many aquatic animals,‚Äù Fleischmann told CNN. It led to an unprecedented mass die off of Amazon river and tucuxi dolphins, the report found.
 

   
  At Lake Tef√©, more than  200 bodies of freshwater dolphins  were found between late September and October 2023. It‚Äôs not fully known why the dolphins stayed in the hot lake and didn‚Äôt seek cooler water downstream towards the Amazon River, but it‚Äôs possible the intense heat affected their brains, the study notes.
 

   
  The temperature spikes also affected wild and farmed fish in the lake, with 3,000 fish dying at one aquaculture pond.
 

   
  River communities were heavily affected during this period. Thousands of people were left isolated and without proper access to food, water and medicine, the study found. ‚ÄúWhen aquatic ecosystems are disrupted, Amazonian communities are disrupted,‚Äù Fleischmann said.
 

   
  There were multiple factors behind the remarkable heat: extreme drought leading to very low lake levels, murky water able to absorb more of the sun‚Äôs energy, intense sunlight, and low winds, which meant less heat was lost through evaporation and nighttime cooling.
 

   
  While the study focused on 2023, the central Amazon endured another  extreme drought in 2024 , again pushing lakes to record low levels and causing severe water heating.
 

   
  A lack of long-term monitoring makes it difficult to understand exactly how fast Amazon lakes have been warming over the decades.
 

   
  The study authors used remote sensing data for 24 lakes across the region to estimate warming trends. They found average surface water temperatures have increased at 0.6 degrees Celsius (about 1 degree Fahrenheit) a decade over the past 30 years.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAmazon lakes are facing a long-term warming process, likely associated with climate change and global warming,‚Äù Fleishmann said.

articles.title: Massive Fire Heavily Damages Home Owned by Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A massive fire destroyed a home owned by Miami Heat head coach Erik Spoelstra in Miami on Thursday, November 6, 2025. The fire broke out around 4:30 a.m. while Spoelstra was away, having just returned from a game in Denver. The home, which he purchased in December 2023 and renovated extensively, was unoccupied at the time of the blaze, and no injuries were reported. Fire crews from Miami-Dade Fire Rescue responded with both ground and aerial units, containing the fire within hours despite flames reaching as high as trees. The blaze was fully contained by early morning, and no nearby homes were damaged due to natural barriers like trees and a privacy fence. Drone footage showed the home reduced to charred rubble. An investigation into the cause of the fire is ongoing and may take weeks. Spoelstra, who has coached the Heat for 18 seasons and is set to become head coach of the U.S. Olympic men‚Äôs basketball team in 2028, was seen at the scene in disbelief after arriving at the property shortly after the fire began.
