Massive fire heavily damages home owned by Miami Heat coach Erik Spoelstra 
       
  By Associated Press
 

       
Updated: 
        1:59 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: AP
 
   
  Fire destroyed a home owned by  Miami Heat  coach Erik Spoelstra early Thursday, with officials saying more than 20 units were dispatched in what became a futile effort to save the property.
 

   
  Spoelstra was not home when the fire began, and no injuries were reported. Fire officials said ‚Äúthe home was unoccupied‚Äù when the blaze broke out around 4:30 a.m.
 

   
  An investigation into what caused the fire was starting, officials said. Those probes can take weeks in some cases.
 

   
  Spoelstra and the Heat played in Denver on Wednesday night and their charter flight back to Miami did not land until 5:11 a.m.
 

   
  Spoelstra arrived at the home shortly after the plane landed, with several fire crews working to try to contain the blaze. He was seen walking around the outside of the property as the fire continued, sometimes stopping and holding his head in disbelief.
 

   
  Drone footage showed that much of the home was reduced to charred rubble.
 

   
  Smoke was still seen rising over parts of the property more than three hours after the first fire trucks arrived, but officials declared the blaze as contained around that time. Some crews were still on the scene early Thursday afternoon.
 

   
  Miami-Dade Fire Rescue said the blaze ‚Äî with flames ‚Äúas tall as the trees,‚Äù battalion chief Victoria Byrd said in a brief news briefing ‚Äî was fought with crews both on the ground and in the air. The fire was contained to the property owned by Spoelstra and no nearby homes were damaged, Byrd said, adding that a privacy fence and tree cover impeded the initial firefighting efforts.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOur units came in and did an excellent job,‚Äù Byrd said.
 

   
  Property records show Spoelstra bought the five-bedroom home in December 2023. He had done extensive work to the property following the purchase.
 

   
  Spoelstra ‚Äî who has been part of all three of Miami‚Äôs NBA championship runs, two as head coach ‚Äî is in his 18th season as coach of the Heat, an organization he originally joined as a video coordinator in 1995. He finalized a deal last month to serve as coach of the U.S. Olympic men‚Äôs basketball team at the 2028 Los Angeles Games.
 

   
  The Heat were scheduled to be off Thursday and will play host to the Charlotte Hornets on Friday night.

articles.title: Nancy Pelosi Announces She Will Not Seek Re-election to Congress After Nearly 40 Years in Washington
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Nancy Pelosi, the first and only woman to serve as Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, has announced she will not seek reelection after nearly 40 years in Congress, marking the end of a transformative political era. Her decision comes shortly after a major political victory: championing a redistricting ballot measure in California that favors Democrats ahead of the 2026 midterms. Pelosi has led the Democratic Party through pivotal legislative achievements, including the passage of the Affordable Care Act, and has been a central figure in the party‚Äôs shift toward more progressive policies. Her tenure was marked by fierce opposition to President Donald Trump, including during the January 6 Capitol riot and the infamous incident where she tore up Trump‚Äôs State of the Union speech. Personal events, such as the violent attack on her husband Paul Pelosi in 2022, and political challenges, including her private encouragement of President Joe Biden to step down in 2024, highlight both the risks and complexities of her leadership. The announcement has prompted strong reactions, with Biden praising her legacy and Trump calling her a 'terrible' and 'evil' figure. As a trailblazer in politics and a symbol of women‚Äôs empowerment, Pelosi‚Äôs departure represents a turning point in American democratic history.
keyTakeAways: Nancy Pelosi, the first and only female Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, has announced she will not seek reelection after nearly 40 years in Congress.
Pelosi‚Äôs decision follows a major political victory: her support for a redistricting ballot measure that favors Democrats, which she personally funded and championed.
Pelosi has led Democrats through major legislative achievements, including the Affordable Care Act, and has been a central figure in the party‚Äôs ideological shift toward left-leaning policies.
Her leadership included two stints as Speaker, the first being in 2007 and the second in 2019, making her the first woman and the first to win non-consecutive terms in the role.

Pelosi has been a fierce opponent of President Donald Trump, including during the January 6 Capitol riot, when her leadership suite was attacked, and she famously tore up Trump‚Äôs State of the Union address.

The announcement has sparked strong reactions: President Joe Biden praised her as 'the best Speaker in American history' and awarded her the Presidential Medal of Freedom, while former President Donald Trump called her 'terrible' and 'a tremendous liability'.
Pelosi‚Äôs personal background ‚Äî raised in Baltimore, daughter of a former city mayor, sister of another politician ‚Äî influenced her political strategy and resilience.
Her legacy includes breaking gender barriers in politics, projecting confidence in a traditionally male-dominated environment, and empowering women to stand firm in political conflict.

articles.content:
Nancy Pelosi announces she will not seek reelection to Congress after nearly 40 years in Washington 
       
  By Sarah Ferris, Dana Bash, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:54 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
   Nancy Pelosi , the first and only female speaker of the US House of Representatives and one of the most powerful figures in Democratic politics for decades, has announced she will not seek reelection.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI have truly loved serving as your voice in Congress, and I have always honored the song of St. Francis, ‚ÄòLord make an instrument of thy peace,‚Äô the anthem of our city. That is why I want you, my fellow San Franciscans, to be the first to know. I will not be seeking reelection to Congress,‚Äù Pelosi, 85, said Thursday in a sweeping video that stood as a love letter to the city she has represented for nearly 40 years in Washington.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWith a grateful heart, I look forward to my final year of service as your proud representative. As we go forward, my message to the city I love is this: San Francisco, know your power. We have made history. We have made progress. We have always led the way, and now we must continue to do so by remaining full participants in our Democracy and fighting for the American ideals we hold dear.‚Äù
 

   
  The announcement ends heightened speculation in recent days that the longtime Democrat would soon announce her intention to draw her congressional career to a close after 38 years. She was widely expected to leave Congress after this term, her first in decades as a rank-and-file member.
 

   
  Reflecting on her many roles on Capitol Hill, Pelosi said Thursday: ‚ÄúI say to my colleagues in the House all of the time, no matter what title they had bestowed upon me ‚Äì speaker, leader, whip ‚Äì there has been no greater honor for me than to stand on the House floor and say, ‚ÄòI speak for the people of San Francisco.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  Pelosi was first elected to Congress in 1987, and made history as the House‚Äôs first-ever female speaker in 2007. She remains the only woman to have wielded the gavel, which she earned after the 2006 and 2018 elections. Even now, decades after her ascent to the top of the House Democratic caucus, she remains one of the most influential voices in the party.
 

   
  The congresswoman made public her decision to retire two days after one of her biggest political victories in recent years: a resounding win for a ballot measure in California that redraws the state‚Äôs congressional map to favor Democrats ahead of the 2026 midterm elections. She personally raised tens of millions of dollars for the push, according to a person familiar with her fundraising efforts.
 

   
  While Pelosi herself wasn‚Äôt on the ballot Tuesday, it was a fitting closing coda to a storied political career. The long-time Democratic leader has devoted her recent years in Congress ‚Äî both as speaker and as a rank-and-file member ‚Äî to fighting President Donald Trump and his remake of the Republican Party. In recent months, she worked furiously behind the scenes with her longtime friend, Gov. Gavin Newsom, to pass ‚Äú Proposition 50 ,‚Äù which won with a whopping 63% of the vote.
 

   
  Raised in Baltimore‚Äôs Little Italy neighborhood, Pelosi grew up walking the halls of the Capitol, where her father served as a US congressman from Maryland. The daughter of one former city mayor and the sister of another, her colleagues have often attributed that upbringing to her sharp negotiating tactics and fierceness in politics.
 

   
  She held an iron grip over Democrats in Congress ‚Äî almost never losing a vote on the floor, which has been a regular occurrence under the House GOP ‚Äî and used old-school tactics to keep that power, including exacting revenge on her rivals by blocking them from powerful committees. She never once faced a serious challenger in her time as speaker. (Behind the scenes, she encouraged endangered Democrats to run against her publicly if they needed to do so to win favor at home, telling them: ‚ÄúJust win.‚Äù)
 

   
  Two years after Pelosi stepped back from House Democratic leadership under pressure to let the younger generation in the party lead, the longtime congresswoman is still widely regarded as one of the most powerful speakers in modern history. In her second term with the gavel, Pelosi presided over historic clashes with Trump, including congressional oversight battles that twice escalated to the level of a rare House impeachment against a US president. In one of her most infamous moments of Trump‚Äôs first term, Pelosi  tore up a copy  of the president‚Äôs State of the Union speech to Congress while sitting behind him during the nationally televised address.
 

   
  The animosity between the two reached a new level after the January 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol, during which pro-Trump rioters stormed the complex and among the widespread destruction broke into Pelosi‚Äôs leadership suite and terrorized her staff.
 

   
  The president on Thursday reacted to the congresswoman‚Äôs announcement by calling her ‚Äúterrible,‚Äù ‚Äúan evil woman‚Äù and ‚Äúa tremendous liability for the country.‚Äù
 

   
  Her legislative legacy, however, extends far beyond Trump. As a newly elected representative from San Francisco in the late 1980s, her maiden speech focused largely on fighting the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Since then, her time in Congress has spanned seven presidents, during which she cast historic votes such on whether to authorize then-President George W. Bush‚Äôs nascent war in Iraq after the September 2001 terrorist attacks or to impeach then-President Bill Clinton. (Pelosi opposed both measures.)
 

   
  After a steady climb up the leadership ladder, Pelosi first won the speaker‚Äôs gavel 18 years ago. Then, in 2019, Pelosi took the gavel again, becoming the first person to win non-consecutive terms as speaker in six decades.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt is an historic moment for the Congress, and an historic moment for the women of this country,‚Äù Pelosi said in her first speech as speaker in 2007. ‚ÄúIt is a moment for which we have waited over 200 years.‚Äù
 

   
  Her time leading the House Democratic caucus included two separate stints during which the party held the White House and majorities in both the House and Senate. During those years of full Democratic control of Washington, Pelosi, alongside then-Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, followed by Chuck Schumer, muscled through enormous pieces of legislation, including the landmark Affordable Care Act, of which Pelosi‚Äôs team has described her as the ‚Äúchief architect.‚Äù
 

   
  She had a longtime and personal relationship with the most recent Democratic president, Joe Biden, and the two passed billions of dollars in new funding to help the nation recover from the Covid pandemic and expand programs, like the enhanced ACA subsidies now at the center of the government shutdown. But Pelosi notably withheld her support for Biden in the final months of his campaign and was also one of the senior Democrats who was  privately helping to encourage  him to leave the presidential ticket in the summer of 2024, worried about his ability to defeat Trump. (Former first lady Jill Biden later called Pelosi‚Äôs actions in the run-up to the election ‚Äúdisappointing‚Äù after 50 years of friendship.)
 

   
  On Thursday, the former president  publicly sent  his well-wishes to Pelosi and praised her as ‚Äúthe best Speaker of the House in American history.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I awarded her the Presidential Medal of Freedom,‚Äù Biden wrote.
 

   
  In her nearly four decades in office, Pelosi steered Democrats as more ardent redistricting efforts peeled away moderates in the party ‚Äî nearly eliminating the southern Blue Dogs who once almost tanked the Democrats‚Äô health care law. Now, the caucus represents a far more left-leaning party, with virtually no dissent on once-divisive issues like abortion or gay marriage.
 

   
  Years after drafting that health care law, Pelosi then helped Democrats win back the majority in 2018, fueled by anti-Trump wave on a health care-driven message that was a direct result of the Trump administration‚Äôs repeated attempts to repeal the law.
 

   
  She oversaw a time of rapid change in the party, as increased political polarization reshaped national politics. That included a sharp rise in political violence that struck her own family in 2022, in which her husband Paul Pelosi was violently attacked with a hammer by a man who broke into their San Francisco home. Paul Pelosi, who suffered a fractured skull, required surgery and underwent a long recovery. She later told CNN that the attack  complicated her decision  on whether to remain in party leadership at the time.
 

   
  Pelosi does not often speak of the glass ceilings for women in politics or her own role in breaking them. But she has previously opened up to CNN about playing in what was traditionally a boys‚Äô club of politics.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI get some names called, because if you‚Äôre effective as a woman, then they have to undermine you, because that‚Äôs a real threat,‚Äù Pelosi said in an interview in 2018.
 

   
  She reflected at the time on the importance of projecting confidence.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYou know why I do it? I do it, because I want women to see that you do not get pushed around. You don‚Äôt run away from the fight,‚Äù she said.

  A teaser trailer for ‚ÄúMichael,‚Äù the film about the musician‚Äôs rise debuted on Thursday and gave the first glimpse of his real life nephew, Jaafar Jackson, portraying his late uncle.
 

   
  The elder Jackson died in 2009 at the age of 50 as a result of acute propofol intoxication.

  According to a description, the film ‚Äúis the cinematic portrayal of the life and legacy of one of the most influential artists the world has ever known‚Äù and explores the ‚ÄúSmooth Criminal‚Äù singer‚Äôs ‚Äúlife beyond the music, tracing his journey from the discovery of his extraordinary talent as the lead of the Jackson Five, to the visionary artist whose creative ambition fueled a relentless pursuit to become the biggest entertainer in the world.‚Äù
 

   
  Absent from the trailer is any mention of any mention of the singer‚Äôs well publicized legal troubles. He was acquitted of child molestation charges after a well-publicized trial in Santa Maria, California, in March 2006.

  Representatives for the Jackson family estate and Fuqua did not return CNN‚Äôs request for comment earlier this year.
 

   
  Chandler was not the only person to accuse Michael Jackson of sexual abuse.

articles.content:
Russian soldier jailed for life after being found guilty of shooting dead Ukrainian PoW, in unprecedented ruling 
       
  By Daria Tarasova-Markina, Sophie Tanno, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:06 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A Ukrainian court has found a Russian soldier guilty of killing a Ukrainian prisoner of war in a January 2024 incident and sentenced him to life in prison, in the first ruling of its kind.
 

   
  Dmitriy Kurashov, 27, was convicted by a court in Ukraine‚Äôs southeastern city of  Zaporizhzhia  for shooting dead a Ukrainian soldier who had just surrendered to his unit.
 

   
  According to Ukraine‚Äôs security service, Kurashov had previously served time in a Russian prison for theft, and in November 2023, he signed a contract with the Russian defense ministry in exchange for amnesty.
 

   
  The court found Kurashov guilty of firing on the Ukrainian soldier at point blank range during an attack in the vicinity of the village of Pryiutne in the Zaporizhzhia region on January 6, 2024.
 

   
  The soldier  had already surrendered during the battle after running out of ammunition, the security service said. According to the prosecutor, the Ukrainian came out of a dugout unarmed, raised his hands and clearly indicated his surrender. At the request of the Russian soldier, he knelt down, but was shot with an automatic weapon and died on the spot.
 

   
  In a separate case, a Russian soldier who had been accused of robbing a house in the village of Blystavitsy in the Bucha district of the Kyiv region in March 2022 was found not guilty. This ruling was based on a lack of evidence.
 

   
  Kurashov‚Äôs sentencing is unprecedented, marking the first time a Russian soldier has been jailed for killing a captured Ukrainian since the start of the war.
 

   
  Kyiv says many Ukrainian prisoners of war have been killed by Russia‚Äôs forces, but there have so far been no legal ramifications.
 

   
  Earlier this year, the Ukrainian Prosecutor General‚Äôs office said it had, as of May 5, opened 75 criminal investigations into the suspected executions of 268 Ukrainian prisoners of war.
 

   
  It said the number of alleged executions of Ukrainian prisoners of war has been rising, with eight cases involving 57 soldiers in 2022, eight cases involving 11 soldiers in 2023, 39 cases with 149 soldiers in 2024, and 20 cases up to May 5 this year, with 51 soldiers.

articles.title: You‚Äôll never guess the Louvre‚Äôs onetime CCTV password. (You absolutely will)
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A French court report released in November 2025 criticizes the Louvre Museum for years of neglecting security in favor of expensive art purchases and renovations, citing a 2019 heist in which four men stole valuable jewelry by scaling the building and bypassing alarms. The report reveals that the museum had only 432 CCTV cameras for 465 galleries in 2024‚Äî61% of space without coverage‚Äîwhile using dangerously weak passwords like 'LOUVRE' and 'THALES' for its systems. Despite knowing these flaws since at least 2014, the museum leadership delayed critical security upgrades, with recommendations from a 2015 audit not completed until 2032. The Louvre spent over 105 million euros on artwork acquisitions between 2018 and 2024, compared to less on security, and the French government, including Culture Minister Rachida Dati, initially defended the security systems but later acknowledged failures. The report calls for a major overhaul of both physical and cybersecurity measures, including doubling the number of CCTV cameras and improving internal controls.
keyTakeAways: The Louvre's security system had fundamental flaws, including a known password 'LOUVRE' for its CCTV network and a similarly weak password 'THALES' for Thales-managed software, exposing serious cybersecurity vulnerabilities.
The museum had only 432 CCTV cameras to monitor 465 galleries in 2024, meaning 61% of the museum space lacked any surveillance, directly contributing to the 2019 heist.

The Louvre leadership prioritized visible projects like art purchases and renovations over security, spending 105 million euros on artworks between 2018 and 2024, compared to less on security infrastructure.
A 2015 security audit recommended upgrades that were delayed until 2032, indicating a systemic failure in implementing recommended security improvements.

The security breach occurred when thieves scaled the building and broke into a reinforced case within four minutes, after the perimeter alarms were triggered, showing critical weaknesses in physical and internal security.

The French government and culture minister, Rachida Dati, initially defended the museum‚Äôs security but later acknowledged that 'security failures did indeed occur' after the heist, signaling a shift in public perception.
The Louvre director, Laurence des Cars, admitted that perimeter security was known to be weak and has committed to doubling the number of CCTV cameras in the future.

articles.content:
You‚Äôll never guess the Louvre‚Äôs onetime CCTV password. (You absolutely will) 
       
  By Joseph Ataman, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:22 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  It‚Äôs the smoking gun behind  the most spectacular heist  this side of the Millennium.
 

   
  A French court released a report Thursday slamming the leadership of the Louvre for its focus on headline-grabbing purchases and renovation projects over maintaining the security of on of the world‚Äôs largest museums.
 

   
  The audacious daytime robbery, which saw  four men walk away  with priceless historic jewellery, was a ‚Äúdeafening alarm signal,‚Äù Pierre Moscovici, president of the Court of Accounts, which authored the report, told journalists Thursday.
 

   
  Echoing the report, which was commissioned before the October 19 heist, he said that the museum leadership had prioritized ‚Äúvisible and attractive‚Äù projects, like art purchases and revamping the museum layout at the detriment, notably, of the Louvre‚Äôs security .
 

   
  Since the heist, information has resurfaced showing that  gaps in security appear to have been known for years ‚Äì including a 2014 warning that alleged one of the museum‚Äôs key passwords was simply ‚ÄúLOUVRE.‚Äù The new report only adds to a number of security failings exposed by the heist.
 

   
  So what went wrong?
 

   
    Eyes on
 

   
  Within four minutes of arriving at the outside wall of the Louvre, the thieves had scaled the building and were breaking through a window. Only then were internal alarms triggered. Four minutes later, after breaking into a reinforced case and grabbing nine pieces of historic jewelry, the thieves were making their escape.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe weaknesses of the protection of our perimeter are known and identified,‚Äù Louvre director Laurence des Cars told lawmakers after the heist.
 

   
  Internally too, the situation seems stark.
 

   
  For the Louvre‚Äôs 465 museum galleries, security staff had only 432 CCTV cameras to monitor the interior in 2024, according to the report. While that‚Äôs a nearly 50% increase on the number available in 2019, it still left 61% of the galleries without any CCTV coverage.
 

   
  The world‚Äôs largest museum, the Louvre covers some 652,300 square feet.
 

   
  In comparison, the Detroit Institute of Arts boasts a similar footprint (including a theatre and recital hall) but has over 550 CCTV cameras,  according to camera manufacturer Axis .
 

   
  Des Cars told French senators that she envisions a doubling of the number of cameras within the 37-hectare Louvre property in the years to come.
 

   
  In its recommendations, the Court of Accounts‚Äô report stressed the need for the Louvre to ‚Äústrengthen its internal control function, which remains underdeveloped for an institution the size of the Louvre.‚Äù
 

   
    Foolproof cybersecurity
 

   
  The holes in the Louvre‚Äôs security weren‚Äôt all physical. In the virtual realm its track record left much to be desired.
 

   
  A 2014 report from the French information security agency (ANSSI) seen by French daily Liberation claimed that the password for the server managing the museums‚Äô sprawling CCTV network was simply ‚ÄúLOUVRE.‚Äù Access to software managed by the security technology company Thales was protected by a similarly foolproof password: ‚ÄúTHALES‚Äù ‚Äì according to Liberation.
 

   
  In the security audit, ANSSI reportedly recommended the Louvre boost its cyber security as well as move away from outdated software that could jeopardize its protective stance.
 

   
  ANSSI did not deny the report to CNN but added that the audit, ‚Äúcannot be considered representative of the current level of security‚Äù of the Louvre‚Äôs IT systems.
 

   
    Bling, bling
 

   
  The report focused on the museum‚Äôs budgetary priorities in recent years, which saw some 27 million euros ($31.1 million) spent on maintenance works between 2018 and 2024, with a further 60 million on restoration of the Louvre palace.
 

   
  In contrast, that period saw the Louvre splash double that figure on altering the museum layout and buying up artworks.
 

   
  The museum spent 105 million euros on artworks in the six years to 2024, sweeping up 2,754 pieces in that time.
 

   
  In 2021, the Louvre  spent  some 5 million euros on two works by French Rococo painter Jean-Honor√© Fragonard. In April 2025, the Louvre made a 2.2-million euro purchase of an ‚Äúexceptional‚Äù Faberg√© triptych.
 

   
  Many of the Louvre‚Äôs purchases are clouded in a certain secrecy, particularly regarding the purchase price. The Court of Accounts‚Äô report said the Louvre should pay greater attention to the price of acquired works and specifically warned the museum against buying art works at a higher price if they were sold at auction for less than two years prior.
 

   
    Heads firmly in place
 

   
  In contrast to the focus on glitzy, eye-catching purchases, the damning report notes astonishing delays to work on the Louvre‚Äôs security infrastructure.  Recommended security upgrades from a 2015 audit still won‚Äôt be completed until 2032, it revealed.
 

   
  The report examined nearly eight years of museum operations across periods helmed by two executives.
 

   
  At the time of publication, no executives (or other staff) have been fired or resigned over the theft.
 

   
  The offer of des Cars to resign as museum director was not accepted by French Culture Minister Rachida Dati.
 

   
  Dati ‚Äì known as something of a political bulldog in France ‚Äì has aggressively defended the Louvre since the embarrassment of the October 19 heist.
 

   
  ‚ÄúDid the Louvre Museum‚Äôs security measures fail? No, they didn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs a fact. The Louvre Museum‚Äôs security measures worked,‚Äù she told lawmakers on October 21.
 

   
  The following day, Macron requested an acceleration of improved security measures at the museum.
 

   
  The following week, Dati had softened her tone, admitting to French senators that although installed security systems had functioned and staff had followed protocol ‚Äúto the letter,‚Äù the ‚Äúspectacular theft‚Äù was obviously a failure for the museum.
 

   
  ‚ÄúSecurity failures did indeed occur,‚Äù she said.

NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄòWicked‚Äô TV special: How to watch, what to expect and will you be changed ‚Äòfor good‚Äô? 
       
  By Dan Heching, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:59 PM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Somehow, it‚Äôs November, and our long wait for the conclusion to last year‚Äôs hit Oz-set  musical extravaganza ‚ÄúWicked‚Äù  is almost over.
 

   
  But first, NBC is  dusting off the broom and glittery tiara  for a TV special airing Thursday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWicked: One Wonderful Night‚Äù is set to feature some of the cast from the two John M. Chu-directed movies, and will unveil a never-before-seen clip from the sequel out later this month, possibly changing everyone who watches for good.
 

   
  How, you ask? I‚Äôm not your therapist. But here are some details about the so-called special (which actually seems like fairly run-of-the-mill corporate synergy).
 

   
    When and where can I watch ‚ÄòWicked: One Wonderful Night‚Äô?
 

   
  The two-hour musical special will air on‚ÄØThursday, November 6 at 8 p.m. ET on NBC, and those of you who pay for Peacock can stream it the next day.
 

   
    Who will be appearing?
 

   
  The central witchy duo, portrayed by Oscar-nominees Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, will lead the charge, performing alongside their ‚ÄúWicked: For Good‚Äù costars Michelle Yeoh, Jeff Goldblum, Ethan Slater, Bowen Yang and Marissa Bode. Jonathan Bailey, the recently crowned king of  sexy alive men , will be MIA. There will also be a 37-piece orchestra made up of human beings who don‚Äôt get their names in press releases but matter, too.
 

   
    What can I expect to see?
 

   
  An announcement promises sneak peeks of songs from the upcoming movie, which will be comprised of numbers from the second act of the Tony-winning Broadway musical that preceded the films along with some new music .  Additionally,  Ozians  can hope to experience ‚Äúreimagined musical arrangements, cast interviews, behind-the-scenes moments, exclusive surprises‚Äù and more, oh my! Who doesn‚Äôt love an hours-long commercial, with commercials?
 

   
    Remind me, where did ‚ÄòWicked‚Äô leave off?
 

   
  If you‚Äôre allergic to Wikipedia or think a year is just a really long time to remember something (I get it, honestly), here‚Äôs a brief refresher: The stakes were set by the end of the first film, with Elphaba (Erivo) famously ‚ÄúDefying Gravity‚Äù after being branded ‚ÄúThe Wicked Witch‚Äù by both Madame Morrible (Yeoh) and the Wizard of Oz himself (Goldblum). Glinda (Grande) was caught in the middle but seemed to bow to the authority of Morrible and the Wizard.
 

   
    What happens in the new movie?
 

   
  If you‚Äôre one of the over  15 million audience members who‚Äôve seen ‚ÄúWicked‚Äù on Broadway  (or the 65 million folks who‚Äôve taken in a traveling production worldwide), you probably have some idea‚Ä¶ unless you‚Äôre like me and have totally forgotten what happened since I saw it in, like, 2006. In any case, if  early trailers are any indication , the next installment will dovetail with the beloved story of ‚ÄúThe Wizard of Oz,‚Äù since elements from that 1939 classic have been spotted in the new film ‚Äì including the Yellow Brick Road and even Dorothy, Toto and the Cowardly Lion.
 

   
  Last year‚Äôs ‚ÄúWicked‚Äù became the  highest-grossing film based on a Broadway musical , and it earned 10 Oscar nominations, including best picture. Grande and Erivo also scored acting nominations. The film  won two  statues ‚Äì one for best achievement in production design and one for costume design.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWicked: For Good‚Äù soars into theaters on November 21.

articles.title: What to Do If Your Flight Is Canceled or Delayed During the Government Shutdown
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: As the U.S. government shutdown continues into its longest period in history, major airports face widespread flight delays and cancellations due to a shortage of air traffic controllers. The Department of Transportation has announced a reduction in air traffic starting November 7, 2025, with airlines like Delta and United waiving fees for flight changes or cancellations. Passengers are legally entitled to a full refund if a flight is canceled, and experts recommend booking refundable tickets, checking flight status early, and preparing alternative travel plans. While U.S. airlines do not automatically provide accommodations during disruptions, UK travelers may be entitled to hotel stays and food under civil aviation laws. Travelers are also encouraged to use frequent flyer miles strategically and consult travel insurance, especially as the holiday season approaches and demand rises.
keyTakeAways: Passengers are entitled to a full refund if a flight is canceled in the U.S. under Department of Transportation (DOT) rules.
Airlines such as Delta and United are waiving change and cancellation fees due to the government shutdown.
Travelers should check flight status early to avoid last-minute surprises and save time and money.
Booking refundable tickets and travel insurance is recommended to protect against disruptions caused by government shutdowns.
If a flight is canceled due to government shutdowns (not airline-controlled), passengers are not automatically entitled to hotel accommodations in the U.S., but may be entitled in the UK.
Frequent flyer miles can be used to book alternate flights, but duplicates on the same airline are automatically canceled and unused miles may be forfeited.
Passengers should act quickly at the airport, speak politely, and prepare alternative options when talking to airline agents.
Travelers may be able to transfer to another airline‚Äôs flight through interline agreements if their original carrier is affected.

articles.content:
Here‚Äôs what to do if your flight is canceled or delayed 
       
  By Forrest Brown, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        11:30 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Delays and cancellations are affecting major airports across the country as the government shutdown ‚Äî the longest in history ‚Äî drags on.
 

   
  Air traffic controller shortages have caused issues at numerous airports since the shutdown began more than a month ago, with ripple effects hitting flights almost everywhere. Now, the government has promised  it will ‚Äúreduce‚Äù air traffic  at all the major airports because of the shutdown, beginning Friday, November 7.
 

   
  Some US airlines, including Delta and United, are waiving fees for customers who want to change or cancel their plans because of Friday‚Äôs looming cuts. Passengers should check with their carriers for the latest on airlines‚Äô plans to mitigate disruptions.
 

   
  Keep in mind that in the United States, when an airline cancels your flight, you are entitled to a refund if you choose not to travel.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf a flight does get canceled, travelers are owed a full refund for the ticket, full stop. If they are presented with a credit, they have the right to refuse and ask for monetary refund,‚Äù said Katy Nastro, a spokesperson for travel site Going.com, who was underlining  Department of Transportation rules .
 

   
  If your upcoming plans involve impacted US airports, ‚Äúlook to make alternative travel plans immediately,‚Äù said Eric Napoli, chief legal officer at  AirHelp , an air passenger rights company.
 

   
  With the busy holiday season approaching alongside looming shutdown-related cancellations, ‚Äúcompetition for seats on open flights will likely be more fierce than normal,‚Äù Napoli said. ‚ÄúTravelers should consider looking at flights that are very early in the morning ‚Äî as these are typically less delayed, too.‚Äù
 

   
  Here‚Äôs more on what experts say you should do if your flight is delayed or canceled.
 

   
    It starts long before you go to the airport
 

   
  As bad as it is to find out your flight has been delayed for a long time, or worse, canceled, it‚Äôs better to find out from the comfort of home or a hotel room.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCheck your flight status before you go the airport. Most of these notifications are not happening at the last minute,‚Äù said Scott Keyes, the founder of¬† Going.com . ‚ÄúSave yourself the drive to the airport.‚Äù
 

   
  In this uncertain travel climate, it‚Äôs important that passengers closely monitor the routes they‚Äôre planning to travel, Napoli said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe recommend booking refundable tickets or purchasing travel insurance in case of any issues that come up,‚Äù he said. Napoli also recommends getting to the airport extra early because security and check-in wait times could be longer than usual.
 

   
  Other tips from Keyes and Going.com:
 

   
    If you‚Äôre at the airport already
 

   
  If you‚Äôre at the airport, act with urgency. Quickly head to the airline agents‚Äô desk. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to make a difference who arrives first. It‚Äôs first-come, first-serve. Positioning yourself close to the desk can pay off,‚Äù Keyes said.
 

   
  You should also call up your carrier while you‚Äôre waiting, Keyes suggested. It might be faster to get through to a call center.
 

   
  Other tactics you can try:
 

   
    Attitude and research matter
 

   
  How you approach things can make a big difference, whether on the phone or in person.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHoney attracts more flies than vinegar,‚Äù Keyes said. ‚ÄúLook at this from the airline agents‚Äô perspective. ‚Ä¶ The agent is the one who has the most ability to help you. Asking nicely and sympathetically is far more likely to get what you want than being a jerk about it.‚Äù
 

   
  And when it‚Äôs your turn to talk to an agent about new arrangements: ‚ÄúCome prepared to offer your own options already. Doing your own research is absolutely helpful.‚Äù
 

   
  Other considerations:
 

   
    Help from other airlines
 

   
  Cooperation between airlines could work in your favor.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhen flights are canceled, many airlines have the option of putting you on another carrier‚Äôs flight because they have interline agreements,‚Äù Lousson Smith, product operations specialist at Going.com, told CNN Travel.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis means, for example, if Delta is having service interruptions but American is running a flight to your destination, you may be able to get on that flight.‚Äù
 

   
    Frequent flyer miles
 

   
  Thanks to changes in frequent flyer programs over the past several years, airlines often still have flights available with miles even when demand is high during a weather event, Julian Kheel, founder and CEO of  Points Path , told CNN Travel.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll need to be prepared to spend a lot of miles, and you may not get the best value for them,‚Äù Kheel said, but the cash savings could be significant.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMost US airlines now allow you to cancel flights booked with frequent flyer miles without any fee or penalty right up until departure time. That means you can book multiple alternate flights on different airlines using your miles in case one of them ends up delayed or canceled.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBut don‚Äôt try to book alternate flights on the same airline, as duplicates can be automatically canceled. And don‚Äôt forget to cancel the remaining flights you don‚Äôt end up using so you can get your miles back.‚Äù
 

   
    Trapped for the night
 

   
  What do you do if you‚Äôre not going to be able to fly out until the next day and you‚Äôre not in your home city?
 

   
  This depends on the specifics of your situation ‚Äî in the US, for example, airlines aren‚Äôt legally required to put you up in a hotel. US-based airlines have their own individual policies for situations ‚Äúwithin the airline‚Äôs control‚Äù that are tracked by the Department of Transportation,  here .
 

   
  According to the DOT, ‚Äúa controllable flight cancellation or delay is essentially a delay or cancellation caused by the airline. Examples include: maintenance or crew problems; cabin cleaning; baggage loading; and fueling.‚Äù So weather events ‚Äî or government shutdowns ‚Äî typically would not fall into this category.
 

   
  But requirements in other countries are different. In the United Kingdom, for example, you‚Äôll likely be automatically entitled to  food and drink vouchers and accommodation . You can read  all the details  at the UK‚Äôs Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)‚Äôs website.
 

   
  Your canceled flight will be  covered by UK law  if it was supposed to be departing from the UK, no matter who you were flying with.
 

   
  And if your flight was supposed to be arriving in the UK, you‚Äôll be covered by UK law as long as you were traveling on an EU or UK airline.  This document  from the UK‚Äôs Civil Aviation Authority explains all the ins and outs of these rules.
 

   
  Despite this, sometimes airlines can‚Äôt help everyone, and as the CAA says, ‚Äúthis can happen when staff are stretched during major disruptions.‚Äù The  CAA advice  is to organize ‚Äúreasonable care and assistance yourself, then claim the cost back later. If you end up paying for things yourself, keep every receipt and do not spend more than is reasonable.‚Äù
 

   
  Other things to consider:
 

   
    Refunds in the US
 

   
  Airlines in the United States are now required to give passengers cash refunds if the airline cancels or significantly delays or changes a flight and the passenger chooses not to travel. See more from the  Department of Transportation here .
 

   
    Travel insurance and receipts
 

   
  Travel insurance can be helpful to ensure reimbursement in a wide variety of circumstances. However, it doesn‚Äôt help in every situation.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMany policies won‚Äôt cover shutdown-related disruptions outright, and because this is now a foreseen event, coverage would only apply if the plan was purchased before Oct. 1,‚Äù said Going.com‚Äôs Nastro, in an emailed statement outlining shutdown-related impacts on air travel.
 

   
  She suggests checking on any protections offered by your credit card before purchasing additional coverage.
 

   
  Be sure to save all of your receipts in case you need to file a claim with your insurer or your airline.
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Marnie Hunter contributed to this report.

Mexico‚Äôs President Sheinbaum takes legal action after groping incident 
       
  By Alessandra Freitas, Uriel Blanco, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        10:57 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Mexico‚Äôs President  Claudia Sheinbaum  is pressing charges against a man who she said was ‚Äúdrunk‚Äù and harassed her on Tuesday, calling the incident ‚Äúan assault on all women.‚Äù
 

   
  The man was arrested overnight, according to Mexico City Mayor Clara Brugada, and is in custody at the Sex Crimes Investigation Unit.
 

   
  The incident took place on Tuesday when a man broke through a crowd of people greeting  Sheinbaum  in Mexico City and appeared to grope her, according to viral footage of the incident.
 

   
  The  video showed  a man approach Sheinbaum. He appeared to touch her breast, and attempt to kiss her while bystanders in the central neighborhood of Z√≥calo watched. The incident ended when one of her top aides, Juan Jos√© Ram√≠rez Mendoza, intervened.
 

   
  The episode has sparked outrage online and renewed a debate over harassment and the safety of women in public life.
 

   
  Mexico City police said preliminary findings link the individual to the alleged harassment of two other women that same day. CNN is attempting to determine if the man has legal representation to receive comment.
 

   
  Sheinbaum, who is Mexico‚Äôs first female president, announced Wednesday that she was motivated to take legal action against the man, who she described as ‚Äúcompletely drunk.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI decided to press charges because this is something I experienced as a woman ‚Äî something all women in our country experience,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúNo man has the right to violate that space,‚Äù she said.
 

   
  She added that this was not the first time she had experienced harassment. Throughout her career, Sheinbaum has been candid about the harassment she experienced in the past. In 2021, as Mexico City mayor,  she shared a video  for International Women‚Äôs Day in which she recalls being harassed on public transportation at the age of 12 and being harassed by a professor when she was a student.
 

   
    Security concerns
 

   
  Tuesday‚Äôs incident has raised questions about Sheinbaum‚Äôs security. It comes just days after the brutal assassination of Uruapan Mayor  Carlos Manzo  during a public event for the Day of the Dead, raising questions about the level of security scrutiny needed for public officials.
 

   
  Sheinbaum, like her predecessor Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador, has chosen not to maintain a Presidential Guard,  which was dissolved in 2018 .
 

   
  Security analyst Ra√∫l Ben√≠tez-Manaut told CNN en Espa√±ol that the decision left a gap in high-level protection: ‚ÄúAfter the dissolution of the Presidential Guard, no specialized protection system was rebuilt. Sheinbaum relies on a small team of aides, not a professional perimeter security unit.‚Äù
 

   
  Sheinbaum defended her approach on Wednesday. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt stay far from the people ‚Äî that would deny who we are. Our aides will continue to accompany us, but we must remain close to citizens,‚Äù she said.
 

   
  The Secretariat for Women, part of Sheinbaum‚Äôs administration, condemned the incident  on Tuesday , saying proximity to the public ‚Äúcannot be used as an excuse to invade someone‚Äôs personal space or make physical contact without consent.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúUnfortunately, no woman is exempt from sexual harassment in our country,‚Äù the ministry said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crucial for men to understand that these acts are not only violent but criminal.‚Äù
 

   
  The office urged victims to report incidents rather than dismiss them.  ‚Äú These forms of violence must not be trivialized; denouncing them is fundamental to justice and cultural change,‚Äù it wrote.
 

   
    ‚ÄòA call to confront misogyny head-on‚Äô
 

   
  The incident involving Mexico‚Äôs head of state underscores a wider problem for women in public life.  The National Electoral Institute (INE) has recorded 516 recorded cases  of violence against women in political positions from September 2020 to July 2025.
 

   
  Mexico City‚Äôs mayor echoed Sheinbaum‚Äôs own campaign message about women‚Äôs representation, saying the event shows why ‚Äúbeing the first woman president is not just symbolic ‚Äî it‚Äôs a call to confront misogyny head-on.‚Äù
 

   
  The occurrence on Tuesday points to a deep-rooted national problem. According to Mexico‚Äôs National Institute of Statistics and Geography‚Äôs (INEGI) 2021 national survey, 70.1% of Mexican women aged 15 and older have experienced at least one form of violence, with 49.1% of those women reporting sexual violence.
 

   
  Sheinbaum said Wednesday she will work with the Secretariat for Women to review whether harassment is criminalized in all Mexican states and launch a national campaign against harassment.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere must be respect for women in every sense,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHarassment is a crime ‚Äî and it‚Äôs time everyone in this country understands that.‚Äù

articles.title: Americans Still Support Democrats‚Äô Shutdown Demands, Despite Prolonged Government Shutdown
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government shutdown has reached its 37th day, the longest in history, and a new poll from KFF shows that 48% of Americans support Democrats continuing to refuse budget approval unless it includes extended Obamacare tax credits, even if it means the government remains shut down. A similar 50% believe the shutdown should end quickly by approving a budget without those credits. This level of support‚Äîconsistently around 47‚Äì52% since the start of the shutdown‚Äîis notably higher than public support for past shutdowns over defunding Obamacare or building a border wall, and it has remained stable despite real-world consequences like travel disruptions and food stamp risks. The lack of public fatigue suggests Democrats are politically insulated and may continue pushing their demands. Republicans are signaling willingness to compromise, and Democrats have not lost ground in recent elections, with former President Donald Trump suggesting the shutdown harmed Republicans. Democratic Senator Chris Murphy emphasizes that it would be 'very strange' for the public to support Democrats' stand and then abandon it without achieving policy goals, reinforcing the idea that public sentiment supports continued negotiation pressure.
keyTakeAways: A new KFF poll shows that 48% of Americans support Democrats continuing to refuse budget approval unless they include extended Obamacare tax credits, even if it means the government remains shut down.
A similar 50% of Americans believe Democrats should approve a budget without the tax credits to end the shutdown quickly, even if it increases health insurance costs.
This level of support is notable because it is significantly higher than public support for prior government shutdowns over defunding Obamacare (2013) or building a border wall (2019).

Support for Democrats‚Äô position has remained stable since the beginning of the shutdown, with 47% in a Washington Post poll on October 1 and 52% in a pre-shutdown poll, indicating public patience has not waned.
Despite real-world impacts such as travel delays and food stamp disruptions, Americans‚Äô support for Democrats holding the line remains largely unchanged.
Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut emphasized that it would be 'very strange' for the public to support Democrats' stance and then abandon it without achieving policy goals.

Republicans are showing signs of softening by suggesting they may support votes on Obamacare tax credits, and Democrats have not lost political ground in the recent election, with Trump suggesting the shutdown harmed Republicans.

articles.content:
The shutdown is dragging on. But Americans aren‚Äôt tiring of Democrats‚Äô demands. 
       
  Analysis by Aaron Blake, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        11:23 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The federal government shutdown  became the longest in history  on Wednesday. It‚Äôs now in its 37th day.
 

   
  And a new poll is the latest sign that it could remain pretty stubborn in the days ahead.
 

   
  That‚Äôs because it doesn‚Äôt seem like Americans are getting particularly tired of Democrats‚Äô gambit. And combined with Democrats‚Äô big wins in Tuesday‚Äôs elections and all of the other polling, there remains seemingly  little political incentive for them to back off  ‚Äì along with plenty of potential downside.
 

   
  The new poll comes  from KFF , a nonpartisan health policy research group.
 

   
  Other surveys have generally tested who gets blamed more for the shutdown ( the GOP, usually by double-digits ) and how much people support Democrats‚Äô policy goal of an extension of the enhanced Obamacare tax credits ( usually more than 70% ).
 

   
  But this one gets at the crux of the matter: Do people think this goal is actually worth continuing the shutdown?
 

   
  It turns out, based on the new poll, lots of Americans do think that: about half, in fact.
 

   
  The poll found that 48% agree with the statement that Democrats should continue to ‚Äúrefuse to approve a budget unless it includes extending these tax credits, even if it means the government remains shut down.‚Äù
 

   
  A similar number ‚Äì 50% ‚Äì chose the alternative: that Democrats should approve a budget without the tax credits ‚Äúin order to quickly end the shutdown, even if it means the cost of health insurance will increase for some people.‚Äù
 

   
  That about half of Americans would support Democrats‚Äô holding the line isn‚Äôt an overwhelming number. But it is remarkable for a couple reasons.
 

   
  One is that this is not at all normal.
 

   
  When Republicans shut down the government over their demands to defund Obamacare in 2013 and build a border wall in 2019, very  few Americans thought those goals merited a shutdown .
 

   
  A New York Times-CBS News poll in 2013 showed only about 1 in 5 Americans said defunding Obamacare was worth risking a shutdown. A  CBS News poll  in 2019 showed only 28% said building the border wall was worth the shutdown, and only 31% said President Donald Trump should ‚Äúrefuse a budget unless it has wall funding, even if that means the shutdown‚ÄØcontinues.‚Äù
 

   
  The other reason it‚Äôs significant is that this number has stayed more or less consistent.
 

   
  It was 47% in a  Washington Post poll  conducted the very first day of the shutdown, October 1. That‚Äôs the percentage that said Democrats should continue demanding the Obamacare tax credits ‚Äúeven if it continues the government shutdown.‚Äù
 

   
  And it was 52% in a pre-shutdown  Strength in Numbers-Verasight poll . Back then, that‚Äôs the percentage that said Democrats should withhold their votes unless ‚ÄúRepublicans agree to restore funding for some government health care programs.‚Äù
 

   
  So more than a month later, despite  all the real-world impacts of the shutdown  ‚Äì including travel delays, food stamps being jeopardized, etc. ‚Äì Americans‚Äô appetite for Democrats holding the line appears ‚Ä¶ largely unchanged.
 

   
  You could imagine a scenario where people might have sympathized with Democrats‚Äô goal but ultimately lost their patience and decided to throw in the towel. That‚Äôs not what has happened.
 

   
  It‚Äôs merely the latest sign that Democrats could be tempted to keep driving a hard bargain.
 

   
  They continue to have the blame game in their favor. Republicans seem to be easing off their hard-line, no-negotiating strategy by floating the prospect they will promise  votes on the Obamacare tax credits. And the shutdown didn‚Äôt appear to harm Democrats on Election Day on Tuesday, at all. Indeed, Trump keeps suggesting the shutdown actually  hurt Republicans .
 

   
  Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut summed it up well in comments to the Associated Press.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt would be very strange for the American people to have weighed in, in support of Democrats standing up and fighting for them,‚Äù Murphy  said , ‚Äúand within days for us to surrender without having achieved any of the things that we‚Äôve been fighting for.‚Äù

articles.title: South Africa to probe recruitment of citizens as mercenaries in Russia-Ukraine conflict
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: South Africa has launched an investigation into the recruitment of 17 of its citizens into mercenary forces in the Russia-Ukraine conflict, after the men sent distress signals from Ukraine‚Äôs Donbas region. They were allegedly lured into joining under the false pretense of lucrative employment contracts. President Cyril Ramaphosa ordered the probe, noting that such involvement may violate South African law. The case reflects a broader regional pattern where several African nations‚Äîincluding Kenya, India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka‚Äîhave reported citizens being exploited under false pretenses. South Africa is navigating a delicate foreign policy balance, maintaining non-alignment in the war while preserving ties with Russia as a BRICS member. This investigation also follows earlier warnings from South Africa about fake job offers on social media and reports from international bodies like the Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime about women being recruited to manufacture drones for Russia's war effort.

The case is part of a broader regional trend where multiple African countries‚Äîsuch as Kenya, India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka‚Äîhave reported citizens being recruited under false pretenses to work or fight in Russia‚Äôs war effort.
The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime reported that women from over 20 African countries were recruited under false pretenses to manufacture drones for Russia‚Äôs war effort.
South Africa previously warned young people about fake job offers in Russia circulating on social media, especially after reports of South African women being tricked into drone production.

articles.content:
South Africa to probe recruitment of citizens as mercenaries in Russia-Ukraine conflict 
       
  Story by Reuters
 

       
Updated: 
        9:40 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: Reuters
 
   
  South Africa‚Äôs government said on Thursday it will investigate how 17 of its citizens joined mercenary forces in the Russia-Ukraine conflict after the men sent distress calls for help to return home.
 

   
  The men were lured into fighting under the pretext of lucrative employment contracts, a statement issued by South Africa‚Äôs presidency said. All are between the ages of 20 and 39 years and are trapped in Ukraine‚Äôs Donbas region, it said, adding that the government was working to bring them home.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPresident Cyril Ramaphosa has ordered an investigation into the circumstances that led to the recruitment of these young men into these seemingly mercenary activities,‚Äù said the statement.
 

   
  The presidency statement did not say which side the men were fighting on, and presidential spokesperson Vincent Magwengya said: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know yet, hence the investigation‚Äù.
 

   
  Most of Ukraine‚Äôs Donbas region, where the 17 were said to be trapped, is under Russian military control, and Moscow has been accused in the past by developing countries of recruiting their citizens to fight on its behalf under false pretenses.
 

   
     South Africa non-aligned over war
 

   
  A spokesperson for Ukraine‚Äôs foreign ministry said it was looking into the reports. Russia‚Äôs embassy in South Africa did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment.
 

   
  South Africa seeks to project itself as non-aligned on the war, while maintaining warm relations with Moscow as a fellow member of the BRICS group of emerging economies. Ramaphosa has met leaders of both countries.
 

   
  Under South African law, it is illegal for citizens to provide military assistance to foreign governments or participate in foreign armies unless authorized by South Africa.
 

   
    Africans caught in the conflict under false pretenses

  ‚ÄúAgents who masquerade as working with the Russian government‚Ä¶ use unscrupulous methods including falsified information to lure innocent Kenyans into the battlefield,‚Äù the country‚Äôs foreign ministry said in a statement on Oct. 27.
 

   
   India, Nepal  and Sri Lanka are among other countries that have said scores of their citizens were recruited under false pretenses to join Russia‚Äôs war effort.
 

   
  In August, South Africa‚Äôs government warned young people to be wary of fake job offers in Russia, which were circulating on social media, after reports that some South African women had been tricked into making drones.
 

   
  The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime said in a May report that women from more than 20 African countries had been recruited under false pretences to make drones for Russia‚Äôs war.

articles.title: Appeals Court Revives Trump‚Äôs Effort to Fight Hush Money Conviction in Light of Supreme Court Immunity Ruling
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal appeals court in New York has revived Donald Trump‚Äôs effort to move his hush money conviction from state to federal court, citing the Supreme Court‚Äôs recent immunity ruling that protects presidential officials from prosecution for official acts. The court sent the case back to district judge Alvin Hellerstein to reassess whether Trump has ‚Äògood cause‚Äô for a second removal motion and whether evidence from former aides like Hope Hicks and Madeleine Westerhout‚Äîpertaining to private conduct‚Äîviolates the immunity doctrine. While Trump argues that the prosecution improperly used private, unofficial acts and that state prosecution violates federal preemption under FECA and the Supremacy Clause, Manhattan DA Alvin Bragg maintains the case is already decided and the evidence does not fall within the immunity scope. The decision gives Trump another avenue to challenge his conviction in federal court, but does not allow him to bypass the district judge or overturn the conviction immediately.
keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court's immunity ruling, which protects officials from criminal prosecution for official acts, is being used by Trump to argue that prosecutors violated the rule by introducing testimony from former White House aides like Hope Hicks and Madeleine Westerhout, who spoke about Trump‚Äôs private conduct.

The New York 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals revived Trump‚Äôs effort to move his hush money conviction to federal court, but did not allow him to bypass the district judge, instead sending the case back for further review of whether he has 'good cause' and meets the threshold for federal jurisdiction.

Trump‚Äôs legal team argues that the state prosecution violates federal campaign finance laws and the Supremacy Clause, asserting that state efforts to regulate campaign finance are preempted under federal law.

District Judge Alvin Hellerstein previously denied both initial and second motions to transfer the case to federal court, citing that the reimbursement of hush money payments were private, unofficial acts.

The appeals court panel, all appointed by Democratic presidents, emphasized that the district judge must reassess whether Trump's actions were official or private, and whether federal intervention is warranted under the immunity doctrine.

Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg maintains that the case is already decided and that the evidence presented‚Äîespecially testimony from aides‚Äîdoes not fall within the scope of the Supreme Court's immunity decision.

articles.content:
Appeals court revives Trump‚Äôs effort to fight hush money conviction in light of Supreme Court immunity ruling 
       
  By Kara Scannell, John Fritze, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        10:56 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A federal appeals court in New York on Thursday said that President Donald Trump should be allowed to make a case for why federal courts should review his  hush money  conviction for possible conflicts with the Supreme Court‚Äôs landmark immunity decision last year.
 

   
  A panel of three judges sent the case back to a district court judge to address certain questions raised by the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision and determine whether Trump meets the threshold to be heard a second time. The district court judge has already twice denied Trump‚Äôs effort to move the hush money case into federal court.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe leave it to the able and experienced District Judge to decide whether to solicit further briefing from the parties or hold a hearing to help it resolve these issues. We express no view and ‚Äòneither rule nor imply‚Äô that the District Court should resolve Trump‚Äôs motion for leave to file a second removal notice in any particular way,‚Äù  the judges wrote in Thursday‚Äôs opinion .
 

   
  The decision gives Trump another chance to try to move the state case into federal court, but it does not give Trump what he ultimately asked for - to bypass the district judge and allow the appeal of his conviction to be heard before the federal appeals court judges.  Trump is simultaneously appealing his conviction on 34 counts of falsifying business records in New York State court.
 

   
  Trump‚Äôs argument turns in part on evidence prosecutors used against him in the case, including testimony from former White House Communications Director  Hope Hicks .
 

   
  The Supreme Court‚Äôs decision granted Trump immunity from criminal prosecution for his official acts and it barred prosecutors from attempting to enter evidence involving official acts, even if they were pursuing alleged crimes involving that president‚Äôs private conduct.
 

   
  Put another way, the underlying question in the case is whether prosecutors crossed the line by including the testimony from Hicks and former executive assistant Madeleine Westerhout ‚Äì two former White House aides ‚Äì in a hush money case that was tied to Trump‚Äôs personal actions.
 

   
  A three-judge panel of the New York-based 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals, all appointed by Democratic presidents, asked probing questions of both sides during arguments in the case in June 11.
 

   
  The judges wrote that district court Judge Alvin Hellerstein did not address ‚Äúsignificant issues‚Äù related to whether Trump had ‚Äúgood cause‚Äù when Trump sought removal a second time. They sent the case back with guidance, suggesting the judge review evidence related to Trump‚Äôs time in the White House, determine whether Trump has a federal defense and whether he asked the court to intervene in a timely matter.
 

   
  Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg has argued that it‚Äôs too late for federal courts to intervene. Trump was already convicted and sentenced, he has said. Prosecutors have also argued that the evidence at issue isn‚Äôt the kind the Supreme Court was referring to. Bragg‚Äôs office declined to comment on Thursday‚Äôs ruling.
 

   
  Hicks may have been a White House official when she testified, they said, but she was speaking about actions Trump took in a private capacity.
 

   
  Federal officials facing prosecution in state courts may often move their cases to federal court under a law designed to ensure states don‚Äôt attempt to prosecute them for  conduct performed ‚Äúunder color‚Äù  of a US office or agency. A federal government worker, for instance, might seek to have a case moved to federal court if they are sued after getting into a car accident while driving on the job.
 

   
  Trump‚Äôs conviction stems from allegations that he falsely accounted for a payment to his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, who paid adult-film star Stormy Daniels to keep her from speaking out about a past alleged affair with Trump weeks before the 2016 presidential election. (Trump has denied the affair.)
 

   
  Trump‚Äôs lawyers also argued the state‚Äôs attempt at ‚Äúseeking to regulate federal campaign finance issues relating to the 2016 election are void under FECA‚Äôs express preemption provision and the Supremacy Clause.‚Äù
 

   
  Judge Hellerstein, nominated to the bench by President Bill Clinton,  denied Trump‚Äôs request to move the case to federal court . Trump openly complained about the New York trial court judge in his case, Juan Merchan, and said he wanted his case heard in an ‚Äúunbiased federal forum.‚Äù
 

   
  Hellerstein previously ruled that removal was not warranted because the reimbursement of the hush money payment were ‚Äúprivate unofficial acts.‚Äù After the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision on presidential immunity, Trump made a second attempt to move the case into federal court. Judge Hellerstein  denied  that motion, writing that ‚Äúnothing‚Äù in the Supreme Court‚Äôs opinion altered his view.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPrivate schemes with private actors, unconnected to any statutory or constitutional authority or function of the executive, are considered unofficial acts,‚Äù the judge wrote.
 

   
  The appeals court said Hellerstein needed to do a further review of the factors.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPresident Trump continues to win in his fight against Radical Democrat Lawfare,‚Äù a spokesman for Trump‚Äôs legal team said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe Supreme Court‚Äôs historic decision on Immunity, the Federal and New York State Constitutions, and other established legal precedent mandate that the Witch Hunt perpetrated by the Manhattan DA be immediately overturned and dismissed.‚Äù

articles.title: Vibe coding named Collins Dictionary‚Äôs Word of the Year
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Collins Dictionary has named 'vibe coding' as its Word of the Year for 2025, a term describing AI-assisted software development where natural language prompts generate code, coined by AI pioneer Andrej Karpathy. This reflects a major shift in how humans interact with technology, making coding more accessible through the integration of AI and human creativity. The selection is based on data from the Collins Corpus, a 24-billion-word database, and signals a broader cultural and linguistic evolution tied to AI and modern work life. Other shortlisted terms include 'clanker', 'broligarchy', 'henry', 'taskmasking', 'micro-retirement', 'biohacking', 'coolcation', 'glaze', and 'aura farming', each reflecting different societal trends related to technology, wealth, work, and personal identity.
keyTakeAways: Vibe coding, a form of AI-assisted software development where natural language prompts generate code, has been named Collins Dictionary's Word of the Year for 2025.

The term was coined by AI pioneer Andrej Karpathy, former director of AI at Tesla and founding engineer at OpenAI, to describe a process where developers can create apps using AI and 'forget that the code even exists'.
Collins Dictionary uses its 24 billion-word Collins Corpus to analyze language trends, including social media, to identify emerging and notable terms.
The selection of 'vibe coding' reflects a major shift in software development, where AI is making coding more accessible and enabling a seamless blend of human creativity and machine intelligence.

Other notable terms on the shortlist include 'clanker' (a derogatory term for AI or robots), 'broligarchy' (a wealthy political clique), 'henry' (acronym for high earner, not rich yet), 'taskmasking' (falsely appearing productive), 'micro-retirement' (short breaks between jobs), 'biohacking' (altering body processes for health), and 'coolcation' (a holiday in a cool climate).
The 2024 Word of the Year was 'brat' and the previous year, AI, highlighting a growing linguistic trend around technology and human interaction with machines.

articles.content:
‚ÄòVibe coding‚Äô named Collins Dictionary‚Äôs Word of the Year 
       
  By Lianne Kolirin, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        11:26 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  ‚Äú Vibe coding ,‚Äù a form of software development that involves turning natural language into computer code by using artificial intelligence (AI), has been named Collins Dictionary‚Äôs  Word of the Year  for 2025.
 

   
  Overall, terms that describe humans‚Äô relationship with technology feature prominently on this year‚Äôs list.
 

   
  Although obviously two words, ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù was chosen by the UK-published dictionary at a time when AI plays an increasing role in our daily lives.
 

   
  As  Collins‚Äô  definition states, ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù is ‚Äúthe use of artificial intelligence prompted by natural language to assist with the writing of computer code.‚Äù Or, as a  blog post  on the dictionary‚Äôs website explains: ‚ÄúBasically, telling a machine what you want rather than painstakingly coding it yourself.‚Äù
 

   
  The term was coined by AI pioneer Andrej Karpathy, former director of AI at Tesla and founding engineer at OpenAI, to describe creating an app with the help of AI while being able to ‚Äúforget that the code even exists.‚Äù
 

   
  Lexicographers at Collins Dictionary monitor the Collins Corpus, a database of 24 billion words that draws from a range of sources including social media. They used this information to compile the annual list of new and notable words.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe selection of ‚Äòvibe coding‚Äô as Collins‚Äô Word of the Year perfectly captures how language is evolving alongside technology,‚Äù Alex Beecroft, managing director of Collins, said in a press release Thursday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt signals a major shift in software development, where AI is making coding more accessible. The seamless integration of human creativity and machine intelligence demonstrates how natural language is fundamentally changing our interaction with computers.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúVibe coding‚Äù was not the only tech-related term to make the shortlist. ‚ÄúClanker‚Äù is another one, though it takes a far less rosy view of AI. That word, in British English, is a derogatory term for a robot, computer or a type of AI, originating from ‚ÄúStar Wars: The Clone Wars.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúBroligarchy,‚Äù which refers to a small clique of very wealthy men with political influence, also saw greater usage, Collins said. The dictionary‚Äôs publisher cited Mark Zuckerberg, Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk and Sundar Pichai, who were high-profile attendees of US President Donald Trump‚Äôs inauguration this year, as examples.
 

   
  Someone not quite as wealthy as these tech bros may be labeled ‚ÄúHenry,‚Äù another of the shortlisted words, which is an acronym for ‚Äúhigh earner, not rich yet.‚Äù
 

   
  Other work-related terms that made it onto the shortlist were ‚Äútaskmasking‚Äù and ‚Äúmicro-retirement.‚Äù The former is defined as ‚Äúthe act of giving a false impression that one is being productive in the workplace,‚Äù while the latter is a ‚Äúbreak taken between periods of employment in order to pursue personal interests.‚Äù
 

   
  Another way to improve your quality of life is through ‚Äúbiohacking,‚Äù which involves ‚Äúaltering the natural processes of one‚Äôs body in an attempt to improve one‚Äôs health and longevity.‚Äù
 

   
  Taking a ‚Äúcoolcation‚Äù is less about showing off on social media and more about the environment, as the dictionary defines it as ‚Äúa holiday in a place with a cool climate‚Äù  ‚Äì  usually taken to get away from soaring temperatures back home.
 

   
  Other terms that have  been widely searched for this year have been ‚Äúglaze,‚Äù which can mean ‚Äúto praise or flatter someone excessively or undeservedly,‚Äù and ‚Äúaura farming,‚Äù which describes a deliberate effort to cultivate ‚Äúa distinctive and charismatic persona.‚Äù
 

   
  The dictionary‚Äôs Word of the Year in 2024 was ‚Äúbrat‚Äù ‚Äì someone ‚Äúcharacterized by a confident, independent, and hedonistic attitude,‚Äù though it can also have another, less positive meaning in British English. And the year before, the accolade went to AI, which Collins said was ‚Äúconsidered to be the next great technological revolution.‚Äù

articles.title: Israel says hostage body returned from Gaza belongs to Tanzanian student as it probes fate of longest-held captive
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Israel has identified the body of Tanzanian student Joshua Loitu Mollel as belonging to a deceased hostage from the October 7 attacks, bringing the total number of returned deceased captives to six. The Israeli military and intelligence community believe the remains of Lt. Hadar Goldin, killed in 2014, may be located in Rafah, southern Gaza, near a tunnel housing Hamas militants, though the IDF denies that Goldin's body is currently being held there. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has acknowledged Hamas pockets in Rafah and Khan Younis and is considering an Egyptian proposal for safe passage to Hamas operatives in exchange for concessions, though no final decision has been made. The brother of Lt. Goldin has publicly stated that no passage should be allowed until the return of Hadar and the remaining hostages, underscoring the moral and political stakes of the situation. The article highlights both the ongoing humanitarian crisis and the geopolitical complexity of negotiations involving international actors and military operations.
keyTakeAways: Israel has identified the body of Joshua Loitu Mollel, a Tanzanian agricultural student, as belonging to a deceased hostage taken during the October 7 attacks.
This brings the total number of deceased captives with bodies returned to Israel to six.
The remains of Lt. Hadar Goldin, killed in 2014 during the Israel-Hamas war, are believed to be located in Rafah, southern Gaza, near a tunnel housing up to 200 Hamas militants.
The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) deny that Goldin‚Äôs body is currently being held in the tunnel with Hamas operatives, contradicting earlier media reports.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu acknowledged the existence of Hamas pockets in Rafah and Khan Younis, stating they are being systematically eliminated.
Israel is considering an Egyptian proposal to grant safe passage to Hamas militants in exchange for concessions, though Netanyahu has not yet made a final decision.
The brother of Lt. Hadar Goldin stated it is forbidden to allow any passage to Hamas until the return of Hadar and the remaining hostages, emphasizing the political and moral stakes of negotiations.

articles.content:
Israel says hostage body returned from Gaza belongs to Tanzanian student as it probes fate of longest-held captive 
       
  By Eugenia Yosef, Tal Shalev, Oren Liebermann, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        10:41 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Israel has identified the body of another deceased hostage from Gaza as it gathers intelligence on the location of the longest-held remains.
 

   
  Hamas transferred the remains of a deceased hostage to Israel via the Red Cross Wednesday night, marking the third such transfer this week.
 

   
  The remains were identified as belonging to Joshua Loitu Mollel, an agricultural student from Tanzania who was abducted from Kibbutz Nahal Oz during the October 7 attacks, according to the the Hostages and Missing Families Forum. This brings the number of deceased captives whose bodies remain in Gaza to six.
 

   
  On Tuesday evening, the body of Itay Chen, the last  Israeli-American citizen  held in Gaza, was returned to Israel. On Sunday, Israel received the  remains of three other hostages , including Israeli-American citizen Omer Neutra.
 

   
  Israel also believes it has new information about the location of the longest-held remains in Gaza, two Israeli sources told CNN. The remains of Lt. Hadar Goldin, who was killed in the final days of the 2014 war between Israel and Hamas, are likely held in Rafah in southern Gaza, the sources said, near an area where up to 200 Hamas militants are hiding in an underground tunnel in territory occupied by Israel.
 

   
  However, contrary to reports in the Israeli media, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said on Sunday that it had ‚Äúno information‚Äù that Goldin‚Äôs body was being held in the tunnel itself with the Hamas operatives.
 

   
  CNN previously reported that Israel was weighing an Egyptian proposal that would grant safe passage to the militants to Hamas-held territory in Gaza, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has not yet made a decision. An Israeli security official said he would decide on the issue at a later stage.
 

   
  Netanyahu acknowledged these isolated Hamas cells publicly for the first time on Sunday when he said, ‚ÄúThere are still Hamas pockets in the areas under our control in Gaza, and we are systematically eliminating them. There are two in Rafah and in Khan Younis, and they will be eliminated.‚Äù
 

   
  Goldin is the only deceased hostage who was taken before October 7, 2023. On Wednesday morning, Goldin‚Äôs brother said on social media, ‚ÄúIt is forbidden to allow the 200 any passage until the return of Hadar and the remaining hostages ‚Ä¶ Any concession would be an abandonment.‚Äù
