articles.content:
Arctic blast to bring the first taste of winter to much of the US. Here‚Äôs how low temperatures will plunge 
       
  By CNN Meteorologist Mary Gilbert
 

       
Updated: 
        10:05 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A big pattern change is on the way for the United States with a blast of Arctic air set to bring a first taste of winter to millions.
 

   
  It all starts this weekend as a cold front allows December-like air from near the North Pole to start spreading into the northern US. This front will push farther south and east through the weekend, and temperatures could drop 10 to 20 degrees below normal almost everywhere east of the Rockies by Monday.
 

   
  These winter-like conditions ‚Äî with the coldest temperatures of the season ‚Äî could make it as far south as the Gulf Coast early next week. Several locations in the Southeast could even flirt with daily record low temperatures.
 

   
  The brief pattern flip will also bring parts of the Midwest their first snowflakes of fall and switch on the  lake-effect snow  machine for the first time this season and bring some measurable snow downwind of the Great Lakes.
 

   
  Here‚Äôs how this chilly change-up will play out.
 

   
    A winter-like weekend for some
 

   
  Parts of the northern Plains and the Upper Midwest will be first in line for plummeting temperatures starting Saturday. This temperature drop could also be accompanied by a wintry mix for some.
 

   
  Minneapolis will likely have a near-normal high temperature in the mid to upper 40s on Friday, but will barely hit the upper 30s by Saturday. There‚Äôs a slight chance of a mix of rain and snow throughout Saturday, but that‚Äôs more likely to fall south of the Twin Cities. Minneapolis usually has its first measurable snow ‚Äî defined as at least 0.1 inches ‚Äî by November 3, but that has not happened yet and it isn‚Äôt likely to Saturday.
 

   
  December-like chill will expand into much more of the country on Sunday.
 

   
  The day will start with low temperatures in the 20s or lower for much of the central US and stay frigid. Temperatures could end up 15 degrees below average for much of the Plains, Midwest and portions of the Ohio and Tennessee valleys.
 

   
  The high temperature in Chicago will likely struggle to reach the upper 30s Sunday, which is about 15 degrees colder than normal. St. Louis will be 15 degrees colder than it should be with a high near 40 degrees.
 

   
    Coldest air since spring to start the week
 

   
  Monday morning will be the coldest since spring for tens of millions of people east of the Rockies. Low temperatures at or below freezing ‚Äì 32 degrees ‚Äì are possible as far south as Texas and as far east as the Appalachians.
 

   
  Buffalo, New York, could drop into the 20s on Monday morning and only reach the mid-30s by the afternoon. A normal early November high for the city is about 50 degrees.
 

   
  Monday will likely be the coldest day of the wintry blast for much of the eastern two-thirds of the US, but the Southeast will be the epicenter for some of the coldest air relative to normal.
 

   
  Nashville, Tennessee, will likely have a high in the mid-40s on Monday, after temperatures drop below freezing early in the morning. That high is almost 20 degrees below normal ‚Äî 63 degrees would be normal on Monday‚Äôs date.
 

   
  Monday will also feature a dramatic temperature drop for Atlanta. Sunday‚Äôs high in the city is expected to be in the mid-60s, but temperatures will struggle to reach the mid-40s on Monday. Temperatures could tumble to the upper 20s by Tuesday morning, which could end up being Atlanta‚Äôs coldest morning since February.
 

   
  Much of the East will remain quite chilly on Tuesday. It‚Äôs likely to be the coldest morning of the stretch for Washington, DC, and New York City. Low temperatures in both cities could be right around the freezing mark, with morning wind chills down in the lower to mid-20s.
 

   
  This cold snap won‚Äôt stick around long though: Temperatures in much of the central US will quickly rebound to near or even above normal on Tuesday and most of the East will follow suit on Wednesday.
 

   
    Snow chances highest in Great Lakes
 

   
  The blast of Arctic air could set up some places to get their first measurable snow event of the year, but exactly where ‚Äì and how much ‚Äì is still coming into focus.
 

   
  The typical snow belts downwind of the Great Lakes are so far the most likely to achieve this feat later this weekend into next week, with lake-effect possible after the cold front swings over the lakes   on Sunday. Some snow could accumulate in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York through Monday night.
 

   
  There‚Äôs also the possibility for snow in other parts of the Midwest this weekend. Chicago, Milwaukee and Rochester, Minnesota, are among the places that could see a mix of rain and snow or get their first proper snowflakes of the season, though little ‚Äì if any ‚Äì accumulation is expected.

FDA warns websites selling unapproved Botox for cosmetic purposes 
       
  Associated Press
 

       
Updated: 
        7:48 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  U.S. health regulators on Wednesday sent warning letters to 18 websites selling  counterfeit or unapproved versions of Botox  and similar injectable drugs commonly used to smooth wrinkles.
 

   
  The  Food and Drug Administration  said it was taking action after receiving reports of injuries in connection with the products, including toxic side effects.
 

   
  Botox is a diluted, purified form of botulinum, one of the most toxic substances in the world. The ingredient works by temporarily blocking nerve signals and causing muscles to relax. While most famously approved for cosmetic use, Botox is also approved in the U.S. for a number of medical conditions, including muscle spasms, eye disorders and migraines.
 

   
  The FDA warning letters mostly went to cosmetic websites. In each case, the FDA said the companies were offering unofficial or mislabeled versions of Botox-like drugs that haven‚Äôt been approved by the agency. In addition to the original drug, introduced by Allergan in 1989, the FDA has approved several competing versions.
 

   
  FDA-approved Botox drugs carry the agency‚Äôs most serious warning, a boxed label alerting doctors and patients that the medications can cause  serious or life-threatening side effects .
 

   
  In rare cases, the toxin can spread beyond the injection site to other parts of the body, paralyzing or weakening muscles needed for breathing and swallowing. Signs of botulism include difficulty swallowing or breathing, slurred speech and muscle weakness. Those symptoms can occur several hours after an injection.
 

   
  In a press release Wednesday, the FDA said patients should only receive the drugs from health professionals who are licensed and trained to administer them. Patients experiencing signs of botulism should ‚Äúseek immediate medical care,‚Äù the agency noted.

articles.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi slams into Vietnam after killing 114 people in the Philippines
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Typhoon Kalmaegi, one of the strongest storms on record to hit Vietnam, made landfall in central Vietnam after killing over 114 people in the Philippines, primarily in Cebu province. The storm caused catastrophic flooding due to slow movement and extreme rainfall‚Äîequivalent to a month‚Äôs worth in 24 hours‚Äîleading to widespread destruction, displacement, and drownings. Scientists attribute the storm‚Äôs intensity to the human-induced climate crisis, with warmer oceans providing more energy for extreme rainfall events. The Philippines, already vulnerable to typhoons, faces additional challenges from poor drainage, inadequate early warning systems, and corruption in flood control projects. Meanwhile, another storm, Fung-Wong (Uwan), is expected to intensify and threaten northern Luzon, and Vietnam continues to face recovery efforts in areas like Gia Lai and Hoi An, both of which were previously devastated by flooding.
keyTakeAways: Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 114 people in the Philippines, primarily in Cebu province, where it caused catastrophic flooding and destroyed homes.
Kalmaegi reached maximum sustained winds of 125 mph and made landfall in central Vietnam, one of the strongest typhoons on record to hit the region.
The storm's slow movement and extreme rainfall‚Äîequivalent to a month's worth in 24 hours‚Äîled to deadly flash floods, especially in areas with poor drainage and rugged terrain.
The Philippines, already vulnerable to typhoons, faced exacerbated damage due to climate change, with warmer oceans fueling more intense rainfall and storm activity.
There is a growing concern over climate-related disaster preparedness, including weak early warning systems and corruption in flood control projects.
Another storm, Fung-Wong (known as Uwan locally), is expected to intensify into a Category 3 or 4 typhoon, threatening northern Luzon and increasing regional flood risks.

At least 350,000 people were evacuated from central Vietnam‚Äôs Gia Lai province due to Kalmaegi's approach, and the region was still recovering from previous flooding affecting Hoi An, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The impact of climate change is highlighted as a key factor in intensifying typhoons, with global ocean temperatures reaching record highs for eight consecutive years.

articles.content:
Typhoon Kalmaegi slams into Vietnam after killing 114 people in the Philippines 
       
  By Helen Regan, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        9:14 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Typhoon Kalmaegi  made landfall  in central Vietnam late Thursday after killing   more than 100 people in the Philippines and cutting a path of destruction.
 

   
  Kalmaegi, one of the strongest typhoons on record to hit Vietnam, was expected to bring heavy rainfall to an area already saturated by heavy rains last week, raising fears of flash floods as well as damaging winds.
 

   
  It left a trail of death and devastation as it tore through the central Philippines this week, reducing entire neighborhoods to rubble and displacing tens of thousands of people. At least 114 people were killed, most in Cebu province, a tourist hotspot, local authorities said.
 

   
  The typhoon strengthened as it barrelled towards the coast of Vietnam Thursday, carrying maximum sustained winds of 125 mph, records from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) showed.
 

   
  Scientists have  long warned  the human-induced climate crisis ‚Äì for which industrialized nations bear greater historical responsibility ‚Äì has only exacerbated the scale and intensity of regional storms that disproportionately impact populations in the Global South.
 

   
  In the Philippines, survivors have begun the mammoth task of salvaging belongings and digging through the thick mud and debris of their destroyed homes, as the receding floodwaters expose widespread devastation.
 

   
  Another tropical storm Fung-Wong ‚Äì or Uwan locally ‚Äì is expected to intensify and could become a dangerous Category 3 or 4 over the weekend, according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, threatening more flooding and damage to the northern portions of the Philippines‚Äô Luzon Island.
 

   
  Here‚Äôs what to know:
 

   
    Homes turned to rubble
 

   
  The scale of the disaster in the hardest-hit Cebu province and surrounding areas took residents and local officials by surprise.
 

   
  Drone footage showed catastrophic flooding that turned streets into rivers, submerged homes and overturned cars as Typhoon Kalmaegi, known locally as Tino, dumped more than a month‚Äôs worth of rain in only 24 hours in some areas.
 

   
  In Talisay city, rows of homes were flattened and communities along the Mananga River were buried in mud and debris. In Cebu city, and rescue workers could be seen wading through waist-deep water to free trapped residents from roofs and submerged homes.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have any home anymore. We weren‚Äôt able to salvage anything from our house,‚Äù Mely Saberon, 52, from Talisay told Reuters news agency. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt expect the surge of rain and wind. We‚Äôve experienced many typhoons, but this one was different. Our homes were gone.‚Äù
 

   
  Another survivor in Cebu city said the floodwaters ‚Äúquickly rushed in‚Äù and they had no time to gather belongings.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been living here for almost 16 years and it was the first time I‚Äôve experienced the flooding,‚Äù said Marlon Enriquez, 58.
 

   
  Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. on Thursday declared a state of national calamity and promised to continued relief and response operations.
 

   
    Why was the storm so destructive and deadly?
 

   
  The Philippines is no stranger to typhoons and Kalmaegi was the 20th named storm to impact the country this year, according to local officials.
 

   
  Though not the strongest storm to hit, it was slow-moving and dumped huge volumes of water over highly populated areas. Officials said most people died from drowning.
 

   
  Nearby Leyte and northern parts of Mindanao, both populous islands in the center of the country, saw between 150 and 250 mm (6 to 10 inches) of rain in only 24 hours ‚Äî well above the typical monthly rainfall for November.
 

   
  On Cebu, the rugged terrain funnelled water straight into communities that lack sufficient drainage.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWind speed is often what the public focuses on and it is in fact how meteorologists categorize these systems, but water is almost always the no. 1 killer,‚Äù said CNN meteorologist Taylor Ward.
 

   
  The impact of the storm was worsened by clogged waterways in an already flood-prone area, and an apparent lack of understanding of early warnings, Bernardo Rafaelito Alejandro IV, deputy administrator for the Philippines Office of Civil Defense told local media.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe need to check how we issue our early warnings and translate it into actions,‚Äù he said
 

   
  Alejandro also called for the building of better and bigger drainage systems and resilient infrastructure that can withstand the threats of more intense storms fueled by climate change.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe need to rethink how we build our megacities and improve on our resiliency,‚Äù he added.
 

   
  The Philippines is one of Asia‚Äôs most flood-prone countries but this year it has also been mired in a massive  corruption scandal  involving flood control projects that have brought thousands of protesters out onto the streets.
 

   
  Dozens of legislators, senators and construction companies have been accused of receiving kickbacks with money that was supposed to go toward establishing thousands of flood control projects.
 

   
    What next for Kalmaegi?
 

   
  Kalmaegi will weaken to a tropical storm as it tracks farther inland from central Vietnam before moving on to northern Cambodia, Laos and eastern Thailand through Friday, local time.
 

   
  Around 350,000 people were expected to be evacuated from central Vietnam‚Äôs Gia Lai province, according to Reuters.
 

   
  The typhoon comes as the region struggles to recover from devastating flooding last week that submerged historical sites including the ancient town of Hoi An.
 

   
  At least 13 people were killed and over 116,000 houses and 5,000 hectares of crops flooded, Reuters reported, citing the government‚Äôs disaster agency. Roads and railways were damaged and power disrupted in several areas.
 

   
  Usually packed with tourists wandering through the lantern-lit streets lined with iconic wooden houses and bustling markets, images showed the UNESCO World Heritage listed Hoi An submerged in water and mud after record rainfall.
 

   
    Climate crisis supercharging typhoons
 

   
  The western Pacific is the most active tropical basin on Earth but global ocean temperatures have been  at record levels  for each of the last eight years.
 

   
  Hotter oceans, fueled by  human-caused global warming , provide ample energy for storms to strengthen.
 

   
  The climate crisis is supercharging rainfall events ‚Äì like those seen in Vietnam and with Typhoon Kalmaegi ‚Äì as warmer air can hold more moisture, which it then wrings out over towns, cities and communities.
 

   
  In September,  Typhoon Ragasa  brought destructive winds and torrential rain to the Philippines, Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China as the strongest storm in the region this year.

articles.title: Ben & Jerry‚Äôs board chair is not fit to serve, parent company says
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Magnum Ice Cream Company, a subsidiary of Unilever, has announced that the chair of Ben & Jerry‚Äôs independent board, Anuradha Mittal, no longer meets the required criteria to serve after external investigations. The move comes amid a long-standing conflict dating back to 2021, when Magnum halted sales in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, and Ben & Jerry‚Äôs responded by labeling the Gaza war as a 'genocide' and advocating for progressive social policies. Ben & Jerry‚Äôs co-founder Ben Cohen has accused Magnum of attempting to dismantle the independent board‚Äôs legal authority and destroy the brand‚Äôs long-term value. The dispute is further complicated by a planned spin-off of Magnum from Unilever, delayed by a month due to a US government shutdown, which will increase the brand's significance within Magnum‚Äôs business. The board structure was established in 2000 with provisions allowing majority board votes and a limited number of Unilever-appointed members, raising questions about governance and autonomy. The situation could lead to legal action, with both parties refusing to disclose further details.

Ben & Jerry‚Äôs has taken a strong stance, accusing Magnum of attempting to strip away the board‚Äôs legal authority and targeting Mittal to eliminate progressive advocacy, which is central to the brand‚Äôs identity.

The conflict is rooted in ideological differences: Ben & Jerry‚Äôs has publicly labeled the Gaza war as a 'genocide' and advocated for political positions, while Magnum has objected to such content and restricted sales in certain regions.

Unilever, which owns both brands, is preparing for a spin-off of Magnum in early December 2025, increasing the stakes as Ben & Jerry‚Äôs will represent a larger share of Magnum‚Äôs business post-spinoff.
Magnum‚Äôs move may threaten the long-term brand value of Ben & Jerry‚Äôs, which is known for its progressive social messaging and activism, and could trigger legal action from the brand‚Äôs board.

articles.content:
Ben & Jerry‚Äôs board chair is not fit to serve, parent company says 
       
  By Reuters
 

       
Updated: 
        7:37 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The Magnum Ice Cream Company has concluded that the chair of its Ben & Jerry‚Äôs independent board ‚Äúno longer meets the criteria‚Äù to serve after internal investigations, according to a securities filing late Tuesday, the latest twist in an internal feud.
 

   
  The spat between Magnum and the Vermont-based Ben & Jerry‚Äôs brand is heating up as consumer goods conglomerate Unilever prepares for the spinoff of the Magnum ice cream division in early December, which has been delayed by a month due to the US government shutdown.
 

   
  Until the spin-off, Ben & Jerry‚Äôs and Magnum are both ultimately owned by Unilever.
 

   
  Magnum said in a filing that after commissioning investigations by external advisers, it found that the current chair ‚Äúno longer meets the criteria to serve as a member of the Ben & Jerry‚Äôs Board.‚Äù
 

   
  Magnum did not give any details on the nature of the investigations.
 

   
  Ben & Jerry‚Äôs website names Anuradha Mittal, the executive director and founder of the Oakland Institute, a think tank, as chair of its independent board focused on advancing the brand‚Äôs progressive social mission. Unilever has previously said the board has evolved into advocacy for controversial and polarizing topics such as the war in Gaza, a change driven by Mittal.
 

   
  Magnum said in the filing that it informed Ben & Jerry‚Äôs board about the investigation and will consider its options depending on the response it receives.
 

   
  It is unclear what action Magnum can take, however, as the board was set up to operate independently when Ben & Jerry‚Äôs was bought by Unilever 25 years ago.
 

   
  According to the merger agreement from 2000, replacing most board members requires a majority vote from the board, which is capped at 11 members. Ben & Jerry‚Äôs parent company has at least two spots on the board, according to the agreement.
 

   
    At odds since 2021
 

   
  Both Magnum and Unilever declined to provide further clarity. Mittal did not respond to a request for comment.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is a deliberate attempt to rewrite history and strip the Ben & Jerry‚Äôs Independent Board of the legal authority it was guaranteed,‚Äù Ben & Jerry‚Äôs co-founder Ben Cohen said in a statement.
 

   
  Unilever and Ben & Jerry‚Äôs have been at odds since at least 2021 when the Chubby Hubby ice cream maker said it would stop selling in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
 

   
  Ben & Jerry‚Äôs has sued Unilever over alleged attempts to silence it and called the Gaza war a ‚Äúgenocide,‚Äù highly unusual for a major US brand.
 

   
  Magnum in the securities filing warned it could face additional lawsuits from the board.
 

   
    Threat to brand‚Äôs long-term value
 

   
  Cohen said Magnum was targeting Mittal and trying to grab power that would ultimately destroy the long-term value of the brand.
 

   
  He warned last month that the conflict with the parent company would likely become more pronounced once the spin-off is complete, because the brand will account for a larger percentage of Magnum‚Äôs business than it does under Unilever.
 

   
  Reuters could not establish whether Magnum, which plans secondary listings in New York and London, would be able to remove the chair.
 

   
  Unilever expects Magnum, which had revenues of 4.5 billion euros ($5.25 billion) in the first half of 2025, to command just over one-fifth of the approximately $88 billion global ice cream market and compete with rivals such as Nestle-backed Froneri. In the securities filing, it says that Ben & Jerry‚Äôs is the second-largest ice cream brand in both the United States and the United Kingdom.

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A German palliative nurse was convicted in 2025 of murdering 10 patients and attempting to murder 27 others using lethal injections of sedatives and painkillers between December 2023 and May 2024 at a clinic near Aachen. articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Layoff announcements in the United States surged in October 2025, reaching the highest level in over 20 years and a 175% increase from the same month in 2024, according to a report by Challenger, Gray & Christmas. This surge is linked to AI-driven automation, softening consumer and corporate spending, and rising costs. Major companies including Amazon and Target have cited AI as a factor in workforce reductions. However, the absence of official government employment data‚Äîdue to a prolonged government shutdown that suspended the Labor Department's jobs report‚Äîhas created significant uncertainty for policymakers. In this context, private sector data from ADP is being used as a substitute, though Fed Chair Jerome Powell stresses that government data remains the 'gold standard' for economic measurement. The lack of reliable data may delay critical monetary policy decisions, such as future interest rate adjustments, and could lead to more cautious economic actions.

Major companies like Amazon and Target have cited AI as a reason for recent layoffs, reflecting a broader technological shift impacting employment.

articles.content:
Layoff announcements surged last month: The worst October in 22 years 
       
  By Bryan Mena, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        7:03 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Company announcements of layoffs in the United States surged in October as AI continued to disrupt the labor market.
 

   
  Announced job cuts last month climbed by more than 153,000, according to a report by Challenger, Gray & Christmas released Thursday, up 175% from the same month a year earlier and the highest October increase since 2003. Layoff announcements surpassed more than a million in first 10 months of this year, an increase of 65% compared to the same period last year.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is the highest total for October in over 20 years, and the highest total for a single month in the fourth quarter since 2008. Like in 2003, a disruptive technology is changing the landscape,‚Äù the report said.
 

   
  The outplacement and executive coaching firm said America‚Äôs labor market continued to normalize after a pandemic-era boom, but also cited ‚ÄúAI adoption, softening consumer and corporate spending, and rising costs‚Äù as key factors putting companies under pressure.
 

   
  Indeed, major companies such as Amazon and Target  have announced major layoffs  in recent months, with several of them citing AI. However, announcements of layoffs don‚Äôt immediately translate to higher unemployment.
 

   
  It‚Äôs also been complicated to assess the labor market‚Äôs health because of the government shutdown, which has now become the longest on record: Official economic statistics have been suspended since the beginning of October, including the Labor Department‚Äôs closely watched employment report, which includes the unemployment rate and monthly payroll growth numbers.
 

   
  The September jobs report, which was scheduled for October 3, hasn‚Äôt been released and there will not be an October jobs report this month; it was originally scheduled for Friday. That has made it difficult for economic policymakers, such as Federal Reserve officials, to make important decisions.
 

   
  Investors and policymakers now look to alternative data, such as Wednesday‚Äôs private-sector  payroll data from ADP , along with the Challenger report, to understand the state of the US economy.
 

   
  But, as Fed Chair Jerome Powell said in a news conference last month, private data cannot replace government figures, which are widely known as the ‚Äúgold standard‚Äù of measuring the world‚Äôs largest economy. And the persistent absence of those figures could derail monetary policymaking and put future rate cuts at risk.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a possibility that it would make sense to be more cautious,‚Äù Powell said.

articles.content:
Car ramming injures 10 people on French island, interior minister says 
       
  By Sana Noor Haq, Joseph Ataman, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        6:44 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A motorist rammed into pedestrians and cyclists on the French island of Ol√©ron on Wednesday, injuring nearly a dozen people just off the Atlantic coast.
 

   
  Within 35 minutes, the driver ran over five people, according to the French Interior Minister Laurent Nu√±ez.
 

   
  Ten passersby were injured, CNN affiliated BFMTV reported. At least two people were seriously wounded, including a 22-year-old woman, the interior minister added.
 

   
  Police swiftly arrived at the scene and apprehended the driver ‚Äúwith difficulty,‚Äù CNN affiliated BFMTV reported on Wednesday, citing the mayor of Saint-Pierre-d‚ÄôOl√©ron, Christophe Sueur.
 

   
  He was taken into custody, BFMTV added.
 

   
  Authorities subsequently opened an investigation, Nu√±ez said. France‚Äôs national anti-terror prosecutor‚Äôs office is also monitoring the case, BFMTV said.
 

   
  Nu√±ez later told journalists at the site of the attack that officials need to search the suspect‚Äôs phone records to determine whether the case will evolve into an anti-terror investigation.
 

   
  ‚ÄúUp until now he‚Äôs not saying much,‚Äù Nu√±ez said on Wednesday.
 

   
  Some of the survivors will be evacuated by helicopter to Poitiers, a city in mainland France, the mayor of Saint-Pierre-d‚ÄôOl√©ron, Christophe Sueur, told BFMTV. There were no children among the injured, he added.
 

   
  After hitting several people, the driver stepped out of his car and tried to set it on fire, BFMTV said. He shouted ‚ÄúAllahu Akbar‚Äù during the attack, local prosecutors said, adding that they could not yet determine a clear motive.
 

   
  The motorist ‚Äì a French, Caucasian national in his 30s ‚Äì is known to local police for common law offenses, including theft and driving under the influence of alcohol, added BFMTV, which also reported that he was not known to French intelligence services.
 

   
  He has family on the island of Ol√©ron ‚Äì where he lived and started his car journey on Wednesday, Sueur said.
 

   
  In the aftermath, his vehicle lay on the roadside ‚Äúwith its front ripped off,‚Äù Sueur recalled.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt all happened very quickly,‚Äù the mayor told reporters. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt associate with him, but he is a person who is known, particularly to the police services,‚Äù he added.

articles.content:
Why the Grammys, and its nominations, might be a bit different this time around 
       
  By Lisa Respers France, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        9:31 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  When the nominations for the 68th Annual Grammy Awards are announced Friday, the spotlight will be on more than just the stars whose names get read aloud.
 

   
  This week‚Äôs nominations will show us if a more diverse voting membership will have a meaningful effect on the awards, beyond looking good in a press release.
 

   
  Five years ago, CEO Deborah Dugan  filed a lawsuit against the Recording Academy . In it, she said she was wrongfully fired after raising allegations of sexual harassment and irregularities with Grammy nominations.
 

   
  Dugan said she was put on administrative leave three weeks after she sent an email to the Recording Academy‚Äôs managing director of human resources outlining numerous bombshell allegations against the organization and its ‚Äúhistorically male dominated leadership,‚Äù according to the EEOC complaint at the time. She was pushed out, she said, after raising concerns about various ‚Äúirregularities and conflicts‚Äù with the academy‚Äôs nomination and review process, and that she discovered numerous conflicts of interest made possible by a ‚Äúboys‚Äô club mentality.‚Äù
 

   
  The Recording Academy, in turn, said in a statement to CNN at the time that Dugan raised her allegations only after legal claims were made against her by another employee who alleged she ‚Äúcreated a ‚Äòtoxic and intolerable‚Äô work environment and engaged in ‚Äòabusive and bullying conduct.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  In any case, Recording Academy chairman and then-interim CEO Harvey Mason Jr. shortly thereafter  announced a series of new initiatives .
 

   
  The biggest change they could make? Growing the awards voting population. Days ago, the Recording Academy announced that ‚Äúmore than 3,800 diverse music creators and professionals‚Äù had joined the Academy as part of its 2025 new member class.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOf those in the accepted class, 50 percent are 39 and under, 58 percent are People of Color, and 35 percent identify as women,‚Äù  a press release  announced. ‚ÄúFor the first time ever, invitations were also extended to all Latin Recording Academy Voting Members, helping to build a more globally representative voting body.‚Äù
 

   
    What to look for in the nominations
 

   
  Music industry insiders and music fans alike will be watching to see how the new class of voters will help shape the nominations. Here‚Äôs where you might see the effects ‚Äî and note that music released between August 31, 2024 and August 30, 2025 is eligible for the awards, so don‚Äôt expect Taylor Swift to dominate.
 

   
  Bad Bunny‚Äôs  selection as the next Super Bowl halftime show headliner  powered lots of cultural conversation that will heat up as that game approaches.
 

   
  Next week, the performer is set to see if his 12 Latin Grammy nominations ‚Äì the most of any artist this year ‚Äì translate into award hardware. A heap of Grammy nominations would be an excellent accessory going into that red carpet. A three-time Grammy winner, Bad Bunny has been nominated for 10 Grammys in the past, including album of the year in 2022 when  ‚ÄúUn Verano Sin Ti‚Äù  became the first Spanish-language album to be nominated in that category.
 

   
  Kendrick Lamar won for record of the year  at last year‚Äôs Grammy Awards  for his Drake diss track ‚ÄúNot Like Us,‚Äù and he could potentially be nominated again, this time with collaborator SZA for their long-charting single ‚ÄúLuther,‚Äù and for album of the year, with ‚ÄúGNX.‚Äù
 

   
  One quirk to look out for: it‚Äôs possible HUNTR/X will become the first Kpop artists to be nominated in the prestigious record of the year category for their ‚ÄúGolden‚Äù from the Netflix megahit ‚ÄúKPop Demon Hunters.‚Äù It would be an oddity for a fictional band to break this new ground.
 

   
  The expectation is that Sabrina Carpenter could bring all the girlie pop power to secure an album of the year nod for ‚ÄúMan‚Äôs Best Friend,‚Äù and that she might be joined by Lady Gaga for her ‚ÄúMayhem.‚Äù
 

   
  Women may also reign supreme in the best new artist category.
 

   
  Performers like Olivia Dean and PinkPantheress have pretty much provided the soundtrack for TikTok this past year, and are being viewed as strong contenders in that category, along with Ravyn Lenae and Megan Moroney. For context,  Chappell Roan  clinched that trophy last year.
 

   
  Nominations arrive at 11 a.m. ET on November 7. Then, the 2026 Grammy Awards will air live on CBS on February 1, 2026. The ceremony will be held at the Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles.

articles.title: Chicago Day Care Teacher Detained by ICE Agents as Parents Were Dropping Off Their Children
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A day care teacher, Diana Patricia Santillana Galeano, was detained by ICE agents inside Rayito de Sol Spanish Immersion Early Learning Center in northwest Chicago during peak drop-off hours, sparking widespread condemnation from local officials and parents. The incident occurred amid 'Operation Midway Blitz,' a DHS enforcement campaign launched in September 2025, and raised serious concerns about the use of federal immigration enforcement in civilian spaces. According to DHS, the arrest followed a vehicle pursuit where Galeano fled into the daycare, claiming she had no knowledge of the driver. However, multiple community members and officials, including Rep. Mike Quigley and Delia Ramirez, criticized the event as a violation of child safety, community trust, and basic human dignity, calling it 'domestic terrorism' and a 'complete lack of humanity.' The teacher, who entered the U.S. in 2023, had a work permit but no legal status, and officials are now investigating the circumstances and procedures that led to the unlawful and traumatic arrest.
keyTakeAways: A day care teacher, Diana Patricia Santillana Galeano, was detained by ICE agents inside a childcare center in northwest Chicago during drop-off hours, sparking outrage from local leaders.
The incident occurred during the busiest time of day when children and parents were present, making the situation deeply traumatic and violating community trust.

The teacher was reportedly arrested in a vestibule, not inside a classroom, after a traffic stop that escalated when a vehicle registered in her name was pursued and she and a passenger fled into the daycare.
DHS claims the woman was a 'female illegal alien from Colombia' who entered the U.S. in 2023 and lied about her identity; however, she claims to have a work permit and was a trusted community member.
Local leaders condemned the incident as a violation of children's welfare, a breach of community trust, and a form of 'domestic terrorism,' citing that teachers were hiding in fear for their safety.
The event is part of a broader federal enforcement strategy under Operation Midway Blitz, which has drawn criticism for aggressive and untargeted actions in civilian spaces.
The daycare, Rayito de Sol, serves children from infancy through pre-kindergarten and has locations in Chicago and Minneapolis, indicating the incident may have wider regional implications.

articles.content:
Chicago day care teacher detained by ICE agents as parents were dropping off their children 
       
  By Whitney Wild, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        6:18 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The arrest by federal agents of a day care teacher inside a child care center in northwest Chicago has drawn strong condemnation from local leaders.
 

   
  Two ICE agents flanked the teacher Wednesday inside Rayito de Sol Spanish Immersion Early Learning Center and then forced her outside through the doors with her arms behind her back.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis morning ICE agents followed a teacher into the facility without a warrant and abducted her in front of her students,‚Äù Rep. Mike Quigley said at a news conference Wednesday afternoon, adding the incident showed a ‚Äúcomplete lack of humanity.‚Äù
 

   
  The day care teacher‚Äôs arrest marks the latest action by federal immigration authorities to  draw condemnation  in the Chicago area, which has seen a series of  aggressive tactics  since the Department of Homeland Security launched ‚ÄúOperation Midway Blitz‚Äù at the beginning of September as part of President Donald Trump‚Äôs nationwide  enforcement agenda .
 

   
  The arrest happened ‚Äúduring the busiest time of drop-off where kids and families have to witness a teacher being forcibly removed and agents kitted up in tactical gear,‚Äù Chris Widen, whose 4-month-old son is taught by the woman, told the  Associated Press .
 

   
  ‚ÄúThese are the nicest, kindest people. They don‚Äôt deserve, these children don‚Äôt deserve to be living through this,‚Äù Esmeralda Rosales, whose child attends the daycare, told the AP.
 

   
  Rayito de Sol, which translates to Little Ray of Sunshine, offers services for infants through pre-kindergarten-aged children, with several locations throughout the Chicago and Minneapolis areas, according to the company‚Äôs website.
 

   
  CNN has reached out to a representative for the teacher.
 

   
  Quigley, a Democrat, said the teacher, identified by DHS, as Diana Patricia Santillana Galeano, was a trusted and beloved member of the community, insisting she has a work permit.
 

   
  A DHS spokesperson disputed the narrative that Galeano was chased inside the day care center.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOfficers attempted to conduct a targeted traffic stop of this female illegal alien from Colombia,‚Äù Tricia   McLaughlin wrote in In a  long post on X .
 

   
  Officers attempted to pull over a vehicle registered to Galeano with sirens and emergency lights, ‚Äúbut the male driver refused to pull the vehicle over,‚Äù the post continued.
 

   
  ‚ÄúLaw enforcement pursued the vehicle before the assailant sped into a shopping plaza where he and the female passenger fled the vehicle. They ran into a daycare and attempted to barricade themselves inside the daycare‚Äîrecklessly endangering the children inside.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe illegal alien female was arrested inside a vestibule, not in the school. Upon arrest, she lied about her identity. The vehicle is registered to in her name, though she claims that she didn‚Äôt know the man who was driving her car and just picked him up from a bus stop,‚Äù McLaughlin added.
 

   
  Galeano entered the US illegally after crossing the southern border in 2023, DHS said in a separate statement, noting having a work authorization ‚Äúdoes NOT confer any type of legal status to be in the US.‚Äù
 

   
  Maria Guzman, a day care representative and parent at Rayito de Sol, called the arrest an act of ‚Äúdomestic terrorism.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is horrific. They have crossed a line,‚Äù Guzman said.
 

   
  Rep. Delia Ramirez said she talked to teachers who were hiding inside the day care center, worried they were going to die.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhat happened today is despicable,‚Äù Ramirez said during the news conference.
 

   
  Ramirez, a Democrat, is a member of the House Committee on Homeland Security and said she will work with her colleagues to launch a federal review of the arrest.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe need to make sure that people understand that these businesses have rights and we are going to do everything we can to help them uphold those rights. Those agents not just rushed in, they went into other rooms,‚Äù Ramirez said.

articles.content:
The unlikely story of how a Russian pool champion became a star of Team USA 
       
  By Jeremy Herb, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:00 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  After struggling to keep up with Europe‚ÄØfor more than a decade, Team USA‚Äôs pool team acquired an unlikely star: Russian world champion Fedor‚ÄØGorst.
 

   
  Gorst, 25, is the No. 1 ranked pool player in the world and has quickly racked up some of the game‚Äôs biggest titles, including two 9-ball world championships and the  US Open .
 

   
  ‚ÄúI knew that I would take heat from a lot of friends back home and my country where I was born,‚Äù Gorst told CNN Sports in an interview at the US Open Pool Championship in Atlantic City, where he was trying to repeat as champion at one of the sport‚Äôs biggest annual events.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBut I also felt it was natural for me to make that decision because I did have a lot of friends in the United States, and everybody was already treating me like one of their own,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Gorst‚Äôs unlikely journey from Russian world champion to a top player on Team USA was set in motion more than three years ago, when he was‚ÄØsuspended from major competitions due to an International Olympic Committee-led ban on Russian athletes following Russia‚Äôs February 2022 invasion of Ukraine.
 

   
  Gorst moved up a planned trip to the US ‚Äì and effectively never left. He moved to southern Indiana with his then-girlfriend, Kristina Tkach, who is the top-ranked female pool-player, where they lived with Gorst‚Äôs manager. He later helped one of his closest friends on the pro circuit, a Ukrainian living in Kyiv, make the move to the US.
 

   
  The next year, Gorst obtained his green card, and pool‚Äôs biggest tournament operator, Matchroom Sport, made the savvy ‚Äî if controversial ‚Äî decision to allow him to begin competing under an American flag at a time when rising tensions between the two nations echoed the Cold War.
 

   
  Though he‚Äôs not yet a citizen, Gorst is poised to be the face of American pool amid one of the biggest pushes in years to get more money and eyeballs on the game‚Äôs stars and to help pool regain a place in mainstream American culture, where it‚Äôs had a long and storied ‚Äî albeit checkered ‚Äî history.
 

   
  Gorst was added to Team USA in 2023 for the Mosconi Cup, an end-of-year event where the US faces off against Europe in a way that‚Äôs similar to golf‚Äôs Ryder Cup. The US has lost 13 of the last 15 competitions, and Gorst gave the five-man US team some world-class firepower to try to close a talent gap.
 

   
  ‚ÄúTechnically, it‚Äôs kind of farcical, but it made sense from the standpoint: This is where he‚Äôs living. This is where he‚Äôs most comfortable. This is where he‚Äôs developed a fan base,‚Äù said Mike Panozzo, the longtime publisher of industry magazine Billiards Digest.
 

   
  The Mosconi Cup, which is organized by Matchroom, is the most anticipated event on the pool calendar, attracting roughly 3,000 fans each year, compared to roughly 500 tickets sold for the US Open finals. The atmosphere for most pool tournaments is similar to a tennis match, where fans are quiet during play and cheer between shots. The Mosconi Cup is the exception ‚Äî it‚Äôs a raucous, party-like scene with a home crowd that taunts the opposing team like it‚Äôs a basketball or football game (or  this year‚Äôs Ryder Cup ).
 

   
  ‚ÄúI get all the people who just roll their eyes and say, ‚ÄòWell, obviously he‚Äôs not American,‚Äô‚Äù Panozzo said of Gorst. ‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs arguing, but it still makes sense. It‚Äôs good for pool, it‚Äôs good for Fedor, it‚Äôs good for the US.‚Äù
 

   
    ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs embraced the publicity‚Äô
 

   
  Away from the table, Gorst comes across as mild-mannered and reserved. But in competition, he brings intensity and competitiveness to his craft often seen in world-class athletes. He moves quickly and purposefully around a pool table, looking intently at the angle of each shot before he leans forward, pauses and delivers the cue with a fluid and powerful follow through.
 

   
  At the US Open in August, 256 players competed for a prize pool of $500,000, with $100,000 for first place. Gorst won his first five matches without much resistance to reach the final 16, raising his arms and curling his biceps in a pose for the cameras after he made the final ball.
 

   
  After his matches, Gorst signed cue balls and other memorabilia and took selfies with fans. While Gorst‚Äôs primary focus is to win championships, he has also built a personal brand that‚Äôs grown to more than 700,000 followers across his social media accounts.
 

   
  A videographer travels with Gorst to tournaments, and he posts clips to YouTube, Facebook, Instagram and Tik-Tok showing off his personality through live practice sessions, snippets from his globe-trotting and streams of matches. The videos offer a window to his supporters that show the professional way he approaches the game and some of his quirky off-the-table habits, like frequent between-match pit stops at Chipotle for a chicken burrito bowl.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHe was the most introverted person ever, super shy,‚Äù said Oscar Dominguez, a veteran American professional pool-player from California. ‚ÄúWithin the last year or so, he kind of broke out of his shell. He‚Äôs becoming more sociable, and he‚Äôs embraced the publicity.‚Äù
 

   
  Gorst has embraced his new American identity as part of his brand and his merchandise. The front of one shirt that he sells says, ‚ÄúStars-Stripes-Strokes,‚Äù with a logo of his nickname, ‚ÄúGhost‚Äù written as a stripe in the American flag on the back.
 

   
  Another shirt displays ‚ÄúFedor Gorst‚Äù stylistically written in the shape of the United States.
 

   
  Gorst has made inroads into mainstream American culture with the help of the biggest podcaster in the United States, Joe Rogan. An avid pool-player, Rogan has interviewed Gorst on his show twice, including this summer.
 

   
  ‚ÄúReally good pool is about as fun as anything. ‚Ä¶ What we need is more people playing,‚Äù Rogan  said to Gorst , jokingly asking aloud how many ‚Äúregular‚Äù people were still tuned in to hear them talk pool. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a game I really wish more people would appreciate.‚Äù
 

   
    A champion at a young age
 

   
  Gorst was born in 2000 in Moscow, where his father owned a table for a different game, Russian pyramid, which has extremely small pockets and is taller than a pool table.
 

   
  While he‚Äôs now a lanky 6-foot-1, as a 7-year-old, Gorst struggled to reach the pyramid table. A coach his father had hired suggested Gorst should play pool instead until he grew to keep from developing bad habits. Gorst said he began playing amateur pool tournaments when he was 10, did well, and never went back to pyramid.
 

   
  At 14, Gorst‚Äôs father died suddenly, a tragedy Gorst said eventually led him toward his desire to take the game more seriously and as a means to support his family.
 

   
  ‚Äú2015 was when I realized I wanted to make a career out of it,‚Äù Gorst said. ‚ÄúI started practicing more, going to school a lot less, and trying to figure out how to dedicate more time toward pool.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúMy mom didn‚Äôt like it at the time,‚Äù he added with a wry smile.
 

   
  When Gorst was a teenager, Russia‚Äôs pool federation hired well-known Dutch coach Johan Ruijsink, who would have a big impact on Gorst‚Äôs trajectory. Gorst was one of several young players on the Russian team, creating a dynamic of internal competition that pushed them all to improve, Riujsink said in an interview.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHe was still young, but he was also kind of different because he wasn‚Äôt really interested in finishing exercises really fast ‚Äî he was more interested in the idea behind it, what he would learn from it,‚Äù Riujsink said. ‚ÄúThe one thing that stood out was his mental stability. He wasn‚Äôt afraid, he wasn‚Äôt hyped, he was always quite cool.‚Äù
 

   
  Gorst continued to climb the ranks in tournaments around the globe, including his first venture to the US for the Derby City Classic in southern Indiana. He won the Junior World 9-Ball Championship at 17 years old. In 2019, still a teenager,  Gorst won  the 9-Ball World Pool Championship in Doha, Qatar.
 

   
  He earned a spot on the five-man European roster for the Mosconi Cup the next year, helping Europe cruise to an 11-3 blowout.
 

   
  His career was quickly on a hall-of-fame trajectory. Then geopolitics turned it upside down.
 

   
    ‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt know anybody here‚Äô
 

   
  Gorst was playing at a tournament in Slovenia in February 2022 two days after Russian troops invaded Ukraine. On the final day of the tournament, the International Olympic Committee recommended banning Russian athletes from competition. While pool is not an Olympic sport, its governing body still has aspirations of getting into the Olympics and  followed through  on the ban.
 

   
  Gorst decided to move up a trip he had already planned to the US. He and Tkach, who were dating, landed in the Washington, DC, area before heading to Memphis, Indiana, a rural town north of Louisville, Kentucky, where they lived with Gorst‚Äôs manager, Jason Sword.
 

   
  The move and the adjustment to small-town living in the US was tough for both of them, Gorst said. While he was banned from major competitions, Gorst traveled around the US playing smaller regional events that didn‚Äôt fall under pool‚Äôs international governing rules.
 

   
  One of Gorst‚Äôs closest friends on the European pro tour going back to their days as juniors was Vitaliy Patsura, a Ukrainian player who was in Kyiv when the war started. After Gorst moved to the US, he helped Patrusa make the trek, too.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHe was trying to support me,‚Äù Patsura said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know nobody here, right? So, Fedor invited me to come here. He introduced me to Jason Sword. That‚Äôs how I started my way in the US.‚Äù
 

   
  Patsura immigrated to the US under the federal government‚Äôs Uniting for Ukraine program, a legal pathway for Ukrainians displaced by the war to temporarily live and work in the US. He settled in Chicago, where there‚Äôs a large Ukrainian population, and is hoping to get a green card so he can remain in the US.
 

   
  Gorst‚Äôs first event back in major competitions was the Matchroom-run US Open in October 2022, in which he competed under a neutral flag.
 

   
  The next year, when Gorst obtained a green card allowing him to remain in the US indefinitely, he began discussions with Matchroom about a more permanent move in the pool world, too.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt was smart for them. It was smart for me,‚Äù he said of the switch to Team USA. (Gorst still competes under a neutral flag in non-Matchroom events.)
 

   
    ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs tough if you‚Äôre not at the top‚Äô
 

   
  Team USA won 10 of the first 12 Mosconi Cups after it began in 1994, after the game saw a surge in popularity from the 1986 Tom Cruise film, ‚ÄúThe Color of Money.‚Äù
 

   
  The US was ‚Äúthe place for pool‚Äù for several decades into the 1990s, Panozzo said. ‚ÄúBut the rest of the world caught up and passed it by professionally.‚Äù
 

   
  In many European countries, government-funded pool federations sponsor their top players, like Olympic training for other sports, even if the notion of pool making the Olympics remains a longshot. But that‚Äôs also the reason that the World Confederation of Billiards Sports enacted the ban on Russian players in 2022.
 

   
  ‚ÄúEurope, on the training side of things, they‚Äôve always been real structured in sports. I think that bled over to pool pretty easily,‚Äù said Jeremy Jones, a US Open champion and former captain of Team USA.
 

   
  There‚Äôs no similar setup for American professionals or promising junior players. The economics of the game make it a challenging career path: Only a handful of players in the US earn enough to make a living solely from pool. Many on the pro circuit supplement their income through lessons, sponsorships and gambling matches, or other businesses like Dominguez, who owns a pool hall in California.
 

   
  Jayson Shaw, a Scottish player and fixture on Europe‚Äôs Mosconi Cup squads, said there are more major tournaments than ever, but the expenses to fly around the world quickly add up for second-and-third tier players.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tough if you‚Äôre not at the top,‚Äù said Shaw, who moved to the US over a decade ago and also owns a pool room in Connecticut.
 

   
    The hunt for more casual sports fans
 

   
  Pool‚Äôs biggest operator, British sports promotion company Matchroom Sport, is making a bet that it can help change the trajectory of pool so more players can make it a career, like it‚Äôs done for its more well-known sports in the UK like snooker and darts.
 

   
  Matchroom has focused much of its attention on growing pool in two markets: the US and Asia. It‚Äôs added events in countries like Vietnam ‚Äî where players like Gorst have found significant followings. Matchroom tripled the prize pool of the 9-Ball World Pool Championship to $1 million thanks to a  10-year partnership  with Saudi Arabia, where the event is now held, in another instance where the Gulf state has looked to sports to shore up its reputation amid a questionable  human rights record .
 

   
  There are still plenty of headwinds. The billiards industry has seen the number of pool halls in the US shrink considerably over the past two decades. At one time, pool was a staple of ESPN weekend programming, but the game has struggled for decades to maintain a consistent professional tour, where past promises of big paydays and interest have repeatedly failed to materialize.
 

   
  Matchroom‚Äôs tournaments are 9-ball, a game where the balls are shot in order and whoever makes the 9-ball wins the rack. For those who have tried a game or two of 8-ball before, it might look unfamiliar, though it‚Äôs simple to learn. But that‚Äôs emblematic of the larger challenge for growing pool in the US, because even many amateurs who play in 8-ball pool leagues might not recognize Gorst or the best American of the last two decades, five-time US Open champion Shane Van Boening.
 

   
  Matchroom has sought to professionalize the production of tournaments. The US Open had four tables streamed online, three under Matchroom‚Äôs paid streaming service and a fourth on YouTube. An emcee revs up the crowd in the arena before the matches begin, and players get an introduction and walkout music. The main TV table includes multiple cameras and commentary for a broadcast aired on TV networks in some countries, including Sky Sports in the United Kingdom.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe just try to do things to get more of a casual sports fan hooked on it,‚Äù said Emily Frazer, CEO of Matchroom Multi Sport, the arm of the company that includes pool. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got personalities screaming to get across to the fans.‚Äù
 

   
  Frazer pointed to a memorable scene when last year‚Äôs USA Mosconi Cup captain, Skyler Woodward, won a doubles match with Gorst and then asked the crowd for two beers,  which the pair downed  while the American fans soaked up the antics and cheered them on.
 

   
  Part of the effort in the US is to shed pool‚Äôs reputation as a game of ‚Äúhustling,‚Äù how it‚Äôs most often depicted in popular culture. That‚Äôs not to say professional pool-players don‚Äôt gamble ‚Äî they often do, for high stakes. But there‚Äôs no trickery in those matches ‚Äî the big ones are pay-per-view promoted events. Gorst and Van Boening, for instance, played lengthy  matches for $100,000  each of the past two years (they split the two contests).
 

   
  Last year, Matchroom created a new event held in the Philippines, the Reyes Cup, named for Filipino pool legend Efren Reyes. The first event pitted Team Asia against Team Europe, but Matchroom changed the format this year so that Asia played against a team ‚ÄúRest of the World.‚Äù
 

   
  That tweak allowed Gorst to be added to the squad. Woodward was also named to the team as a wild card, even though there were European players higher than him in the rankings.
 

   
    ‚ÄòHe feels a lot more pressure‚Äô
 

   
  While Gorst‚Äôs addition to the American Mosconi Cup team improved its talent level, it also meant there‚Äôs one fewer roster spot for the rest of the American players each year, so long as Gorst remains a top player.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhen he first got on the team, I was actually rooming with him in Vietnam, and I told him, ‚ÄòYou owe me dinner for the rest of your career, because you‚Äôre literally taking one of my spots,‚Äô‚Äù Dominguez, who has played on the US Mosconi Cup team three times, said with a laugh.
 

   
  Gorst‚Äôs first Mosconi Cup for Team USA in 2023 didn‚Äôt go well. The US was defeated by Europe 11-3, and the fans in London needled Gorst by chanting ‚Äúnot born in the USA!‚Äù in the tune of the Bruce Springsteen classic.
 

   
  Last year, Gorst easily was the game‚Äôs top player, winning a trio of major events, the World Pool Masters, the 9-Ball World Pool Championship and the US Open, in what was dubbed the ‚ÄúGorst Slam.‚Äù At the Mosconi Cup, however, the US and Gorst were soundly defeated, 11-6.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think he feels a lot more pressure knowing that he‚Äôs already played once for Europe, and now he‚Äôs on the USA team,‚Äù Shaw said.
 

   
  This year, Gorst had the chance to add to his hall-of-fame resume by winning back-to-back titles. At the 9-Ball World Championship in Saudi Arabia, he reached the finals  before losing  to Filipino Carlo Biado, 15-13.
 

   
  At the US Open, Gorst showcased his ability to eke out tight matches, which has been key to his big tournament wins. He fell behind 9-6 in his round-of-16 match and 9-7 in the quarterfinals, in races to 10 racks. Gorst came back in both contests, including a late-night quarterfinal against Michael Baoanan, a player from the Philippines who was backed by a sizable cheering section that created a rowdier atmosphere.
 

   
  Gorst won his semi-final match the next day to reach the finals for the third year in a row. Yet again, Gorst fell behind in a race to 13 racks to Aloysius Yapp of Singapore, trailing 8-3. But he displayed his resilience again, too, with a third comeback to tie the score 10-10 and then 11-11.
 

   
  This time, however, Gorst‚Äôs remarkable string of comebacks ran out as Yapp held him off and won the title, 13-11.
 

   
  Gorst smiled shaking Yapp‚Äôs hand after the match, but the disappointment on his face was clear while Yapp leapt atop the table to celebrate his major championship. Gorst‚Äôs 2nd place finish still came with the consolation of a $50,000 payday.
 

   
  Gorst says he remains highly driven even after reaching the pinnacle of his sport. While the legacy he‚Äôs creating expanding his trophy collection is important, Gorst said that his motivation can also be explained in an even simpler way.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI do have big goals when it comes to my career in pool,‚Äù Gorst said. ‚ÄúFor me, it was easy, I‚Äôll be honest, financial motivation was always the biggest motivator for me.‚Äù

articles.title: The GOP Starts to Confront What Trump‚Äôs Power Grabs Will Mean When Democrats Are in Charge
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article examines how the Republican Party is increasingly confronting the long-term implications of President Donald Trump‚Äôs expansion of presidential power ‚Äî including tariff policies, the use of the National Guard, and attempts to eliminate the filibuster ‚Äî and how these actions could be exploited by future Democratic administrations. Key figures like Senate leaders, governors, and Supreme Court justices are now questioning the legality and consequences of such power grabs. While no direct evidence exists of future Democratic actions, Republican leaders express serious concerns that removing checks like the filibuster or allowing unchecked executive declarations (such as climate emergency tariffs) could enable radical or authoritarian policies under a Democratic president. The article highlights a growing internal GOP reckoning: if Democrats take power, they may use the same tools Trump employed, making the current power dynamics a dangerous precedent.
keyTakeAways: The Republican Party is beginning to confront the implications of President Donald Trump‚Äôs expansive use of presidential power, especially regarding tariffs, the filibuster, and National Guard deployments.
Republican leaders are now seriously considering how such actions could be reversed or exploited if Democrats take control in the future, indicating a shift in internal political discourse.

The Supreme Court, including Trump-nominated Justice Neil Gorsuch and Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, has challenged the Trump administration's claim that a president can impose tariffs based solely on a climate emergency declaration, exposing the legal and constitutional risks of such power.

Republican senators and leaders like Mike Johnson, Markwayne Mullin, Dave McCormick, and Ted Cruz have expressed fears that eliminating the filibuster would enable extreme or radical Democratic policies, including expanding gun regulation and using federal power to silence political opponents.

Republican leaders such as Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt and Washington state Republican Party Chairman Jim Walsh are concerned about the precedent set by Trump‚Äôs use of the National Guard across states, fearing future Democratic use against conservative states.
Former President Barack Obama has noted the absurdity of such actions, suggesting that the right would have reacted strongly if he had deployed the National Guard into a red state like Texas.

Trump has argued that eliminating the filibuster would ensure Democrats never regain power, but this argument is being challenged by GOP members who believe in the balance of power and constitutional checks.

The article emphasizes that while there is no direct evidence of future Democratic actions, the hypotheticals are being taken seriously by Republicans due to the precedent established by Trump‚Äôs actions.

articles.content:
The GOP starts to confront what Trump‚Äôs power grabs will mean when Democrats are in charge 
       
  Analysis by Aaron Blake, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        8:52 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  For nine months, congressional Republicans have largely stood idly by as President Donald Trump has gone to great lengths to try to  expand the power of the presidency, demolish norms and disregard laws .
 

   
  But increasingly, the implications of those power grabs are starting to come into focus ‚Äì and specifically, what they might mean when the shoe is on the other foot the next time Democrats are in charge.
 

   
  And Republicans seem to be starting to reckon with that.
 

   
  Perhaps most striking was a scene Wednesday at the Supreme Court, during oral arguments in  a challenge to Trump‚Äôs worldwide tariffs .
 

   
  The day prior, a CNBC host had asked Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent whether he worried about a Democratic president abusing the power Trump was claiming. Host Joe Kernen posited that this future president could levy large tariffs on energy based solely on a declaration that there was a climate change emergency. Bessent demurred, saying, ‚ÄúI would question whether there‚Äôs a climate emergency.‚Äù
 

   
  But that‚Äôs not really the point. The point is that the Trump administration has more or less argued that it  wouldn‚Äôt matter  if there was actually a climate emergency; it says all that really matters is that a president  would say there‚Äôs one , and that the courts lack the authority to question that.
 

   
  While Bessent was able to squirm out of this hypothetical on Tuesday, the Trump administration wasn‚Äôt so fortunate at the Supreme Court on Wednesday.
 

   
  In fact, three justices ‚Äì including Trump-nominated Neil Gorsuch ‚Äì pressed the Trump administration‚Äôs solicitor general, D. John Sauer, on this exact hypothetical.
 

   
  Gorsuch asked whether a president could impose a 50% tariff on gas-powered cars and auto parts by simply claiming a climate emergency.
 

   
  Sauer, like Bessent, cast doubt on whether that declaration would be accurate. But he otherwise acknowledged: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very likely that could be done. Very likely.‚Äù
 

   
  When Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson asked whether anyone would be able to challenge that declaration, Sauer suggested the bar would be sky-high.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThat would be a situation where at least there‚Äôd be a very, very, very deferential judicial review of that kind of determination,‚Äù Sauer said. He again emphasized the courts‚Äô review should be ‚Äúvery, very deferential and easily satisfied.‚Äù
 

   
  The exchanges laid bare the potential cost of tariff-skeptical Republicans‚Äô acquiescence to Trump.
 

   
  Trump is attempting to set a precedent that his own administration says could be wielded by a liberal president in huge ways that Republicans would very much not like.
 

   
  (Of course, Congress could simply assert its power over tariffs and prevent all that. But that would require actually standing up to Trump.)
 

   
  Another example in recent days is the burgeoning GOP debate over getting rid of the filibuster.
 

   
  Trump seems to have settled on the so-called ‚Äúnuclear option‚Äù as his recipe for ending the  now-record-breaking federal government shutdown . He wants Republican senators to make it so that legislation only requires a bare majority (which Republicans currently have) rather than the currently required 60 votes.
 

   
  Trump has long desired this, of course. But the current debate has apparently given him a good opportunity to break down one of his most significant remaining obstacles.
 

   
  But it‚Äôs also led to some rather unusual and pretty firm pushback among Republicans. Their argument: This would be a disaster when Democrats have power.
 

   
  House Speaker Mike Johnson has repeatedly predicted Democrats would add Democratic senators by making Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia into states. He‚Äôs said they would pack the Supreme Court to overturn the current conservative advantage. And he‚Äôs said they would restrict gun rights, among other liberal grab-bag policies.
 

   
  ‚Äú(The filibuster) holds us back from the Democrats‚Äô worst impulses,‚Äù Johnson said this week.
 

   
  Sens. Roger Marshall of Kansas, Markwayne Mullin of Oklahoma and Dave McCormick of Pennsylvania have made similar points.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAnd listen: Just imagine a world where there‚Äôs no filibuster and you have the crazy radical part of the Democratic Party in charge,‚Äù McCormick told Fox News over the weekend. ‚ÄúWe would become a country of socialism.‚Äù
 

   
  Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas offered similar warnings after Trump‚Äôs Federal Communications Commission chairman, Brendan Carr, pressured ABC to suspend Jimmy Kimmel over a joke about Trump and Charlie Kirk. Cruz compared it to mob tactics and called it ‚Äú dangerous as hell .‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúGoing down this road, there will come a time when a Democrat wins again ‚Äì wins the White House ‚Ä¶ they will silence us,‚Äù Cruz said. ‚ÄúThey will use this power, and they will use it ruthlessly.‚Äù
 

   
  We even saw a smattering of these kinds of objections to Trump‚Äôs extraordinary deployments of the National Guard around the country.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI worry about someday a Democrat president sending troops or National Guard from New York, California, Oregon, Washington state to North Carolina,‚Äù North Carolina Sen. Thom Tillis  told The Hill  last month.
 

   
  Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt in comments to  the New York Times  warned his fellow Republicans about the precedent set by a president working with governors of other states to impose National Guard troops on a state where officials didn‚Äôt want that.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe believe in the federalist system ‚Äî that‚Äôs states‚Äô rights,‚Äù Stitt said, adding: ‚ÄúOklahomans would lose their mind if (Gov. JB) Pritzker in Illinois sent troops down to Oklahoma during the Biden administration.‚Äù
 

   
  Washington state Republican Party Chairman Jim Walsh has also  reportedly raised concerns  about future presidents overusing the National Guard.
 

   
  And Vice President JD Vance last week was pressed on such a hypothetical during a Turning Point USA event. A student told him the Guard deployments were ‚Äúkind of disturbing me a little bit,‚Äù because of how Democrats might use such a precedent against conservatives.
 

   
  Vance urged the student not to worry about such things.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an important part of my entire political philosophy ‚Äì is we cannot be afraid to do something, because the left might do it in the future,‚Äù Vance said. ‚ÄúThe left is already going to do it, regardless of whether we do it.‚Äù
 

   
  Of course, there is no actual evidence Democrats have prepared to do such things with the National Guard.
 

   
  Indeed, former President Barack Obama recently wondered aloud what the right would say if he imposed the National Guard on a red state like Texas. ‚Äú It is mind-boggling to me how Fox News would have responded ,‚Äù Obama said.
 

   
  And this is also an area in which the administration has basically claimed unchecked presidential power when pressed by judges.
 

   
  During an appeals-court hearing back in June, a Trump-appointed judge asked top DOJ official Brett Shumate if it was the Trump administration‚Äôs position that a president‚Äôs decision to call up militias from all 50 states and the District of Columbia was un-reviewable by the courts. Shumate  said that it was .
 

   
  In other words, Obama, under this line of thinking, would indeed have been able to send the Guard into Texas, no questions asked.
 

   
  These kinds of hypotheticals haven‚Äôt caused Republicans to truly move to check Trump‚Äôs power, at least not yet. But if anything, the elections this week, in which  Democrats won pretty resoundingly , should remind them that the shoe could be on the other foot relatively soon.
 

   
  Of course, Trump has an answer for that, too. Maybe if he just gets all the power, he‚Äôll make it so Democrats never actually win power again.
 

   
  ‚ÄúNow, if we do what I‚Äôm saying (on the filibuster), they‚Äôll most likely never attain power,‚Äù Trump told GOP senators on Wednesday. ‚ÄúBecause we will have passed every single thing that you can imagine.‚Äù
 

   
  It seems unlikely GOP senators will actually buy into that.

This crisis reveals how political gridlock directly undermines essential social welfare systems, turning access to food into a political issue rather than a basic human right.

articles.content:
‚ÄòHow can food be political?‚Äô Families in state that pioneered SNAP speak of hardship 
       
  By Ren√© Marsh, Dianne Gallagher, Michael Williams, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        6:00 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Onita Norris is constantly running the numbers to try to solve a problem with no good answer: Figuring out much her two children, both under five, will have to eat, and how much she will have to go without.
 

   
  The West Virginia single mother earns about $2,800 a month working 40 hours weekly for the state. About half of that goes toward rent. The rest is for daycare and her electric, water and phone bills, leaving her only about $100 from her paycheck for other expenses, including groceries.
 

   
  Aid from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP, usually adds $265 to her monthly budget for food. But with benefits disrupted  as the government lurches into what is now its longest shutdown on record, Norris now must find other ways to feed her family.
 

   
  ‚ÄúRather than myself having, like, a full plate of food along with my kids, I‚Äôm making sure that they have a full plate of food,‚Äù Norris said. ‚ÄúI may have either less, or I may not eat.‚Äù
 

   
  Tears come to her face as she worries she‚Äôs failing her children. ‚ÄúIt feels like I‚Äôm failing them because I am trying, I‚Äôm trying to do all that I can, and, of course, as a human you get frustrated,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúand I never want my kids to see that, or feel like I‚Äôm taking that out on them, for something as simple as dinner.‚Äù
 

   
  More than 40 million Americans rely on SNAP benefits, also known as food stamps, to pay for food. They are caught in the middle of a protracted budget  standoff between Republicans and Democrats in Congress who have, for more than a month,  been unable to come up with an agreement that would fund the government.
 

   
  The difficult circumstances SNAP recipients are facing have become one of the most pressing issues for lawmakers, who are under pressure to work harder toward an agreement to get the benefits fully funded again.
 

   
  In West Virginia, the state that was the first testing ground in 1961 for what is now SNAP, some 15% of its 1.7 million   residents rely on the benefits today.
 

   
  Food banks in the state are struggling to meet demand. They were already dealing with budget cuts caused by federal belt tightening    toward the beginning of the year. Now, things are even more stretched as furloughed federal workers become new clients.
 

   
  One charity in Martinsburg, CCAP/Loaves & Fishes, saw the number of households it serves roughly double from 72 households per week to 159 in the third week of October, and 119 in the fourth.
 

   
  Even though it is better positioned than other pantries thanks to the generosity of the community and local churches, there are worries about how long it can continue to keep serving at such a rate.
 

   
  ‚ÄúUntil the SNAP benefits are replenished, the federal workers go back to work, we‚Äôre going to be just slammed like this all day,‚Äù its president, Leigh Fleming, told CNN.
 

   
    ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a struggle out here‚Äô
 

   
  Following a court order, the Trump administration earlier this week said it would  partially fund SNAP for November.  But the funds won‚Äôt cover full benefits, and November payments for millions of Americans who rely on them have been delayed.
 

   
  Trump then appeared to threaten to withhold SNAP funding on Tuesday until Democrats voted to reopen the government. The White House later clarified the administration would follow through on its plan to fund partial food aid during the shutdown.
 

   
  In West Virginia, the federal government‚Äôs responses have brought confusion and dismay.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt feel as though the folks at Washington quite understand the gravity of the situation,‚Äù said Norris. ‚ÄúI just‚ÄØdon‚Äôt‚ÄØunderstand how‚ÄØwe‚Äôve‚ÄØcome to a point where‚ÄØwe‚Äôre‚ÄØusing food in‚ÄØpolitics and being‚ÄØessentially political‚ÄØpawns.‚Äù
 

   
  Laura Bowles, a West Virginia mother of five children aged four to 13 ‚Äî with a sixth on the way ‚Äî said she had to explain to her older kids that ‚Äúthere are some right now in the government who can‚Äôt figure things out, and we can‚Äôt have everything we used to have right now.‚Äù
 

   
  For her family, it means having to buy less food. ‚ÄúMy kids eat a lot,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd groceries are already so expensive these days ‚Äî it was already hard,‚Äù Bowles said. Like Norris, she is cutting back her own food intake to make her kids‚Äô meals stretch further.
 

   
  Her husband‚Äôs paycheck from Walmart, where he works full time and makes $14 an hour, usually covers all their household bills.
 

   
  But this month, without SNAP, it‚Äôs mostly going to groceries. That means the family has had to pick what other bills to pay.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI let my trash and internet bill slide already,‚Äù said Bowles. Only half the electricity and car insurance could be covered, she added, and the family are even cutting back on driving to the park to save money on gas.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a struggle out here. I am pregnant again, and that wasn‚Äôt part of the plan ‚Äì but it was God‚Äôs plan,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI guess people struggle everywhere, but it‚Äôs hard here in West Virginia. It just feels extra hard here.‚Äù

articles.title: Mayor-elect Mamdani: New York businesses share their hopes and worries
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In the aftermath of Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs victory in the 2025 New York City mayoral election, small business owners from diverse immigrant and minority backgrounds have expressed hope that his affordability-centered policies‚Äîsuch as cutting business fines and fees, speeding up permits, and creating a 'Mom & Pops Czar'‚Äîwill ease their struggles with rising costs, red tape, and limited support. While some business leaders, like Mark Jaffe of the Greater New York Chamber of Commerce, express concern about potential city-run grocery stores threatening bodega revenues, owners such as Kadjahtou Balde, Aliyyah Baylor, and Serine Aklouche emphasize that Mamdani‚Äôs vision aligns with their lived experiences of financial hardship, cultural belonging, and the need for equitable economic opportunity. The article underscores how Mamdani‚Äôs rise reflects a shift toward inclusive, community-driven governance in one of the world‚Äôs most expensive and diverse cities.
keyTakeAways: Mamdani‚Äôs victory in the 2025 mayoral race has sparked hope among small business owners, especially those from immigrant and minority backgrounds, who previously faced high costs, red tape, and limited support.
Mamdani‚Äôs campaign emphasized affordability, reducing regulations, and increasing support for small businesses, including proposing a 'Mom & Pops Czar' and cutting fines and fees in half.

Business owners like Kadjahtou Balde, Aliyyah Baylor, and Serine Aklouche highlight how Mamdani‚Äôs policies address their struggles with high rent, access to information, and affordability of essential goods like medication and utilities.

Despite concerns from business leaders like Mark Jaffe over potential city-run grocery stores threatening bodega revenue, many small business owners see Mamdani as a progressive, inclusive alternative to past mayoral leadership.

The article underscores the cultural and historical significance of small businesses in Harlem, Queens, and other neighborhoods, where immigrant and minority communities have long contributed to the city's economic and social fabric.
