articles.content:
Mayor-elect Mamdani: New York businesses share their hopes and worries 
       
  By Ramishah Maruf, Gordon Ebanks, John Towfighi, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:30 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  New York‚Äôs wealthiest had  warned of a business exodus  if Zohran Mamdani won Tuesday‚Äôs mayoral race. But for small business owners like Kadjahtou Balde, Mamdani‚Äôs victory is a reason to stay in one of the country‚Äôs most expensive cities.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAs somebody who is a young person, who is a mom, who is an entrepreneur, who‚Äôs a (child of an) immigrant, existing in New York is something that is very difficult,‚Äù said Balde, who runs a modest thrift store in Harlem. ‚ÄúMamdani is now another reason for me to actually believe that I can make it in the city.‚Äù
 

   
  Mamdani‚Äôs meteoric ascent from local politics to City Hall was boosted by a base that often works behind the scenes in the ever-fast-paced, high-cost city.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI speak of Yemeni bodega owners and Mexican abuelas. Senegalese taxi drivers and Uzbek nurses. Trinidadian line cooks and Ethiopian aunties,‚Äù Mamdani said in his victory speech on Tuesday night.
 

   
  Among his  small business proposals : cutting fines and fees for small businesses in half, speeding up permits, appointing a ‚ÄúMom & Pops Czar‚Äù and increasing funding for a program for 1:1 support.
 

   
  But some business leaders are worried about the lofty ambitions of the 34-year-old self-described democratic socialist. For example, Mark Jaffe, who leads the Greater New York Chamber of Commerce, worries Mamdani‚Äôs proposals for  city-run grocery stores  would cut into business at bodegas.
 

   
  Here‚Äôs what some local small   business leaders told CNN about Mamdani‚Äôs election win.
 

   
    Aliyyah Baylor, co-founder of Make My Cake and I Like it Black Coffee Shop
 

   
  Aliyyah Baylor, the co-founder of Harlem bakery Make My Cake, was ‚Äúcelebratory‚Äù on Wednesday.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI love my city,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna be excited now.‚Äù
 

   
  Baylor‚Äôs grandparents came to Harlem from the South as part of the Great Migration, a period when millions of Black families moved to the north and west hoping to find more opportunities and escape violence and disenfranchisement in the South.
 

   
  But even after coming north, her grandparents encountered racial discrimination and struggled to find jobs. ‚ÄúSo being able to be self-sufficient was really important, and I think it was just a necessity.‚Äù That in turn helped inspire her entrepreneurial spirit.
 

   
  She hopes the new mayor will expand on programs started by Michael Bloomberg, who led the city from 2002 to 2013, that supported workforce development.
 

   
  For Baylor, policies that make it easier to advocate for her 30-year-old family business ‚Äî and even the playing field between small business and large corporations ‚Äî are important.
 

   
  Mamdani‚Äôs affordability-centered campaign made an issue of the city‚Äôs thousands of regulations that, he argues, have   unnecessarily hobbled small businesses. He‚Äôs proposed speeding up permitting and cutting back on some red tape.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI hope he also gets more people in positions to be able to help expedite opening up store fronts,‚Äù Baylor said, noting her difficulties getting inspectors when opening Make My Cake.    
 

   
    Serine Aklouche, pharmacy technician at Steinway Street Pharmacy
 

   
  Serine Aklouche, a 33-year-old pharmacy technician in Queens, commended Mamdani‚Äôs focus on lowering prices: ‚ÄúWhen he speaks about the prices and everything, that‚Äôs really, really, really important.‚Äù
 

   
  Aklouche has noticed customers   struggling more and more to pay for medications.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not talking about clothing ‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre talking about medication and food,‚Äù Aklouche said.
 

   
  Mamdani was the assemblyman for the 36th district in Queens, where optimistic business owners digested his victory on Wednesday. The mayor-elect even gave a shoutout to Steinway Street in his Tuesday victory speech.
 

   
  Steinway Street is the home of New York‚Äôs Little Egypt and also hosts a hodgepodge of cultures.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to know that he supports all of these businesses, whether we‚Äôre Arab, whether Hispanic, any type,‚Äù said Aklouche, whose office sits on Steinway.
 

   
    Kadjahtou Balde, Modify Thrift
 

   
  Balde supports not only Mamdani‚Äôs plan for a small business czar but also other policies she says will improve how she runs her shop. She also noted the promised lower utility costs will help offset high rent.
 

   
  Balde‚Äôs storefront originally belonged to her father, an immigrant from Guinea who ran an essential goods store. Her father used to work 10-hour shifts, seven days a week, and she watched him struggle to keep up with store expenses under three previous mayoral administrations.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe language is a barrier, number one. But then having access to information around how to grow your business, how to scale your business, none of those things were available,‚Äù Balde said.
 

   
  She expects that to change with Mamdani. Already, she has opened the first city‚Äôs Muslim-friendly thrift store at her dad‚Äôs store location, two months post-partum (Mamdani‚Äôs proposed universal childcare is a huge plus for the full-time store owner).
 

   
  Balde said many of her friends have moved out of the city due to the high cost of living, but she intends to stay.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm somebody who recognizes the legacy that my dad has built,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd so it has taken everything in me to want to continue being here.‚Äù

articles.title: Tariff Refunds Are Now a Very Real Possibility ‚Äî and a Giant ‚ÄòMess‚Äô
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Following deep skepticism from multiple justices on the Supreme Court about the constitutionality of Trump administration tariffs, the possibility of large-scale tariff refunds for businesses has emerged. As of September 23, 2025, the federal government has collected nearly $90 billion in tariff revenue, which may be returned if the Supreme Court rules against the administration. While five small- and medium-sized businesses represented by Neal Katyal are clearly entitled to refunds, others may need to file separate appeals, making the process complex and potentially a 'mess.' Importers are advised to act now by filing protests or requesting liquidation extensions to increase refund eligibility. Financial firms like Oppenheimer and Jefferies are actively selling businesses a stake in future refunds at 20% to 30% of the total amount, allowing immediate cash flow and avoiding public legal filings. However, such deals come with risks‚Äîmany businesses have already accepted low offers (5%‚Äì7%) under pressure, and after the Supreme Court‚Äôs oral arguments, some are now experiencing regret or cautious optimism. A precedent from a 1998 harbor maintenance fee case shows that refunds can take years to process, suggesting that a large-scale refund effort would be slow and logistically challenging. Overall, the situation reflects a major intersection of law, finance, and trade policy, with significant implications for both businesses and financial markets.
keyTakeAways: The Trump administration's tariffs are under legal challenge, with the Supreme Court showing deep skepticism, raising the possibility of refunds for businesses that paid under the challenged tariffs.

Approximately $90 billion in tariff revenue has been collected by the federal government as of September 23, 2025, and this amount could be returned if the Supreme Court rules against the administration.

Only five businesses represented by Neal Katyal are clearly entitled to refunds, while others may need to file separate appeals with lower courts, making a broad refund process 'a very complicated thing' or even 'a mess'.
Importers must assess their import entries and liquidation timelines; CBP may require updated payment details via forms, and statutory interest could apply to any refunds.

Investment banks such as Oppenheimer and Jefferies have offered to sell businesses a stake in potential tariff refunds at 20% to 30% of the total amount, enabling immediate cash flow without public legal filings.

Businesses are being aggressively approached by financial firms, especially those that are credit-stretched or vulnerable to new tariffs, often accepting low offers of 5% to 7% to secure immediate funds.
After the Supreme Court's oral arguments on November 6, 2025, some businesses are experiencing seller‚Äôs remorse or cautious optimism about the refund outcome.

A precedent exists from a 1998 Supreme Court decision on harbor maintenance fees, where $730 million in refunds took two years to process‚Äîhighlighting the potential logistical and financial complexity of a large-scale refund program.

articles.content:
Tariff refunds are now a very real possibility ‚Ä¶ and a giant ‚Äòmess‚Äô 
       
  By Elisabeth Buchwald, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        6:30 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The chances of businesses getting tariff refunds grew significantly on Wednesday after the Trump administration‚Äôs case to keep most of his levies in place was  met with deep skepticism  from multiple conservative and liberal justices on the Supreme Court.
 

   
  The big question now: How would potential tariff refunds work?
 

   
  The federal government has collected nearly $90 billion in revenue from the tariffs being challenged, according to US Customs and Border Protection data as of September 23. That number is set to keep growing at least until a verdict is announced, which could be months from now.
 

   
    The who
 

   
  It‚Äôs unclear who might be  eligible for a refund  if the justices rule against the Trump administration.
 

   
  Justice Amy Coney Barrett, whom President Donald Trump appointed,  raised the issue  Wednesday, pressing Neal Katyal, the former acting solicitor general representing the small- and medium-sized businesses challenging the law.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf you win, tell me how the reimbursement process would work. Would it be a complete mess?‚Äù she said.
 

   
  Katyal said the five businesses he‚Äôs representing should undeniably be entitled to a refund if the justices rule in their favor, but for other businesses, he said it would be ‚Äúa very complicated thing.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúSo, a mess,‚Äù Barrett interjected.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult, absolutely, we don‚Äôt deny that,‚Äù Katyal responded.
 

   
  Businesses outside the five that Katyal represents may not necessarily be eligible for automatic refunds. Instead, they may have to file separate appeals with lower courts for the chance at a refund, said Thomas Beline, a trade attorney and partner at Cassidy Levy Kent.
 

   
  ‚ÄúSo, what I‚Äôd be looking at as an importer would be my importations over the last several months and when the entries will liquidate,‚Äù he said, referring to the process CBP undergoes to determine an importer‚Äôs finalized tariff payment.
 

   
  Before that, importers make what‚Äôs considered an estimated tariff payment. It can take CBP several months to arrive at a final figure because of how complicated the tariff code is.
 

   
  Beline recommends importers ask for liquidation extensions or file protests with CBP, which prevent entries from fully settling and could make it easier to get a refund.
 

   
    The when and the how
 

   
  Katyal on Wednesday brought up the administrative process Beline described. He also highlighted a 1998 Supreme Court decision on harbor maintenance fees that resulted in importers getting tariff refunds.
 

   
  But in the 1998 decision, it took two years for $730 million in tariff payments to be returned to the importers ‚Äî and that amount is a drop in the bucket compared to the tens of billions of dollars under consideration in the current Supreme Court case.
 

   
  ‚ÄúGiven the high volume of expected refunds, it would not be surprising if CBP implemented a streamlined or automated process, as seen in prior duty refunds, with importers possibly needing to update payment details via a CBP form,‚Äù said Ashley Akers, a senior counsel at the Holland & Knight law firm and a former Justice Department trial lawyer. ‚ÄúIt is also possible but unlikely that CBP would issue automatic blanket refunds without specific claims.‚Äù
 

   
  Ultimately, the refunds that businesses receive could come with statutory interest, she said.
 

   
    Enter Wall Street
 

   
  For months, investment banks, including Oppenheimer and Jefferies, have approached importers in an attempt to broker deals where they sell their stake in a potential tariff at a discount in exchange for immediate cash. If the Supreme Court sides against the Trump administration, these investment banks would get a cut of the total tariff refund businesses forfeited. Representatives for Jefferies and Oppenheimer declined to comment.
 

   
  In marketing materials viewed by CNN that Oppenheimer distributed in July, the firm said the ‚Äúmarket rate‚Äù for what businesses could receive upfront was 20% to 30% of the payments made to cover the tariffs being challenged.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis solution provides the ability to de-risk the outcome and receive a guaranteed payment now, without having to wait for final court rulings,‚Äù the marketing material prepared by the firm‚Äôs special assets team said.
 

   
  Additionally, Oppenheimer said selling a refund stake would allow businesses to avoid making a public legal filing that may be required to get the funds, thus avoid drawing the possible ‚Äúire from the Trump administration.‚Äù
 

   
  Kyle Peacock, principal at Peacock Tariff Consulting, said businesses attempting to buy tariff refund stakes have been ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù in how they‚Äôve pitched his clients, over 100 of whom have sold their tariff refund stakes.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a very scary mentality that‚Äôs happening,‚Äù said Peacock, who has listened to several calls with clients with businesses involved in buying refund claims. When business are speaking to his clients, they‚Äôre saying, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôll never get this so take this little bit of money, or you won‚Äôt get anywhere.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  Companies pounce on importers, especially when Trump threatens to enact a new tariff like the additional  100% levies on Chinese goods last month . Their target customer, he said, appears to be importers that are ‚Äúmore credit-stretched.‚Äù
 

   
  It‚Äôs those types of customers that ended up accepting what Peacock considered ‚Äúextremely low offers‚Äù of 5% to 7% of a potential tariff refund down the line. And in the end, instead of the 100% tariff threat, Trump  lowered Chinese tariffs by 10% .
 

   
  After Wednesday‚Äôs oral arguments, many of Peacock‚Äôs clients that sold refund claims are feeling a bit of ‚Äúseller‚Äôs remorse,‚Äù he said, and ones that didn‚Äôt are generally feeling ‚Äúmore cautiously optimistic.‚Äù

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The global climate summit COP30 in Bel√©m, Brazil, is facing severe logistical, political, and environmental challenges. A massive shortage of accommodations‚Äîhighlighted by inflated hotel prices and the need for love motels like Love Lomas to adapt‚Äîthreatens to exclude developing countries and non-profits from meaningful participation. This crisis is exacerbated by Brazil‚Äôs decision to approve oil drilling at the Amazon‚Äôs mouth, seen as hypocritical given the summit‚Äôs focus on protecting the rainforest. Meanwhile, the United States, under President Donald Trump, has withdrawn its high-level delegation and dismissed climate change as a 'con job,' undermining international efforts. A UN analysis reveals that current climate policies are on track for a 2.8¬∞C warming, far exceeding the 1.5¬∞C goal, and most nations have failed to submit national climate plans. articles.content:
‚ÄòLove motels‚Äô and Amazon oil drilling are just a few of the ways this global gathering is mired in chaos 
       
  By Laura Paddison, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:00 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Ricardo Teixeira has spent the past few weeks freshening up Love Lomas, the ‚Äúlove motel‚Äù he owns in the Brazilian port city of Bel√©m. He‚Äôs also mulling how to tone down some of the rooms‚Äô more sensual aspects, including erotic chairs and menus of sex toys for sale. It‚Äôs all in anticipation of welcoming a very different type of guest than his usual clientele.
 

   
  Love motels are common throughout Brazil, with rooms available by the hour often booked for romantic trysts. But as tens of thousands of people descend on Bel√©m  for COP30  ‚Äî the world‚Äôs biggest annual climate summit ‚Äî a dearth of accommodation has led to a scramble for beds. Love motels like Teixeira‚Äôs are ready and willing to fill the gap.
 

   
  The prospect of diplomats, scientists and climate activists being asked to specify which erotic features they‚Äôd like removed from rooms is striking, but it also speaks to a serious issue. As delegates compete for beds, rates have spiked and some developing countries and non-profits say they are being priced out of the summit.
 

   
  ‚ÄúTheir voices (will be) silenced in the very rooms where decisions about their survival are being made,‚Äù said Harjeet Singh, a COP negotiations veteran and founding director of Satat Sampada Climate Foundation.
 

   
  Accommodation woes are just one example of the chaos and uncertainty some experts say have paved the way to this summit.
 

   
  COP30 was billed as a landmark gathering, where countries would chart a course to dramatically cut climate pollution. Instead, huge polluters have missed multiple deadlines to submit national climate goals, President Donald Trump is fresh from a speech  calling climate change a ‚Äúcon job,‚Äù  the US says it will not send a delegation to the summit, and Brazil has just approved oil drilling at the mouth of the Amazon ‚Äî all the while, global temperatures  tick upward  and climate targets  slip out of reach .
 

   
  In 2015, under the  Paris climate agreement , countries agreed to limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, with the ambition to keep it below 1.5 degrees. ‚ÄúTen years later, we need to have very honest and very tough conversations on whether we‚Äôre actually following that roadmap,‚Äù said Juan Carlos Monterrey G√≥mez, Panama‚Äôs special representative for climate change.
 

   
  Brazil‚Äôs choice of Bel√©m as the COP30 location was symbolic. The city is known as the ‚Äúgateway to the Amazon,‚Äù and the aim was to focus minds on the existential danger this vast rainforest faces from the barreling climate crisis.
 

   
  But Bel√©m was not set up for the influx that accompanies COP. The city typically has around 18,000 hotel rooms but is expecting roughly 50,000 people.
 

   
  The official COP30  website  lists hotels, many of which are dozens of miles outside Bel√©m, for prices ranging from about $200 a night to more than $1,000, most requiring minimum stays of 11 nights. One head of a negotiating delegation told CNN they were being charged more than $20,000 for two weeks in a three-bedroom apartment.
 

   
  Organizers insist there will be rooms for all and have scrambled to arrange extra accommodation, including on cruise ships, and are offering extra assistance to the most vulnerable nations.
 

   
   But some countries and non-profits have been forced to send skeleton teams, or no one at all. ‚ÄúOur fear is that these logistical barriers might prevent the full participation of everybody that needs to be there,‚Äù Monterrey G√≥mez told CNN.
 

   
  As well as logistics, the ‚ÄúAmazon COP‚Äù is also being overshadowed by Brazil‚Äôs decision in October to greenlight exploratory oil drilling at the mouth of the Amazon River. Activists have decried the decision as hypocrisy. ‚ÄúBrazil is asking the world to come to Bel√©m to save the most critical ecosystem, while at the same time auctioning it off to the very industry that is destroying it,‚Äù Singh said.
 

   
  Brazilian President Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva has defended the decision. ‚ÄúIt would be incoherent, an irresponsible action, if I said we will no longer use oil,‚Äù he said Tuesday in a speech ahead of COP30, as reported by  AP .
 

   
  Promoting climate action while simultaneously approving new fossil fuel projects ‚Äúis the sort of contradiction we‚Äôre dealing with right now,‚Äù said Alden Meyer, a senior associate with the research group E3G. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs pretty widespread complicity,‚Äù he told CNN. And it brings into stark focus one of the thorniest issues at COP: the future of fossil fuels.
 

   
  Two years ago, at COP28 in Dubai, countries made an unprecedented call to transition away from oil, coal and gas. It was heralded as a  breakthrough , remarkably the first time a COP final agreement had referred to fossil fuels.
 

   
  Since then, however, the world has changed; there‚Äôs a huge Trump-shaped hole torn through climate diplomacy. Petrostates and oil companies are  increasingly emboldened  to push back against any  language blaming fossil fuels  for climate change or committing to phasing them out.
 

   
  When it comes to transitioning away from fossil fuels, there is ‚Äúno timeline, no targets, no rate of change, no program to support countries and communities in that transition,‚Äù Meyer said.
 

   
  A flurry of reports released in the run up to COP suggests this transition is happening far more slowly than needed.
 

   
  A UN  analysis  of countries‚Äô current climate policies found they put the world on course for a 2.8 degree Celsius temperature rise, far above 1.5 and a level of warming that could push the planet over several catastrophic and  potentially irreversible tipping points .
 

   
  Another  UN report  assessing the climate impact of countries‚Äô formal goals for cutting planet-heating pollution over the next decade found there was not enough data to ‚Äúdraw wide-ranging global-level conclusions,‚Äù because too few countries have submitted them.
 

   
  The original deadline for these goals, required under the Paris climate agreement, was February;  95% of governments  missed it. Major climate polluters, including India and Saudi Arabia, still have yet to formally submit.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere is limited appetite right now from countries to step up and come forward with ambitious climate action or pledges,‚Äù said Niklas H√∂hne, an international climate policy expert at the NewClimate Institute, an independent non-profit. In part, this is due to turbulent geopolitics, including conflict, war and a global shift to the right, he told CNN.
 

   
  The actions of the US, the planet‚Äôs second largest climate polluter, may also be an influence. Trump called climate change ‚Äúthe greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world,‚Äù in a  speech  at the UN in September, and the US has since confirmed it won‚Äôt  send a high level delegation  to COP30.
 

   
  But its absence will hover over COP30 like a shadow ‚Äî and it could still exert influence. The US has proven to be a powerful disruptive force at international climate negotiations this year, helping derail what would have been two historical agreements: a  global plastics treaty  and  a tax  on the shipping industry‚Äôs climate pollution.
 

   
  US actions send ‚Äúa chilling message to the world‚Ä¶ (and) gives other laggard countries a shield to hide behind,‚Äù Singh said.
 

   
  It‚Äôs hard to know what will emerge from COP30, but experts say there are real signs of hope outside the talks, not least the  remarkable clean energy boom  unfolding even as global political momentum to tackle climate change falters.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe climate negotiations are the lowest common denominator of what countries are willing to do in the current political circumstances,‚Äù H√∂hne said, and outside of the fraught negotiating venues in Bel√©m is a ‚Äútotally different world.‚Äù

articles.title: The Supreme Court Could Undo Trump‚Äôs Signature Economic Policy. But Tariffs Aren‚Äôt the Problem
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court may rule that President Donald Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariff policies exceed presidential authority, but the article argues that these tariffs have had a limited and indirect impact on inflation and consumer prices. While annual inflation remains at 3%, significantly lower than pandemic peaks, businesses have absorbed most of the tariff costs so far, with signs that companies are beginning to pass on increased expenses to consumers. The article emphasizes that the broader economic pain Americans feel stems from five years of cumulative inflation, not directly from tariffs. Even if the Supreme Court invalidates the tariffs, Trump retains legal alternatives‚Äîsuch as Section 232, Section 301, and Section 338‚Äîto impose new import levies. Experts like JPMorgan‚Äôs Michael Hanson and Jamie Dimon stress that the long-term economic burden will ultimately fall on consumers, and that tariffs are a misleading scapegoat for deeper, long-standing inflation trends.
keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court may rule that President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff policies exceed presidential authority, but this decision is unlikely to significantly relieve inflation or consumer price pressure.
Tariffs have only marginally raised prices, with inflation at 3% in September 2025‚Äîfar below the 9% peak during the pandemic‚Äîindicating limited immediate economic impact.
Businesses have absorbed roughly 80% of tariff costs so far, but signs suggest companies are preparing to pass costs on to consumers via rising wholesale prices and higher retail prices.
The broader economic pain Americans feel stems from five years of cumulative inflation, not tariffs specifically; households now spend $1,043 more per month than in 2021 on the same goods.
Even if tariffs are deemed illegal, Trump has alternative legal tools (e.g., Section 232, Section 301, Section 338) to impose new tariffs without relying on emergency powers.
JPMorgan economists and CEOs indicate that the long-term economic burden of tariffs will ultimately fall on consumers, despite short-term business absorption.
The perception of tariffs as a primary cause of economic hardship is misleading, as inflation is the result of a prolonged economic trend, not a direct tariff effect.

  Analysis by David Goldman, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:00 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Many Americans  worried about high prices  might expect some relief if a deeply skeptical Supreme Court reins in President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs. If you‚Äôre among them, don‚Äôt get your hopes up.
 

   
  In a  consequential Supreme Court case  Wednesday, a majority of the justices expressed concern that Trump may have overstepped his authority in levying tariffs with practically zero limits. Trump has imposed enormous import taxes in a number of unprecedented ways: He placed tariffs high enough to effectively serve as a temporary embargo on all Chinese goods, retaliated against Brazil‚Äôs conviction of its former president and Trump ally Jair Bolsanaro, and  pressured India  to ditch Russian oil.
 

   
  Those tariffs have begun to raise some prices for Americans, who ranked the cost of living as the most important issue facing the country in a new  CNN poll conducted by SSRS . Nearly three quarters (72%) of Americans say the US economy is in bad shape, and 61% say Trump‚Äôs policies have made economic conditions worse.
 

   
  The Supreme Court may ultimately rule the bulk of Trump‚Äôs tariffs ‚Äì his signature economic policy ‚Äì to be illegal. But that wouldn‚Äôt give Americans much of a breather: Tariffs haven‚Äôt raised prices as much as you may think. And Trump has other tools to raise tariffs even if the Supreme Court rules against him.
 

   
    Tariffs‚Äô limited effect
 

   
  The US government‚Äôs inflation data shows tariffs have started to gradually raise some prices, particularly for goods that are almost exclusively imported, such as shoes and furniture. Still, the overall pace of price hikes has been far from dramatic.
 

   
  Annual inflation rose to 3% in September, the highest rate since January but far from the 9% rate during the post-pandemic inflation crisis.
 

   
  Tariffs have had a limited impact for a number of reasons.
 

   
  That‚Äôs not to say tariffs are inconsequential.
 

   
  Businesses have chosen to pay roughly 80% of the tariffs‚Äô cost ‚Äì for now ‚Äì according to a recent JPMorgan analysis. And what you‚Äôre not feeling in your pocket, you may be feeling in your job prospects: That hit to companies‚Äô profit has contributed to America‚Äôs slowing job market, JPMorgan economist Michael Hanson says.
 

   
  And consumers could still pay more of  tariffs‚Äô cost down the line . There‚Äôs mounting evidence companies are preparing to  pass along those costs : Recent Producer Price Index reports showed that businesses are  beginning to raise their wholesale prices , indicating many companies have reached the limit of what they can pay for before charging customers more. And CEOs on recent earnings calls have said some higher prices are inevitable.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere is no free lunch,‚Äù Hanson said. ‚ÄúWe continue to expect that consumers ultimately will foot most of the tariff bill.‚Äù
 

   
  Nevertheless, most inflation-weary Americans are upset with the economy because the  cumulative effect of higher prices  have been wreaking havoc on the economy for the past five years ‚Äì not because of tariffs, specifically. The typical household is spending $1,043 more per month than they did at the start of 2021 ‚Äì for the same stuff, according to Moody‚Äôs. Paychecks haven‚Äôt kept up.
 

   
  Inflation rose to a four-decade high in 2022. That means an entire generation of Americans had never experienced anything like the surging prices of the past several years.
 

   
  Although inflation ‚Äì the rate of those price hikes ‚Äì has since returned to normal, those higher prices haven‚Äôt really had time to settle into the country‚Äôs psyche. People are still shocked when they compare the prices they‚Äôre paying now to what they were paying just a few years ago.
 

   
  Typically, price hikes occur gradually, in such small increments you hardly notice. And for some products, like new technology, prices can actually fall over time as supply increases ‚Äì that‚Äôs why you can get a high-quality gigantic 4K TV for a couple hundred bucks now, when those TVs would set you back thousands a few years ago.
 

   
  This is something different: The first inflation shock many Americans experienced hasn‚Äôt yet worn off, and tariffs are a convenient ‚Äì if largely inaccurate ‚Äì foil for their pain.
 

   
    Trump can still impose tariffs
 

   
  The Supreme Court isn‚Äôt exactly Sonic the Hedgehog. Even with an expedited case, the justices may not rule for several months. In the meantime, Trump can continue to impose his tariffs, and price hikes may ultimately start to take hold of the economy.
 

   
  But if the Supreme Court ultimately rules that the bulk of his tariffs are illegal, Trump has other options, including other laws he‚Äôs already used to raise some import levies. They may be more restrictive than his broad use of emergency powers, but they‚Äôre not part of the current case before the Supreme Court.
 

   
  For example, Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 allows the president to raise tariffs on national security grounds. Trump has used that to raise steel, aluminum and copper tariffs. Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 allows the president to raise tariffs on nations deemed to violate trade agreements. And Section 338 of the Tariff Act of 1930, although never used, would allow the president to raise tariffs up to 50% on countries if they‚Äôre believed to be engaged in discriminatory trade practices.
 

   
  Trump called the case ‚Äúlife or death.‚Äù But  JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon  told CNN‚Äôs Erin Burnett Wednesday that he disagreed with the president.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a factor,‚Äù Dimon said. ‚ÄúBut it may not be the deciding factor‚Äù in whether the US economy keeps growing.
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Elisabeth Buchwald contributed to this report.

articles.content:
From ‚Äòmazel tov‚Äô to ‚Äòconflicted,‚Äô Jewish New Yorkers react to Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs mayoral win 
       
  By Eric Levenson, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:00 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Sen. Chuck Schumer, the New York Democrat and one of the most powerful Jewish politicians in the United States, did not endorse Zohran Mamdani and would not say who he voted for in New York City‚Äôs mayoral election.
 

   
  But on Wednesday morning, he said he called the mayor-elect to offer his congratulations.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe had a very, very good conversation,‚Äù Schumer said. ‚ÄúWe said that we cared about New York City, and that we look forward to working together to help the city and improve the city. I congratulated him on running a very, very good campaign.‚Äù
 

   
  Schumer‚Äôs comments represent just one taste of the mix of wary acceptance, fearful concern and joyous celebration from Jewish New Yorkers in the wake of Mamdani‚Äôs victory Tuesday.
 

   
  Jews have long reliably  supported the Democratic Party , but the mayoral election revealed a deep schism related to concerns about rising antisemitism and Mamdani‚Äôs long history of anti-Israel and pro-Palestinian activism.
 

   
  Preliminary  CNN exit polls  found about 64% of Jewish voters cast their ballot for former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, while about one-third voted for Mamdani.
 

   
  Some prominent rabbis and Jewish groups took the unusual step of urging their constituents to vote against the Democratic nominee, saying his positions on Israel were disqualifying. Other Jewish voters, particularly of the younger generations, saw his views on Israel as a positive or viewed them overall as less important than his domestic policies on affordability, housing and standing up to President Donald Trump.
 

   
  The results show that Jewish New Yorkers have a diverse set of political views, according to Lila Corwin Berman, a New York University professor of Jewish history.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt really has not been the case that there has been a single political voice or political bloc among Jewish New Yorkers, from the earliest period when Jews lived in this city,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThere has always been a diversity of views about what is best.‚Äù
 

   
  Speaking Wednesday, Mamdani affirmed he would work with rabbis and other community leaders ‚Äúto deliver on the promise of not just protecting Jewish New Yorkers, but celebrating and cherishing them in the same city.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI look forward to being the mayor for every person that calls this city home, that includes the Jewish New Yorkers that voted for our campaign and those that didn‚Äôt,‚Äù he told reporters.
 

   
  Still, Alana Zeitchik, an Israeli-American Brooklyn resident whose  family members were kidnapped by Hamas , said the poll results show Jewish residents remain skeptical of Mamdani.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt just shows there‚Äôs a lot of work to be done,‚Äù she told CNN. ‚ÄúHe hasn‚Äôt built the coalition with Jewish New York that needs to happen for a strong New York that can tackle all kinds of hatred. There needs to be a strong coalition with the Jewish community, and he didn‚Äôt capture the majority of us.‚Äù
 

   
    Mamdani pledges to fight antisemitism
 

   
  Zeitchik said she left the mayoral vote blank on her ballot, unwilling to support Cuomo or Mamdani.
 

   
  As a liberal voter, she said she agreed with much of Mamdani‚Äôs promises to make New York affordable, equitable and safe. But she was not convinced he fully understood the prevalence of antisemitic and anti-Zionist views, which she argued have taken over progressive spaces.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI want him to succeed. It‚Äôs just that he‚Äôs not yet shown me that he‚Äôs earned my vote,‚Äù she said.
 

   
  She said she was ‚Äúvery conflicted‚Äù about the results of the election and felt the debate within the Jewish community about Mamdani was too black-and-white.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he is some evil danger to our community,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúbut I do think it‚Äôs unfair for some people in the Jewish community to diminish very real concerns that we have over the permission structure that his activism and his own words and worldview allows around anti-Zionism, and how that contributes to antisemitism.‚Äù
 

   
  The concern among Jews stems from Mamdani‚Äôs support of the  Boycott, Divest, and Sanctions movement  against Israel, his challenge to Israel‚Äôs status as a Jewish state, and his pledge to arrest Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He previously refused to condemn the phrase ‚Äúglobalize the intifada,‚Äù a phrase that some Jews see as threatening, though he recently said he  would discourage its use .
 

   
  In more recent months, Mamdani has tried to reassure Jewish voters worried about antisemitic attacks like the ones in  Washington, DC , and  Boulder, Colorado . He attended High Holiday services with allies and sat for a  Q&A at Congregation Beth Elohim , a synagogue in Brooklyn that counts Sen. Schumer as a member.
 

   
  Jewish voters who supported Mamdani were excited with the results of the election.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMazel Tov @ZohranKMamdani, Mazel Tov NYC,‚Äù wrote  Jews for Racial & Economic Justice , a New York-based Jewish progressive organization.
 

   
  Brad Lander, the outgoing city comptroller and one of Mamdani‚Äôs most prominent Jewish progressive supporters, attended Mamdani‚Äôs election night watch party. He posted a photo of himself wearing a  shirt in Mamdani‚Äôs campaign font  with a message for Cuomo: ‚ÄúGood f**king riddance.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúOur message to Andrew Cuomo was loud & clear in June,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs louder & clearer tonight.‚Äù
 

   
    ADL launches ‚ÄòMamdani Monitor‚Äô
 

   
  Jewish groups and leaders who had previously criticized Mamdani expressed ongoing concern in the wake of his victory.
 

   
  The Anti-Defamation League, the Jewish advocacy group, announced on Wednesday a ‚ÄúMamdani Monitor‚Äù to track his policies and appointments as well as a tip line for New Yorkers to report antisemitic incidents.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe expect the mayor of the city with the largest Jewish population in the world to stand unequivocally against antisemitism in all its varied forms and support all of its Jewish residents just as he would all other constituents,‚Äù ADL CEO Jonathan Greenblatt said in a statement.
 

   
  Mamdani on Wednesday morning expressed his skepticism of the project and criticized Greenblatt.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think that anyone is free to catalogue the actions of our administration,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI have some doubts in Jonathan‚Äôs ability to do so honestly given that he previously said  I had not visited any synagogues  only to have to  correct himself .‚Äù
 

   
  In addition, a  joint statement  from several Jewish nonprofit groups, including the UJA-Federation of New York, said they ‚Äúcannot ignore that the Mayor-elect holds core beliefs fundamentally at odds with our community‚Äôs deepest convictions and most cherished values.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúAs we have done for over a century, we will continue to work across every level of government to ensure that our city remains a place where our Jewish community, and all communities, feel safe and respected,‚Äù the groups wrote. ‚ÄúWe call on Mayor-elect Mamdani and all elected officials to govern with humility, inclusivity, and a deep respect for the diversity of views and experiences that define our city.‚Äù
 

   
  Meanwhile, Bill Ackman, the billionaire hedge-fund manager who warned a Mamdani win would lead  wealthy New Yorkers to flee  the city and exhorted voters to rally behind Cuomo, offered a conciliatory congratulations.
 

   
  ‚ÄúNow you have a big responsibility. If I can help NYC, just let me know what I can do,‚Äù  he wrote on X .
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhile I did not support Mamdani for mayor and have concerns about the unintended and negative consequences of his policies, I want to do everything I can to help NYC regardless of who (our) mayor is,‚Äù  Ackman added .
 

   
  Mamdani, who frequently criticized Ackman during the campaign, offered some conciliation of his own in response.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI appreciated Bill Ackman‚Äôs tweet and the sentiment of it, and I will continue to have conversations with anyone who is committed to the welfare of the city, the vitality of the city,‚Äù he said.

articles.title: USDA revises SNAP reduction plan to provide more partial benefits in November
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Department of Agriculture revised its plan to reduce SNAP benefits in November by lowering the maximum cut from 50% to 35% to comply with a court order requiring the use of SNAP‚Äôs contingency fund during a government shutdown. This change, based on analysis showing that a deeper cut was unnecessary, prevents nearly 5 million recipients from receiving no benefits and reduces the average cut for many households. However, implementation varies significantly by state, with Pennsylvania facing major technical delays due to outdated systems, prompting criticism from state officials. A legal dispute continues, with plaintiffs arguing that delayed benefits violate a judge‚Äôs directive for expeditious payment, while the USDA maintains it has fulfilled its obligations by releasing funds and providing guidance. The situation raises broader concerns about food security, administrative efficiency, and equitable access to nutrition assistance.
keyTakeAways: The USDA revised its SNAP benefit reduction plan, reducing maximum benefits by 35% instead of the originally proposed 50%, to comply with a court order requiring use of the SNAP contingency fund during a government shutdown.
The change was based on an analysis indicating that a 50% cut was excessive and unnecessary, with only a 35% reduction sufficient to deplete the contingency fund.
Approximately 5 million SNAP recipients would have received no benefits under the original plan, and many households would have received less than half of their usual assistance.
States face significant technical challenges in implementing the revised plan, with Pennsylvania estimating a 10,000-hour overhaul and delays of up to a month due to outdated systems.
The USDA declined to shift funds to provide full benefits, citing risks to other nutrition programs, and instead opted for partial reductions.
The legal dispute involves multiple states, cities, nonprofits, unions, and small businesses arguing that the administration failed to provide timely, adequate benefits, violating a court order.
The court has ordered expeditious implementation of benefits, but the administration maintains that it has fulfilled its obligations by releasing funds and providing guidance to states.
A hearing is scheduled for Thursday to address whether the delayed benefits violate the court‚Äôs directive for expeditious implementation.

articles.content:
USDA revises SNAP reduction plan to provide more partial benefits in November 
       
  By Tami Luhby, Devan Cole, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:19 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The US Department of Agriculture issued revised guidance to states on Wednesday evening that will result in food stamp enrollees receiving somewhat larger  partial benefits  in November.
 

   
  The update, disclosed in a new court filing, calls for reducing the maximum Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefit by 35%, instead of the original 50%.
 

   
  The agency is issuing only partial benefits this month to comply with a  court order  requiring it to tap into  SNAP‚Äôs contingency fund  amid the government shutdown.
 

   
  ‚ÄúUSDA performed further analysis and determined that the maximum allotments need only be reduced by 35%, instead of 50%, to deplete the SNAP contingency fund,‚Äù Patrick Penn, a top USDA official, told the court.
 

   
  The update comes shortly after a left-leaning think tank published an analysis arguing that the USDA‚Äôs original guidance called for cutting benefits more deeply than needed. The agency had said in a previous court filing it planned to use $4.65 billion in the fund to provide SNAP assistance this month.
 

   
  However, the USDA‚Äôs initial plan would have provided only about $3 billion in  food stamp benefits , which would have resulted in an average cut of 61% for the month, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities‚Äô analysis. The think tank asserted that only a 43% cut would be needed to keep spending in line with the available funds.
 

   
  In addition to requiring the USDA to use the contingency fund to provide at least partial benefits, two federal judges also gave the USDA the option of shifting other money to SNAP to enable it to pay full benefits in November, but the agency declined, citing risks to other nutrition programs. Full benefits would total about $8.2 billion for November.
 

   
  Still, some beneficiaries could receive less than 65% of their usual benefits because of the way food stamp aid is calculated. The formula calls for subtracting 30% of a household‚Äôs monthly net income from the maximum benefit for its household size. Most households have some income and don‚Äôt receive the maximum allotment.
 

   
  The earlier analysis from the center, based on the 50% cut, found that nearly 5 million  food stamp recipients  would not receive any benefits in November. That‚Äôs because their usual allotment is less than the planned reduction in benefits.
 

   
  And many households with at least some income would have received less than half of their normal assistance, according to the analysis.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBy cutting benefits even more deeply than necessary, the Administration ‚Äî which previously argued (contrary to federal law and the Administration‚Äôs own prior practice) that SNAP‚Äôs contingency funds aren‚Äôt legally available to cover regular benefits ‚Äî has once again gone out of its way to inflict further harm on low-income families,‚Äù the center wrote.
 

   
  CNN has reached out to the USDA for comment on the analysis. The Justice Department, which represents USDA in court, said in Wednesday evening‚Äôs filing that the change was not made in response to a plaintiffs‚Äô filing earlier in the evening that included the center‚Äôs analysis.
 

   
  The lawsuit, one of two demanding that USDA tap into the contingency fund, was brought by a coalition of cities, nonprofits, unions and small businesses.
 

   
    Delayed benefits
 

   
  Just when food stamp enrollees will receive their partial benefits depends on where they live. States must reconfigure their systems to take into account the reduced payments. That could take some states that use older technology weeks ‚Äì or even months ‚Äì to implement, a top USDA official said in a court filing.
 

   
  In North Carolina and Massachusetts, enrollees should receive their benefits next week, according to statements on the states‚Äô websites.
 

   
  But Pennsylvania wrote a letter to USDA on Wednesday saying the agency had chosen the ‚Äúmost complex and labor-intensive approach possible‚Äù to issue partial benefits.
 

   
  The process will require 10,000 hours ‚Äì a minimum of nine to 12 business days ‚Äì to overhaul the state‚Äôs system, and it then would take another 10 days to issue benefits, according to the letter from Valerie Arkoosh, the state‚Äôs Department of Human Services secretary, which CNN has viewed. Also, the plan could increase Pennsylvania‚Äôs payment error rate.
 

   
  Instead, the USDA should let states send food stamp recipients half of their usual benefit as a one-time issuance for November, Arkoosh said, noting that the agency used this method to provide Covid-19 pandemic food assistance during the first Trump administration.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis will only further delay availability of food assistance for nearly 2 million Pennsylvanians who are currently not receiving benefits to which they are entitled, and result in wasted taxpayer dollars and long-term harm to Pennsylvania‚Äôs SNAP program,‚Äù Arkoosh wrote of the USDA‚Äôs guidance.
 

   
    Continued legal proceedings
 

   
  The delay in payments has raised fresh legal questions in cases challenging the administration‚Äôs initial decision to not provide SNAP benefits for November.
 

   
  In his ruling last week that the administration must tap into the contingency fund to provide at least partial SNAP benefits this month, US District Judge John McConnell in Rhode Island ordered the government to work ‚Äúexpeditiously‚Äù to ensure payments are made.
 

   
  But the coalition behind the legal challenge raced back to the court earlier this week, arguing the delayed payments meant the administration had run afoul of McConnell‚Äôs directive and urged the judge to issue a new order requiring the government to fully fund SNAP benefits for November.
 

   
  The administration pushed back strongly on those assertions in court papers filed Wednesday afternoon, saying that since it had released the money from its contingency fund to states and provided guidance on how state officials can calculate reduced payments, ‚Äúthere is nothing more USDA could do.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe states are nonparties to this suit, and the court has not ordered them to, for example, hire additional technical staff or meet any particular deadlines. And Plaintiffs have not identified any authority for USDA to compel States to do anything other than distribute reduced benefits once the States have been authorized and the funds provided, as USDA has already done,‚Äù the government attorneys wrote.
 

   
  McConnell has set a hearing over the issue for Thursday.
 

   
   This story and headline have been updated with additional developments.

articles.title: How Johnson and Jeffries‚Äô once collegial relationship has soured in the era of Trump and shutdown politics
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The once-collegial relationship between House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries has deteriorated significantly in the era of President Donald Trump‚Äôs return to power and a prolonged government shutdown. Initially built on mutual respect, shared committee work, and a commitment to bipartisanship, their dynamic shifted after December 2024, when Johnson was accused of prioritizing Trump's demands over bipartisan compromise‚Äîsuch as by adding partisan provisions to the defense bill and derailing a spending deal. As the shutdown continues, both leaders have issued increasingly personal and hostile public statements, accusing each other of extremism and hypocrisy. Jeffries criticized Johnson for ignoring threats and for aligning with Trump's authoritarian style, while Johnson dismissed Jeffries‚Äôs political affiliations and labeled him a 'socialist'. Their in-person meetings have ceased, and communication has reduced to check-ins. The situation has prompted calls for President Trump to directly intervene in negotiations. While both leaders still maintain professional ties, their relationship is now widely seen as fractured, undermining bipartisan governance and highlighting the impact of Trump-era politics on congressional functionality.
keyTakeAways: Mike Johnson and Hakeem Jeffries, once known for a collegial and bipartisan working relationship, have seen their collaboration deteriorate due to the political realignment under President Donald Trump and the resulting government shutdown.

The breakdown in trust began around December 2024, following controversial decisions by Johnson to include partisan provisions in the National Defense Authorization Act and to prioritize Trump‚Äôs demands over bipartisan compromise.

Both leaders have engaged in public personal attacks, with Johnson accusing Jeffries of being a 'socialist' and Jeffries accusing Johnson of ignoring threats and supporting Trump‚Äôs authoritarian tactics.
The shutdown has intensified the divide, with each leader blaming the other‚Äôs party for the impasse, undermining bipartisan negotiations and the functioning of Congress.

A key factor in the deterioration is the shift from a cooperative model to one where Johnson appears to follow Trump's directives, leading Democrats to feel betrayed and Republicans to question the leadership‚Äôs integrity.

Despite shared past accomplishments, such as mutual support in committee work and preventing censure, their current relationship is described as 'fractured' and 'it‚Äôs complicated', with limited meaningful communication since September 29.
The situation has prompted calls for President Trump to directly intervene, with both Jeffries and Chuck Schumer urging him to take active steps to end the shutdown.

articles.content:
How Johnson and Jeffries‚Äô once collegial relationship has soured in the era of Trump and shutdown politics 
       
  By Annie Grayer, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:00 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  When Hakeem Jeffries handed Mike Johnson the speaker‚Äôs gavel on the House floor in October 2023, the pair hugged, marking the promise of a new era of bipartisanship.
 

   
  In one of their first private meetings, the two party leaders agreed they would not launch personal attacks against each other, according to multiple sources familiar with the dynamic.
 

   
  As two fathers with deeply held religious beliefs, the pair often discussed their faith, the sources said, and forged a working relationship that stemmed from serving together on the House Judiciary Committee early in their congressional careers. At one-point last term, Jeffries even helped Johnson save his job.
 

   
  But that was in an era of split government when Johnson, trying to put his Republican conference back together after a messy   speakership fight, had to work with Democrats who controlled the Senate and President  Joe Biden  in the White House.
 

   
  Now,   with President  Donald Trump ‚Äôs resurgence, a Republican takeover in Washington that has at times ceded   congressional authority on federal spending, and   a  historic   government shutdown , the dynamics between Johnson and Jeffries are different.
 

   
  As the shutdown drags on, the changing relationship between Johnson and Jeffries may make it even harder for lawmakers to find a way out of the impasse, particularly if a deal to end the stalemate requires a compromise and each leader must make a difficult sell to their members.
 

   
  The shutdown has also placed a spotlight on the frayed dynamic between Johnson and Jeffries. As the funding lapse has grown more painful for federal workers going without pay and millions of Americans who rely on critical social safety net programs, the two House leaders have sharpened their rhetoric and sought to cast blame on each other‚Äôs party for the failure to reopen the government.
 

   
  And a number of challenges lay ahead. In addition to needing to reopen the government, lawmakers are under pressure ‚Äì and up against the clock ‚Äì to negotiate a broader spending deal and come to an agreement on how to address soon-to-expire enhanced Affordable Care Act subsidies.
 

   
  Even though the leaders have remained in contact as the shutdown has dragged on, they have not met in person since a White House meeting on September 29, and multiple sources characterize their brief phone conversations as more of check-ins than meaningful deliberations.
 

   
  In the meantime, their public comments have become more charged as Johnson has kept the House out of session since September 19.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries are irredeemable at this point,‚Äù Johnson said at a press conference on October 29 in response to a question about the shutdown. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve given up on the leadership.‚Äù
 

   
  The next day, Jeffries said at his own press conference, ‚ÄúRepublicans hold press conferences every day, and you know what they do? They lie to the American people. These people are stone-cold extremist liars, starting from the very top.‚Äù
 

   
  After Jeffries faced a death threat from a pardoned US Capitol rioter, Jeffries said Johnson never raised the issue with him personally after the individual was arrested  last month. 
 

   
  ‚ÄúI spoke to him briefly this week, but he had nothing to say about the death threats. And you know, that‚Äôs irredeemable,‚Äù Jeffries told reporters of the speaker late last month.
 

   
  Johnson has condemned the death threat publicly, telling reporters several days earlier, ‚ÄúAnybody who threatens to kill any political official, we denounce it absolutely.‚Äù
 

   
  Earlier this week, Jeffries accused Trump and Johnson of running a ‚Äúpedophile protection program‚Äù for not holding a vote on the release of the Jeffrey Epstein case files and on Wednesday, Johnson said Jeffries ‚Äúapparently is a socialist‚Äù for having endorsed New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani.
 

   
  Asked for comment about the status of his relationship with Johnson, Jeffries said in a statement to CNN, ‚ÄúThe unhinged and personal attacks coming from the other side of the aisle are a sign of desperation.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThat said, I don‚Äôt take the baseless ad hominem attacks personally because we‚Äôre focused on lowering the high cost of living and addressing the devastating Republican healthcare crisis,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  A Johnson spokesperson separately told CNN that ‚Äúthe Speaker and the Leader have a productive working relationship based on mutual respect and trust‚Äù when asked about the pair‚Äôs relationship.
 

   
  ‚ÄúEven when they vehemently disagree on politics and policy, they do not make it or take it personal. The Speaker considers the Leader a friend, and he has always encouraged his colleagues on both sides of the aisle to treat one another as fellow Americans and as individuals made in the image of God,‚Äù the spokesperson said in a statement.
 

   
  But some lawmakers see it playing out differently.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think it is fractured,‚Äù GOP Rep. Tim Burchett said of the leaders‚Äô relationship. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs reparable or not.‚Äù
 

   
  Democratic Rep. Jared Huffman said that when Johnson became speaker, ‚ÄúI think he began with a lot of good will to the point that lots of Democrats talked about defending him if there was a motion to vacate.‚Äù
 

   
  But, Huffman said of the speaker, ‚Äúthere‚Äôs just no more goodwill. He‚Äôs burned it. He made a choice. His choice is to be joined at the hip with Donald Trump, no matter what Trump says or does, and basically, to pretend Article I doesn‚Äôt exist.‚Äù
 

   
  Sources close to both leaders were careful, however, not to say the relationship has fully deteriorated, while still conceding it‚Äôs not exactly rosy either.
 

   
  One source familiar with the relationship likened its current state to a Facebook status of ‚Äúit‚Äôs complicated.‚Äù
 

   
  A senior House Democratic leadership aide emphasized: ‚ÄúWe are right up at that line. All you need to do is listen to the daily press conference antagonistic sound bites.‚Äù
 

   
    When things shifted and why it matters
 

   
  In Johnson‚Äôs first term as speaker, the two men found multiple opportunities to find common ground. They met regularly and their staffs had open lines of communication. For nearly two years, Johnson led a razor-thin majority and relied heavily on Jeffries to deliver key votes on foreign aid, to keep the government open, and even fight off a GOP-led effort to remove him from his job.
 

   
  But by December 2024, shortly after Trump‚Äôs election, Johnson no longer needed Jeffries to govern with Trump back in power and Democrats started to feel burned by some of Johnson‚Äôs maneuvers.
 

   
  Multiple Democratic lawmakers and aides pointed to two key episodes in December that they say foreshadowed the current dynamics. The first, they say, was Johnson allowing last-minute partisan provisions to be added to the critical defense policy bill known as the National Defense Authorization Act that led to a breakdown in bipartisan negotiations. The second was when, in their view, Johnson moved to accommodate Trump and Elon Musk  when the pair   derailed  a bipartisan, short-term spending compromise.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAll of us felt burned in December,‚Äù Huffman reflected. ‚ÄúThings shifted.‚Äù
 

   
  Democrats have increasingly felt that Johnson will do whatever Trump asks of him and because of that no longer think Johnson is capable of being a reliable dealmaker on his own. As a result, many believe the president will need to get involved in negotiations before an end to the shutdown feels real.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere is total agreement on that: He will only do whatever Trump says,‚Äù one Democratic lawmaker told CNN.
 

   
  Even a Republican lawmaker conceded: ‚ÄúThe president is doing all the negotiating.‚Äù
 

   
  On Wednesday, Jeffries and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer again requested to meet with Trump directly.
 

   
  ‚Äú[Trump] needs to get off the sidelines and get in the game, because until he does, this government will remain shut down. Mike Johnson and John Thune have zero authority to act on their own,‚Äù Jeffries told reporters.
 

   
  While both offices have remained in contact, Democrats say that some norms started to erode that made it difficult to work across the aisle. Johnson did not finalize a top line number for appropriators to work off of for 2025, multiple sources told CNN, forcing lawmakers to work on spending bills without an overarching price tag and complicating the bipartisan process that is a bedrock of the institution. Republicans contend that Democrats corroded standards when they stopped voting to keep the government open, a GOP source said.
 

   
  And Johnson‚Äôs team did not give Democrats a heads up when the House would be voting on the new GOP-led January 6 committee ‚Äì Democratic aides only discovered a mention of a vote to establish the new panel when reading through a separate bill it was tucked into, two sources said.
 

   
  By the time the September 30 government funding deadline came around, the good will between Jeffries and Johnson appeared on   rocky ground.
 

   
  The Democratic leader used to defend Johnson behind closed doors, telling his Democratic colleagues in caucus meetings that Johnson was an honest broker and that the pair had an understanding, three Democratic lawmakers familiar with the conversations told CNN. But in recent months, that had started to change, the lawmakers said.
 

   
  One of those Democratic lawmakers told CNN that what Jeffries says about Johnson in private meetings has ‚Äúchanged dramatically.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhen Johnson came in it was a fresh start, it was a better beginning. It seemed like staff were working together. Everyone wasn‚Äôt in agreement, but they were coordinated on things. But I think that has pretty much eroded at this point,‚Äù the lawmaker said.
 

   
  A separate House Democrat said that while Jeffries had once told his members ‚Äúgive him [Johnson] a chance,‚Äù Jeffries is now ‚Äúmuch more negative.‚Äù
 

   
  The shutdown has fueled concerns  ‚Äì mostly among Democrats, but also among some GOP lawmakers ‚Äì about the future of the two Hill leaders‚Äô working relationship that many had previously held up as key to the function of the institution.
 

   
  After Trump‚Äôs sharing of a racist, AI-generated video of Jeffries and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, Johnson‚Äôs message to his ‚Äúfriend Hakeem‚Äù during a press conference on October 2 was: ‚ÄúMan, just ignore it.‚Äù
 

   
  Jeffries called the video ‚Äúracist and fake‚Äù and the condemnation spread among his caucus .  In one particularly fiery moment, Rep. Madeleine Dean, who served with Johnson on the House Judiciary panel,  confronted the speaker  to condemn the video.
 

   
  With Johnson keeping the House out of session for more than a month and consequently refusing to swear in Arizona Rep.-elect Adelita Grijalva, some Democratic lawmakers say the bad blood has only worsened.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHakeem Jeffries has a temperament of being firm in convictions but wanting to find common ground for the country. But when Johnson arbitrarily has shut down Congress ‚Äì debasing an institution so many of us have pride in ‚Äì it has really made it difficult for Jeffries to find a way forward,‚Äù Democratic Rep. Ro Khanna told CNN.
 

   
  Another Republican lawmaker conceded: ‚ÄúI know they used to talk a lot. I don‚Äôt know where it stands now.‚Äù
 

   
  There have been a few glimmers of bipartisanship for Johnson and Jeffries since Trump got elected. In particular, there‚Äôs their work on increasing   lawmaker security and Jeffries delivering Johnson the votes to stave off censure resolutions brought from his right-flank to the House floor targeting certain members, moves that take up valuable floor time and take time away from other priorities of GOP leadership.
 

   
  With Trump in the White House, however, their once productive working relationship appears not what it used to be.
 

   
  Even so, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle say the mutual respect and understanding that both leaders initially made the foundation of their relationship is key to reopening the government and moving forward.
 

   
  ‚ÄúLeft to their own devices, they‚Äôre powerful and well-intentioned, principled men who have real and meaningful disagreements. The device that has been inserted here is the president,‚Äù remarked a source familiar with Jeffries and Johnson‚Äôs relationship.
 

   See Full Web Article

articles.title: ‚ÄòD-Day Watches‚Äô Made From WWII Helmets ‚Äî And Beach Sand From Normandy
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Col&MacArthur, a luxury watchmaker founded in 2013, is launching a commemorative collection honoring D-Day in 1944 by crafting watches from actual US Army M-1 helmets and haversacks, as well as sand from Normandy beaches. The watches, including a premium Legacy edition and a standard version, aim not to tell time but to provide a tangible, emotional connection to history. The brand sources materials ethically and respectfully, navigating legal hurdles like sand collection laws in France and moral questions about using potentially blood-stained military items. Col&MacArthur's broader mission is to preserve historical memory through physical artifacts, a tradition seen in earlier collections such as those based on World War I and the Apollo missions. The project reflects both a growing public interest in historical memory and the complex ethical questions surrounding the use and repurposing of military relics.
keyTakeAways: Col&MacArthur‚Äôs Normandie 1944 watches are made from real WWII US Army M-1 helmets and haversacks, as well as sand from Normandy beaches, blending history and craftsmanship.
The watches are not primarily about timekeeping but about emotional and historical connection, allowing consumers to engage with the memory of D-Day and WWII.
The brand faces ethical concerns, including the use of potentially blood-stained haversack material and legal restrictions on collecting beach sand in France.
Col&MacArthur has a precedent of using rare and tangible historical materials ‚Äî like Pearl Harbor water and moon dust ‚Äî in its commemorative watches.

The company is committed to authenticity and historical respect, and may face criticism for repurposing military artifacts, yet believes these actions preserve memory and prevent artifacts from being lost to storage.

articles.content:
The ‚ÄòD-Day watches‚Äô made from WWII helmets ‚Äî and beach sand from Normandy 
       
  By Oscar Holland, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:55 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  In an age when clocks are found in most pockets and on every screen, watchmaker Col&MacArthur‚Äôs selling point is not just time, but history itself.
 

   
  Known for using unconventional materials ‚Äî from Pearl Harbor seawater to meteorite moondust ‚Äî in the name of horological storytelling, the brand is now commemorating the  D-Day landings  with a series of watches made from US soldiers‚Äô helmets and haversacks, as well as sand from the beaches of Normandy.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPeople are not buying this watch because it tells the time,‚Äù the company‚Äôs CEO S√©bastien Colen said on a call from Belgium, where the former energy executive co-founded the company in 2013. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs because it is bringing them back somewhere in the past.‚Äù
 

   
  Colen had spent three years developing a prototype for his Normandie 1944, a luxury watch featuring metal from an M-1, the standard-issue helmet used by the US Army during World War II. Sourced from a military memorabilia trader in Dallas, Texas, the helmet was flattened in a press, rather than with a hammer, to preserve its original markings and imperfections. The resulting metal sheet was then cut into circles that can be incorporated into dials and inserted in the watches‚Äô 43-millimeter cases at the brand‚Äôs studio in Li√®ge, Belgium.
 

   
  The pieces are being produced to order, meaning the number of helmets required depends on how many are sold. (One M-1 contains enough metal for ‚Äúabout 20‚Äù watches, Colen said.) The watchmaker is currently accepting orders via a Kickstarter  campaign , which has raised over $86,000 at the time of publication.
 

   
  Elsewhere, the design features a small capsule of Normandy sand and a strap made from an M-1928 haversack, the backpacks widely used by the US Army during World War II. The dial displays a historical map of Omaha Beach, a codename given to one of the five landing areas ‚Äî alongside Utah, Gold, Juno and Sword Beaches ‚Äî used by Allied troops on D-Day.
 

   
  Operation Neptune, as it is also known, was the largest amphibious invasion in history, marking a major turning point in the war. The M-1 was worn by the vast majority of the 73,000 US troops who landed in Normandy ‚Äî either on the beaches or as airborne troops ‚Äî on June 6,1944. The helmets‚Äô one-size-fits-all design comprised a manganese steel outer shell and an adjustable inner lining that was attached to a leather chinstrap.
 

   
  In the absence of markings identifying the wearer, it is often impossible to trace individual helmets to specific soldiers or battles. And although Col&MacArthur cannot guarantee that each M-1 helmet it uses was worn during the D-Day landings, certificates of authenticity from the dealer, Gustafsons, confirm that they were used during the wider liberation of Europe.
 

   
  Col&MacArthur will produce two versions of the watch, the varying prices reflecting differences in their internal mechanisms. The premium ‚ÄúLegacy‚Äù edition (priced at $1,749 and limited to a symbolic run of 1,944 units) features a Swiss-made movement, while the standard version (priced at $699) uses a cheaper Japanese movement.
 

   
    Ethical quandaries
 

   
  Colen came up with the idea while at Belgium‚Äôs Ciney Militaria, one of the world‚Äôs largest military collectibles fairs. He then visited Normandy to speak to locals and familiarize himself with the landings‚Äô geographical context. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very important that we go on site, to feel it,‚Äù he explained.
 

   
  Unlike the helmets and haversacks, the sand presented a legal hurdle: Taking sand from any French beach is  prohibited  by law. Normandy‚Äôs D-day sites are commonly targeted by souvenir-seekers (France‚Äôs Ministry of Culture has meanwhile asked UNESCO to afford them World Heritage status), and although authorities tolerate people taking small amounts for personal use, doing so at scale or for commercial purposes can attract fines of 1,500 euros ($1,724).
 

   
  Colen instead sought permission from a local mayor, whose office advised him to collect sand that had naturally blown from Sword Beach onto a neighboring road. ‚ÄúIf we want to respect the memory, it‚Äôs very important that we do these things properly,‚Äù Colen said.
 

   
  Other ethical considerations will arise as the watches go into production. Among them is the question of whether to use stained parts of the haversacks ‚Äî possibly containing blood ‚Äî on the straps‚Äô reverse side, or to cut around them entirely. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tricky, because some people could be offended. But on the other hand, for me, it‚Äôs something that‚Äôs very important to show,‚Äù Colen said, without offering a definitive answer to how he will approach this dilemma. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a question of authenticity.‚Äù
 

   
  Then there is the wider moral question of whether historical artifacts should ever be intentionally destroyed. M-1 helmets were mass produced, with over 20 million made between 1941 and 1945 ‚Äî and they are relatively common on the collectors‚Äô market, where they typically fetch hundreds, rather than thousands, of dollars each. But Colen understands why people might criticize his decision to recycle them into luxury items.
 

   
  ‚ÄúEvery time we do a project, we really question ourselves, ‚ÄòIs it is it respectful?‚Äô‚Äù he said, before referencing Winston Churchill‚Äôs quote that those who ‚Äúfail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is exactly what is happening today,‚Äù he argued. ‚ÄúSo, instead of having a helmet sitting in a warehouse, it‚Äôs on a watch, it‚Äôs providing emotion and it‚Äôs reminding us, every single day, of events of the past.‚Äù
 

   
    ‚ÄòTangible‚Äô memories
 

   
  Col&MacArthur‚Äôs short history is rooted in British, rather than American, military tradition. Originally a collaboration between Colen and former British serviceman Iain Wood, the company was founded 12 years ago to produce watches for the country‚Äôs Scots Guards, the latter‚Äôs erstwhile regiment. The pair later designed pieces for various regiments of the Royal Guards, the sentries protecting Buckingham Palace and St James‚Äôs Palace in London.
 

   
  In 2017, Col&MacArthur began work on a line of watches marking the centenary of World War I ‚Äî one of which was presented to French president Emmanuel Macron. The watch‚Äôs success heralded a pivot towards timepieces centered on major historical figures and events. ‚ÄúWithout knowing at the time, I was already working on our first commemorative watches,‚Äù Colen said.
 

   
  In the years since, the watchmaker has released collections based on more than a dozen themes, from Leonardo da Vinci to the Battle of Britain. Many of them contain ‚Äútangible‚Äù artifacts, including moon dust from a lunar meteorite (used in watches dedicated to the Apollo 11 mission) and water from Pearl Harbor (trapped between sapphire crystals in watches commemorating the Japanese attack on America‚Äôs naval base there in 1941).
 

   
  If its latest crowdfunding campaign exceeds $100,000, Col&MacArthur will start putting money toward its next collection: timepieces memorializing the Battle of the Bulge, Nazi Germany‚Äôs last campaign on the Western Front. Colen plans to incorporate fragments of a shell, dropped on the Belgian city of Bastogne, into the watches‚Äô design.
 

   
  ‚ÄúFor every single watch, we really try to integrate something unique,‚Äù he said.

articles.title: Alex Ovechkin becomes first player to score 900 career goals in NHL history
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Alex Ovechkin, the NHL's all-time leading scorer, became the first player in history to reach 900 career goals during a game against the St. Louis Blues at Capital One Arena on November 5, 2025. The goal, scored just over two minutes into the second period on a backhand rebound off goalie Jordan Binnington, marked a historic milestone achieved at age 40. The achievement, celebrated by fans and the Capitals' mascot Slapshot, highlights Ovechkin's enduring legacy in hockey, including his record of 20 goals in 20 consecutive seasons and a Stanley Cup win in 2018. Although Ovechkin downplayed the emotional impact, he emphasized the importance of continuing to play well. The Capitals will honor him ahead of their next game against the Winnipeg Jets, affirming his status as one of the greatest players in NHL history.
keyTakeAways: Alex Ovechkin became the first player in NHL history to score 900 career goals, achieving the milestone in a game against the St. Louis Blues on November 5, 2025.
The goal came just over two minutes into the second period, following a backhand rebound off goalie Jordan Binnington.
Ovechkin, 40 years old, played his entire NHL career with the Washington Capitals and is the league‚Äôs all-time leading scorer.
The milestone was celebrated with fan enthusiasm and a special sign held by the Capitals‚Äô mascot, Slapshot.
Binnington initially tried to keep the puck in his pants after the goal, but an official intervened and returned it to the linesman.
Ovechkin downplayed the emotional weight of the achievement, emphasizing his focus on playing well and continuing to compete.
Ovechkin has 13 All-Star appearances, three league MVP awards, and is among the greatest players in NHL history, including being named one of the 100 best NHL players of all time.
He led the Capitals to a Stanley Cup victory in 2018 and has nine seasons with 50+ goals, including a career-high of 65 in 2007‚Äì08.
He is one of only two players in NHL history to record 20 goals in 20 consecutive seasons (with Gordie Howe).
The Washington Capitals plan to honor Ovechkin prior to their game against the Winnipeg Jets on November 26, 2025.
