articles.content:
Alex Ovechkin becomes first player to score 900 career goals in NHL history 
       
  By Jacob Lev, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        11:23 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Alex Ovechkin is no stranger to making history.
 

   
  The  NHL‚Äôs all-time leading scorer  has been swimming in uncharted waters for a little under a year and on Wednesday, he finally found land ‚Äì in the 900 goal club.
 

   
  The 40-year-old Russian became the first player to reach the mark in the Washington Capitals‚Äô game against the St. Louis Blues on Wednesday at the Capital One Arena in Washington, DC.
 

   
  Just over two minutes into the second period, Ovechkin backhanded a rebound off Blues goalie Jordan Binnington for his milestone goal.
 

   
  As the arena goal horn blared and the fans went berserk, Ovechkin swung his arms into the air and collided with the boards as his teammates cleared the bench to celebrate with him.
 

   
  While the celebration didn‚Äôt match the ones that followed after Ovechkin broke Wayne Gretzky‚Äôs career record with his 895th goal in April, the team‚Äôs mascot, Slapshot, held up a big sign with ‚Äú900‚Äù written on it along with confetti.
 

   
  After the goal, the TNT broadcast showed Binnington apparently stuffing the milestone puck into his hockey pants but an official confronted him. Binnington would give the puck to the linesman. The 32-year-old allowed two more goals in the period before being pulled out of the game by Blues head coach Jim Montgomery for backup goalie Joel Hofer.
 

   
  Ovechkin told reporters after the game that he often thought about the feat when recanting on being asked about it by someone in a conversation.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOf course, it‚Äôs a huge number. No one ever did it in NHL history,‚Äù Ovechkin said. ‚ÄúTo be the first player, its a special moment. So, its nice that it‚Äôs over and it‚Äôs nice to get it at home so the fans and family can be here and yeah, its pretty cool.‚Äù
 

   
  Ovechkin downplayed the notion that a ‚Äúweight from his shoulders‚Äù had been lifted upon achieving the miletone.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI just try to play the game, try to do best as I can. 13 or 14 games, you got plenty of games left. Of course you are going to score one goal, maybe an empty net or whatever. But yeah, its nice to get it done,‚Äù he added.
 

   
  Coming into his 21st season in the league, Ovechkin needed three goals to become the inaugural member of the 900 club.
 

   
  He has played all of his NHL seasons with Washington, leading the team to its only Stanley Cup win in 2018. Earlier this year, he joined Gordie Howe as  the only NHL players  in history to rack up 20 goals in 20 straight seasons.
 

   
  Ovechkin has also amassed nine seasons of 50+ goals ‚Äì including a career-high 65 in 2007-08 ‚Äìbeen named an All-Star 13 times, league MVP three times, and in 2017 was honored as one of the best 100 NHL players of all time.
 

   
  A year later, he  lifted the Stanley Cup  for the first time as the Capitals dispatched the expansion Las Vegas Golden Knights in five games.
 

   
  After last season, Ovechkin was  noncommittal  if this year would be his last in the league.
 

   
  ‚ÄúTo be honest with you, I haven‚Äôt thought about it yet. But we‚Äôll see what‚Äôs going to happen. Obviously, I‚Äôm going to do my best to be able to do well next year and ‚Ä¶ we‚Äôll see,‚Äù he said following the team‚Äôs elimination in the playoffs.
 

   
  During Wednesday‚Äôs postgame press conference, Ovechkin reiterated there are a lot of games left in the season and ‚Äúwe will see what will happen.‚Äù
 

   
  Ovechkin now has eight points on the year despite the Capitals‚Äô disappointing start to the 2025-2026 campaign. Washinton went on to win 6-1 to move up in the Metropolitan Division standings.
 

   
  The Capitals said they will honor Ovechkin prior to the team‚Äôs home game against the Winnipeg Jets on November 26.

articles.title: Border Patrol Agent Appears to Brag About Shooting Chicago Woman Five Times in Text Messages, Court Reveals
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A Customs and Border Protection agent, Charles Exum, allegedly bragged in text messages to fellow agents about shooting Chicago woman Marimar Martinez five times, resulting in seven bullet holes, after a car collision. The defense claims the incident was a minor accident and that Exum‚Äôs conduct violates federal use-of-force policies, with evidence suggesting the government mishandled the vehicle‚Äîallowing it to be driven over 1,000 miles to Maine and undergoing mechanical work‚Äîpotentially destroying or altering evidence. The case has drawn national attention, with U.S. District Judge Georgia Alexakis expressing skepticism over inconsistencies in the government‚Äôs narrative, including contradictory statements about the vehicle‚Äôs status and who authorized its removal. The government maintains it preserved relevant evidence, but the defense and judge have raised concerns about bad faith or prejudicial influence on the investigation, leading to a court-ordered return of the vehicle to Chicago with strict preservation rules.
keyTakeAways: Border Patrol agent Charles Exum allegedly bragged in text messages to fellow agents about shooting Marimar Martinez five times, resulting in seven bullet holes, suggesting a lack of concern for proportionality in force usage.
The government‚Äôs decision to release Exum‚Äôs vehicle and allow it to travel more than 1,000 miles to Maine raised concerns about evidence destruction and the potential for tampering.
The vehicle was eventually returned to Chicago under court order, but defense attorneys claim they were not allowed to fully examine or touch the vehicle due to restrictive access.

Judge Georgia Alexakis expressed skepticism over inconsistencies in the government‚Äôs narrative, including contradictory statements about whether the vehicle was a personal or official asset, and the approval of mechanical work.
The case highlights a broader tension between federal law enforcement accountability and the handling of physical evidence in high-profile incidents involving use of force.
The defense argues that the government may have acted in bad faith or influenced the evidence by releasing and altering the vehicle, undermining fairness in the legal process.

articles.content:
Border Patrol agent appeared to brag about his accuracy after shooting Chicago woman five times, messages in court reveal 
       
  By Omar Jimenez, Elizabeth Wolfe, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        9:16 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A Customs and Border Protection agent appeared to brag to fellow agents about his marksmanship after he repeatedly  shot a Chicago woman  following a collision between their cars, text messages shown in court revealed.
 

   
  The woman, Marimar Martinez, is accused of closely pursuing the agent and ramming into his car. But her defense attorney has alleged the opposite, saying it was actually the agent who sideswiped Martinez.
 

   
  Text messages from the agent, Charles Exum, were displayed in court Wednesday as Martinez‚Äôs defense attorney sought to prove his claim  the government potentially destroyed evidence  that may have supported the defense when it released Exum‚Äôs damaged vehicle and allowed the agent to drive it more than 1,000 miles to his home state of Maine.
 

   
  Criminal defense attorney Christopher Parente pointed to the messages as an indication Exum understood the high public scrutiny of the case and would have recognized the potential evidentiary value of this vehicle.
 

   
  As the case grasped the attention of national media and the public, Exum sent an  article from The Guardian  on October 7 to a group of other agents, which quoted Parente saying Martinez had ‚Äúseven holes in her body from five shots from this agent.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúRead it. 5 shots, 7 holes,‚Äù Exum said in the next text.
 

   
  When Parente pressed him on what he meant, Exum responded he was a firearms instructor. He said, ‚ÄúI take pride in my shooting skills.‚Äù
 

   
  Another message to the group read, ‚ÄúI have a MOF amendment to add to my story. I fired 5 rounds, and she had 7 holes. Put that in your book boys.‚Äù
 

   
  Exum explained to the judge MOF is a ‚ÄúMiserable Old F**ker‚Äù who is always trying to one up someone wherever possible.
 

   
  It‚Äôs unclear what exactly he was responding to because the text conversations were redacted when presented to the court.
 

   
  When asked to explain the text, Exum said, ‚ÄúThat means illegal actions have legal consequences.‚Äù
 

   
  Exum defended his use of force against Martinez, saying his life was at risk and ‚ÄúI did what I had to do.‚Äù
 

   
  Later, he noted Border Patrol agents consider ‚Äútransferred intent‚Äù when deciding whether to use force, meaning, for example, whatever was done to an agent‚Äôs vehicle is considered as intent to do the same to the agent. The agent‚Äôs responding use of force needed to be proportionate, he said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis incident is so unlike anything we have trained for,‚Äù Exum told the judge. He said it was something one might see in ‚Äúcartel-controlled‚Äù areas of the world, not on American streets.
 

   
  He did not elaborate further. Parente, a former federal prosecutor, has often described the incident leading up to the shooting as nothing more than a minor car accident.
 

   
  Martinez, a 30-year-old American citizen, and her co-defendant, Anthony Ruiz ‚Äì who was driving a different vehicle ‚Äì have been accused by federal prosecutors of ‚Äúaggressively and erratically‚Äù following and then ramming Exum and other agents inside his vehicle who were on security detail in Chicago.
 

   
  Martinez and Ruiz allegedly drove within inches of the Border Patrol car, at times running red lights and driving in the wrong lane as they pursued the agent, according to an affidavit filed by an FBI agent.
 

   
  Martinez and Ruiz were present in court Wednesday and both have entered not guilty pleas to a federal charge of assaulting, resisting or impeding federal officers.
 

   
  When Parente asked whether Exum was ever concerned his conduct could have violated CBP policy, Exum responded, ‚ÄúNot in the slightest.‚Äù
 

   
    FBI decided the car didn‚Äôt need to be preserved as evidence
 

   
  Though one might expect hearings in the case to focus on what happened in the moments leading up to the collision, Wednesday instead focused on what happened afterward ‚Äì and what, exactly, the government did with Exum‚Äôs car.
 

   
  US District Judge Georgia Alexakis expressed skepticism Wednesday over why the cars of the two drivers charged in the case ‚Äì Martinez and Ruiz ‚Äì have been kept in Chicago as evidence, while the Border Patrol agent‚Äôs car was released and allowed to travel normally.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhat gives me great pause is the fact the cars have been treated differently,‚Äù Alexakis said.
 

   
  Government attorneys defended federal agents‚Äô decisions, saying the FBI had preserved any evidence they believed was relevant before releasing the car back onto the street.
 

   
  On the day of the crash, the FBI collected pictures of the car‚Äôs exterior, paint samples and other evidence, according to an affidavit filed by the Justice Department. The vehicle was given back to Exum that evening, and he was not told to preserve the car in any way, he said.
 

   
  For the next three days, Exum drove the car around Chicago as he finished his rotation in the city, according to the affidavit. He also met with the FBI and US Attorney‚Äôs Office, and data was downloaded from his car, he said.
 

   
  On October 8 ‚Äì four days after the crash ‚Äì he drove the SUV back to Maine and parked it in a secure Border Patrol garage. There, a mechanic began repairs on the car, but was ordered to stop because of the ongoing court arguments over the car.
 

   
  About a week after returning to Maine, Exum said an FBI agent called and said they may need to retrieve the car, the agent said. Though Exum initially told the FBI he did not believe any work had been done to the car, he later found out a mechanic had buffed scuff marks off of it.
 

   
  Exum said he sent an email to his chain of command that his vehicle may have evidentiary value and it was not to be worked on.
 

   
  Exum‚Äôs supervisor said he approved mechanical work on the vehicle because he believed all evidence had been collected in Chicago, the agent testified.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf they needed it as evidence, I did not think they would have released it from the investigation, had you drive three days all the way back to Maine, possibly destroying some of that evidence along the way, if they still needed it,‚Äù the supervisor wrote in an email sent to Exum on October 17 and shown in court.
 

   
  But the judge, Alexakis, said the government clearly believed the vehicle could be exculpatory evidence, otherwise it would not have gone through the trouble to preserve records on the car.
 

   
  Alexakis ordered the government last month to return the SUV to Chicago ‚Äì this time on the back of a flatbed truck. No alteration should have been made ‚Äì not even a car wash ‚Äì before the defense could examine it.
 

   
  But Parente claims he has been blocked from fully examining the vehicle since it was returned.
 

   
  He and his expert were able to inspect the vehicle, he said Wednesday, but they were not allowed to get within two feet of it or touch it.
 

   
    Judge questions ‚Äògovernment narrative‚Äô
 

   
  Before moving forward with the hearing, Alexakis noted the government‚Äôs case has included some discrepancies and omissions that have caused her to tread carefully.
 

   
  She pointed out the Justice Department had previously said in court the agent took the SUV back to Maine because it was his ‚Äúpersonal vehicle,‚Äù then stated in a later court filing the car is part of an official Border Patrol fleet.
 

   
  The judge also noted she had not previously been told a mechanic had worked on the car, and also the government has given at least two different accounts of who approved the car‚Äôs removal to Maine.
 

   
  She acknowledged the government version of events may turn out to be true, ‚Äúbut I can‚Äôt accept that possibility at this juncture,‚Äù she said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe fact that these discrepancies are popping up cause me to question the narrative being put forward,‚Äù the judge said.
 

   
  Alexakis acknowledged the government was working under a tight time frame to relay information to the court but, she said, ‚Äúthe compressed time frame is a time frame of their own making.‚Äù
 

   
  Among the questions in front of her now, she said, is whether the government acted in bad faith or whether the evidence was influenced in a prejudicial manner.

articles.title: How Trump‚Äôs lawyer could pull off another surprise Supreme Court win for his boss
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump, who declined to attend a Supreme Court hearing on his sweeping tariffs, saw his lawyer D. John Sauer present a bold, policy-driven case asserting the president‚Äôs authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). Sauer relied heavily on the 1981 Dames & Moore precedent to argue that foreign affairs executive power grants broad latitude for emergency actions, including tariffs. While three liberal justices were skeptical of the emergency justification and the precedent, and several justices, including Amy Coney Barrett and Neil Gorsuch, raised serious legal and practical concerns about the use of tariffs, the case remains close. The tariffs have generated $90 billion in revenue but have disrupted global markets and increased costs for businesses and consumers. With lower courts having ruled against Trump and the momentum with the challengers, the final decision is expected to be made by Friday, with a full opinion drafting process beginning in the coming weeks. Sauer‚Äôs track record of successfully defending Trump in previous legal cases ‚Äî including securing immunity from criminal prosecution ‚Äî suggests a possible surprise win for the administration, though the Court‚Äôs final ruling will depend on a careful balance of constitutional interpretation, precedent, and economic realities.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump declined to attend the Supreme Court hearing on his tariffs, but his lawyer, D. John Sauer, presented the case using aggressive, policy-driven rhetoric reminiscent of Trump‚Äôs own language.

Sauer relied on the 1981 Dames & Moore v. Regan case to justify the president‚Äôs use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose tariffs, arguing that the power of the executive in foreign affairs is broad and presumptively valid.

Key justices, including Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan, and Ketanji Brown Jackson, expressed skepticism about whether the tariffs constitute a valid emergency under IEEPA, especially since such tariffs have never been used before.
Justice Amy Coney Barrett questioned whether the IEEPA text supports tariff-imposing authority, noting that previous applications of the law did not involve tariffs.

Chief Justice John Roberts expressed conflicting signals: initially skeptical of Sauer‚Äôs interpretation of Dames & Moore, yet acknowledged the effectiveness of the tariffs in foreign policy and their alignment with executive power in foreign affairs.

Justice Neil Gorsuch raised a hypothetical about imposing a 50% tariff on gas-powered vehicles for climate change, which Sauer dismissed as a 'hoax' ‚Äî highlighting the policy subjectivity and political framing of what constitutes a 'real crisis'.

Sauer has previously won a major legal victory for Trump by securing substantial immunity from criminal prosecution in 2024, suggesting a pattern of successful advocacy for the president‚Äôs executive actions.

The tariffs have generated $90 billion for the Treasury but have also caused economic disruption, increased costs for businesses, and harmed consumers, creating a significant legal and economic tension.
Lower courts have already ruled against Trump‚Äôs tariffs, and the momentum remains with the challengers ‚Äî including a New York wine importer, an Illinois toy maker, and a group of states.
The final decision is expected to be made by Friday, with a full opinion drafting process likely taking weeks.

articles.content:
How Trump‚Äôs lawyer could pull off another surprise Supreme Court win for his boss 
       
  By Joan¬†Biskupic, CNN Chief Supreme Court Analyst
 

       
Updated: 
        4:00 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  President Donald Trump, who has declared it a matter of ‚ÄúLIFE OR DEATH,‚Äù opted against attending  Wednesday‚Äôs Supreme Court hearing  over his billion-dollar tariffs, but his lawyer presented the case in similarly audacious terms.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPresident Trump determined that our exploding trade deficits had brought us to the brink of an economic and national security catastrophe,‚Äù US Solicitor General D. John Sauer said, layering his arguments with warnings about the ‚Äúruthless trade retaliation‚Äù and ‚Äúruinous economic and national security consequences‚Äù Americans   would face if the court struck down Trump‚Äôs tariffs.
 

   
  Sauer exhibited his usual rapid-paced, overconfident style at the courtroom lectern as he seemed to channel Trump. He faced considerable skepticism from justices for his assertion of unilateral tariff power, yet key justices also poked holes in the challengers‚Äô arguments.
 

   
  At the end of nearly three hours of intense argument ‚Äì in which Sauer was twice encouraged to slow down ‚Äì the case appeared close. Lower courts have ruled against Trump, and the momentum remains with the challengers: a New York-based wine importer, Illinois educational-toy maker and a group of states.
 

   
  All three of the liberal justices (Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan and Ketanji Brown Jackson) looked ready to strike down the sweeping tariffs, and three of the six conservatives voiced reservations.
 

   
  Yet Sauer has previously pulled out surprising results, as in 2024 when, serving then as Trump‚Äôs personal lawyer, he won him substantial immunity from criminal prosecution.
 

   
  Whatever the majority view when the justices left the elevated bench Wednesday, important negotiations and their own internal advocacy will now occur behind closed doors. If past practice holds, the nine justices will vote on Friday in a small room off the chambers of Chief Justice John Roberts and then begin drafting opinions, a process likely to take weeks.
 

   
  Roberts, who is apt to want to write the opinion for the court in a case of this magnitude, sent conflicting signals. At the outset, he questioned Sauer‚Äôs interpretation of a  1981 case the administration has highlighted  and likened the imposition of tariffs to the regulation of taxes, ‚Äúcore‚Äù powers of Congress under the Constitution.
 

   
  But Roberts also undercut part of lawyer Neal Katyal‚Äôs arguments on behalf of the small businesses suing the administration for the tariffs that have brought the US Treasury an estimated $90 billion while upending global markets and, in the US, hiking costs for businesses and hurting consumers.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe tariffs are a tax, and that‚Äôs a core power of Congress. But they‚Äôre a foreign-facing tax, right? And foreign affairs is a core power of the executive,‚Äù Roberts told Katyal. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt think you can dismiss the consequences.‚Äù
 

   
  Roberts also observed that the tariffs, which the justices allowed to remain in effect as the litigation continued, have proved their usefulness to Trump in foreign affairs.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOne thing is quite clear, is that the foreign-facing tariffs ‚Ä¶ were quite effective in achieving a particular objective,‚Äù Roberts said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you can just separate it. When you say, ‚ÄòWell, this is a tax, Congress‚Äô power,‚Äô it implicates very directly the president‚Äôs foreign affairs power.‚Äù
 

   
  Justice Amy Coney Barrett, another of the skeptical conservatives who could be a decisive vote against Trump, suggested at points that she was inclined to find the administration had exceeded its authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.
 

   
  IEEPA, as the 1977 law is known, has previously been used to impose economic penalties but has never been used for tariffs. By its text, the law authorizes the president to ‚Äúregulate ‚Ä¶ importation‚Äù of goods to deal with a national emergency arising from an ‚Äúunusual and extraordinary threat‚Äù to the national security, foreign policy or economy of the US.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCan you point to any place in the code ‚Äì or any other time in history ‚Äì where that phrase, together ‚Äòregulate importation‚Äô has been used to confer tariff imposing authority?‚Äù Barrett asked Sauer.
 

   
  He offered several examples, but Barrett sounded unconvinced; she remarked, ‚ÄúNone of those cases talked about it as conferring tariff authority.‚Äù
 

   
  Yet, like Roberts, she expressed doubts about some of Katyal‚Äôs claims. She homed in on the potential difficulty of unwinding the billions of dollars collected under potentially invalid tariffs.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf you win, tell me how the reimbursement process would work. Would it be a complete mess?‚Äù Barrett said, adding, ‚ÄúIt seems to me like it could be a mess.‚Äù
 

   
    The president‚Äôs voice in the courtroom
 

   
  At the lectern in the well of the courtroom, Sauer wears the traditional somber gray morning coat but cuts a pugnacious figure. He has a distinctive gravelly voice and a forceful style, gesturing with both hands, leaning in, his shoulders rising as he speaks. A former college wrestling champion (at Duke University), he also was a Rhodes scholar and attended Harvard law school before serving as a  clerk to the late Justice Antonin Scalia .
 

   
  In Sauer‚Äôs arguments, it is often difficult to draw a line between policy declarations and legal reasoning.
 

   
  Before the dispute reached the justices, Sauer sent a letter to a US appeals court asking that the tariffs remain in place during the litigation, mimicking one of the president‚Äôs oft-used rhetorical phrases.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOne year ago, the United States was a dead country, and now, because of the trillions of dollars being paid by countries that have so badly abused us, America is a strong, financially viable, and respected country again,‚Äù Sauer wrote.
 

   
  A few weeks later, as he appealed the case to the Supreme Court, Sauer attributed that ‚Äúdead country‚Äù declaration to Trump.
 

   
  Sauer, who will turn 51 next week, has been in sync with Trump since he began defending him in late 2023 during Trump‚Äôs personal battle against charges brought by special counsel Jack Smith. Trump was accused of election fraud, conspiracy and other offenses in protest of the valid results that gave the 2020 presidential election to Joe Biden. Sauer persuaded the Supreme Court to give Trump substantial immunity, and the case never went to trial.
 

   
  After Trump won reelection, one year ago Wednesday, he named Sauer to the prestigious post of US solicitor general, the federal government‚Äôs top lawyer before the Supreme Court.
 

   
  Sauer has already argued at the high court on behalf of the administration, but Wednesday‚Äôs hearing over the centerpiece of Trump‚Äôs economic agenda marks the most important appearance to date of Trump‚Äôs second term.
 

   
  In his written brief and as he began in person on Wednesday, Sauer leaned heavily on a 1981 case, Dames & Moore v. Regan, in which the justices upheld President Jimmy Carter‚Äôs reliance on IEEPA to use frozen Iranian assets as a ‚Äúbargaining chip‚Äù to win the release of 52 American hostages.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIn Dames & Moore against Regan, this Court held that IEEPA‚Äôs sweeping and unqualified language grants the President‚Äôs actions the strongest presumption of validity and the widest latitude of judicial interpretation,‚Äù Sauer said.
 

   
  That Dames & Moore decision was  written by then-Justice William Rehnquist  in a session when Roberts happened to be a law clerk to Rehnquist.
 

   
  And the chief justice   seemed eager to set Sauer straight on the limited reach of the case.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCounsel, you ‚Äì you‚Äôve already mentioned Dames & Moore three times, which surprises me a little because the court in Dames & Moore went out of its way to say that it was issuing a very narrow decision it pretty much expected to apply only in this case,‚Äù Roberts said, going on to list a few choice phrases from the decision explaining exactly that.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMaybe I can put it this way,‚Äù Sauer rejoined. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt dispute that Dames & Moore is, as you state, a narrow opinion. However, it addressed certain principles that we think are equally applicable here.‚Äù
 

   
  Among those principles, Sauer argued, is that the president‚Äôs IEEPA power is vast, and that actions in the realm of foreign affairs should be presumed valid.
 

   
    What is a real crisis, anyway?
 

   
  Justices on the left and right questioned the administration‚Äôs assertion of an emergency arising from an ‚Äúunusual and extraordinary‚Äù threat ,  since trade deficits have existed for decades and no other president has sought to impose tariffs under the IEEPA.
 

   
  Justice Neil Gorsuch, the third conservative who sounded dubious of Sauer‚Äôs positions, queried how far the Trump view of a threat could take the administration. And he did it with a hypothetical that, first, induced Sauer to try to find common ground with Gorsuch.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCould the President impose a 50-percent tariff on gas-powered cars and auto parts to deal with the unusual and extraordinary threat from abroad of climate change?‚Äù asked Gorsuch, raising a scenario that could occur with an administration with progressive priorities.
 

   
  Responded Sauer, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very likely that that could be done, very likely.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think that has to be the logic of your view,‚Äù Gorsuch said.
 

   
  But then Sauer, hewing once more to Trump policy, interjected: ‚ÄúI mean, obviously, this administration would say that‚Äôs a hoax, not a real crisis.‚Äù
 

   
  Gorsuch‚Äôs retort: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you would.‚Äù

articles.title: Federal Judge Extends Order Blocking Trump From Deploying National Guard to Portland
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A U.S. District Court judge, Karin Immergut, extended her order blocking President Donald Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, citing a lack of credible evidence that protests reached an out-of-control state or constituted a 'rebellion' under federal law. The ruling, based on trial testimony, found that violent incidents were isolated and primarily between protesters and counter-protesters, with no organized armed hostilities. The decision upholds the Tenth Amendment by affirming that federal action infringes on state sovereignty and constitutes constitutional harm. Despite arguments from federal officials that protesters engaged in 'disturbingly intrusive' behavior, state and city attorneys maintained that local law enforcement could handle the situation. The case highlights broader tensions over presidential authority, state rights, and the use of federal military power in domestic unrest, with the Ninth Circuit now reconsidering its prior ruling en banc, ensuring continued legal restrictions on troop deployment.
keyTakeAways: A federal judge extended her order blocking President Donald Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, citing lack of evidence of out-of-control protests or a legal basis for federalization.
The ruling emphasized that the protests were largely sporadic and involved no organized armed rebellion, thus failing to meet the legal threshold for National Guard deployment under federal law.
The decision reaffirmed the principle of state sovereignty under the Tenth Amendment, finding that federal action infringed on Oregon‚Äôs autonomy.
Evidence of isolated violent incidents between protesters and counter-protesters was presented, but not sufficient to justify deployment under the legal definition of a 'rebellion'.

Federal agencies claimed protesters engaged in 'disturbingly intrusive behavior' and 'organized violence,' while state officials argued that local law enforcement could handle the situation and that federal deployment inflamed tensions.
Protests at the ICE facility resulted in nearly 250 arrests between June and October, with disputes over whether force used by federal agents was disproportionate.
A key trial revelation was that National Guard troops were present at the ICE facility even after a judicial order prohibited their presence, indicating potential disregard for court orders.
State and city officials argued that the deployment of troops was an unconstitutional infringement on state sovereignty and a politically charged escalation.
The Ninth Circuit‚Äôs decision to reconsider the case en banc means that the Trump administration remains legally blocked from deploying troops, despite earlier rulings allowing it.
The case raises broader constitutional questions about presidential authority to deploy National Guard forces in cities under Democratic leadership.

articles.content:
Federal judge extends order blocking Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland 
       
  By Danya Gainor, Karina Tsui, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        8:55 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A judge has extended her order blocking President Donald Trump from deploying any National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, until Friday ‚Äì keeping soldiers in the city in limbo as the legal showdown over presidential power continues.
 

   
  US District Court Judge Karin Immergut‚Äôs decision on Sunday followed a three-day trial that saw arguments over whether the Trump administration violated the law by federalizing and trying to deploy Oregon and California troops to Portland.
 

   
  The legal saga over the balance of presidential and state power has seen numerous twists and turns as it unfolded in both the district court and before appeals judges.
 

   
  The ruling comes as the Trump administration faces challenges over its power to send National Guard troops into Democratic-led cities. A federal court last month  blocked the deployment  of National Guard troops in Chicago. And last week the  Supreme Court  took the rare step of asking for additional briefing in that high-profile case.
 

   
  National Guard troops have been staging at Portland training bases for weeks while the legal case plays out, having been activated to protect federal officials and an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility that has been  the focal point  of daily protests since June.
 

   
  Federal attorneys have argued it‚Äôs within Trump‚Äôs presidential authority to respond to the daily protests outside the facility that have subjected the building and its agents to what it described as coordinated violence.
 

   
  But state and city attorneys called the move ‚Äúone of the most significant infringements‚Äù on Oregon‚Äôs sovereignty in the state‚Äôs history and argued the Trump administration is dramatically misrepresenting the situation and risking inflaming tensions.
 

   
  The order from Immergut, a  Trump appointee  from his first term, says the federal government was unable to show the situation in Portland was out of control or federal officers were unable to do their jobs.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBased on the trial testimony, this Court finds no credible evidence that during the approximately two months before the President‚Äôs federalization order, protests grew out of control or involved more than isolated and sporadic instances of violent conduct that resulted in no serious injuries to federal personnel,‚Äù her order reads.
 

   
    Judge says protests do not justify a National Guard deployment
 

   
  Immergut preliminarily   ruled the federal government‚Äôs deployment of the National Guard in Oregon exceeded its legal authority, violated the Tenth Amendment by infringing on state sovereignty, did not meet the legal definition of a ‚Äúrebellion,‚Äù and caused ongoing constitutional harm that justified immediate judicial intervention.
 

   
  She noted the trial testimony ‚Äúincluded evidence of sporadic isolated instances of violent behavior toward federal officers and property damage to a single building,‚Äù but those incidents do not appear to be backed by an ‚Äúorganized group engaged in armed hostilities for the purpose of overtaking an instrumentality of government by unlawful or antidemocratic means.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe majority of violence that did occur during this time period involved violence between protesters and counter-protesters and isolated sporadic incidents of low-level unlawful conduct,‚Äù the order read.
 

   
  Oregon has argued federal agents used ‚Äúdisproportionate‚Äù force against demonstrators, introducing surveillance video at the trial to support the claim.
 

   
  One exhibit appeared to show an agent running into a protester at full speed from behind and knocking the person to the ground. The August 13 video, provided to CNN by the Oregon Department of Justice, did not show the protester interacting with agents or any provocation immediately before being hit.
 

   
  DHS denied any allegations of its officers using excessive force in Portland.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOn August 13, DHS law enforcement made a targeted arrest of a dangerous rioter who previously evaded arrests. He has repeatedly assaulted law enforcement, throwing rocks and other objects at them, obstructed law enforcement by blocking the driveway, and refused to follow law enforcement commands outside the ICE facility in Portland. Law enforcement made the arrest from behind the rioter for their own safety in the case he was armed,‚Äù DHS said in a statement.
 

   
  Another video, from October 2, showed a protester who took a step across a line marking the ICE facility property immediately rushed by more than a dozen agents and taken into custody.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOn October 2, as seen in the video the woman clearly trespasses on federal property and is attempting to (impede) law enforcement by blocking a federal driveway,‚Äù the DHS statement continued.
 

   
  A government attorney argued at  trial  that protesters have exhibited ‚Äúdisturbingly intrusive behavior‚Äù and organized violence.
 

   
  Nearly 250 arrests were made or citations issued against protesters at the ICE building between early June and mid-October, according to the  FBI  and  Portland Police Bureau . It is not clear how many of those taken into custody have been charged with a crime.
 

   
  Meanwhile, a separate  Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals  decision allowing Trump to deploy the Oregon National Guard troops to Portland is being reconsidered ‚Äúen banc‚Äù by a broader 11-judge panel.  That case revolves around a now-frozen second order from Immergut that blocked the deployment of troops from Oregon. A date for the hearing was not set.
 

   
  While  400 soldiers  from Oregon and California together were federalized and sent to the greater Portland area, a Trump administration lawyer  said  in a previous hearing before the Ninth Circuit that the administration didn‚Äôt plan to deploy more than 200.
 

   
  Oregon and Portland officials jointly sued on September 28 after Trump declared he was sending National Guard troops to the city, and Immergut‚Äôs  two temporary orders  blocking those efforts closely followed.
 

   
  Then, the three-judge Ninth Circuit panel on October 20 issued a stay on Immergut‚Äôs first restraining order ‚Äî a ruling that could have paved the way for a deployment as the legal battle played out. But the decision to have a new set of appeals judges rehear the case meant that the Trump administration was still barred from deploying troops.
 

   
    Insights and surprises from the trial
 

   
  The October trial Immergut presided over featured a surprising revelation: National Guard troops were on the ground at Portland‚Äôs ICE facility earlier last month even after the judge ordered them not to show up.
 

   
  Though Immergut filed her restraining order at 3:40 p.m. PT on October 4, Justice Department attorney Eric Hamilton told her as many as 10 soldiers were at the facility until midnight. Earlier, his colleague Jean Lin had said the troops were there until 2 a.m.
 

   
  Hamilton argued it took time to implement the order. ‚ÄúMy clients were working to end the mission,‚Äù he added.
 

   
  The trial also provided insight on what federal and National Guard officials knew ‚Äì and didn‚Äôt know ‚Äì when Trump called for hundreds of troops to protect the ICE facility.
 

   
  Top officials charged with the safety of the Portland ICE facility were not consulted before Trump ordered National Guard troops to Portland in September, a deputy regional director for the Federal Protective Service, identified in court by the initials R.C., said.
 

   
  Testifying in court, R.C. stated he and his boss, the FPS regional director, were ‚Äúsurprised‚Äù by the order, which they had learned about on the news.   
 

   
  A fundamental disagreement from the trial was over how extreme the demonstrations were ‚Äì and whether local law enforcement can handle them.
 

   
  State and city attorneys argued a simmering protest scene only ramped up after Trump ordered Guard troops to enter Portland in late September, and while there had been ‚Äúsporadic and inexcusable crimes‚Äù along with peaceful protests, they were nothing existing law enforcement couldn‚Äôt handle.
 

   
  For months, the Trump administration has argued that federal agents face systematic disruption and assault from protesters which justifies a more forceful response.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt is a frequent occurrence for agitators to carry bats, improvised weapons and shields,‚Äù Hamilton told the court. Protesters have displayed ‚Äúdisturbingly intrusive behavior‚Äù and organized violence, he said.
 

   
   This story has been updated with additional information.

articles.title: Democrats emboldened by election results mobilize against centrists‚Äô emerging shutdown deal
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Following strong Democratic victories in the November 4, 2025, elections‚Äîincluding in Virginia‚Äîparty leaders are emboldened to resist a proposed shutdown deal with Republicans that lacks a binding commitment to extend enhanced Affordable Care Act subsidies. Sen. Bernie Sanders has led a push against centrist Democrats, warning that surrendering without gains would anger voters. Key Democratic figures, including Sen. Chris Murphy, Rep. Rosa DeLauro, and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, are pressuring their colleagues to maintain a firm stance, citing public sentiment and Trump‚Äôs own criticism of the shutdown as politically damaging. While a group of centrist Democrats and some Republicans are in private talks over a compromise involving temporary subsidy extensions and potential reforms, leaders like Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer remain resistant. Trump continues to pressure Republicans to end the shutdown, but GOP leaders are divided on his proposals, with concerns that he may push for extreme measures. The article underscores the growing tension between progressive and centrist Democrats and the uncertainty of whether a resolution will emerge before significant real-world harm continues to grow.
keyTakeAways: Democrats are emboldened by strong election night results, including in Virginia, to resist a shutdown deal with Republicans that lacks a commitment on health care expansion.

Sen. Bernie Sanders has publicly urged Democrats not to accept a compromise without a binding commitment from President Trump to sign a health care bill, citing voter backlash against yielding without gains.
A group of centrist Democrats, along with some Republicans, are engaged in private negotiations to end the 36-day government shutdown by extending enhanced Obamacare subsidies with potential reforms.

President Donald Trump has expressed political frustration over the shutdown's impact on GOP electoral outcomes, stating it was a negative factor for Republicans and warning of dire consequences if the shutdown continues.

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer remains noncommittal on publicly negotiating with Republicans, though he has acknowledged the need for discussions and agreed with Sanders on the need for Trump to engage in talks.
House GOP leadership, including Speaker Mike Johnson, is resistant to any compromise that does not include a firm commitment on health care or a binding legislative path.

Senate Democrats, including Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto, emphasize that no formal deal exists and that ongoing negotiations include discussions about limiting Trump‚Äôs ability to interfere with appropriations powers.
The political pressure is mounting on Senate Democrats to maintain a firm stance, especially given public sentiment and Trump‚Äôs own comments about the shutdown being politically damaging.
Despite some progress in negotiations, the path to a resolution remains uncertain, with party leaders divided and the risk of prolonged shutdowns continuing to grow as the crisis persists.

articles.content:
Democrats emboldened by election results mobilize against centrists‚Äô emerging shutdown deal 
       
  By Sarah Ferris, Manu Raju, Adam Cancryn, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        9:58 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Hours before the first major elections since  President Donald Trump‚Äôs  win last November, Sen. Bernie Sanders offered a stern warning for Democrats about the party‚Äôs closed-door talks to end the shutdown.
 

   
  Inside a tense, three-hour meeting at the Capitol on Tuesday, a fiery Sanders urged Democrats not to yield to Republicans without a real victory on health care. The Vermont independent was armed with fresh polling from a Democratic-aligned firm that showed voters would punish the party for giving up with nothing in return, according to a person familiar with his remarks.
 

   
  By Wednesday morning, Sanders and his colleagues in Congress pointed to Democrats‚Äô  blow-out victories  ‚Äî including in Virginia, a state with thousands of furloughed federal workers ‚Äî as the most powerful evidence yet they needed to keep fighting.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt would be very strange if on the heels of the American people rewarding Democrats for standing up and fighting, we surrendered without getting anything,‚Äù Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut said. ‚ÄúI think we are in an enormously strong position right now.‚Äù
 

   
  During a private call of House Democrats on Wednesday afternoon, lawmakers, including senior Rep. Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut, urged each other to call their centrist Senate colleagues directly to make the case against the emerging deal. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries signaled on the call that he was keeping the pressure on his Senate counterpart, according to two people familiar with the discussion. Outside Democratic groups, too, have swiftly mobilized to ramp up pressure on centrists.
 

   
  Emboldened Hill Democrats pointed to  jitters from Trump  himself, who privately told a group of Senate Republicans that their party was being ‚Äúkilled‚Äù politically by the shutdown. Trump said publicly that ‚Äúthe shutdown was a big factor, negative for the Republicans.‚Äù
 

   
  Some of his GOP allies in Congress agreed. Asked if he believed the shutdown hurt Republicans in the elections, Sen. Jim Justice told CNN: ‚ÄúLook, if you didn‚Äôt, you‚Äôre living in a cave. That‚Äôs all there‚Äôs to it. Of course, it did.‚Äù Justice added that everyday Americans are sitting there watching the shutdown saying, ‚Äú‚ÄòYou people are in control. Fix it.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  Democrats‚Äô election night romp has further scrambled Washington‚Äôs shutdown politics, with leaders of both parties now cautiously assessing their next steps as the pain continues to grow for millions of Americans.
 

   
  Yet it‚Äôs not clear if it will substantively shift the strategy of either side, including among the dozen or so centrist Democrats who are still actively engaging in talks with Republicans in a bid to end the record 36-day standoff before the election, potentially without the kind of clear commitment on health care that some Democrats are seeking.
 

   
  Democrats have made a push to extend soon-to-expire enhanced Affordable Care Act subsides central to the shutdown fight. The fear among some in the party now is that centrists will cut a deal with Republicans that won‚Äôt lock in an extension and will only provide for a vote over the issue with no guaranteed outcome.
 

   
  ‚ÄúLast night was a good night but it was one night of the year,‚Äù Sen. Mark Kelly of Arizona told CNN when asked about the elections, not answering directly if he would accept a promise of a health care vote. He noted that Democrats are discussing a ‚Äúreasonable path forward‚Äù with the GOP.
 

   
  Sen. Gary Peters, the retiring Democrat from Michigan, added that many in the party are ‚Äúfeeling very good that the messaging is getting through and Republicans are in a much weaker position today than they were yesterday.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel (it) changed a lot,‚Äù added Sen. John Hickenlooper of Colorado, referring to the outcome of Tuesday‚Äôs elections.
 

   
  As of Tuesday night, roughly a dozen Senate Democratic centrists had privately signaled they were open to the GOP‚Äôs proposed shutdown offramp ‚Äî which includes a future vote on extending the enhanced Obamacare subsidies. That group, along with a handful of Republicans, met all morning Wednesday and are still in intense negotiations over a deal that could lead to reopening the government, according to sources familiar with the effort. The timing of when a deal would be announced, and when any votes would occur, is still unclear.
 

   
  Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada stressed to CNN that there was ‚Äúno deal‚Äù yet and that discussions were ongoing on health care, adding there are also serious talks about constraining Trump on spending cuts. Party leadership, she said, is not directly involved in the talks.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think it has to be part of the discussion,‚Äù Cortez Masto, a member of appropriations panel, said of a push to restrain Trump‚Äôs ability to interfere with Congress‚Äôs power of the purse.
 

   
  There was at least some post-election movement: Some Senate Democrats involved in talks to end the shutdown sought to use their momentum ‚Äî as well as Trump‚Äôs shutdown comments at the White House ‚Äî to spur their Republican colleagues to support a compromise framework that would temporarily extend enhanced Obamacare subsidies with some reforms to reopen the government, two Democrats involved in the talks told CNN.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWith that it ends fast; without we stare at each other another week,‚Äù one of the sources said of the Obamacare compromise proposal.
 

   
  But that outcome, too, is unclear, with Speaker Mike Johnson and his leadership team fiercely resistant to the idea, according to multiple House GOP sources.
 

   
  The pressure is now ‚Äî again ‚Äî on Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, who‚Äôs been mum on his own stance in the talks. To increase that pressure, Sanders showed up Wednesday morning to Schumer‚Äôs press conference to listen in. Instead, he ended up taking the podium before the New York Democrat‚Äôs arrival to insist that the party take the right message away from election night.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhat people want is that the Democrats stand up and continue to fight,‚Äù Sanders said at his own impromptu press conference. He stressed that Schumer and Democrats can‚Äôt simply accept a promise: ‚ÄúThere has to be a commitment that the President of the United States is prepared to sign the bill.‚Äù
 

   
  Minutes later, when Schumer was pressed on whether he agrees with Sanders‚Äô position, he would not state his own, saying he isn‚Äôt going to negotiate in public.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe want, we must address the health care needs of the American people, the Republicans ‚Äògotta sit down and talk to us about it, and I agree with Bernie Sanders, the way to solve this is for Trump to sit down with Jeffries and I,‚Äù said Schumer, who also did not express a preference in Tuesday‚Äôs marathon lunch meeting of Senate Democrats, according to people familiar with the gathering.
 

   
  Sanders told CNN‚Äôs Kaitlan Collins on ‚ÄúThe Source‚Äù Wednesday night that him taking the podium ‚Äúwas not planned.‚Äù
 

   
  When asked if he was satisfied with Schumer‚Äôs remarks, Sanders said, ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôve got to go beyond just saying I want to meet.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúSure, you know, the president should be inviting Jeffries and Schumer into the White House to discuss it. But I think we‚Äôve got to lay out what we want,‚Äù Sanders said.
 

   
  It‚Äôs not yet clear if Trump‚Äôs frustration with the off-year elections will change his own strategy on the shutdown. Despite the president‚Äôs evident annoyance with the electoral outcomes, he‚Äôs signaled no new appetite for granting Democrats any additional concessions ‚Äî insisting instead that Senate Republicans should simply abolish the filibuster. GOP leaders have deemed that idea a nonstarter, in a rare split with Trump.
 

   
  Among more circumspect Trump advisers, there remained an overriding belief that moderate Democrats‚Äô desire to find an off-ramp would ultimately outweigh progressives‚Äô will to keep fighting.
 

   
  At most, one person close to the process predicted, Democrats would hold out long enough to take a final victory lap on the Sunday political shows before agreeing to a deal early next week.
 

   
  Still, Republicans acknowledged, the GOP is under increasing pressure to find a resolution as the real-world pain piles up ‚Äî and Trump presses in harsher terms for the party to go nuclear.
 

   
  ‚ÄúA winning Trump is less dangerous than a losing Trump. People forget this. If Rs look they they‚Äôll lose midterms, his pressure on filibuster to pass agenda before he leaves office will be insane,‚Äù one Senate GOP aide said in a text to CNN. ‚ÄúTrump is about to throw everything at Congress. Especially if he doesn‚Äôt get his way on tariffs.‚Äù
 

   
   This story has been updated with additional details.

articles.title: A Secret Garden in Beijing Has Opened to Visitors for the First Time in a Century
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A secret garden within Beijing‚Äôs Forbidden City, the Qianlong Garden, has reopened to the public for the first time in nearly a century. Designed by Emperor Qianlong in the 1770s as a personal retreat, the garden was closed for decades due to disrepair and lack of restoration. After a 25-year, $15‚Äì18 million partnership between the Palace Museum and the World Monument Fund, the garden was restored and reopened on September 30, 2025. This effort is part of a broader, decades-long initiative to restore the Forbidden City, beginning in 2002, which has expanded public access from less than one-third to 80% of the site. The restoration reflects China‚Äôs growing commitment to preserving its cultural heritage, with national leaders like Xi Jinping emphasizing the importance of protecting historical sites. The garden, inspired by southern Chinese private gardens, features a compact layout with four courtyards and varied perspectives, offering a unique contrast to the open, grand spaces of the Forbidden City‚Äôs main areas.
keyTakeAways: The Qianlong Garden, a private retreat designed by Emperor Qianlong in the 1770s, was closed for nearly a century before reopening on September 30, 2025, as part of a broader restoration effort.
Restoration of the Qianlong Garden took over 25 years due to a 2000 cooperation agreement between the Palace Museum and the World Monument Fund, with an estimated cost of $15‚Äì18 million.
The Palace Museum opened in 1925 and began major restoration in 2002, with public area access increasing from less than one-third to 80% by 2018.

The reopening of the Qianlong Garden, a compact and intricately designed garden with four courtyards, reflects a shift from imperial grandeur to intimate, scenic spaces, inspired by southern Chinese private gardens.
Emperor Qianlong designed the garden to be a personal retreat, using layered perspectives and varied courtyard layouts to create visual interest and depth.
The restoration of the Yangxindian (Hall of Mental Cultivation) is expected to follow in 2025, continuing the museum‚Äôs long-term conservation program.

Chinese leader Xi Jinping emphasized the importance of protecting and restoring cultural relics during a visit to the museum in October 2025, underscoring national priorities in heritage conservation.
Architectural expert Ho Puay-peng praised the effort, noting that China is now applying lessons from the Palace Museum‚Äôs restoration to protect Qing Dynasty architecture across the country.

articles.content:
A secret garden in Beijing has opened to visitors for the first time in a century 
       
  By Fred He
 

       
Updated: 
        1:39 AM EST, Thu November 6, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  When Ho Puay-peng first visited Beijing‚Äôs Forbidden City in the late 1980s, the Singaporean architect saw many of the historic courtyards used for storage, filled with garbage, and occupied by  danwei  (government offices).
 

   
  He summed it up with one word: ‚Äúhorrible.‚Äù
 

   
  That was when the majority of the sprawling former imperial palace in the center of the Chinese capital was not yet open to the public. Besides government offices, many areas had been severely damaged by disrepair, and fires ‚Äì easy to occur since most buildings were wooden structures.
 

   
  The Forbidden City was constructed in the 15th century during the Ming Dynasty as the imperial family‚Äôs workplace and residence. It was later taken over by the emperors of the Qing Dynasty, who restored and reconstructed many parts.
 

   
  The Palace Museum opened on the site in 1925, after the already-abdicated last Qing emperor Pu Yi was forced out of the Forbidden City, but proper restoration works started much later.
 

   
  Since Ho‚Äôs first visit decades ago, all the  danwei  have moved out of the Palace Museum, one of the most popular attractions in China. ‚ÄúSo, it now owns the whole compound, and they will restore bit by bit to open it up,‚Äù said Ho, the UNESCO Chair on Architectural Heritage Conservation and Management in Asia. ‚ÄúAnd I think that‚Äôs a wonderful effort.‚Äù
 

   
  As the Palace Museum celebrated its 100th anniversary in October, a small site in its northeastern section attracted outsized attention upon its public opening on September 30, with the museum describing it as ‚Äúthe most exquisite and beautifully decorated garden‚Äù of the entire compound.
 

   
  The Qianlong Garden was closed for nearly a century. While its construction was completed within five years in the 1770s, the restoration took 25 years through a partnership between the museum and World Monument Fund. ‚ÄúI am happy to see they spent such a long time on this,‚Äù said Ho.
 

   
  This is one step in the museum‚Äôs long-term conservation efforts. Last Monday, Chinese leader Xi Jinping visited the museum for an anniversary exhibition, where he said the museum is ‚Äúan important symbol of the Chinese civilization‚Äù and should ‚Äúwork harder to protect, restore, and make good use of the cultural relics.‚Äù
 

   
    A first glimpse
 

   
  On the rainy last day of China‚Äôs recent Golden Week holiday, long queues of domestic tourists formed inside Qianlong Garden, with the attraction trending on the country‚Äôs social media platforms.
 

   
  The garden, bearing the name of Emperor Qianlong, sits next to another popular tourist site inside the museum. Its discreet entrance speaks to the Qing ruler‚Äôs design and desire to make it a personal retreat.
 

   
  Covering 6,0000 square meters, the garden is smaller than a soccer field. That‚Äôs a significant contrast to other parts of the Forbidden City, marked by wide open spaces intended to represent the grandeur of imperial power and territory.
 

   
  Qianlong took a page from the design of private gardens in southern China to make the layout more compact, and divided the site into four connected courtyards, two of which are currently open to the public, from south to north. He varied the courtyard arrangements: some filled with a cluster of buildings, others open and spacious.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe architecture has carved up the very tight space to accommodate many sceneries,‚Äù explained Ho. ‚ÄúWhen you look at the sceneries from below and up on the inner pavilion, on the artificial hills, you get different perspectives.‚Äù
 

   
    A quarter-century of work
 

   
  Major renovation work of the Palace Museum only started in 2002 after the State Council, China‚Äôs cabinet,  held a meeting  on site and announced the initiative.
 

   
  When the restoration project was launched,  less than one third  of the Museum was open to the public. The area increased to 80% by 2018, according to  state media , after numerous buildings and city walls were restored, and  135 temporary structures  inside the compound were torn down.
 

   
  Restoring the Qianlong Garden took more than two decades, a costly and painstaking process based on a  2000 cooperation agreement  signed by the World Monuments Fund and the museum, which estimated a price tag of  $15-18 million .
 

   
  Back in  2006 , the restoration work of  Taihedian  (Hall of Supreme Harmony), the largest building in the palace, took less than two years.
 

   
  Following the Qianlong Garden,  museum officials  said  Yangxindian  (Hall of Mental Cultivation), the residence and administrative office for Qing emperors, is also expected to reopen this year after completing restoration work that started in 2018.
 

   
  For Ho, it‚Äôs important for China to apply what it has learned from the experiences of restoring the Palace Museum buildings to ‚Äúprofessionally and scientifically‚Äù conserving Qing Dynasty architecture across the country -  including a smaller imperial palace in northeastern China as well as old streets in many other regions.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBy and large, I think the country has woken up to the very, very important task in protecting historical heritage,‚Äù he added.

articles.title: Top Democrat Expresses Confidence in US Intel on Boat Strikes, But Calls for More Transparency from Trump Administration
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In November 2025, U.S. lawmakers, particularly Senate Intelligence Vice Chairman Mark Warner and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, express skepticism over the legality and transparency of U.S. military strikes in the Pacific targeting alleged drug traffickers. While Warner and Himes support the intelligence behind the operations, they raise concerns about civilian casualties and lack of direct evidence linking vessels to drug trafficking. Critics like Rep. Gregory Meeks argue that the closed briefing provided no convincing evidence or legal justification. House Speaker Mike Johnson defends the strikes as a necessary military response to cartel activity, citing high mortality rates from cocaine. The administration has shared a legal opinion from the Office of Legal Counsel asserting that congressional approval is not needed, but lawmakers demand more openness, especially as Congress debates the scope of presidential war powers. Warner also notes that the legal opinion does not address potential military actions in Venezuela against Nicol√°s Maduro, whose legitimacy is disputed internationally, and criticizes the U.S. for failing to act in that region after the 2024 Venezuelan election.
keyTakeAways: Senate Intelligence Vice Chairman Mark Warner expresses confidence in U.S. intelligence on drug trafficking strikes in the Pacific but calls for greater transparency from the Trump administration.
Rep. Jim Himes supports intelligence-based confidence in the strikes but raises concerns about civilian casualties and the lack of proven links to drug trafficking.
Rep. Gregory Meeks claims the closed briefing provided no convincing evidence linking vessels to drug trafficking and questions the legality of the strikes.

House Speaker Mike Johnson defends the strikes as legally justified under a 'military paradigm,' citing high statistics on cocaine-related deaths and asserting the U.S. is responding to a 'declaration of war' by cartels.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries demand a full, open briefing for all senators, criticizing the administration's selective disclosures and the absence of a comprehensive congressional review.

Mark Warner notes that the legal opinion shared with lawmakers does not cover potential military actions inside Venezuela against President Nicol√°s Maduro, who is not widely recognized as the legitimate leader.
Warner criticizes the U.S. for missing an opportunity to rally regional support against Maduro after the 2024 Venezuelan presidential election.

Top Democrat expresses confidence in US intel on boat strikes, but calls for more transparency from Trump administration 
       
  By Alison Main, Morgan Rimmer, Manu Raju, Jennifer Hansler, Kylie Atwood, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        8:39 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Senate Intelligence Vice Chairman Mark Warner on Wednesday expressed confidence in the intelligence used by the Pentagon to strike alleged drug traffickers in the Pacific Ocean, but he urged the Trump administration to divulge more information to a skeptical public as Democrats question the legal justification for continued attacks.
 

   
  After a briefing with Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, Warner said, ‚ÄúI think our intelligence assets are quite good,‚Äù explaining that he believes the administration does have ‚Äúvisibility‚Äù into the transport of illegal drugs. But the Virginia senator contended that making more information available about the strikes would help instill confidence in the US‚Äôs actions in the region.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe notion on the kinetic strikes, without actually interdicting and demonstrating to the American public that these are carrying drugs and they‚Äôre full of bad guys, I think, is a huge mistake and undermines the confidence in the administration‚Äôs actions,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Warner, who was deeply critical when the administration briefed a group of only GOP senators last week, said it‚Äôs ‚Äúgood‚Äù that all senators are now able to view the administration‚Äôs detailed legal justification for the strikes in a classified setting.
 

   
  However, he added that he thinks all of his colleagues should also be able to hear from administration officials, especially as Congress continues to debate limiting the president‚Äôs war powers in the region.
 

   
  Rep. Jim Himes, the House Intelligence committee ranking member, echoed Warner‚Äôs confidence in the work of the US intelligence community, telling reporters, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt worry there‚Äôs not some connection of these boats to trafficking.‚Äù But he added, ‚Äúwhat I‚Äôm not sure about is whether we have the same architecture to make sure innocents aren‚Äôt killed, etc, that we do when we traditionally do counter-terrorism strikes.‚Äù
 

   
  Rubio and Hegseth, as well as an official from the White House‚Äôs Office of Legal Counsel, briefed a group the administration described as the ‚ÄúGang of 12‚Äù ‚Äî leadership from both chambers, as well as the top Republicans and Democrats on key committees.
 

   
  House Foreign Affairs Committee ranking member Rep. Gregory Meeks told CNN he heard ‚Äúnothing‚Äù during the closed-door briefing to convince him of the legality of the strikes.
 

   
  And Meeks said they did not share evidence that ties the vessels or their passengers to the drug trade. Officials, including Rubio, have repeatedly claimed to have such evidence to support the deadly strikes.
 

   
  The New York Democrat said the administration referred to the Office of Legal Counsel  memo  that says they do not need congressional approval for the military action. The memo was shared with lawmakers, he said.
 

   
  However, Meeks said he was still seeking an answer as to why the administration issued a War Powers notification after the first strike if they don‚Äôt believe they legally need to.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt seems to me that what they are doing is they‚Äôre making mental gymnastics to figure out and to justify circumventing Congress‚Äô role on matters of war and peace,‚Äù he told CNN. ‚ÄúWith some of their legal, what they say is legal authorization, I don‚Äôt buy it all.‚Äù
 

   
  House Speaker Mike Johnson argued that ‚Äúexquisite intelligence‚Äù backs the legal justification for the strikes, which he said is based on a ‚Äúmilitary paradigm,‚Äù rather than traditional law enforcement protocol.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is a necessary, appropriate and legal response to effectively, the cartels having declared war on us,‚Äù he said, explaining, ‚Äúif you look statistically, cocaine has been the cause of death for more Americans in the last two years than all of the casualties that we suffered in the Vietnam War combined.‚Äù
 

   
  As for the question of whether the administration was aware of the identities of every person on board the vessels, Johnson said he didn‚Äôt know the exact answer, while also saying there was ‚Äúhigh reliability‚Äù behind the belief that those on board were affiliated with cartels and not just ‚Äúhaphazardly on a boat.‚Äù
 

   
  Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said he‚Äôs pressing for an all- senators briefing on the issue, telling reporters, ‚ÄúWhat we heard isn‚Äôt enough. We need a lot more answers‚Äù after the closed meeting Wednesday.
 

   
  House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries also said he wants to hear ‚Äúmore information,‚Äù partially blaming Johnson‚Äôs decision to keep the House out of session during the shutdown for the lack of a full congressional briefing.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHouse Republicans have literally been on a taxpayer funded vacation for the last six weeks. This is extraordinary. Mike Johnson has castrated his own majority,‚Äù Jeffries said.
 

   
  Johnson said he didn‚Äôt sense a ‚Äúnegative vibe‚Äù in the room, despite the frustration from Democrats, telling reporters, ‚ÄúThey wanted the briefing earlier, but I don‚Äôt think anybody who was in there can complain about a lack of thorough information.‚Äù
 

   
  Warner said the legal opinion shared with lawmakers does not address the separate consideration of any potential military action inside of Venezuela.
 

   
  Asked by CNN if he was comfortable with the potential of the US taking action to oust Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, Warner responded, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve said repeatedly that Maduro, not just in terms of American recognition, but roughly 50 nations around the world, is not even recognized as the legal leader of Venezuela at this point.‚Äù
 

   
  He said the US ‚Äúmissed a huge opportunity‚Äù to rally the region against Maduro when he seized power last year after his competitor who won more votes in the presidential election had to flee the country.

articles.content:
Jamie Dimon hopes Mamdani calls Detroit mayor for advice 
       
  By Matt Egan, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        8:01 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon Ôªø  has some advice for New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani: Talk to the man who  helped bring Detroit back from the dead .
 

   
  Dimon, who has been  critical of Mamdani , suggested the incoming New York City mayor could learn a lot from  outgoing Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan. 
 

   
  ‚ÄúI hope he calls up‚Ä¶this mayor because that‚Äôs the way you learn. You say, ‚ÄòHow did you do it? What did you do?‚Äô‚Äù Dimon told CNN‚Äôs Erin Burnett on Wednesday during a live interview alongside Duggan, who is stepping down from office next year and running for governor of Michigan.
 

   
  The JPMorgan CEO said he left Mamdani a message on Wednesday and is willing to meet with the self-proclaimed democratic socialist.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf I find it productive, I‚Äôll continue to do it,‚Äù Dimon said, adding that he considers himself ‚Äúpatriotic‚Äù and is willing to help ‚Äúany mayor, any governor.‚Äù
 

   
  During a press conference on Wednesday, Mamdani said he looks forward to meeting with Dimon and argued universal agreement across ‚Äúevery single issue‚Äù should not be a prerequisite to have a dialogue.
 

   
  Dimon is among the business leaders whose companies invested in Detroit when it was in dire straits.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis city was in deep trouble,‚Äù Dimon said of Detroit after the Great Recession. ‚ÄúThis wasn‚Äôt like New York, which is kind of healthy.‚Äù
 

   
  But Dimon suggested the jury is still out on whether Mamdani will succeed ‚Äì and the key will be how he executes his vision.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen a lot of mayors and governors, political leaders. Some grow into the job. ‚Ä¶They fix the life, they fix the crime, they fix the hospitals. They fix the ambulance times,‚Äù Dimon said.
 

   
  On the other hand, Dimon said some mayors get overwhelmed by the job.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen a lot of people when it comes to the execution part, they fall down so flat that it doesn‚Äôt matter where the heart is, they will fail to accomplish their goals,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping he‚Äôs the good one. That will be important to the future of New York,‚Äù Dimon said.
 

   
  The Detroit mayor argued city leaders must be willing to work alongside business leaders.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI embraced Jamie Dimon at a time when people said this was maybe politically risky,‚Äù Duggan said, adding the way JPMorgan provided low-income housing and job training programs helped win over the public. ‚ÄúThere is a way to embrace a partner that the community buys into. And that‚Äôs what we did.‚Äù
 

   
  JPMorgan announced Wednesday that its investment in Detroit has now surpassed $2 billion, and the bank‚Äôs main presence in the city is moving to Hudson‚Äôs Detroit, a new complex downtown.
 

   
    Trade and tariffs
 

   
  Duggan, a former Democrat now running as an independent, criticized  President Donald Trump‚Äôs aggressive trade agenda, which the White House says is meant to help American factory workers who have been hurt by jobs shipped overseas.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI live in Detroit. You don‚Äôt have to explain anything to Detroiters about bad trade agreements America has made over the years. They‚Äôve emptied out the manufacturing industry in Michigan, and I think the right tariffs on Mexico and Canada could have helped,‚Äù Duggan said.
 

   
  Yet the Detroit mayor argued Trump‚Äôs tariffs on Canada are backfiring because of how closely intertwined the North American supply chain has become. He noted Canadian auto supplier plants, located right across the river from Detroit, send parts to his city‚Äôs three manufacturing plants.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhen you put a tax on Canada, you put a tax on Michigan cars. I do think the Canadian tariffs need to be addressed, because it is starting to hurt the Michigan economy,‚Äù Duggan said.
 

   
  The comments came hours after the Supreme Court heard oral arguments on   a case challenging Trump‚Äôs use of emergency powers to impose global tariffs. Most justices  appeared deeply concerned  with Trump‚Äôs reliance on a vague federal law to impose the duties.
 

   
  Trump argued in a social media post on Tuesday that the case is ‚Äúliterally, LIFE OR DEATH for our Country‚Äù because without the emergency powers the United States would be ‚Äúvirtually defenseless against other Countries.‚Äù
 

   
  Asked if the Supreme Court case is a matter of life or death, Dimon said: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so.‚Äù
 

   
  Dimon said tariffs are ‚Äúa factor,‚Äù but ‚Äúmay not be the deciding factor‚Äù in growing the US economy.
 

   
  The JPMorgan CEO did, however, credit Trump officials with ‚Äústarting to do a better job‚Äù on trade by examining ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs working, what‚Äôs not working and making adjustments.‚Äù
 

   
    Dimon on recession, AI bubble worries
 

   
  But Dimon did say that there is ‚Äúweakening in the job market, there‚Äôs no question, . ‚Äù albeit not yet at a recessionary level.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe economy is still chugging along. It may have gotten a little bit weaker, but right now it‚Äôs still kind of in that soft landing,‚Äù Dimon said.
 

   
  Unlike the real economy, the stock market has been on fire since April ‚Äì propelled in part by the artificial intelligence boom.
 

   
  Dimon called chipmaker Nvidia ‚Äì a company whose near-$5 trillion valuation is now greater than the size of all but two or three economies in the world ‚Äì an ‚Äúunbelievable company‚Äù and praised AI as ‚Äúreal‚Äù and capable of making companies ‚Äúhugely productive.‚Äù
 

   
  Dimon conceded that not all AI companies will ultimately succeed, and there will be setbacks along the way ‚Äì like with the dotcom bubble.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like the internet thing. They may not all pay off, but you did get Google, Facebook, YouTube, part of Microsoft, Amazon, Salesforce,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYeah, there was a little bit of a bubble in there.‚Äù
 

   
  Dimon acknowledged the ‚Äúvaluation today may be too high for some of these folks,‚Äù but he added there is ‚Äúenormous‚Äù potential for AI to open the door to breakthrough inventions in medicine, engineering and elsewhere.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMankind should benefit,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Dimon conceded that AI could eliminate up to 80% of the jobs in some professions, but he emphasized the technology could create jobs elsewhere.
 

   
  The key, according to Dimon, will be coming up with ‚Äúthoughtful‚Äù government assistance if AI moves ‚Äútoo fast for society‚Äù and ‚Äúproper regulation‚Äù to safeguard the technology.
