articles.title: Judge Orders Improvements at Chicago-Area Immigration Facility After Claims of Inhumane Conditions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge in Chicago, Robert Gettleman, ordered immediate improvements at the Broadview ICE detention facility after detainees alleged inhumane conditions, including overflowing toilets, lack of beds, and no access to basic hygiene items. The 14-day order mandates clean bedding, sufficient sleeping space, regular cleaning, access to soap, towels, toothbrushes, menstrual products, and prescribed medication. Detainees are also entitled to free legal counsel and must be allowed to shower at least every other day. In parallel, Judge Sara Ellis has previously restricted the use of tear gas and required body cameras for ICE agents, and is now reviewing allegations of excessive force during protests. Senior Border Patrol official Greg Bovino defended actions involving pepper balls, tear gas, and physical contact with protesters, denying allegations of assault despite testimonies from Pastor David Black, Oak Park Trustee Juan Munoz, youth organizer Leslie Cortez, and Chicago Newspaper Guild Executive Director Emily Steelhammer, who all reported being exposed to chemical agents or physically targeted during peaceful protests. The cases highlight tensions between federal immigration enforcement and civilian rights, especially in the context of peaceful protest and detention standards.
keyTakeAways: A federal judge in Chicago ordered immediate improvements at the Broadview ICE facility due to allegations of inhumane conditions, including overflowing toilets, lack of beds, and poor sanitation.
Detainees were reportedly sleeping on top of each other and without access to basic necessities like soap, towels, toothbrushes, and menstrual products.
Judge Robert Gettleman condemned the conditions as 'unnecessarily cruel' and emphasized the credibility of witnesses describing severe overcrowding and unsanitary environments.
Federal authorities were required to allow detainees to access legal counsel at no cost and provide a list of pro bono attorneys in English and Spanish.
ICE agents were barred from misrepresenting documents to detainees and were required to clean holding rooms twice daily.

In a separate case, Senior Border Patrol official Greg Bovino defended the use of force against protesters, denying allegations of pepper balls, tear gas, and physical assault, including claims of striking Pastor David Black and tackling Oak Park Township Trustee Juan Munoz.

Multiple witnesses, including youth organizer Leslie Cortez and Chicago Newspaper Guild Executive Director Emily Steelhammer, reported being exposed to chemical agents like tear gas and rubber bullets during peaceful protests.
Judge Sara Ellis previously ordered ICE agents to wear badges, ban the use of tear gas on peaceful protesters, and require body cameras, and is now reviewing allegations of excessive force.
Plaintiffs allege that agents used force without warning, including at a Halloween parade and outside a grocery store, and that such actions were unprovoked.
Defense officials, including Bovino, claim that non-compliance with instructions by protesters indicates potential obstruction, though witnesses argue that peaceful protest is not a threat.

articles.content:
Judge orders improvements at a Chicago-area immigration facility after claims of inhumane conditions 
       
  By Associated Press
 

       
Updated: 
        7:38 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: AP
 
   
  A federal judge on Wednesday ordered authorities to improve a Chicago-area immigration facility after a group of detainees sued, alleging they were being kept in ‚Äúinhumane‚Äù conditions.
 

   
  The order will be in effect for 14 days. It requires officials to provide detainees at a US Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in the west Chicago suburb of Broadview with a clean bedding mat and sufficient space to sleep, soap, towels, toilet paper, toothbrushes, toothpaste, menstrual products and prescribed medications.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPeople shouldn‚Äôt be sleeping next to overflowing toilets,‚Äù US District Judge Robert Gettleman said. ‚ÄúThey should not be sleeping on top of each other.‚Äù
 

   
  The order says the holding rooms at the facility must be cleaned twice a day. Detainees must be allowed to shower at least every other day and should have three full meals and bottled water upon request.
 

   
  Gettleman required authorities to allow detainees to call lawyers in private with no cost and provide them with a list of pro bono attorneys in English and Spanish. Agents are also barred from misrepresenting documents provided to detainees to sign.
 

   
  The judge had called the alleged conditions ‚Äúunnecessarily cruel‚Äù after a hearing Tuesday about overflowing toilets, crowded cells, no beds and water that ‚Äútasted like sewer.‚Äù
 

   
  He said he found the witnesses ‚Äúhighly credible,‚Äù adding he was moved by the seriousness of the conditions.
 

   
  Gettleman requested a status report by noon Friday on how authorities are fulfilling the requirements.
 

   
  A message left Wednesday for Immigration and Customs Enforcement wasn‚Äôt immediately returned.
 

   
    Officer defends use of force
 

   
  In another Chicago courtroom, Senior Border Patrol official Greg Bovino defended the use of force by agents accused of using pepper balls, tear gas and other tactics against people protesting federal immigration policies and the detaining of immigrants in the area.
 

   
  Bovino made the statement in a deposition ‚Äî a private interview with lawyers from both sides ‚Äî given last week. It was brought into evidence during a preliminary injunction hearing Wednesday  in a lawsuit  filed by news outlets and protesters.
 

   
  In the deposition, Bovino said he does not remember the name of a Chicago-area pastor who claims to have been struck in the head by pepper balls as he prayed outside the Broadview ICE facility.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what the use of force was here, and I can‚Äôt make a judgment either way because I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Bovino said after viewing footage of the Rev. David Black being shot with the chemical agents.
 

   
  Black testified earlier that he and others were not threatening agents and that protesters had been hit with pepper balls and tear gas. Agents did not warn protesters before using the chemicals, Black said.
 

   
  Attorneys for the plaintiffs also played a clip of Bovino grabbing and tackling a man to the ground during one demonstration outside the Broadview facility.
 

   
  Oak Park Township Trustee Juan Munoz said he was standing beside the man and was also knocked down and pinned by Bovino during the chaos. Munoz said Bovino also smacked his phone from his hands.
 

   
  Munoz said he was arrested and detained in the Broadview facility for eight hours. He has not returned to the facility to protest, Munoz added.
 

   
  After attorneys played footage of Munoz‚Äôs arrest, Bovino repeatedly denied during the deposition that he tackled ‚Äúan older gentleman‚Äù in the video and dodged questions on whether he used force.
 

   
  Bovino acknowledged that he made physical contact with the man, but denied that he applied force, saying it was not ‚Äúreportable use of force.‚Äù
 

   
    Excessive force claims dog ICE agents
 

   
  US District  Judge Sara Ellis  has already ordered agents to wear badges and banned them from using certain  riot-control techniques , such as tear gas, against peaceful protesters and journalists. After repeatedly chastising federal officials for not following her previous orders, she added a requirement for body cameras.
 

   
  Ellis will weigh how to respond to allegations that federal immigration agents in the Chicago area have  used excessive force , following a surge of recent court filings detailing tense encounters  between agents and residents .
 

   
  Craig Futterman, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, noted recent examples of agents using tear gas on Chicago-area residents, including at a Halloween parade and outside a grocery store. He said Bovino, himself, has been  filmed throwing tear gas canisters  at protesters. A video of Bovino throwing a canister was played during Wednesday‚Äôs hearing.
 

   
  Justice Department lawyer Sarmad Khojasteh accused many protesters of threatening to kill law enforcement officers, impeding their duties and throwing rocks and other objects at agents.
 

   
  ‚ÄúSuch conduct must be rejected,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTo what extent does the freedom of speech protect individuals in obstructing and/or threatening conduct ‚Äî throwing rocks, bottles, fireworks, surrounding and pinning down law enforcement officials?‚Äù
 

   
  But witnesses say the actions by agents have been unprovoked.
 

   
    Witnesses say ICE actions not called for
 

   
  Leslie Cortez, a youth organizer, said she was recording and explaining rights in Spanish to day laborers being arrested by ICE agents outside a Home Depot when one agent pointed a gun at her.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI could see inside the barrel,‚Äù Cortez testified. ‚ÄúMy heart accelerated. I was nervous they were going to shoot.‚Äù
 

   
  Chicago Newspaper Guild Executive Director Emily Steelhammer also took the stand, recounting how members of the union said they were hit with rubber bullets, pepper balls and chemical weapons, including tear gas. The incidents mostly occurred in Broadview, but also took place at other Chicago-area demonstrations, she said.
 

   
  In his deposition, Bovino denied allegations of excessive use of force, saying, ‚ÄúI have not seen our men or women deploy force against protesters.‚Äù
 

   
  When asked by attorneys if a peaceful protester who refuses an instruction from law enforcement would be considered a violent or ‚Äúassaultive subject,‚Äù Bovino said it is an indicator that someone is ‚Äúpotentially on that road‚Äù to obstructing agents.
 

   
  ‚ÄúNot following instructions is certainly one indication of someone that‚Äôs, that‚Äôs already ready to break the law, be where they‚Äôre not supposed to be,‚Äù Bovino said.
 

   
  Wednesday‚Äôs hearing follows Ellis‚Äô questioning of Bovino at a public hearing last week, where she took the rare step of ordering him to brief her each evening on the federal immigration crackdown in Chicago. That move was swiftly blocked by an appeals court.

articles.content:
Michael Burry of ‚ÄòThe Big Short‚Äô is back with cryptic messages ‚Äî and two massive bets 
       
  By John Towfighi, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        7:40 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Michael Burry, the famed investor behind ‚ÄúThe Big Short,‚Äù is betting artificial intelligence is more of a bubble than a revolution.
 

   
  Burry‚Äôs fund, Scion Asset Management, disclosed on Monday that it bought puts ‚Äî bets that share prices will fall ‚Äî on two stars of the AI wave: Nvidia ( NVDA ) and Palantir ( PLTR ). Scion bought roughly $187.6 million in puts on Nvidia and $912 million in puts on Palantir, according to Securities and Exchange Commission  filings .
 

   
  Burry is known for his prophetic call that the US housing market would collapse in 2008. He was profiled in the 2010 book ‚ÄúThe Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine,‚Äù by Michael Lewis, and portrayed by Christian Bale in the 2015 film adaptation.
 

   
  Now Burry is betting against the hottest AI stocks on the market at a time when concerns are mounting about a bubble. Tech and AI stocks have carried the market in recent months.  The S&P 500, which is increasingly concentrated in tech companies, is trading at historically expensive levels.
 

   
  Meanwhile, the  circular financing  of AI deals has raised eyebrows on Wall Street, with many tech companies entwined in a massive web of deals with each other. Some investors are also skeptical whether future profit growth will continue to justify the enormous amounts of spending taking place.
 

   
  The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite tumbled 2.04% on Tuesday, posting its worst day since August. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 fell 1.17%.
 

   
    ‚ÄòSometimes, we see bubbles‚Äô
 

   
  Burry made a splash among investors on Thursday, when he posted on X for the first time since 2023. In his post, he shared a photo of Bale portraying him in ‚ÄúThe Big Short‚Äù and wrote: ‚ÄúSometimes, we see bubbles. Sometimes, there is something to do about it. Sometimes, the only winning move is not to play.‚Äù
 

   
  Four days later, Burry‚Äôs fund disclosed its bearish positions in Nvidia and Palantir. The SEC filings are for the third quarter of this year. Scion Asset Management did not respond to a request for comment.
 

   
  Angelo Zino, a tech analyst at CFRA Research, said a pullback in tech stocks was overdue, given how far they have rallied in recent months. He said Burry‚Äôs comments likely exacerbated concerns.
 

   
  Burry has made public calls about the market in the years since ‚ÄúThe Big Short.‚Äù He has not always been correct. The hedge fund manager in January 2023 infamously posted on X, ‚ÄúSell,‚Äù before posting two months later, ‚ÄúI was wrong to say sell.‚Äù
 

   
  Nonetheless, his words carry weight on Wall Street.
 

   
  Burry‚Äôs return to social media comes at a time when investors have voiced concerns about expensive valuations, a market concentrated on a handful of large companies and rising investor expectations.
 

   
  For example, Palantir beat Wall Street forecasts in earnings reported Monday. Yet it wasn‚Äôt enough to impress traders after a series of strong earnings results.
 

   
  On Tuesday, its shares tumbled 7.95% ‚Äî their worst day since August.
 

   
  Palantir was the top performing stock in the S&P 500 in 2024 and is in the top five performing stocks this year. Its shares are still up 152% this year.
 

   
  The company‚Äôs earnings results on Monday were ‚Äústellar,‚Äù according to CFRA Research‚Äôs Zino, but the company‚Äôs valuation ‚Äî a measure of how pricey it is ‚Äî ‚Äúis a bit extreme.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúDespite the great results, when you coincide that with the comments that Michael Burry made and everybody already talking about concerns about an AI bubble, I think the combination of those factors really helped drive a pullback in the shares, the broader tech index and as a result the broader markets,‚Äù Zino said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not overly concerned about the pullback, but I would say it‚Äôs one of those situations where you‚Äôve got to keep an eye on it.‚Äù
 

   
  Meanwhile, Nvidia shares fell 3.96% on Tuesday. Shares are still up 48% this year.
 

   
  Alex Karp, CEO at Palantir, told CNBC on Tuesday that people betting against the company ‚Äî including Burry ‚Äî are ‚Äúcrazy.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhen I hear short sellers attacking what I believe is clearly the most important software company in America, therefore in the world, in terms of our impact, ‚Ä¶ it just is super triggering,‚Äù Karp said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crazy motivating,‚Äù Karp said. ‚ÄúEvery time they short us, we are just like tripling down on getting the better numbers, in part honestly, to make them poorer.‚Äù

articles.title: Trump Wants GOP to Focus More on His Economic Achievements, But Often Changes the Subject
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump is urging Republican leaders to highlight economic achievements from his presidency, such as job creation and factory growth, to improve party messaging in the face of disappointing election results. However, Trump frequently shifts focus away from economics‚Äîmentioning topics like McDonald‚Äôs, the UN, and renaming Denali‚Äîdemonstrating a pattern of diverting attention from policy realities. Public sentiment, as shown by a CNN survey, is increasingly critical of Trump‚Äôs economic performance, with 72% viewing the economy as in poor shape and 61% believing his policies have worsened economic conditions. Despite this, Trump‚Äôs aides and GOP leaders, including House Speaker Mike Johnson, are now prioritizing economic issues ahead of the midterms, signaling a strategic pivot. Trump‚Äôs inconsistent messaging and denial of inflation and rising prices contrast sharply with public experience, raising concerns about the credibility of his economic claims and the party‚Äôs ability to regain public trust.

articles.content:
Trump wants GOP to focus more on his economic achievements. But he‚Äôs often changing the subject. 
       
  By Kevin Liptak, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        7:19 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
   President Donald Trump  spent the morning after a  terrible election night  for Republicans publicly processing the results, and arrived at several conclusions.
 

   
  First, he determined his party was losing the messaging battle over the now-record-length  government shutdown , and told GOP senators so in no uncertain terms over coffee and orange juice in the State Dining Room.
 

   
  Second, he adopted the view that any election where he‚Äôs not on the ballot will be a struggle for his party, notwithstanding the fact he‚Äôs unlikely to appear on a ballot ever again.
 

   
  And third, he deemed his party just too quiet about the economic accomplishments of his term so far, including how many new factories are being built or jobs being created.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI tell Republicans, you want to win elections, you got to talk about these facts,‚Äù he told a financial conference in Miami, where he flew after his breakfast session with senators. ‚ÄúYou know, it‚Äôs really easy to win elections when you talk about the facts.‚Äù
 

   
  In determining Republicans have been insufficient in their promotion of his policy accomplishments, Trump arrived at the same conclusion many presidents before him have when confronted with stiff political headwinds. If only the people knew what he was doing, the thinking goes, the political blessings will follow.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt just happen. You have to tell them,‚Äù Trump said in his speech, sounding a little like Joe Biden bemoaning how no one understood his sweeping economic agenda or Barack Obama regretting not better explaining the Affordable Care Act.
 

   
  But it can often be Trump himself obscuring his policy achievements. Even in his speech Wednesday ‚Äî billed as a ‚Äúmajor economic address‚Äù on the one-year anniversary of his 2024 victory ‚Äî Trump meandered well outside the economic realm.
 

   
  Among the topics touched on: transgender weightlifters, the teleprompter that  malfunctioned at the United Nations  six weeks ago, his decision to rename Denali to Mount McKinley, whether South Africa should remain a member of the G20, the liquid wealth held by Saudi Arabia‚Äôs ambassador to the United States, and the time he worked a drive-thru window at McDonald‚Äôs during last year‚Äôs campaign.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI guess there‚Äôs something about McDonald‚Äôs, right?‚Äù he reflected.
 

   
  Indeed, it was the election that took place 365 days ago that received far more time in Wednesday‚Äôs speech than the vote that occurred a day earlier. Trump was in a nostalgic mood, perhaps because the results this week were vastly more disappointing for the GOP than those a year ago.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOn November 5, 2024, the American people reclaimed our government, we restored our sovereignty ‚Äì we lost a little bit of sovereignty last night in New York, but we‚Äôll take care of it,‚Äù Trump said at the start of his address, referring to the success of Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about it.‚Äù
 

   
  Trump did test drive a new political construction that seems destined to reappear after the the democratic socialist‚Äôs victory.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe have a choice between communism and common sense,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúDoes that make sense to you?‚Äù In all, Trump said the words ‚Äúcommunist‚Äù or ‚Äúcommunism‚Äù 14 times in his speech, while naming Mamdani only once.
 

   
  Still, for all his barbed attacks on Democrats‚Äô economic policies, Trump encouraging his fellow Republicans to focus more on the economy seemed an acknowledgment, however tacit, that the longtime edge he and the GOP have long held on economic matters has mostly disappeared.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThey have this new word called affordability, and they don‚Äôt talk about it enough. The Democrats did. And the Democrats make it up ‚Äì because we took over a mess. ‚Ä¶ As a Republican, you have to let people know that,‚Äù he told Fox News‚Äô Bret Baier in an interview later Wednesday.
 

   
  Winning Democratic candidates in New Jersey, Virginia and New York all made the cost of living central to their campaigns, holding out Trump‚Äôs policies as a reason why things like groceries and electricity are becoming more expensive, despite his promises of an economic turnaround.
 

   
  Trump‚Äôs aides have signaled that economic issues will be central for the president ahead of critical midterm elections that will determine the balance of power in Congress for the remainder of his term.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe president is very keyed into what‚Äôs going on, and he recognizes, like anybody, that it takes time to do an economic turnaround, but all the fundamentals are there, and I think you‚Äôll see him be very, very focused on prices and cost of living,‚Äù James Blair, the political director for Trump‚Äôs 2024 presidential campaign and now a deputy White House chief of staff, told Politico on Wednesday.
 

   
  In Trump‚Äôs first nine months, economic matters have not always been at the center of his agenda. He has spent an outsized amount of time on foreign affairs, sometimes meeting multiple world leaders at the White House per week and working to broker peace agreements (his count is seven or eight).
 

   
  He‚Äôs also been focused on his White House renovations, including during the shutdown, by tearing down the East Wing to make way for a 90,000 square-foot ballroom, renovating a guest bathroom in the residence and covering the Oval Office in gold fixtures. Trump often talks about his projects as major successes of his presidency so far.
 

   
  When he does discuss the economy, Trump can sometimes sound dismissive of ongoing cost-of-living concerns. He has insisted there is no inflation when there is. And he insists grocery prices are down when they‚Äôre up. And he‚Äôs  kept up his own travel and golf schedule  during a shutdown that‚Äôs snarled airline travel and slowed food stamp benefits for millions of Americans.
 

   
  Denying economic realities that people are experiencingÔªø in their everyday lives is a political pitfall Democrats have been eager to seize upon, particularly as polls show Americans souring on Trump‚Äôs economic performance.
 

   
   A CNN survey  this week showed Americans broadly dissatisfied with the state of the country ‚Äî 68% said things are going badly ‚Äî and the economy, with 72% saying it‚Äôs in poor shape, and 47% calling the economy and cost of living the top issue facing the US. About 6 in 10 (61%) said Trump‚Äôs policies have worsened economic conditions in the US.
 

   
  How much Trump can shift his economic messaging over the next year remains to be seen. What is clear is that his fellow Republicans, who mostly avoided pointing any fingers in Trump‚Äôs direction after Tuesday‚Äôs losses, will be relying on him and his political impulses to avoid another decisive defeat.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHe is, in a very real sense, on the ballot. He‚Äôs fiercely committed to us winning. He is going to help,‚Äù House Speaker Mike Johnson said on the steps of the Capitol. He said he‚Äôd received assurances in private from Trump that he would take an active role in campaigning ahead of the midterms.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs offered to do rallies and the tele-town halls and all the things,‚Äù Johnson said, adding later: ‚ÄúHe is very much engaged, very dialed in, and he understands the stakes. President Trump is on the ballot in 2026, and we‚Äôre looking forward to that contest.‚Äù

articles.title: Deliberations to resume Thursday in lawsuit filed by Virginia teacher shot by 6-year-old student
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A $40 million civil lawsuit filed by Virginia teacher Abby Zwerner, who was shot by a 6-year-old student at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News in January 2023, is now entering its deliberation phase. The case hinges on whether assistant principal Ebony Parker, who was responsible for school safety, failed to act on warnings about a student possessing a gun. Zwerner claims Parker had a duty to investigate and remove the student, and her failure caused her life-threatening injury and long-term trauma. The defense argues it was unforeseeable for a child of such a young age to carry a gun, and that school safety is a shared responsibility among staff. Expert testimony emphasizes that no single person bears sole blame. The case could set a major legal precedent on accountability in school shootings, especially as criminal charges against school officials are rare. The civil trial may serve as a 'dry run' for the upcoming criminal case against Parker, who faces eight counts of felony child neglect.
keyTakeAways: A civil lawsuit of $40 million is underway between former Virginia teacher Abby Zwerner and assistant principal Ebony Parker, following a shooting at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News.
Zwerner claims Parker, as assistant principal, had a duty to investigate concerns about a gun in a student's backpack and failed to act, resulting in her injury.
The case centers on the question of responsibility in school shootings: who bears legal and ethical blame when a child with a gun is on campus?
Defense attorneys argue that a 6-year-old child bringing a gun is unimaginable and that no one could foresee such a scenario, emphasizing shared responsibility in school safety.
Expert testimony suggests school safety is a collective duty, and no individual is solely responsible for preventing such incidents.
Zwerner suffered life-threatening injuries, including a bullet wound to the chest and hand, which have led to long-term physical and psychological trauma including PTSD and permanent disability.
The civil trial may establish a legal precedent for holding school officials accountable in cases where safety protocols are allegedly neglected despite warnings.

The case is rare, as filing criminal charges against school officials after a school shooting is uncommon, and the civil trial could serve as a 'dry run' for the upcoming criminal proceedings against Parker.

articles.content:
Deliberations to resume Thursday in lawsuit filed by Virginia teacher shot by 6-year-old student 
       
  By Cindy Von Quednow, Chris Boyette, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:25 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Deliberations will resume Thursday after a jury deliberated for nearly two hours in the $40 million lawsuit filed by a former Virginia teacher shot by her 6-year-old student in a case that could set a dramatic precedent for who to blame after school shootings.
 

   
  ‚ÄúA gun changes everything,‚Äù a lawyer for the teacher, Abby Zwerner, told jurors Wednesday, stressing it was the job of defendant  Ebony Parker , then an assistant principal, to make sure everyone on campus was safe after people raised concerns a child had a gun.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYou stop and you investigate. You get to the bottom of it,‚Äù attorney Kevin Biniazan continued. ‚ÄúYou get to the bottom of that backpack. You get to the bottom of his pockets, whatever it is. You get to the bottom of it to know whether that gun is real and on campus so you can deal with it.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs not what happened.‚Äù
 

   
  Zwerner is suing Parker, who is accused of neglecting to act on  concerns  the student had a gun in January 2023 at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News.
 

   
  Parker‚Äôs attorneys have argued no one could fathom a child so young would bring a gun to school and carry out a shooting. Parker did not take the stand during the trial that began last week but was in court through it.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYou will be able to judge for yourself whether or not this was foreseeable. That‚Äôs the heart of this case,‚Äù Parker‚Äôs attorney, Daniel Hogan,  said earlier  in the trial.
 

   
  In his closing argument, Biniazan challenged that position.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYou cannot stick your head in the sand and then come into court and say, ‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt have the information,‚Äô when it was your job to find it,‚Äù Zwerner‚Äôs lawyer said Wednesday. ‚ÄúEvery second that a gun is in the possession of a 6-year-old, who I agree, has totally unpredictable behavior ‚Ä¶ All the more reason to find the gun.‚Äù
 

   
  At the center of the lawsuit is who gets the blame when children have access to guns and carry out school shootings, which continue to plague the country. As of last week, there were  64 US school shootings  this year, 27 of them on K-12 school grounds.
 

   
  ‚ÄúParker did not have a legal duty to protect Miss Zwerner,‚Äù Sandra Douglas, one of Parker‚Äôs attorneys said in her closing argument. ‚ÄúShe did not volunteer to protect Miss Zwerner.‚Äù
 

   
  Douglas sought to discredit the testimony of the plaintiff‚Äôs witnesses, recounting the school‚Äôs reading specialist was the first to hear the student might have a gun, and she and the school guidance counselor did not remove the student or his backpack from the room.
 

   
  Douglas said the reading specialist previously said she thought there might be a toy gun, but testified during the trial she told Parker students had told her the boy had a gun. She texted Parker two days later saying she should have removed the student from the class herself.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the judges of the credibility of these witnesses,‚Äù Douglas said.
 

   
  She argued Zwerner should have talked to Parker herself, and she had discussions with Parker about the student‚Äôs behavior during lunch, but not about a report of the gun.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt was largely unthinkable and certainly unprecedented. Your job is to consider only what Dr. Parker knew at the time,‚Äù Douglas said.
 

   
  The defense attorney challenged the testimony that Zwerner was unable to fully use her hand because she graduated cosmetology school. And she challenged that while witnesses testified Zwerner had trouble leaving the house, she went to concerts in the months after the shooting.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not minimizing what happened to Miss Zwerner,‚Äù Douglas said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not doing that.‚Äù
 

   
  In rebuttal, Biniazan characterized the defense argument as ‚Äúeveryone is lying‚Äù and pointed out they didn‚Äôt call any witnesses from the school.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe only people they called as an expert were the people that they paid to come into this courtroom,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  The civil trial offers a window to some of the key details that will be presented during the criminal case next month against Parker, who faces  eight counts  of felony child neglect. Filing charges against school officials in the aftermath of a school shooting is rare.
 

   
  In instructions given to the jury Wednesday, the judge told jurors they‚Äôd be deciding whether Parker was grossly negligent and whether her negligence caused Zwerner‚Äôs injury and damages. Jurors were also tasked with deciding whether Zwerner was negligent and caused any of her own damages; if so, she would be barred from recovering any money from Parker, the judge instructed the jury.
 

   
    Injured teacher shared emotional testimony
 

   
  Zwerner testified about the physical and emotional consequences wrought by the shooting. After she was shot in the chest and hand while sitting at a reading table, Zwerner thought she had died and gone to heaven.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI thought I was dying. I thought I had died,‚Äù she  said last week .
 

   
  The teacher now says she‚Äôs more reserved and sometimes gets overwhelmed at the thought of going out in public.
 

   
  Zwerner‚Äôs twin sister, Hannah, also testified how Abby‚Äôs demeanor changed after the shooting: She was full of light, outgoing and silly, but now ‚Äúshe‚Äôs just not the person that she was,‚Äù Hannah said during her emotional testimony.
 

   
  Zwerner has suffered post-traumatic stress disorder after the shooting, psychiatrist Dr. Clarence Watson testified last week. And Zwerner‚Äôs devastating hand injury has left her unable to perform daily activities.
 

   
  Despite six surgeries, Zwerner‚Äôs hand will never be normal, an orthopedic surgeon testified earlier in the trial.
 

   
  Previous testimony from doctors on her care team revealed Zwerner‚Äôs injuries were life-threatening after a bullet narrowly missed her heart. And the impacts extended beyond the physical damage, she testified.
 

   
  During cross-examination, an attorney for Parker worked to undermine Zwerner‚Äôs claims the shooting had limited her willingness to go out in public, saying she was emotionally ready to attend concerts like Taylor Swift‚Äôs Eras Tour.
 

   
  The attorney also sought to undermine claims Zwerner is physically hindered by her wounds, asking how she successfully attended and graduated from cosmetology school, worked and frequented a gym if she had physical limitations.
 

   
    Assistant principal did not act with indifference, expert testifies
 

   
  An expert for the defense  testified Monday  the assistant principal did not breach professional standards or act with indifference.
 

   
  Dr. Amy Klinger, an expert in education administration and school safety, said it would have been difficult for anyone to foresee the incident and testified the assistant principal‚Äôs role is collaborative and school safety is a shared responsibility among all staff.
 

   
  ‚ÄúNo one is the sole person responsible for school safety,‚Äù she said.
 

   
  Parker did not breach professional standards or act with indifference, Klinger said, and it would have been difficult for anyone to foresee the incident.
 

   
  This case could set a precedent for future events, said Darryl K. Brown, a law professor at the University of Virginia, adding the civil trial could be a ‚Äúdry run‚Äù for what‚Äôs to come in the criminal case.
 

   
  ‚ÄúEveryone on both sides the prosecution and the defense should have a very clear idea of what the evidence is going to be and what the witnesses are going to say,‚Äù the professor said.

articles.title: Newly Freed Israeli Hostage Says He Was Sexually Assaulted in Captivity
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Rom Braslavski, a 21-year-old Israeli security guard kidnapped on October 7, 2023, during the Hamas-led attacks, is the first male hostage to publicly allege he was subjected to horrific sexual assault and humiliation while held by Palestinian Islamic Jihad in Gaza. He described being stripped naked, tied up, and violently abused with the explicit intent to degrade his dignity. His case marks a significant expansion of known abuse, as prior reports had focused only on female hostages. Braslavski‚Äôs mother said he was pressured to convert to Islam for food, and the group released footage of him in emaciated condition. Other hostages, such as Amit Soussana, have also reported sexual violence, with the UN‚Äôs Pramila Patten and the Dinal Project citing clear evidence of systemic abuse. The article highlights rising international concern over the use of sexual violence as a weapon in conflict and calls for accountability, especially in Gaza.
keyTakeAways: Rom Braslavski, a 21-year-old Israeli security guard, is the first male hostage to publicly allege sexual assault while in captivity by Palestinian Islamic Jihad.
Braslavski claimed he was stripped naked, tied up, and subjected to humiliating sexual violence, which he described as a deliberate attempt to crush his dignity.
The incident is significant because it marks the first time a male Israeli hostage has publicly described such abuse, expanding the scope of reported sexual violence beyond female victims.
Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a militant group allied with Hamas, held Braslavski and other Israeli hostages during the conflict and released footage of him showing extreme emaciation.
His mother reportedly said he was pressured to convert to Islam in exchange for food, indicating coercive religious manipulation during captivity.
Other Israeli hostages, including Amit Soussana, have previously reported similar sexual abuse, though Hamas has consistently denied these allegations.

The United Nations Special Representative on Sexual Violence in Conflict, Pramila Patten, reported finding 'clear and convincing' evidence of sexual abuse of hostages in Gaza, lending international credibility to the claims.
The revelation underscores global concern over the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war and the need for accountability in conflict zones.

articles.content:
Newly freed Israeli hostage says he was sexually assaulted in captivity 
       
  By Jeremy Diamond, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        5:01 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A recently freed  Israeli   hostage  has alleged he was subjected to ‚Äúhorrific‚Äù and humiliating sexual assault while held captive in Gaza.
 

   
  Rom Braslavski, who was working as a security guard when he was kidnapped from the Nova music festival on October 7, said in an interview with Channel 13‚Äôs ‚ÄúHazinor‚Äù that he was stripped naked and tied up while he was held by Palestinian Islamic Jihad.
 

   
  He is the first male hostage to publicly allege he was sexually assaulted while in captivity.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThey stripped me of all my clothes, my underwear, everything. They tied me up from the ‚Ä¶‚Äù Braslavski, 21, said, his voice trailing off without finishing his sentence. ‚ÄúWhen I was completely naked. I was wiped out, dying without food. And I prayed to God ‚Äì save me, get me out of this already, and you just say to yourself like ‚Ä¶ what the hell is going on?‚Äù
 

   
  Braslavski said it was ‚Äúunequivocally‚Äù sexual assault.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt is sexual violence and its main purpose was to humiliate me. The goal was to crush my dignity and that‚Äôs exactly what he did,‚Äù Braslavski said in the interview, which was filmed last week and shared with CNN. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard for me to talk about that part, specifically. I don‚Äôt like to talk about it.‚Äù
 

   
  CNN has approached Palestinian Islamic Jihad for comment.
 

   
  Braslavski was among the final 20 living hostages released last month after more than two years in captivity as part of the ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas. He was held by Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a Palestinian militant group in Gaza allied with Hamas which also held Israeli hostages during the war.
 

   
  The militants released footage of an emaciated Braslavski earlier this year, with his father saying he did not recognize his son. His mother  told Israeli media  he was allegedly pressured to convert to Islam in exchange for food.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard. It was a horrific thing,‚Äù Braslavski said of his alleged sexual assault. ‚ÄúYou just pray to God for it to stop. And while I was there ‚Äì every day, every beating ‚Äì I‚Äôd say to myself, ‚ÄòI survived another day in hell.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúTomorrow morning, I‚Äôll wake up to another hell. And another hell. And another hell,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt end.‚Äù
 

   
  Other Israeli hostages alleged they were sexually assaulted or abused while in Hamas captivity, an allegation Hamas officials repeatedly denied. But until now, it had been only female hostages coming forward.
 

   
  Amit Soussana, an Israeli hostage who was released after nearly two months in captivity, alleged she was sexually assaulted at gunpoint by her Hamas guard. She is one of more than a dozen former hostages who described experiencing or witnessing sexual violence while in captivity, according to a  report compiled by the Dinal Project .
 

   
  The UN‚Äôs Special Representative on Sexual Violence in Conflict Pramila Patten also published a report last year which alleges they  found ‚Äúclear and convincing‚Äù information  that hostages in Gaza were sexually abused.

articles.title: Maine Rep. Jared Golden won‚Äôt run for reelection, opening a tough seat for Democrats in 2026
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Maine Democratic Representative Jared Golden has announced he will not seek reelection in 2026, creating a crucial open seat in one of the nation‚Äôs most competitive districts. The 2nd District is notable for being narrowly won by Democrats in 2024 while Donald Trump carried it by 10 points, making it a key battleground. Golden, a Marine veteran and advocate for bipartisan solutions, cited personal concerns‚Äîsuch as threats to his family and political exhaustion‚Äîalong with frustration over growing partisan extremism in the Democratic Party as reasons for stepping down. His decision opens the door for a competitive primary, with challengers like Maine State Auditor Matthew Dunlap and former Governor Paul LePage entering the race. While Democratic leaders like Suzan DelBene praise Golden‚Äôs contributions and view recent election results as a hopeful sign for the party, Golden warns that Democrats are risking ideological polarization by embracing obstructionist tactics. His departure signals both a personal retreat from politics and a strategic opening for a new generation of political leaders in Maine.
keyTakeAways: Jared Golden, a Democratic representative from Maine, announced he will not seek reelection in 2026, opening a competitive seat for both parties.
Golden won Maine‚Äôs 2nd District by less than 1 point in 2024, while Donald Trump carried it by about 10 points, making it one of the most politically volatile districts in the country.

Golden's decision stems from personal and political concerns, including the length of the government shutdown, political violence threats to his family, and frustration with partisan extremism within the Democratic Party.
Golden has been a vocal critic of partisan bickering and obstruction, especially during the government shutdown, and has often crossed party lines to promote bipartisan solutions.
A primary challenge from Maine State Auditor Matthew Dunlap emerged, with criticism from both Democrats and Republicans over Golden‚Äôs moderate stance and past disagreements with party leadership.
Golden expressed skepticism about the viability of his challengers, including Dunlap and former Governor Paul LePage, calling them not aligned with the future of Congress.
Democratic leadership, including Suzan DelBene, praised Golden‚Äôs efforts and viewed the recent election results as a positive sign for Democratic competitiveness in the 2026 midterms.
Golden warned that the Democratic Party risks becoming dominated by extreme, obstructionist elements, urging members to reject no-holds-barred tactics seen in recent political conflict.

articles.content:
Maine Rep. Jared Golden won‚Äôt run for reelection, opening a tough seat for Democrats in 2026 
       
  By David Wright, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:47 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Democratic Rep. Jared Golden of Maine announced Wednesday that he would not seek reelection in 2026, putting pressure on his party to hold one of the toughest seats in the country for them next year.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt fear losing. What has become apparent to me is that I now dread the prospect of winning,‚Äù Golden wrote in  The Bangor Daily News . ‚ÄúSimply put, what I could accomplish in this increasingly unproductive Congress pales in comparison to what I could do in that time as a husband, a father and a son.‚Äù
 

   
  Golden‚Äôs decision robs Democrats of the advantage of incumbency in one of the country‚Äôs top battleground districts, which Golden won by less than 1 point last year while Trump carried it by roughly 10 points.
 

   
  The Marine veteran, who was first elected to Congress in 2018, has defended Maine‚Äôs sprawling, rural 2nd District as President Donald Trump has done well there. But even as Golden‚Äôs been key to bolstering numbers in the House Democratic Caucus, he‚Äôs long bucked party leadership in Washington, DC.
 

   
  Golden on Wednesday pointed to the record-breaking length of the government shutdown, writing that ‚Äúthe nonstop, hyperbolic accusations and recriminations by both sides reveal just how broken Congress has become.‚Äù His simmering frustration with party politics in Washington was apparent last month when he castigated members of his own party over the shutdown, which he wrote was ‚Äúdriven by demands, from some in the Democrats‚Äô base and far-left groups, for the party to visibly ‚Äòfight‚Äô Donald Trump.‚Äù
 

   
  Amid the backbiting, Golden drew a primary challenge from Maine state Auditor Matthew Dunlap, who criticized the moderate congressman for his series of high-profile breaks with Democrats since entering Congress in 2019.
 

   
  In announcing his retirement from Congress, Golden expressed skepticism about his challengers including Dunlap and former Republican Gov. Paul LePage.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMy sincere hope is that by creating an open seat, my departure makes space for a competitive primary for both Democrats and Republicans, as Paul LePage and Matt Dunlap are a far cry from being standard bearers of the generations that will inherit the legacy of today‚Äôs Congress,‚Äù Golden said.
 

   
  The four-term congressman and father of young children also invoked recent high-profile episodes of political violence and threats against his own family in explaining his decision ‚Äî including, he wrote, one that saw his family ‚Äúsitting in a hotel room on Thanksgiving last year after yet another threat against our home.‚Äù
 

   
  Golden insisted the electoral challenge of defending his seat wasn‚Äôt part of his calculus.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI know that if I were to continue my campaign, I would prevail. My record of winning the most challenging district held by any Democrat ‚Äî of outperforming the top and bottom of the ticket four times ‚Äî speaks for itself,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee Chairwoman Suzan DelBene praised Golden while pointing to Tuesday night‚Äôs election results as a hopeful sign for the party in the 2026 midterms.
 

   
  ‚ÄúHis efforts to revitalize the Blue Dog Coalition have helped to grow our party, and his willingness to cross the aisle and find bipartisan solutions was deservedly rewarded time and time again by his constituents who continued to re-elect him despite bruising campaigns,‚Äù the Washington state Democrat said in a statement.
 

   
  ‚ÄúLast night‚Äôs election results make clear that voters are ready to elect a Democratic majority that keeps its promise to lower costs and fight for everyday people,‚Äù she added, committing ‚Äúeverything necessary‚Äù to keep Maine‚Äôs 2nd District blue.
 

   
  But Golden on Wednesday offered a warning to members of his party, whom he cautioned are ‚Äúallowing the most extreme, pugilistic elements of our party to call the shots.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis year, reeling from the losses of the last election, too many Democrats have given into demands that we use the same no-holds barred, obstructionary tactics as the GOP,‚Äù he said.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani Announces All-Female Leadership Team for NYC Transition Including Lina Khan
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani has announced an all-female leadership team for his transition, featuring former FTC Chair Lina Khan, former deputy mayor Maria Torres-Springer, United Way head Grace Bonilla, Melanie Hartzog, and political consultant Elana Leopold. The team reflects a commitment to progressive policies, including aggressive antitrust enforcement and tax reforms targeting the wealthy to reduce the cost of living. Mamdani emphasizes a grassroots, inclusive transition approach, calling for renewed donations from supporters to fund operations. He also signals openness to dialogue with President Donald Trump despite political tensions, focusing on shared concerns about economic policy and its impact on New Yorkers.
keyTakeAways: Zohran Mamdani has announced an all-female leadership team for his transition to New York City Mayor, emphasizing inclusivity and representation.

The team includes prominent figures such as former FTC Chair Lina Khan, former first deputy mayor Maria Torres-Springer, Grace Bonilla (United Way of New York City), Melanie Hartzog (former deputy mayor for health and human services), and political consultant Elana Leopold.

Lina Khan's appointment signals Mamdani's continued commitment to anti-oligarchy policies and aggressive antitrust measures, aligning with his call for tax reforms on the wealthy to reduce the cost of living.

Mamdani emphasizes a broad, inclusive transition that will draw from frontline organizers, veterans, policy experts, and working-class residents, indicating a grassroots and community-driven approach.
Mamdani calls for renewed donations from supporters to fund transition operations, highlighting a direct link between public support and the practical execution of his agenda.

Despite criticism from President Donald Trump, who has labeled Mamdani a 'communist' and threatened to withdraw federal funding, Mamdani is open to dialogue about shared policy goals such as cost of living and the impact of Trump-era legislation on New Yorkers.

Zohran Mamdani announces an all-female leadership team for his transition including former FTC Chair Lina Khan 
       
  By Gloria Pazmino, David Wright, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:25 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani on Wednesday announced an all-female team of co-chairs for his transition team, including  former Federal Trade Commission chair Lina Khan .
 

   
  The team of co-chairs includes Khan, former first deputy mayor Maria Torres-Springer, United Way of New York City head Grace Bonilla, Melanie Hartzog, who is a former deputy mayor for health and human services, and political consultant Elana Leopold.
 

   
  Khan is a prominent ally of Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders who  was an aggressive antitrust regulator  when she led the FTC during Democrat Joe Biden‚Äôs presidency. Her appointment is a signal that Mamdani, who has called for tax hikes on the wealthy to pay for policies intended to reduce the cost of living, will continue to push against what he refers to as the ‚Äúoligarchy‚Äù when he becomes mayor on January 1.
 

   
  Mamdani also previewed the announcement of other ‚Äúleaders who will implement our agenda,‚Äù saying that ‚Äúsome of these people will have familiar names, others will not.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe will cast a wide net,‚Äù Mamdani said. ‚ÄúWe will speak to the organizers on the front lines of the fight to improve our city government, veterans with proven track records, policy experts from around the country and the world, and working people who know better than anyone what their neighborhoods need.‚Äù
 

   
  Mamdani called on his supporters to start donating to his cause again in order to fund ‚Äúa transition that can meet the moment of preparing for January 1.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere were a few months ago where I told supporters across the city to stop donating, and today I am asking them to start once again,‚Äù Mamdani said.
 

   
  He explained that his transition team will require staff, research and infrastructure ‚Äî all of which need funding.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm excited for the fact that it will be funded by the very people who brought us to this point, the working people who have been left behind by the politics of the city,‚Äù Mamdani added.
 

   
  While he said the White House hasn‚Äôt reached out after his win, he said he was open to speaking with President Donald Trump, who has derided him as a ‚Äúcommunist‚Äù and threatened to pull federal funding from his hometown.
 

   
  Mamdani said he is ‚Äúinterested in having a conversation with President Trump on the ways in which we can work together to serve New Yorkers, whether that be delivering on his campaign promises around cost of living or the many issues that New Yorkers have been sharing with me about the drastic impacts that the legislation that President Trump has ushered through Washington will mean for them and their lives.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI look forward to having those conversations and to making clear that if there is ever anything to be spoken about that could benefit the people of the city, I am ready and willing to speak to anyone about it,‚Äù the mayor-elect added.

articles.title: Two New Jersey Men Arrested in Terror Plot Probe on Heels of Michigan Arrests
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Two New Jersey men, a 19-year-old and a 20-year-old, were arrested in connection with an ISIS-inspired terror plot that originated in Michigan. The investigation began after FBI surveillance revealed encrypted communications between suspects discussing travel to Syria to join ISIS, plans for attacks using firearms and improvised explosives, and specific references to the 2015 Paris attacks. One suspect, Mohmed Ali, was arrested at Newark Liberty International Airport after attempting to travel to Turkey, while another, Majed Mahmoud, was taken into custody at his home. A third suspect, Ayob Nasser, was also arrested in Michigan and had viewed violent mass shooting videos and scouted a park as a possible attack site. The suspects were linked through shared online communication, with one group call mentioning travel to Syria and references to attacks in Paris and the U.S. The FBI's surveillance, which began in June 2024, included monitoring phone movements, visits to gun ranges, and late-night meetings, ultimately leading to arrests on October 31, 2025. All three are charged with conspiring to provide material support to ISIS and attempting to transfer firearms and ammunition for terrorist use. The case underscores a growing threat of extremist ideology and coordinated planning among individuals across states, with potential for attacks on public spaces during high-visibility events like Halloween.

The suspects were part of an online communication group discussing detailed travel plans, weapons, training, and methods to avoid detection, with one planning to travel to Turkey and Syria to join ISIS.

The Michigan plot, uncovered through encrypted group calls and surveillance, allegedly involved plans to carry out a terrorist attack on Halloween, possibly at a disco or nightclub, referencing the 2015 Paris attacks.

A third individual, Ayob Nasser (19), was arrested in Michigan and charged with similar terrorism-related offenses, having viewed violent mass shooting videos and scouting a park as a potential attack site.
FBI surveillance included tracking phone movements, physical visits to gun ranges, and late-night park meetings, revealing coordinated preparation for a terrorist attack.
One group call referenced a possible attack in Paris in 2015, indicating a known reference to ISIS's prior successful attacks in France, suggesting a pattern of ideological inspiration and planning.
The suspects allegedly pledged allegiance to ISIS and discussed providing material support, including firearms, ammunition, and travel to Syria.

articles.content:
2 New Jersey men arrested in terror plot probe on heels of Michigan arrests 
       
  By Mark Morales, Brynn Gingras, John Miller, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        7:58 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Two New Jersey men were arrested in a terror plot probe on the heels of  arrests in Michigan  in an alleged ISIS-inspired terrorist plot, said Alina Habba, acting US attorney for New Jersey.
 

   
  The two men are said to have been part of the same online communication group as the ones who hatched the alleged plot in Michigan, a law enforcement official close to the investigation said Wednesday. The forum was not necessarily to discuss and participate in the same plot, but to discuss their own separate schemes, the official said.
 

   
  One suspect is charged with conspiring to provide material support to a designated terrorist organization, while the other is charged with transmitting violent antisemitic threats across the internet to people in New Jersey and beyond, said Habba.
 

   
  Using encrypted messaging applications, the suspects discussed ‚Äúdetailed travel plans,‚Äù including physical training, weapons such as firearms and improvised explosive devices, and methods to avoid law enforcement detection, Habba said.
 

   
  One of the suspects, a 19-year-old man from New Jersey, was taken into custody at Newark Liberty International Airport on Tuesday morning, the official said.
 

   
  Authorities had been monitoring his movements and arrested him once they noticed he moved up his flight to Turkey, the official said. The act of going to the airport was seen as a move to further his plot, triggering the arrest, the official said. Authorities routinely make these types of arrests after monitoring online chatter from targets they are zeroing in on, the official said.
 

   
  The suspect ultimately planned to travel from Turkey to Syria, where he would attempt to join ISIS, the officials said.
 

   
  The second suspect, a 20-year-old New Jersey man who was arrested at his home, had planned to travel to Syria with the other suspect, the officials said.
 

   
  Habba said the two New Jersey suspects ‚Äúpledged themselves to ISIS and were plotting acts of terrorism in our country.‚Äù
 

   
  The FBI declined comment.
 

   
  The two men were scheduled to make their initial appearances in federal court in New Jersey on Wednesday, Habba said. ‚ÄúWe will continue to move swiftly and decisively whenever terrorism or hate threatens our communities,‚Äù she said.
 

   
  A series of encrypted phone calls ‚Äì secretly recorded by a confidential FBI source ‚Äì tipped off federal agents that a group was allegedly planning to carry out a  terrorist attack  in Michigan on behalf of ISIS, according to a criminal complaint unsealed Monday.
 

   
  Mohmed Ali, 20, and Majed Mahmoud, 20, were each charged with ‚Äúreceiving and transferring, and attempting and conspiring to transfer, firearms and ammunition knowing and having reasonable cause to believe that the firearms and ammunition would be used to commit a Federal crime of terrorism,‚Äù according to the criminal complaint.
 

   
  A third person, Ayob Nasser, 19, was arrested on the same charge Wednesday, the US Attorney‚Äôs Office for the Eastern District of Michigan said.
 

   
  All three men also were each charged with conspiring to provide material support resources to a designated foreign terrorist organization, according to an amended complaint.
 

   
  Nasser had viewed videos that depicted several mass shootings in the days leading up to Halloween, including the 2023 shooting at The Covenant School in Nashville, Tennessee, and the 2022 shooting at Tops Supermarket in Buffalo, New York, according to the complaint.
 

   
  The complaint also alleges that Nasser and another individual made two separate trips to an amusement park that they appeared to be scouting as a possible attack location.
 

   
  The attorneys representing Ali and Mahmoud declined comment on Wednesday. CNN has reached out to Nasser‚Äôs attorney for comment.
 

   
  Federal officials have yet to charge a juvenile described throughout the complaint unsealed Monday as Person 1 in connection with the alleged plot.
 

   
  But the complaint details how agents doggedly surveilled the alleged co-conspirators for two months as they visited multiple gun ranges and held late-night meetings in local parks during what authorities allege was preparation for a possible terrorist attack.
 

   
  Then, based on what they believed to be references to a possible attack on Halloween, agents swooped in to seize the weapons and take Ali and Mahmoud into custody in the predawn hours of October 31.
 

   
  According to an FBI affidavit supporting the criminal complaint, the agency began surveilling a man, described as ‚Äúco-conspirator 1,‚Äù in 2024 as he traveled in the US and overseas.
 

   
  In June, agents allegedly tracked the man‚Äôs phone to Dearborn, Michigan, and physical surveillance led them to Ali‚Äôs home there, where he stayed for two nights.
 

   
  The following month, according to the FBI, the man joined a group call from overseas with five others ‚Äì including an FBI confidential source, who recorded the meeting. Person 1, Mahmoud and Ali do not appear to have been part of this call.
 

   
  During the call, the group allegedly discussed ‚Äútraveling together to Syria to join ISIS‚Äù and co-conspirator 1 said they were ‚Äúgonna die there ‚Ä¶ unless,‚Äù he told the group, ‚Äúthe Amir sends you to Paris for a 2015.‚Äù
 

   
  A review of co-conspirator 1‚Äôs cellphone allegedly revealed he had ‚ÄúPerson 1‚Äôs phone number saved in his phone under ‚ÄòAthari‚Äô and ALI‚Äôs phone number saved in his phone as ‚ÄòBukhari.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  According to the complaint, one of the participants on the call also stated, ‚ÄúAthari and Bukhari said they were going to stay back and do the ‚Äòsame thing as France.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúKnowing Athari, it‚Äôs (the attack) probably going to be at like a club, a disco,‚Äù co-conspirator 1 said, according to the complaint.
 

   
  The reference to Paris stood out to FBI counterterrorism experts. They concluded it was a thinly veiled nod to the coordinated ISIS-linked terrorist attacks that unfolded across Paris in  November 2015 . More than 130 people were killed in the attacks and scores more were wounded.
 

   
  After studying the call, the FBI concluded an attack could be imminent and began keeping close tabs on Ali and Mahmoud.
 

   
  In the predawn hours of October 31, FBI agents descended on the Detroit suburb where the men lived and detonated smoke bombs before storming into their homes. Both Ali and Mahmoud were arrested.
 

   
  A detention hearing for them is scheduled for Monday.
 

   
   This story has been updated with additional information.

articles.content:
Why UPS was still flying the 34-year-old MD-11 plane that crashed 
       
  By Chris Isidore, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        6:54 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The UPS freighter that crashed in Louisville was a 34-year old jet. While that‚Äôs old for a passenger plane, that‚Äôs not so unusual in the world of air cargo.
 

   
  There are no initial indications that the age of the McDonnell Douglas MD-11 was in any way a factor in the  fatal crash  that killed at least 12 people shortly after take off from Louisville, Kentucky Tuesday evening. The cause is still under investigation and will be for some time.
 

   
  But the crash does highlight how planes, can have a much longer long lifespan than the average flyer realizes. That‚Äôs because older planes are often retired due to fuel economy, rather than wear-and-tear on the aircraft itself. If a plane isn‚Äôt flying as much, fuel economy isn‚Äôt as large a concern.
 

   
  And cargo jets fly about 30% less than passenger jets.
 

   
  The problem of fuel efficiency is especially true in the case of the MD-11, which has a third engine embedded in the tail, as opposed to the majority of passenger jets flying over American skies today, which only have two. The MD-11 was created in a time when companies sought out three-engine aircraft for range and reliability reasons, as planes with three engines were seen as safer than planes with only two, should an engine go out while flying over the open ocean.
 

   
  But as twin-engine jets became more reliable, that became less of an issue. The MD-11, with its three thirsty engines, became an anachronism almost as soon as it was introduced.
 

   
  Even before the crash, UPS had  announced plans  to phase out the MD-11 for more fuel efficient, newer freighters.
 

   
  UPS has 25 other MD-11s in service, according to data from aviation analytics firm Cirium, and another six that have been in storage for at least the last three months. FedEx, which has been phasing out its MD-11s, has 38 in service, and 34 in storage. And cargo carrier Western Global Airlines has four in service and 12 in storage.
 

   
  And while there are still MD-11‚Äôs flying cargo, the last passenger flight for the jet came more than a decade ago, on a KLM flight from Montreal to Amsterdam in October 2014.
 

   
  McDonnell Douglas ended up building only 200 of the jets, and took its last orders for the plane in 1998 from cargo carriers FedEx and Lufthansa Cargo. By then the company had already merged with Boeing. And it didn‚Äôt take long for most of the passenger versions of the MD-11 to be converted to freighters.
 

   
  The MD-11 that crashed was initially delivered to Thai Airlines the first year the plane was put into service in 1991. It was sold to UPS and converted to a freighter in 2006.
 

   
  At that point it essentially became a new airplane, undergoing a complete overhaul.
 

   
  Aircraft also undergo overhauls even if they continue in passenger service, being stripped down to their bare frames for inspections, maintenance and upgrades in what is known in the industry as a ‚ÄúD-check.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúAn airliner is only as old, basically, as its last D-check,‚Äù aviation consultant Mike Boyd said Wednesday morning.
 

   
  Boyd said there as a number of old passenger plane models still in use. American, Delta and United airlines each fly hundreds of planes models which have an average age of between 20 to 30 years, according to company reports. Southwest has more than 300 737-700s with an average age of 19 years.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAt UPS, I would not be concerned about airplane age. The main issue for operators is increasing maintenance costs, which US carriers don‚Äôt take lightly, and fuel burn.‚Äù
 

   
  But despite those costs, the MD-11 has still found a useful life as cargo carriers, long after the production of the planes came to a halt and passengers airlines stopped flying them.
 

   
   ‚Äì CNN‚Äôs Aaron Cooper contributed to this report.

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Prince William shares with his children a hopeful message about the future, emphasizing that climate progress is real and driven by innovation, especially through the Earthshot Prize. articles.content:
Prince William reveals what he tells his kids about climate change to Amanpour 
       
  By CNN staff
 

       
Updated: 
        3:40 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
   Prince William  says he tells his children that their future is ‚Äúgoing to be as bright as futures gone by‚Äù thanks to scientists working to repair the world‚Äôs climate.
 

   
  In an exclusive interview with CNN‚Äôs Christiane Amanpour, William ‚Äì who had traveled to Brazil ahead of the  COP30 climate summit  to unveil the finalists of his prestigious Earthshot Prize ‚Äì said young people needed to see climate ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù to give them hope for the future.
 

   
  ‚ÄúClimate anxiety is a real thing. I hear about it wherever I go now, lots of (the) younger generation are saying, ‚ÄòWell what kind of a planet are we going to inherit?‚Äô‚Äù the prince said Wednesday, at an event in Rio de Janeiro. ‚ÄúThe younger generations need to be heard more.‚Äù
 

   
  William said he is glad that he can tell his children ‚Äì Prince George, 12; Princess Charlotte, 10; and Prince Louis, 7 ‚Äì that climate progress is being made, thanks in part to some of the work championed by the Earthshot Prize.
 

   
  ‚ÄúFor my children particularly, knowing that the planet is going to be in a healthier, better state because of the brilliant people in this room, is something that I love to tell them when they go to bed: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs going to be great. Your future is going to be as bright as futures gone by,‚Äô‚Äù he said.
 

   
  The Earthshot Prize gives a ¬£1 million ($1.3 million) grant to five winners to help fund their environmental works. This year‚Äôs finalists include a company that has developed a filter for microplastics to one that built an upcycled skyscraper. The winner will be announced later Wednesday.
 

   
  William stressed the Earthshot Prize, which launched five years ago, is not merely ‚Äúphilanthropic,‚Äù but aimed to help create ‚Äúcommercial products that are going to make life better.‚Äù
 

   
  While in Brazil, the prince is also set to give a speech at COP30, which begins on Monday in the northern city of Bel√©m, in the Amazon region.
 

   
  The timing of the conference means the next-in-line to the British throne is isolated from the fallout from the decision of his father, King Charles III, to strip  Andrew Mountbatten Windsor  of his title of prince over his ties to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
 

   
  Asked by Amanpour about the recent ‚Äúchange‚Äù in his own family, William did not answer directly.
 

   
  Instead, he praised the Earthshot Prize as a positive example of ‚Äúchange,‚Äù saying he wants to surround himself ‚Äúwith people who want to make change and do good in the world.‚Äù

articles.content:
Warning signs for the GOP, lessons for Democrats: How Tuesday‚Äôs results will shape the 2026 midterms 
       
  By Eric Bradner, Arit John, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:57 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Democrats‚Äô dominance  in Tuesday‚Äôs elections  reset expectations ahead of next year‚Äôs midterm battle for House and Senate control, reinvigorating a party that has been in the political wilderness and leaving Republicans lamenting that the gains President Donald Trump made a year ago with key portions of the electorate all but evaporated.
 

   
  ‚ÄúLast night, if that wasn‚Äôt a message to all Republicans, then we‚Äôve got our head jammed in the ground,‚Äù said West Virginia GOP Sen. Jim Justice.
 

   
  The list of Democratic winners spanned the party‚Äôs ideological spectrum ‚Äî from Zohran Mamdani, the democratic socialist elected mayor of New York City, to Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill, the moderates with strong national security credentials elected governors of Virginia and New Jersey, respectively.
 

   
  Their wins could rally Democrats in competitive House, Senate and governor‚Äôs races next year around a message all three made central to their campaigns, in different forms: pledges to reduce the cost of living.
 

   
  But the playing field won‚Äôt be easy for Democrats. Strategists in both parties agree that control of the House will be in play, but the net effect of redistricting moves around the country ‚Äî particularly if the  Supreme Court decides  to weaken the Voting Rights Act ‚Äî could leave fewer competitive seats for Democrats. And the 2026 Senate map includes only a handful of GOP-held seats that appear to be in play and multiple seats Democrats will have to defend.
 

   
  Still, Tuesday‚Äôs results may embolden Democrats to continue their strategy in the  ongoing government shutdown,  while igniting new debates over what kinds of candidates can win, and where.
 

   
  Margie Omero, a Democratic pollster, said the elections should be viewed within the broader context of a year in which the party‚Äôs voters have packed town halls and rallies, won key races like the Wisconsin Supreme Court contest in the spring and a slew of special elections, and scored candidate recruitment victories for next year‚Äôs midterms.
 

   
  ‚ÄúTake the whole year into account and it tells a pretty similar story, which is that Democrats are motivated and Republicans are less motivated,‚Äù Omero said.
 

   
  Trump, she said, ‚Äúlost popularity and he‚Äôs lost altitude on all of his top issues, like the economy and immigration.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúWhere does that leave his supporters in a midterm or off-year election?‚Äù Omero said. ‚ÄúWhat are they coming out for, if he‚Äôs less popular and his policies are less popular and his agenda‚Äôs less popular?‚Äù
 

   
  In addition to the wins in governor‚Äôs races and mayoral elections, and a critical victory in a statewide vote to green-light a redistricting effort to add five more seats that favor Democrats in California, the party also scored a long list of lower-profile victories on Tuesday.
 

   
  They broke the GOP‚Äôs supermajority in the Mississippi state Senate. They flipped two seats on Georgia‚Äôs Public Service Commission. They defeated a voter identification ballot initiative in Maine. Their incumbent Pennsylvania Supreme Court justices prevailed in retention votes.
 

   
  The results showed that many of the gains Trump had made in 2024 have evaporated. In New Jersey, Republican gubernatorial nominee Jack Ciattarelli couldn‚Äôt match Trump‚Äôs support levels with Latino and Black voters. In Virginia, Spanberger notched the most impressive Democratic performance in recent years ‚Äî besting the margins of the party‚Äôs last two presidential nominees and carrying a scandal-plagued nominee for attorney general, Jay Jones, to victory on her coattails.
 

   
  For the GOP, the fallout could come in a number of forms ‚Äî including altering the party‚Äôs push for redistricting to add winnable congressional seats in deep-red states, and changing how Republicans in competitive midterm races approach Trump.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe picture is pretty clear,‚Äù said Republican pollster Whit Ayres. ‚ÄúIt is not a muddled message.‚Äù
 

   
  Ayres pointed to several lessons Republicans should take from Tuesday‚Äôs results. In Virginia and New Jersey, two states Trump lost in all three of his presidential runs, Republican gubernatorial candidates tied themselves to the president, a ‚Äúlosing strategy from the start,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Republicans might also be inclined to rethink their strategy on redistricting, he said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúGiven the Democratic margins yesterday, about the last thing you want to do if you want to hold on to the House is weaken Republican incumbent House members, and that‚Äôs exactly what will happen if you‚Äôre trying to carve out more Republican districts,‚Äù he said.
 

   
    Trump world deflects blame
 

   
  For his part, Trump and his top allies publicly downplayed the election results, with the president noting on social media that he wasn‚Äôt on the ballot. He partially blamed the ongoing federal government shutdown,  telling Republican lawmakers  in a closed-door session Wednesday morning that they are getting ‚Äúkilled‚Äù politically by the impasse, a source told CNN.
 

   
  Vice President JD Vance said that ‚Äúit‚Äôs idiotic to overreact to a couple of elections in blue states.‚Äù But he also warned that the GOP needs ‚Äúto do better at turning out voters than we have in the past.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúI said it in 2022, and I‚Äôve said it repeatedly since: our coalition is ‚Äòlower propensity‚Äô and that means we have to do better at turning out voters than we have in the past,‚Äù Vance said Wednesday morning on X.
 

   
  Vance also urged Republicans to focus on affordability. He said the Trump administration ‚Äúinherited a disaster from Joe Biden and Rome wasn‚Äôt built in a day.‚Äù
 

   
  Trump adviser Alex Bruesewitz called the election results a ‚Äúgreat lesson for the Republican Party,‚Äù blaming the losing Virginia gubernatorial nominee, Lt. Gov. Winsome Earle-Sears, for failing to excite Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúMake America Great Again‚Äù movement.
 

   
  ‚ÄúYour candidate needs to be able to turn out ALL FACTIONS of our party, and they do that by being MAGA all the way,‚Äù he  wrote on X .
 

   
  Though Tuesday‚Äôs GOP losses were wide-ranging, Republicans focused on elevating one Democratic winner: Mamdani, the 34-year-old Muslim and democratic socialist mayor-elect of New York City.
 

   
  House Majority Leader Steve Scalise called Mamdani ‚Äúthe new leader of the Democrat Party.‚Äù
 

   
  House Speaker Mike Johnson said House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries is ‚Äúapparently a socialist now,‚Äù since Jeffries endorsed Mamdani.
 

   
    Democratic ideological rifts remain
 

   
  Mamdani‚Äôs victory over former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in New York City emboldened the left wing of the Democratic Party. Usamah Andrabi, a spokesperson for Justice Democrats, a group created to oust ‚Äúcorporate Democrats‚Äù and elect progressives, said Mamdani‚Äôs win marks a ‚Äúturning point‚Äù for their movement and shows the importance of competitive races.
 

   
  One long-simmering debate Tuesday‚Äôs results didn‚Äôt settle is the ideological battle within the Democratic Party over the way forward, with a host of competitive House and Senate primaries just months away and the 2028 presidential primary already looming large.
 

   
  ‚ÄúDemocratic primaries can and should be the battleground for the control of our party‚Äôs direction,‚Äù Andrabi said.
 

   
  However, in New Jersey and Virginia, the winning Democratic candidates are moderates with strong national security credentials. Spanberger, the Virginia governor-elect,  criticized Mamdani  in an interview with CNN just days before the election, suggesting his proposals aimed at reducing the cost of living will ultimately disappoint his supporters.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to settle,‚Äù said Omero, the Democratic pollster. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre able to have more moderate candidates in some places and more progressive candidates in some places. That feels like an important lesson.‚Äù
 

   
  One area where Democrats appeared broadly on the same page Wednesday is the ongoing government shutdown ‚Äî fueled in part by Democrats‚Äô demand that Republicans make concessions on health care funding in order to pass a measure that would fund the government.
 

   
  Connecticut Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy wrote on X that it is ‚Äúnot a coincidence these big wins came at the exact moment when Democrats are using our power to stand for something and be strong. A huge risk to not learn that lesson.‚Äù
