articles.title: Detroit is back from the dead. But not everyone is feeling it
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Detroit, once a city in decline marked by bankruptcy, population loss, and economic stagnation, is experiencing a significant revival. The opening of Hudson‚Äôs Detroit ‚Äî a $1.4 billion mixed-use complex at the site of the historic J.L. Hudson‚Äôs department store ‚Äî symbolizes this transformation. Led by billionaire Dan Gilbert and supported by major investments from JPMorgan and General Motors, which is moving its global headquarters to the site, the city has seen population growth and economic activity rebound. However, the recovery remains uneven: while downtown has seen revitalization, many neighborhoods remain economically disadvantaged, with high vacancy rates, low median income, and declining Black populations. Critics argue that investment has been concentrated in central areas, failing to deliver inclusive prosperity. The city‚Äôs new mayor, Mary Sheffield, is committed to ensuring that growth translates into broader economic benefits, including job creation and increased homeownership, marking a critical moment for equitable urban development.
keyTakeAways: Detroit‚Äôs population declined by nearly 28% between 2000 and 2015, with a sharp drop in Black residents (72,000 fewer since 2013), signaling demographic shifts and ongoing inequality.

Hudson‚Äôs Detroit, a $1.4 billion project at the site of the former J.L. Hudson‚Äôs department store, represents the first major new skyscraper in nearly 50 years and symbolizes the city‚Äôs transformation from bankruptcy to economic revival.
Dan Gilbert, the billionaire behind the project, has invested over $7 billion in downtown properties and helped catalyze a turnaround through real estate and business development.
JPMorgan has invested over $2 billion in Detroit, with programs focused on job training, affordable housing, and community development, particularly in neighborhoods like Corktown.
General Motors is moving its global headquarters to Hudson‚Äôs Detroit, a move that underscores the city‚Äôs deep historical and economic ties to the auto industry.

Despite downtown revival, significant disparities remain: 18 of Detroit‚Äôs 139 square miles are still vacant, median income is $38,000 (half of regional median), and only 26% of households are middle class.
The city has seen population growth for the first time in nearly 60 years, but growth is concentrated in affluent areas, leaving many neighborhoods behind.
Detroit‚Äôs new mayor, Mary Sheffield, is the first woman to lead the city and has campaigned on expanding economic recovery and inclusive growth.

Critics argue that corporate and philanthropic investment has been concentrated downtown and has failed to equitably uplift underserved neighborhoods, highlighting a persistent gap between urban development and equitable prosperity.

articles.content:
Detroit is back from the dead. But not everyone is feeling it 
       
  By Nathaniel Meyersohn, Matt Egan, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        4:03 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Hudson‚Äôs Detroit, the Motor City‚Äôs first new skyscraper in nearly half a century, is a symbol of Detroit‚Äôs transformation from bankruptcy to boomtown.
 

   
  The $1.4 billion project includes a recently opened office building as well as retail on the site of the former J.L. Hudson‚Äôs department store and a skyscraper that will eventually feature high-end condos and a five-star hotel.
 

   
  Detroit ‚Äúwas probably at the bottom of the barrel in this country ‚Äì from crime and unemployment to everything in between,‚Äù Dan Gilbert, the billionaire who has helped catalyze Detroit‚Äôs revival, said in an interview with CNN. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a 180-degree comeback.‚Äù Gilbert‚Äôs real estate company developed the complex at the former Hudson‚Äôs, a shopping mecca for generations that closed in 1983.
 

   
  Detroit‚Äôs population is  growing for the first time in nearly 60 years . General Motors is moving its headquarters to Hudson‚Äôs. JPMorgan is moving there too, having announced a big push to invest $100 million in the city more than a decade ago. On Wednesday, JPMorgan said its investment in Detroit had surpassed $2 billion.
 

   
  But Detroit‚Äôs improbable comeback remains incomplete. Its downtown has made a remarkable recovery from the city‚Äôs 2013 bankruptcy ‚Äì the largest municipal bankruptcy in American history. Meanwhile, some parts of the city have been left behind. Others are still vacant.
 

   
    Detroit‚Äôs rise and fall
 

   
  Detroit was once the fourth-largest city in the country, home to America‚Äôs automobile industry. In 1950, Detroit‚Äôs population topped 1.8 million.
 

   
  By 2013, Detroit‚Äôs population had fallen to 700,000.
 

   
  Numerous factors  hurt Detroit  over many years, including a shrinking tax base, high unemployment and poverty, and rising health care and pension costs for city employees. Detroit‚Äôs reliance on the auto industry hurt the city as free trade agreements, automation and incentives from southern states sent jobs away.
 

   
  People with resources also left Detroit for the suburbs. Detroit‚Äôs population  declined  roughly 28% between 2000 and 2015, while the population in the surrounding six counties grew 3%.
 

   
  Detroit‚Äôs financial woes led to steep cuts in basic city services like trash pickup and snow plowing. An estimated 40% of street lights were  not functioning  by the time Detroit filed for bankruptcy in 2013.
 

   
  During the financial crisis in 2009, Detroit‚Äôs unemployment rate  skyrocketed to 29%  as the auto industry teetered on the brink of collapse. The average price of a home in Detroit stood at just $7,500.
 

   
  In bankruptcy, the state took over control of local government, and a state-appointed manager oversaw city spending and operations. Detroit shed $7 billion in debt and thousands of retired city workers were forced to take pension cuts.
 

   
  The city exited bankruptcy after a year and has rebounded over the past decade, thanks in part to investments from JPMorgan, Gilbert‚Äôs Bedrock and other companies and philanthropic organizations.
 

   
    Downtown vs. neighborhoods
 

   
  Gilbert, the co-founder of Rocket Mortgage and owner of the NBA‚Äôs Cleveland Cavaliers, went all-in on Detroit when many left the city for dead.
 

   
  After moving his mortgage lender‚Äôs offices downtown, Gilbert went on to buy more than 100 downtown properties, spending $7 billion along the way.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe certainly jump-started it,‚Äù Gilbert said. ‚ÄúA lot of businesses followed from suburbs and other parts of the country.‚Äù
 

   
  JPMorgan, which had a long-standing relationship with Detroit, later stepped up its investment in the city in what has become a model for corporate investment in underserved communities.
 

   
  Leveraging data and research, JPMorgan‚Äôs  years-long effort  has helped tens of thousands of Detroiters get apprenticeships or jobs, led to the creation of preservation of thousands of affordable housing units and provided aid to countless small businesses, according to the bank. In 2021, JPMorgan opened one of its first community branches in  Corktown , Detroit‚Äôs oldest neighborhood. The following year, JPMorgan launched a  virtual call center  in Detroit.
 

   
  In January, General Motors is scheduled to move its global headquarters to Hudson‚Äôs Detroit. The move comes 16 years after the bankruptcies of General Motors and Chrysler that intensified Detroit‚Äôs downfall.
 

   
  ‚ÄúGM and the Detroit‚Äôs DNA are interwoven. The two things just go together,‚Äù said Dave Massaron, GM‚Äôs vice president of infrastructure and corporate citizenship. ‚ÄúThe city is on an upward trajectory for the first time in my lifetime. It‚Äôs a great time to be here.‚Äù
 

   
  But Peter Hammer, a law professor at Wayne State University, said that corporate and philanthropic investments have been concentrated downtown and have not done enough to help the neighborhoods that need it most.
 

   
  A report  last year  commissioned by the Detroit City Council that private investments downtown ‚Äúhave not lifted the city to share in any levels of prosperity.‚Äù
 

   
  The city has experienced an influx of White, Hispanic and Asian residents over the last decade. But Detroit, long a majority Black city, has seen its Black population has decline. Since 2013, the largest loss in population has been among Black residents, with 72,000 fewer over that span.
 

   
  The median income in Detroit is $38,000, half the median income of its broader region. Only 26% of Detroit‚Äôs households are middle class, compared to 39% in the region. And 18 out of Detroit‚Äôs 139 square miles of land are still vacant, according to  Detroit Future City , a nonprofit organization.
 

   
  High-paying jobs are often held by people who live in the suburbs and commute into Detroit ‚Äî while the salaries of Detroit residents, regardless of where they work, are  lower . Nearly 70% of Detroit-resident workers traveled outside the city for jobs.
 

   
  ‚ÄúOverall, we have seen fairly widespread increases in both housing wealth and income,‚Äù said Sam Stragand of the Detroit Partnership on Economic Mobility at the University of Michigan‚Äôs Poverty Solutions. ‚ÄúThere are still pockets of the city with little activity in the mortgage market‚Äù and lagging areas in housing wealth, home repairs and high vacancies.
 

   
    New mayor
 

   
  Hudson‚Äôs opens at a moment of major change in Detroit. The city will have a new mayor for the first time since it filed for bankruptcy.
 

   
   Mike Duggan , who was elected mayor in 2013 as a write-in candidate and was the first White mayor in a city that was 80% Black, stepped down after three terms to run for governor of Michigan as an independent.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI ran and said, ‚Äòwe‚Äôre going to end this Black versus White, city versus suburban politics that had taken Detroit down for years.‚Äô And the people of Detroit voted for me and expected me to do that,‚Äù Duggan said in an interview Wednesday with CNN‚Äôs Erin Burnett and JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon.
 

   
  Detroit has passed 11 consecutive balanced budgets under Duggan, who has won praise from business leaders like Dimon.
 

   
  Duggan ‚Äúgot everyone to work and help lift up (Detroit) with good collaboration, good policy,‚Äù Dimon said.
 

   
  Mary Sheffield, president of the City Council,  won the mayoral election  Tuesday to succeed Duggan, making history as the first woman to lead the city. She has been a strong ally of Duggan‚Äôs and ran on a platform of expanding the city‚Äôs economic recovery.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is a really critical moment for Detroit to make sure we can sustain the momentum we are on,‚Äù said Ashley Williams Clark, vice president of Detroit Future City. ‚ÄúWe need to ensure that growth is not just in real estate and physical development, but paychecks and increased home ownership rates.‚Äù

articles.title: Takeaways from Trump‚Äôs rocky Supreme Court arguments over global tariffs
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court is deeply scrutinizing President Donald Trump's claim that he can impose global tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), questioning whether the phrase 'regulate importation' grants such broad authority. Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Amy Coney Barrett raised concerns about the law‚Äôs prior use and congressional intent, while Justice Brett Kavanaugh challenged the precedent set by Nixon‚Äôs 1971 tariffs. The liberal justices, including Sotomayor, Kagan, and Jackson, rejected the administration‚Äôs arguments, emphasizing that Congress designed IEEPA to constrain, not expand, presidential power and applying the 'major questions doctrine' to prevent executive overreach. A significant unresolved issue is the potential for tariff refunds ‚Äî with nearly $90 billion in revenue collected ‚Äî and the complexity of determining who would be entitled to them. The case could mark the first time the conservative Supreme Court limits a major executive action by a president since Trump‚Äôs return to office, setting a precedent for presidential power in economic policy.
keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court expressed deep concern over President Donald Trump's interpretation of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose global tariffs.

Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Amy Coney Barrett questioned whether the phrase 'regulate importation' in IEEPA can be interpreted broadly to include tariffs, noting no prior use of such authority.
Justice Brett Kavanaugh focused on President Nixon‚Äôs 1971 tariffs, asking why Congress did not revise the language of IEEPA if it objected to tariff-imposing power under 'regulate importation'.

The case raises significant questions about tariff refunds, with the government having collected nearly $90 billion in revenue, and legal experts noting the potential for a 'mess' if businesses are required to get refunds.

The court‚Äôs liberal justices ‚Äî Elena Kagan, Sonia Sotomayor, and Ketanji Brown Jackson ‚Äî rejected the administration's arguments, emphasizing that Congress intended IEEPA to constrain, not expand, presidential power.
The case is viewed as a test of the 'major questions doctrine', previously used to limit Biden-era policies, and is now being applied to Trump‚Äôs tariff actions.
The conservative majority has previously upheld expansive executive actions, but this case may mark a shift if the court rules against the administration.

articles.content:
Takeaways from Trump‚Äôs rocky Supreme Court arguments over global tariffs 
       
  By John Fritze, Elisabeth Buchwald, Devan Cole, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        3:12 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The Supreme Court appeared deeply concerned Wednesday with President  Donald Trump‚Äôs reliance on a vague federal law  to impose global tariffs, with several members of the court‚Äôs conservative wing picking apart the administration‚Äôs position in a case that could have sweeping implications for the economy and presidential power.
 

   
  During more than 2 and a half hours of argument in one of the most  important economic cases to reach the high court in years , Chief Justice John Roberts and several of his fellow conservatives pointedly questioned the administration on its contention that it has the power to levy the tariffs and that the duties are a form of ‚Äúregulation‚Äù of imports rather than a tax ultimately paid by American consumers.
 

   
  If it breaks with Trump on tariffs, it would be the first time the 6-3 conservative court has done so in a major argued case since the president returned to power in January. In case after case, the court has blessed the administration‚Äôs boundary-pushing policies on immigration, spending and independent agencies.
 

   
  Here are the key takeaways from Wednesday‚Äôs arguments:
 

   
    Roberts and Barrett pile on fast
 

   
  The arguments were lengthy, but some signals about how the justices are thinking about the appeal were clear almost immediately.
 

   
  Roberts, who is  without a question a key vote , noted that the 1970s law the administration has relied on to levy the tariffs has never before been used for that purpose, and also pointed out that Congress has explicitly authorized presidents to raise tariffs in other laws  but did not do so in the law raised in the case.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCorrect me on this if I‚Äôm not right about it,‚Äù Roberts said, but the justification is being used for ‚Äúa power to impose tariffs on any product, from any country, in any amount, for any length of time.‚Äù
 

   
  At one point, Roberts said the basis for that claim ‚Äúseemed to be misfit.‚Äù
 

   
   The International Emergency Economic Powers Act,  or IEEPA, gives a president power to ‚Äúregulate ‚Ä¶ importation‚Äù during emergencies. US Solicitor General D. John Sauer, the administration‚Äôs top appellate attorney, argued that word plainly includes the power to impose tariffs, since tariffs are the most common way a government regulates imports. But the businesses challenging the duties have balked at that reading of the law.
 

   
  Justice Amy Coney Barrett, who was Trump‚Äôs final nominee to the high court, also had questions on that point.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCan you point to any other place in the code ‚Äì or any other time in history ‚Äì where that phrase, together, ‚Äòregulate importation‚Äô has been used to confer tariff imposing authority,‚Äù Barrett said during one of the more important moments in the argument.
 

   
  Sauer reached for a case involving President Richard Nixon‚Äôs administration.
 

   
  Barrett quickly interrupted, framing that case as involving ‚Äúan intermediate appellate court,‚Äù by which she meant: not the Supreme Court.
 

   
    Kavanaugh focuses on Nixon
 

   
  Justice Brett Kavanaugh emerged as perhaps the most important ‚Äì and hardest to read ‚Äì justice on the court Wednesday.
 

   
  Trump‚Äôs second nominee to the Supreme Court repeatedly returned to an argument the Trump administration raised about Nixon. In 1971, Nixon imposed a 10% tariff on all imports ‚Äì which the administration later justified under the Trading with the Enemy Act, a precursor to IEEPA. Notably, that law used identical language to give the president authority to ‚Äúregulate‚Äù imports.
 

   
  A federal court upheld Nixon‚Äôs tariffs, and Congress enacted IEEPA with the understanding that it had done so. Sauer‚Äôs argument is that if Congress had a problem with presidents imposing tariffs based on the ‚Äúregulate‚Äù language, it would have adjusted those words when it enacted IEEPA.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPresident Nixon announced those tariffs in a nationwide prime-time speech, 10% across the board in August 1971, it was not some kind of little piece of paper, so it was well known,‚Äù Kavanaugh pressed Neal Katyal, the veteran Supreme Court attorney representing the small- and medium-sized businesses challenging the law.
 

   
  The question, Kavanaugh said of Congress, is ‚Äúwhy didn‚Äôt they change the language? Why didn‚Äôt they say regulate but not tariffs?‚Äù
 

   
  Katyal noted that Nixon did not immediately rely on the precursor to IEEPA to impose those tariffs ‚Äì only later, when the tariffs were challenged in court.
 

   
    The ‚Äòmess‚Äô of potential tariff refunds
 

   
  A significant question looming over the arguments was whether businesses would be entitled to tariff payment refunds if the justices rule against the Trump administration‚Äôs use of emergency powers to impose tariffs.
 

   
  The federal government has collected nearly $90 billion in revenue from the tariffs being challenged, according to United States Customs and Border Protection data as of September 23.
 

   
  Earlier this month, Trump said in an interview with Fox Business that if the Supreme Court ruled against him, ‚Äúwe‚Äôd have to pay back money.‚Äù
 

   
  Barrett asked Katyal how that process could work ‚Äì a signal that she may have concerns with the practical implications of ruling against the administration.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWould it be a complete mess?‚Äù she asked.
 

   
  Katyal said the businesses he‚Äôs representing should undeniably be entitled to a refund if the justices rule in their favor, but for other businesses he said it would be ‚Äúa very complicated thing.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúSo, a mess,‚Äù Barrett interjected.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult, absolutely, we don‚Äôt deny that,‚Äù Katyal responded.
 

   
  Justice Samuel Alito, another member of the court‚Äôs conservative bloc, seemed to suggest an appetite for resolving the refunds matter sooner rather than later since waiting would only increase the amount of tariff revenue collected and the complexity of it. While every lower court to consider the tariffs ruled against them, they allowed the duties to remain in place for now.
 

   
  Trade lawyers  previously told CNN  that the justices would likely be tasked with deciding who is entitled to a tariff refund if they rule against the president.
 

   
    Liberals pile on
 

   
  While several members of the court‚Äôs conservative supermajority gave mixed signals of how they may ultimately rule, the court‚Äôs three liberal justices made clear that they weren‚Äôt buying the arguments the Trump administration was attempting to sell.
 

   
  Justices Elena Kagan, Sonia Sotomayor and Ketanji Brown Jackson were reliable foes of Trump‚Äôs arguments during the hearing, repeatedly pushing back on Sauer‚Äôs arguments in defense of the tariffs.
 

   
  At one point, Jackson, an appointee of former President Joe Biden, said in a testy exchange with Sauer that Congress enacted the IEEPA in an effort to ‚Äúconstrain,‚Äù not expand, presidential power.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty clear that Congress was trying to constrain the emergency powers of the president in IEEPA,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSo it seems a little inconsistent to say that we have to interpret a statute that was designed to constrain presidential authority consistent with an understanding that Congress wanted the president to have essentially unlimited authority.‚Äù
 

   
  Kagan, meanwhile, seemed especially peeved by Trump‚Äôs repeated decision this year to declare emergencies to advance various controversial policies, including tariffs. Trump has said that trade imbalances and trafficking of fentanyl are the emergencies that justify the tariffs.
 

   
  Though the emergencies Trump declared earlier this year to justify his sweeping tariffs were not directly at issue, Kagan noted that the administration has consistently argued in a variety of other cases that courts are powerless to review a president‚Äôs decisions around national emergencies.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAnd in fact, you know, we‚Äôve had cases recently which deal with the president‚Äôs emergency powers,‚Äù said Kagan, nominated by former President Barack Obama. ‚ÄúAnd it turns out we‚Äôre in emergencies - everything all the time, about, like, half the world.‚Äù
 

   
    For consistency‚Äôs sake
 

   
  The case is about Trump, but Biden hung over the arguments from the start.
 

   
  The Supreme Court was clear in several high-profile cases during Biden‚Äôs term that administrations can‚Äôt read broad authority into vague legal language. This became known as the ‚Äúmajor questions doctrine,‚Äù or the idea that the administration must point to clear, specific language in the law when exercising policies that involve ‚Äúmajor‚Äù political or economic questions.
 

   
  Two years ago, the court‚Äôs conservative majority relied on what‚Äôs known as the ‚Äúmajor questions doctrine‚Äù to block‚ÄØ Biden‚Äôs student loan forgiveness plan . A year earlier, the court stopped Biden‚Äôs vaccine and testing requirement for 84 million Americans, concluding that Congress never explicitly gave the government the power to demand those measures during the Covid-19 pandemic.
 

   
  Katyal, arguing for the businesses affected by the tariffs, repeatedly returned to the idea that the same doctrine should apply when it comes to Trump.
 

   
  ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt we, in the Biden case, recently say an emergency can‚Äôt make clear what‚Äôs ambiguous?‚Äù asked Justice Sonia Sotomayor, an Obama nominee.
 

   
  Sauer parried with one of the administration‚Äôs central arguments: the major questions doctrine hasn‚Äôt been used before in the foreign policy context. Presidents, it is widely assumed, are due deference from the other branches of government when it comes to foreign affairs.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCounsel,‚Äù Sotomayor shot back. ‚ÄúWe have never applied it to foreign affairs, but this is a tariff. This is a tax.‚Äù
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Austin Culpepper contributed to this report.

articles.title: The vote that could make Elon Musk the first trillionaire ‚Äì or prompt him to leave Tesla
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Elon Musk is set to face a critical shareholder vote at Tesla‚Äôs annual meeting on November 5, 2025, where a new pay package could grant him up to 423.7 million shares worth approximately $1 trillion over ten years, contingent on Tesla reaching an $8.5 trillion market cap and meeting specific financial or operational targets. The package, which includes ambitious goals tied to autonomous driving, robotaxi fleets, and humanoid robots, has sparked debate: while Musk and many investors believe Tesla is on track for success, critics including institutional funds like Norges Bank, public pension funds, and advisory firms like Glass Lewis and ISS argue that the targets are vague and the compensation unfairly dilutes shareholder value. Critics estimate that Musk would earn $275 million per day if the package is fully realized, raising concerns about fairness. Despite this, strong support from Musk‚Äôs allies and past voting trends suggest a high likelihood of approval, though the outcome remains a pivotal test of investor trust in Musk‚Äôs leadership and Tesla‚Äôs future direction.
keyTakeAways: Elon Musk is facing a shareholder vote on a new pay package that could make him the world‚Äôs first trillionaire, contingent on Tesla reaching an $8.5 trillion market cap and achieving specific operational or financial targets.
The pay package includes a stock grant of up to 423.7 million shares over 10 years, which would be worth about $1 trillion if Tesla reaches the $8.5 trillion market cap.
Tesla's market cap would need to increase by 466% from current levels to reach $8.5 trillion, surpassing Nvidia‚Äôs current $5 trillion market cap.

Despite financial challenges such as declining sales and profits in the first half of 2025 and loss of US government EV support, Musk and Tesla executives believe the company is on track to succeed through autonomous driving, robotaxi fleets, and humanoid robots.

Wall Street analysts and shareholders largely support the package, with 84% of shares voting to approve it in a prior vote, while some institutional investors, including Norges Bank and public pension funds in California and New York, are voting against it.
Firms like Glass Lewis and ISS have recommended against the package, arguing that the performance targets are vague and that the package dilutes shareholder value.
Musk has criticized these firms, calling them 'corporate terrorists,' and emphasized that he needs strong voting control to influence Tesla‚Äôs future without being easily fired.
Critics argue that the pay package is excessive‚Äîequivalent to $275 million per day over 10 years‚Äîraising concerns about fairness and shareholder dilution.

articles.content:
The vote that could make Elon Musk the first trillionaire ‚Äì or prompt him to leave Tesla 
       
  By Chris Isidore, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:22 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Tesla shareholders could soon give CEO Elon Musk, already the wealthiest person on the planet, the chance to become the world‚Äôs first trillionaire ‚Äì or risk him walking away entirely.
 

   
  Musk‚Äôs new pay package is the key measure that will be up for a vote at Tesla‚Äôs annual meeting Thursday afternoon. Shareholders have widely approved Musk‚Äôs pay packages in the past, but this year holds an added risk ‚Äì the company warned in September that Musk ‚Äúraised the possibility that he may pursue other interests‚Äù should it be denied.
 

   
  The compensation would come in the form of a stock grant that would give Musk as much as 423.7 million additional shares of Tesla stock over the next 10 years. Those shares would be worth about $1 trillion, assuming the company reaches the $8.5 trillion market cap needed to have Musk qualify for the full potential payout.
 

   
  In addition to increasing the Tesla‚Äôs market cap over this ten-year period, Tesla would also need to achieve a series of either operational or financial targets for him to get the full options.
 

   
  For Tesla to reach $8.5 trillion in market value, it would need an increase of 466% from today‚Äôs stock price. That‚Äôs also about 70% higher than the world‚Äôs most valuable company, Nvidia, which hit a record  $5 trillion market cap  last week.
 

   
  However the company has had rocky financial performance so far this year that saw sales and profits plunge in the first half of the year, and strong financial headwinds going forward from the loss of US government support for EV sales.
 

   
  But Musk and Tesla executives dismiss those problems, saying Tesla is shifting focus from merely selling electric vehicles to selling self-driving cars, including a fleet of ‚Äúrobotaxis,‚Äù as well as humanoid robots.
 

   
  Those products and concepts are still under development and haven‚Äôt gone on sale, however. So even if the pay package passes, it‚Äôs not certain that Musk will ever see any of its potential hundreds of millions of shares. He will need to straighten out the problems the company faces first, and start living up the big promises that he‚Äôs made for the future.
 

   
  But Musk, as well as some Wall Street analysts and investors, think that the company is on course to reach that $8.5 trillion target and beyond, by shifting focus from merely selling electric vehicles to selling self-driving cars as well as humanoid robots as well as rides in a fleet of ‚Äúrobotaxis.‚Äù
 

   
  Still, Musk‚Äôs fans insist he is pivotal to the future, which makes them more certain the package needs to pass.
 

   
  ‚ÄúShareholders are going to support this overwhelmingly, because Musk is the key asset for Tesla,‚Äù said Dan Ives, analyst for Wedbush Securities and one of the biggest Tesla bulls on Wall Street. ‚ÄúTesla needs Musk to take it into the autonomous driving, robotic future.‚Äù
 

   
  Even those who don‚Äôt support Musk‚Äôs vision say they have little doubt the pay package will pass. In the most recent vote on his pay, 84% of shares were voted to approve the package.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI think it passes no matter what,‚Äù said Ross Gerber, CEO of Gerber Kawasaki Wealth & Investment Management, who was an early major shareholder of Tesla, but is now a harsh critic of Musk and the company.
 

   
    $275 million a day
 

   
  Gerber describes some of the operational and financial targets tied to the pay package as ‚Äúsoftball.‚Äù He also questions the size of the pay package, no matter how well the company and its stock price might do going forward.
 

   
  ‚ÄúSo if you get a trillion dollars over 10 years, that‚Äôs $275 million a day,‚Äù he said,   calculating how much Musk would earn daily, on average, if the package pays off as planned.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt know in the world anybody thinks of that as fair to shareholders,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Numerous investment funds have already announced they‚Äôre voting against the package, including Norges Bank Investment Management, which is Norway‚Äôs massive sovereign wealth fund. Some US public pension funds in California, New York, and elsewhere have also come out against the package and urged others to vote no. Some of those have voted no in the past.
 

   
  Influential advisory firms Glass Lewis and ISS have also recommended that institutional investors vote against the package, arguing that the options that Musk could be granted would dilute shareholders‚Äô stakes.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe performance targets included in the (Musk‚Äôs proposed pay package) are in many cases vague, undemanding, and subject to significant discretion by the board,‚Äù said Glass Lewis in a note that recommends voting against the package.
 

   
  Musk attacked both firms during Tesla‚Äôs recent investor call, calling them ‚Äúcorporate terrorists.‚Äù He added that their influence over some investor firms that hold shares and vote is the reason he needs a greater stake in the company.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like I‚Äôm going to go spend the money,‚Äù Musk said on the call. ‚ÄúThere needs to be enough voting control to give (me) a strong influence ‚Äì but not so much that I can‚Äôt be fired if I go insane.‚Äù

articles.title: Oldest and Biggest Maya Temple Was Built to Depict the Cosmos
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The ancient Maya site of Aguada F√©nix, built 3,050 years ago in southeastern Mexico, is the oldest and largest known Maya architectural complex, discovered through LiDAR technology. Unlike later Maya cities such as Tikal and Teotihuac√°n, it lacks stone pyramids and shows no signs of social hierarchy or royal power. Instead, its design reflects a cosmological model of the universe, with a central cruciform pit and aligned ritual artifacts and pigments tied to cardinal directions. This suggests that the Maya at this early stage of their civilization used collective labor and shared beliefs to create a sacred, ritual space aligned with astronomical and calendrical events. The site‚Äôs scale and design challenge traditional narratives of ancient civilizations as being built by elite-led hierarchies, indicating that large-scale construction could emerge from community-based cooperation in early Maya society.
keyTakeAways: Aguada F√©nix is the oldest and largest known Maya architectural site, built 3,050 years ago in southeastern Mexico.
The site was hidden beneath forest and farmland for millennia and only revealed through LiDAR remote sensing technology.
The design of the site represents a model of the cosmos, with a central cruciform pit and cross-shaped arrangements of ritual artifacts and colored pigments (blue north, green east, yellow south).
The east-west axis aligns with sunrise on October 17 and February 24 ‚Äî key dates in the Maya ritual calendar, specifically half of the 260-day ritual cycle.
The site lacks evidence of rulers, social hierarchy, or elite monuments, suggesting it was built collectively by willing participants rather than through forced labor.
The construction required over 1 million days of labor, with the main plateau needing 10.8 million days and canals requiring 255,000 days ‚Äî indicating massive community effort.
No clear signs of palaces, royal statues, or centralized power were found, challenging traditional views of ancient Maya construction as being tied to hierarchical rule.
The site served as a gathering place for over 1,000 people during the dry season, used for ritual worship and community events.
The canals and water features appear to have been unfinished, suggesting the construction was interrupted or not fully completed.

articles.content:
Oldest and biggest Maya temple was built to depict the cosmos 
       
  By Katie Hunt, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:03 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Spotted from an airplane by remote sensing equipment, a vast and ancient Maya complex was hidden from view for millennia by forest and fields before it was  made public in 2020.  Five years on, archaeologists are spilling more of the monumental structure‚Äôs secrets.
 

   
  The artificial plateau made from earth, with connecting causeways, canals and corridors, was built in southeastern Mexico 3,050 years ago and used for around 300 years. Called Aguada F√©nix, it forms the oldest and largest architectural site in the area occupied by the ancient Maya civilization ‚Äî bigger than later Mesoamerican cities such as  Tikal  and  Teotihuac√°n  although without their distinctive stone pyramids.
 

   
  The design of the site was a representation of how the community conceived the universe, according to new research published Wednesday in the  journal Science Advances . The site features crosses of increasing sizes with a cruciform pit containing precious ritual artifacts at its center.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a model of the cosmos or universe. They thought that basically the universe is ordered based on this cruciform pattern, and then that‚Äôs tied to the order of time,‚Äù said Takeshi Inomata, Regents Professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona and lead author of the study.
 

   
  The archaeological site was built during the beginnings of Maya civilization, which reached its height between AD 400 and 900, predominantly in modern-day Mexico and Guatemala. It was a time of development, with the construction of temples, roads, stone pyramids and other monuments, and developed complex systems of writing, mathematics and astronomy.
 

   
  ‚ÄúBefore this site there‚Äôs no substantial construction. There‚Äôs really nothing archaeologically; they were not even using ceramics,‚Äù Inomata said.
 

   
  The team excavated several key places on the site, studied cores of soil and conducted an additional LiDAR, or Light Detection and Ranging, survey of the area. The remote sensing technique, which can produce detailed models of any terrain, has revolutionized archaeology in recent years, revealing ancient structures covered by vegetation and trees, particularly in Central America.
 

   
  The site is not immediately obvious on the ground, although the main platform would have once been almost 15 meters (50 feet) high, said Ver√≥nica Vazquez Lopez, a lecturer in Mesoamerican archaeology at University College London and coauthor of the study. The builders didn‚Äôt use stone, and it‚Äôs easy to confuse their creation with a natural hill, she added.
 

   
  ‚ÄúMost of the platform is used nowadays for agricultural activities,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very subtle, and you don‚Äôt see it from the ground. That‚Äôs why it was only identified with LiDAR.‚Äù
 

   
    Ancient calendar
 

   
  The center of the site is a large, raised rectangular platform or plaza with room for more than 1,000 people to gather. It is situated at the intersection of two long thoroughfares ‚Äî one that runs north to south and a second that runs east to west ‚Äî which might have been used as processional routes.
 

   
  At the middle of the raised plaza, the archaeologists unearthed a cruciform-shaped pit that had stepped access from the platform above. Within it sat a smaller pit that contained a cache of jade artifacts, also arranged in the shape of a cross.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere we found pigments tied to specific directions, blue to the north, green to the east, yellow to the south. West, we don‚Äôt know, but there‚Äôs a red shell so it might be red,‚Äù Inomata said.
 

   
  The east-west axis of the monumental structure was aligned with the direction of the sunrise on October 17 and February 24, leading Inomata to think that the monument might have acted as a ritual site during important days of the Maya calendar year.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe interval is 130 days. That‚Äôs half of 260, and that‚Äôs the main ritual calendar of the Mesoamerican people,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThese directions and this kind of order was important to them, and they put in an enormous amount work to represent it on the ground.‚Äù
 

   
  Inomata and his colleagues also believe that the site would have been built by willing participants, not compulsory labor used to construct many ancient wonders such as Egypt‚Äôs pyramids and later Maya cities. Their excavations revealed no signs of a social hierarchy, such as statues of specific individuals.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIf you have a king or rulers, often in Mesoamerica that‚Äôs represented in sculpture or painting, and then usually you find big buildings or palaces where those powerful people lived. And we don‚Äôt have that at Aguada F√©nix,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  Inomata said the dwellings they have uncovered at the site suggest it wouldn‚Äôt have been permanently occupied by a large number of people and was perhaps used as a place to gather and worship in the dry season.
 

   
  The researchers estimated that more than 1,000 people would have been needed to build the site, spending a few months every year for several years. The canals and pond, which were aggregately 193,000 cubic meters in volume and appear to have no practical purpose, would have taken 255,000 days of labor by a single individual. The main plateau, which has a volume of 3.6 million cubic meters, would have required 10.8 million days of labor, the study reported. The canals did not appear to have been finished, Inomata added.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe have this perception that to do a big thing, you have to have hierarchical organization and that‚Äôs the way it happened in the past. But now we are getting an image of the past which is different,‚Äù he said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúPeople also did big things by organizing themselves, getting together and working together,‚Äù he added.
 

   
  The research was thrilling and of great interest to archaeologists everywhere, according to Stephen Houston, a professor of anthropology at Brown University in Rhode Island.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe finding here is that a common theme in Mesoamerican societies ‚Äî situating the world according to ritual directions and colors attached to them ‚Äî are laid out explicitly, and at an early date, at Aguada F√©nix,‚Äù Houston said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis research is part of a larger intellectual movement in archaeology, to show that large constructions can take place in situations of relative equality.‚Äù
 

   
  Andrew Scherer, a professor of archaeology and the ancient world, also at Brown, said the sheer size of the earthworks, their early age and the lack of a significant social hierarchy made the site particularly interesting.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThere was a tremendous amount of labor invested at Aguada Fenix ‚Äî in not only raising its earthworks but also in importing and carving a large number of greenstone objects ‚Äî and in no instance is there a clear case of something built or manufactured to celebrate a ruler or a particular subset of individuals,‚Äù he said via email.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis is a time period that remains poorly understood in the history of Mesoamerica and so the latest finds reported by ‚Ä¶ (the) team are of utmost importance in making sense of this murky time period.‚Äù

articles.title: Federal judge warns Justice Department it may be veering close to mishandling evidence in Comey case
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge in the Eastern District of Virginia, William Fitzpatrick, has issued a stern warning to the Justice Department about its potential mishandling of evidence in the criminal case against former FBI Director James Comey. The case centers on allegations that Comey made a false statement to Congress related to a leak investigation involving his friend and lawyer Daniel Richman. The judge criticized the prosecution for possibly following an 'indict first, investigate later' approach and questioned prosecutors over the handling of data collected in 2019 and 2020 under search warrants of Richman's electronic accounts. Key concerns include whether confidential attorney-client communications were accessed and whether the defense has fair access to all collected information. The Justice Department has until Thursday at 5 p.m. to provide the defense with full records, including grand jury documents and transcripts. The defense argues that this is an unfair burden and that Comey‚Äôs constitutional rights may have been violated. Both Comey and U.S. Attorney Lindsey Halligan attended the hearing without speaking directly to the judge.
keyTakeAways: Federal Judge William Fitzpatrick warned the Justice Department could be mishandling evidence in its case against former FBI Director James Comey.
The judge expressed concern that prosecutors may be operating under a 'indict first, investigate later' approach, raising issues about the legitimacy and procedural integrity of the investigation.
The case centers on allegations that James Comey made a false statement to Congress regarding a leak investigation involving his friend and lawyer, Daniel Richman.

Defense attorneys requested access to all data collected from Daniel Richman‚Äôs electronic accounts and grand jury documents to protect Comey‚Äôs constitutional rights and prevent prosecutorial overreach.
The Justice Department has until Thursday at 5 p.m. to provide the defense with all relevant records, including electronic search data and grand jury transcripts.
Judge Fitzpatrick described the volume of records as an 'unfair burden' on the defense, emphasizing the need for transparency and due process.

articles.content:
Federal judge warns Justice Department it may be veering close to mishandling evidence in Comey case 
       
  By Hannah Rabinowitz, Katelyn  Polantz, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:40 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  A federal judge on Wednesday warned the Justice Department it may be veering close to mishandling evidence in its criminal  case against former FBI Director James Comey .
 

   
  ‚ÄúRight now, we are in a bit of a feeling of indict first, investigate later,‚Äù Magistrate Judge William Fitzpatrick of the Eastern District of Virginia said in the hearing in Comey‚Äôs case, which lasted under an hour.
 

   
  It was an extraordinary remark in a case that has already faced both internal concern from other prosecutors as well as public accusations of the politicization of the Justice Department.
 

   
  Fitzpatrick focused the hearing around questions he had for the prosecutors about how they had handled data collected under four search warrants in 2019 and 2020, which now could become part of the case against Comey.
 

   
  The judge pressed prosecutor Tyler Lemons for direct answers on what evidence the Justice Department had in its possession, and whether anyone on the investigative side had looked at records that should be confidential because they are attorney-client communications.
 

   
  The judge will ultimately determine whether the department properly handled evidence that it collected years ago in a leak investigation involving Comey and his friend and lawyer, Daniel Richman. Comey has been charged with giving a false statement to Congress related to the leak investigation. ÔªøHe has  pleaded not guilty .
 

   
  Comey‚Äôs defense lawyer said in court on Wednesday their side believed the former FBI director‚Äôs constitutional rights may have been violated but still don‚Äôt know enough about the information federal investigators collected years ago.
 

   
  The defense had requested that the judge give them the ability to review to any information that the government collected as part of their leak probe to ensure that prosecutors can‚Äôt ‚Äúrummage through‚Äù old warrants for anything new that could incriminate Comey.
 

   
  The Justice Department has until Thursday at 5 p.m. to provide Comey‚Äôs team with all of the details it recovered while searching Richman‚Äôs electronic accounts in 2019 and 2020, as well as all grand jury documents and transcripts.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThe government has had this for five and a half years ‚Ä¶ this is an unfair burden the government is placing on the defense, but I don‚Äôt see another path forward,‚Äù the judge said, referring to the enormity of the records the defense will have to review in a short amount of time.
 

   
  Both Comey and US Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia  Lindsey Halligan attended the hearing  but neither spoke to the judge

articles.content:
‚ÄòAll‚Äôs Fair‚Äô is getting vicious reviews. Is it so bad that it‚Äôs good? 
       
  By Lisa Respers France, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        2:13 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  ‚ÄúAll‚Äôs Fair,‚Äù the new  Ryan Murphy drama  starring Kim Kardashian, Niecy Nash and Naomi Watts on Hulu, is getting a ton of buzz. But buzz is not always a good thing.
 

   
  Or maybe it is? After all, 30 years have passed since the film ‚Äú Showgirls ‚Äù was loudly and frequently trashed upon its release. Now it‚Äôs hailed as  ‚Äúinsanely rewatchable‚Äù  and considered a prime example of the ‚Äúso bad it‚Äôs good‚Äù category.
 

   
  We can‚Äôt rule out the idea that ‚ÄúAll‚Äôs Fair‚Äù is actually bad on purpose. In the age of the hate-watch, the truly terrible and the seriously campy can do numbers.
 

   
  That view may be the only positive thought about the sleek-looking legal melodrama ‚ÄúAll‚Äôs Fair,‚Äù which follows a female-led law firm that tries to give off all the girl-boss vibes.
 

   
  Released on November 4, the 10-episode series was immediately slammed by critics, clocking a flat  0%  on Rotten Tomatoes.
 

   
  The Times of London  gave the series a zero star review ,‚Äù describing the show as ‚Äúpreening Insta boasts‚Äù strung together ‚Äúinto a clumsy, haphazard whole.‚Äù  The Wrap  called it a ‚Äústock caricature from a man‚Äôs idea of a woman‚Äôs drama‚Äù and ‚Äúa cavalcade of wigs and screeching in search of truth.‚Äù USA Today cut right to the point with  their story‚Äôs  headline: ‚ÄúKim Kardashian‚Äôs ‚ÄòAll‚Äôs Fair‚Äô is the worst TV show of the year.‚Äù
 

   
  That Kardashian‚Äôs name is so prominent in the reviews is to be expected.
 

   
  While the reality star and Skims magnate had a role in Murphy‚Äôs FX series ‚ÄúAmerican Horror Story: Delicate‚Äù in 2023, Kardashian definitely shows as the rookie opposite established actors like Glenn Close and Sarah Paulson.
 

   
  Murphy appears to have been fascinated by Kardashian long before she started starring in his projects.
 

   
  The first season of his ‚ÄúAmerican Crime Story‚Äù anthology was 2016‚Äôs Emmy-winning ‚ÄúThe People v. O. J. Simpson,‚Äù which starred David Schwimmer as her father, attorney Robert Kardashian, who represented Simpson in his 1995 murder trial.
 

   
  Murphy made sure to include the characters of Kim Kardashian and her sisters as youngsters growing up during the trial; in the show, they are seen watching their father on TV. The series‚Äô showrunners, Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski,  talked to Vanity Fair  at the time and explained the decision, saying they wanted to highlight the beginning of the 24-hour news cycle and the creation of reality TV, and how it might have ‚Äúaffected the future Kardashian empire.‚Äù When ‚Äúall this media frenzy was going on, how would that affect you?‚Äù they asked. One way or another, Kardashian as an adult became the master of the medium.
 

   
  Murhpy‚Äôs fascination seems not to have successfully translated into a convincing big-budget Kardashian star vehicle.
 

   
   Variety‚Äôs Alison Herman  noted in her review that ‚ÄúAll‚Äôs Fair‚Äù reminds her ‚Äúof nothing so much as another unscripted series shot in the Los Angeles area,‚Äù alluding to Kardashian‚Äôs reality show ‚ÄúThe Kardashians,‚Äù which also airs on Hulu.
 

   
  ‚ÄúKardashian doesn‚Äôt embarrass herself, because her role doesn‚Äôt ask much of her to begin with,‚Äù Herman wrote. Her character ‚Äúexists to embody all the laziest stereotypes of what makes a strong woman‚Äù ‚Äî like ‚Äúgetting revenge fillers and, in one particularly cringey fantasy sequence, donning a Beyonc√©-esque yellow dress to go full ‚ÄòLemonade‚Äô on another woman‚Äôs car.‚Äù
 

   
  All these little Instagrammable moments ‚Äî maybe that was Murphy‚Äôs game here all along, to build a camp classic for the modern moment? The shareable nuggets, the bling and opulence, plus the stunt casting of his reality show muse all suggest there‚Äôs something to that theory.
 

   
  Now it‚Äôs everyone‚Äôs turn to decide. So far, the reviews of nonprofessional watchers are mixed but tend to be far kinder. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an ostentatious display of wealth and beauty and we love it,‚Äù wrote one commenter on Rotten Tomatoes. ‚ÄúSome scenes wereü§®üôÑ but it gives a goofy side. Entertaining like a soap opera.‚Äù

articles.title: Jimmy Kimmel Leading Celebs in Addressing Food Insecurity
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: As a result of the U.S. government shutdown, the Trump administration cut half of SNAP benefits, causing widespread fear and food insecurity among millions, especially among children, seniors, and low-income families. In response, celebrities like Jimmy Kimmel, Keith Lee, and Wanda Sykes stepped up: Kimmel established a local food bank on his show‚Äôs backlot to support the Los Angeles Food Bank and St. Joseph Center; Keith Lee mobilized over 100 brands‚Äîincluding Door Dash, Impossible Foods, and Cracker Barrel‚Äîto donate meals, emphasizing his own past reliance on SNAP; and Wanda Sykes used her platform to draw attention to the harm of cutting benefits to vulnerable groups like single mothers. The article highlights how public figures and businesses are using their influence to address immediate food needs during a crisis, revealing the deep social consequences of political decisions on everyday lives.
keyTakeAways: Jimmy Kimmel launched a local food bank on his show's Hollywood backlot to address food insecurity caused by reduced SNAP benefits during a government shutdown.
Influencer Keith Lee mobilized over 100 brands (40 large and 60 small) to donate meals, emphasizing personal experience with SNAP as a survival tool during his early life.
Actress Wanda Sykes used her platform to highlight the disproportionate impact of SNAP cuts on single mothers and vulnerable populations, urging empathy and action.
The Trump administration decided to provide only half of normal SNAP benefits in November due to a government shutdown, causing anxiety and increased demand on food pantries.
A federal judge in Rhode Island ordered the USDA to either fully or partially fund SNAP benefits, resulting in an unprecedented halt to benefits for millions of Americans.
The article underscores a broader societal concern: the vulnerability of low-income families during political and governmental instability.

Jimmy Kimmel leading celebs in addressing food insecurity 
       
  By Lisa Respers France, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        1:48 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Jimmy Kimmel wants to help feed those in need.
 

   
  The late-night host announced Tuesday that his show, ‚ÄúJimmy Kimmel Live!‚Äù had formed a special local food bank in Los Angeles, formed in response to millions being set to be affected by the loss or reduction of their Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits amid the government shutdown.
 

   
  ‚ÄúCutting SNAP benefits creates uncertainty for American children, seniors and families,‚Äù  the announcement reads.  ‚ÄúTo support our community members in need, we‚Äôre starting a donation center in our Hollywood backlot to benefit the (Los Angeles Food Bank) & (the St. Joseph Center).‚Äù
 

   
  People in the area are encouraged to donate food ‚Äì especially nut butters, protein bars and whole grain pastas ‚Äì to the ‚ÄúJimmy Kimmel Live Big Beautiful Food Bank,‚Äù and those who are not local were encouraged to ‚Äúconsider supporting your local food banks.‚Äù
 

   
  Kimmel is not the only one stepping it up to help fight hunger.
 

   
  Popular influencer Keith Lee used his mega influential TikTok platform to announce he was going to partner with companies to feed the less fortunate.
 

   
  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the holidays coming up..I want brands to comment that are willing to give away meals with me,‚Äù  Lee told his more than 17 million followers.  ‚ÄúI refuse to take any money. I don‚Äôt want money.‚Äù
 

   
  He explained that before he became successful, he and his wife had relied on SNAP to survive when they had two young daughters.
 

   
  Multiple brands from Door Dash to Impossible Foods, Top Golf and Cracker Barrel stepped up in response to work with Lee.
 

   
  He later  made a follow up video  to express his gratitude, saying that ‚Äúmore than 40 big brands and 60 smaller brands‚Äù had expressed interest in helping.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm coming to say thank you from the bottom of my heart cause I‚Äôm honored to be part of this in any capacity,‚Äù Lee said, adding that small businesses who wanted to participate would be paid for their products, rather than allowed to donate.
 

   
  The Trump administration said Monday that it will provide only half of the normal  food stamp benefits  for November by tapping into the program‚Äôs contingency fund amid the  government shutdown . But recipients are not likely to see the payments immediately.
 

   
  The decision came after a federal judge in Rhode Island  ordered  the USDA last week to either start providing full November benefits to recipients or partial benefits if the agency opts to only draw on SNAP‚Äôs contingency fund.
 

   
  The  unprecedented decision  to halt benefits has panicked many recipients, driving them to overwhelmed  food pantries  to help feed themselves and their families.
 

   
  Actress Wanda Sykes used her speech at the recent Variety Power of Women event to draw attention to the loss of SNAP benefits.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre at a moment in time where, with everything that‚Äôs going on in the government, we need to create projects where life imitates art,‚Äù she  reportedly said.  ‚ÄúLooking at what‚Äôs happening with cutting SNAP benefits, that‚Äôs going to affect single mothers, hard.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúSo I want to do things that speak to them and uplift them,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúUse your power to uplift women; show them what it looks like.‚Äù

When SNAP benefits will arrive is still in flux. Here's what communities are doing to fill the gap 
         By The NPR Network 
        
           Updated Thursday, November 6, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 6:22 PM EST 
        
        
      

         A Rhode Island federal judge  has ordered the Trump administration to find enough money to restore full funding  for SNAP benefits by Friday.  The government "failed to consider the harms individuals who rely on those benefits would suffer," said U.S. District Court Judge John McConnell Jr. The ruling comes in response to a challenge filed by cities and nonprofits after the administration said it would halt funding on Nov. 1. McConnell and another federal judge in Boston  ordered the government  to use emergency funds to keep SNAP funding flowing, but Trump administration officials said it was only able to partially cover the payments. Starting Nov. 1, SNAP benefits did not hit accounts as scheduled after the USDA, which administers SNAP, citing the federal government shutdown.  It is unclear when low-income families who depend on SNAP will receive these funds. The Trump administration previously said it anticipates long delays ‚Äî "anywhere from a few weeks to up to several months" ‚Äî before benefits arrive in the hands of registered SNAP recipients. It's unclear what McConnell's Thursday ruling will mean for this timeline. Are you worried about your SNAP benefits?  NPR wants to hear your story SNAP, the country's largest anti-hunger program, dates back to the Great Depression and has never been disrupted this way. Most recipients are seniors, families with kids and people with disabilities. Food banks are stretched thin In the few days since SNAP funding elapsed,  food banks  across the country have experienced  a surge of people in need  of their services, leading to  long lines  and widespread worries about  how they will meet  the escalating demand in the coming weeks. Some food bank administrators warn that it may soon amount to a  public health crisis . Small grocery stores ,  local farmers , and other retailers  authorized to accept SNAP benefits  are also bracing for changes as many of their usual customers are without the means to pay for food this month. Some local communities have set up informal systems to  support their neighbors  in need of food assistance. In several cities, food banks  have collaborated with government officials  to connect residents with food resources. Others  put out calls for volunteers  to support their work. While many food banks have previously dealt with difficult situations like natural disasters that strained their operations, the scale of this nationwide shutdown  represents an unprecedented national food crisis .  Senior citizens  may be disproportionately impacted. ‚Äî  Anusha Mathur , NPR Read more:   'The helpers need help'. Food banks brace for impact as SNAP cliff looms Reporters from the NPR Network are covering the uncertainty and lapse in benefits in states across the country. Here's what we know so far. State-specific impacts: Alabama Roughly  749,000 people  are enrolled in SNAP in Alabama, according to the USDA.¬† In 2024, SNAP assistance reached  15% of the state population  (1 in 7 people).¬† Governor Kay Ivey announced she is releasing $2 million dollars in state emergency funds to shore up towards eight food banks. [ Alabama Public Radio ] Alabama's Department of Human Resources (DHR), the agency responsible for SNAP in the state,  says on its website that  individuals can still apply for SNAP benefits during the suspension and DHR will continue to process applications and determine eligibility. Benefits will not be issued until the suspension is lifted.  Current SNAP recipients, however, "must continue to rectify their benefits, report as they normally would, and submit all documentation that would normally be required for them to continue in the program," DHR says. This is necessary so that each SNAP recipient can more quickly use their November funds in the grocery stores. Alaska Roughly  66,000 people  are enrolled in SNAP in Alaska, according to the USDA.¬† Gov. Mike Dunleavy issued a state disaster declaration Monday, Alaska to refill benefit cards with state funds quickly and offer money to food banks around the state . People who rely on SNAP could have their electronic benefits cards refilled as soon as this week.  [ Alaska Public Media ] Officials say the division will continue adding SNAP beneficiaries during the shutdown and Alaskans who lost food because of Typhoon Halong in western Alaska can apply to get October SNAP benefits re-issued. Michelle DeWitt, executive director of Bethel Community Services Foundation, said the state's formal food security safety nets are already stretched thin in the wake of the early October storm. [ Alaska Public Media ] Sen. Lisa Murkowski told NPR's Scott Detrow  that she hopes that contingency funding can be used to help pay out SNAP benefits, particularly for those impacted by Typhoon Halong. "I have seen different statements indicating that these contingency funds need to be reserved for disasters," she said on Friday. "For those SNAP recipients in Alaska who have suffered this disaster, yeah, we want to make sure that they have some level of assistance or relief there." Arizona More than  887,000 people  are enrolled in SNAP in Arizona, according to the USDA.¬† Arizona Gov. Katie Hobbs is allocating $1.8 million in emergency state aid [ KNAU ] She conceded that was only a "drop in the bucket" compared to Arizonans' needs. [ KJZZ ] Indigenous communities, including the Navajo and Cherokee Nations have been hit particularly hard. A third of Navajo households depend on SNAP. Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. declared a state of emergency "due to this federally imposed food crisis." [ KJZZ ] The Arizona Department of Economic Security, which administers SNAP in the state, is directing Arizona SNAP recipients to local food banks if they need immediate food assistance. Food banks in Arizona can be found through the  Arizona Food Bank Network . [ KJZZ ] Arkansas Roughly  236,000 people  are enrolled in SNAP in Arkansas, according to the USDA.¬† Arkansas DHS manages federal dollars for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program.  Little Rock Public Radio  reported on Friday that 37 DHS employees were furloughed at the beginning of October and 34 more would starting Nov. 1. An additional 1,500 employees have been notified they may be furloughed after November 7. Little Rock Mayor Frank Scott Jr. announced the city will relaunch an online portal for community donations called LRCares. [ Little Rock Public Radio ] Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders  directed $500,000 to six food bank networks across Arkansas , blaming Democrats for the shutdown and the impact on SNAP beneficiaries in her state: "The simplest, fastest solution remains for Democrats to reopen the government and fund programs like SNAP, but in the meantime, my administration will work with our legislators, churches, and food banks to help feed Arkansans." Arkansas' DHS is pushing SNAP recipients to find local food pantries, churches and other organizations for temporary food assistance and to check for eligibility of other food programs. As the benefits run dry, some community members have established informal systems to foot their neighbors' grocery bills. [ Little Rock Public Radio ] California Over  5.5 million people are enrolled in CalFresh  ‚Äî the state's implementation of the federally funded SNAP program. Well over 1 million people in LA County. The other major SoCal counties ‚Äî San Bernardino, Riverside and Orange ‚Äî each have more than 300,000 people on CalFresh,  according to state data . [ LAist ] Gov. Gavin Newsom announced Oct. 22 that he would deploy the California National Guard to support food banks across California as the federal government shutdown drags on. [ KQED ]¬† Early into November, food banks and pantries in Los Angeles are already experiencing an uptick in people needing their services [ LAist ]. About 600 Los Angeles Unified schools will start serving supper to offset these delays. [ LAist ] In the San Francisco area, local restaurants and businesses have stepped up to feed families who depend on CalFresh [ KQED ] and have been relying on volunteer support [ KQED ]. Mayor Daniel Lurie pledged $18 million to cover SNAP Benefits for November. [ KQED ]. California is among the states suing the Trump administration over its decision to suspend federal food benefits during the government shutdown. [ KQED ] For more on alternative free resources in the San Francisco Bay Area,  head to KQED .¬† Are you worried about your SNAP benefits?  NPR wants to hear your story Colorado Gov. Jared Polis said 600,000 Coloradans, half of whom are children, won't get SNAP benefits on Nov. 1. Polis warned that state funding would not be nearly enough to offset the federal SNAP delay. [ Colorado Public Radio ] Colorado's Joint Budget Committee has unanimously approved spending $10 million from the state's reserves to shore up food banks and food assistance programs [ Colorado Public Radio ] As the Nov. 1 date nears, food banks and county health services have been preparing for a delay in the federal program and increased crowds needing assistance. [ Colorado Public Radio ] For more resources in Colorado,  head to Colorado Public Radio  or  Denverite .¬† Connecticut SNAP serves an estimated 360,000 people in Connecticut per year, according to state officials. [ CT Public ] Residents already feel the strain, as one woman told Connecticut Public Radio that she may need to tap into retirement savings to help feed her daughter. She's also seeking information on food banks in West Hartford for the first time. [ CT Public ] Connecticut will spend $3 million, which will stretch about two weeks, to partially supplement federal food aid benefits through the nonprofit Connecticut Foodshare. [ WSHU ] Sen. Richard Blumenthal sharply critiqued the Trump administration for the shutdown and resulting impact on SNAP: "Millions of Americans are struggling to put food on the table ‚Äî a harsh reality that President Trump has abjectly failed to recognize, and Republicans have made worse by refusing to work with Democrats on reopening the government and providing access to health care." [ CT Public ] Meanwhile State Sen. Stephen Harding, Connecticut's Senate Minority Leader blamed Democrats: "Bottom line: Democrats need to join Republicans in voting to reopen the government and resolve this crisis."[ CT Public ] For more on alternative free resources in Connecticut and how you can help neighbors experiencing food insecurity,   head to  Connecticut Public Radio  or  WSHU .¬† Delaware Over  110,000 people in Delaware  are enrolled in¬† in SNAP according to the USDA. Gov. Matt Meyer told NPR's A Martinez  on Oct. 31 that Delaware would use state money to temporarily fund SNAP benef.  Meyer announced a state of emergency and on Wednesday was able to reallocate funding from a Legislative Hall parking lot project to fund SNAP benefits through the end of November. [ Delaware Public ]  Republican State Reps. Kevin Hensley and Mike Smith floated the idea to repurpose the parking lot funds last week.  The funding amounts to about $5.4 million per week. [ Delaware Public ]  For more on alternative free resources in Delaware and how you can help neighbors experiencing food insecurity,  head to WHYY. District of Columbia Over  130,000 people in the District of Columbia  are enrolled in SNAP according to the USDA. D.C. Attorney General Brian L. Schwalb was among a group of state attorneys general who  signed on to a letter to the USDA  asking for clarification on why reserve funds set aside for this purpose were not being used.¬† The Capital Area Food Bank has seen some of its own federal funding slashed even as demand skyrockets. [ WAMU ] Florida Nearly  3 million people in Florida  are enrolled in SNAP, according to the USDA. Of Florida's SNAP users, children and seniors comprise the majority of participants. [ WVPB ]¬† Wisconsin According to the USDA, roughly  700,000 people in Wisconsin  are enrolled in FoodShare, Wisconsin's name for SNAP.¬† Gov. Tony Evers declared a state of emergency Saturday, calling on state agencies to take 'any and all' steps necessary to address a lapse in FoodShare benefits. [ Wisconsin Public Radio ] Valerie MacMillian, who runs NourishMKE,  told Wisconsin Public Radio  they've seen three times as many people visiting food centers in recent months, and many are first-time visitors, which MacMillian says reflects the broader challenges facing the region [ Wisconsin Public Radio ]¬† For more on alternative resources in the Milwaukee area,  head to WUWM .¬† Wyoming Roughly  30,000 people in Wyoming  are enrolled in SNAP, according to the USDA. Gov. Mark Gordon declared a public welfare emergency on Friday, authorizing the state to spend up to $10 million to offset the loss of SNAP benefits. The Wyoming Department of Family Services is working to distribute the money to organizations running food pantries across the state. [ Wyoming Public Media ] Are you worried about your SNAP benefits?  NPR wants to hear your story NPR's Anusha Mathur, Jaclyn Diaz, Padma Rama, Carol Ritchie, Emily Alfin Johnson, Kristian Monroe, Luis Clemens and Jennifer Ludden edited this piece.

11 killed in fire at Bosnian retirement home 
       
  Story by Reuters
 

       
Updated: 
        12:09 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: Reuters
 
   
  The death toll from a fire at a retirement home in Tuzla in northern Bosnia-Herzegovina rose to 11 on Wednesday and about 30 people were injured, police said.
 

   
  The blaze engulfed the seventh floor of the old nine-story building at around 8:45 p.m. local time (2:45 p.m. ET) on Tuesday, sending flames and smoke pouring out of the top floors into the night sky. The cause was not immediately clear.
 

   
  Local media said many of the dead had disabilities and those rescued were moved by emergency crews from the upper floors to lower ones. Some of the injured were in critical condition.
 

   
  Identification of the victims will start later on Wednesday, and an investigation into the cause of the fire will start once conditions allow it, police said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAuthorities are taking all necessary actions to shed light on the conditions that caused this tragic event,‚Äù the retirement home said in a statement.
 

   
  The government of Republika Srpska, the Serb Republic, one of the two entities of Bosnia and Herzegovina, offered its assistance to Tuzla.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe feel the pain and are always ready to help,‚Äù Savo Minic, Prime Minister of the Serb Republic  wrote on X .

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 U.S. election revealed a significant reversal of Donald Trump‚Äôs 2024 gains among Latino voters and young male voters, with Democratic candidates Mikie Sherrill and Abigail Spanberger winning strong majorities in New Jersey and Virginia. The data shows that voters who dislike both parties overwhelmingly backed Democrats, and in Georgia, Democrats won their first non-federal statewide race since 2006. Concerns over candidate conduct‚Äîsuch as Attorney General-elect Jay Jones‚Äôs violent texts‚Äîwere raised, yet still had limited impact on voter turnout. In New York, Zohran Mamdani, the city‚Äôs first Muslim mayor, secured a decisive majority, with strong support from Jewish voters and a clear rejection of GOP candidates. Voter intent data shows that only a small percentage of voters cited support for Trump, indicating a broad national shift in political sentiment away from Trump and toward Democratic candidates and policies, especially on issues like redistricting and transgender rights.

Young men under 30 showed strong Democratic support, with Sherrill and Spanberger each winning by 17 and 14 points, respectively.
Democratic support among voters who dislike both major parties surged, with 78% and 82% voting for Spanberger and Sherrill, indicating a strong appeal among anti-Trump voters.
In Georgia, Democrats won their first non-federal statewide race since 2006, defeating GOP incumbents by a 26-point margin.

A significant number of Virginia voters found Democratic Attorney General-elect Jay Jones‚Äô violent text messages disqualifying (41%), yet 9% still voted for him, highlighting concerns about candidate integrity.
Support for transgender rights remained a major issue, with 50% of Virginia voters believing it had gone too far, and 23% still voting for Spanberger despite this.
New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani secured 50.4% of the vote, ending debates about whether Republican Curtis Sliwa was a spoiler.
73% of GOP voters in New York backed Cuomo, showing a strong Republican alignment with a Democratic independent candidate.
32% of Jewish voters supported Mamdani, the city‚Äôs first Muslim mayor, prompting Trump to call them 'stupid'.
California Republican voters supported a Democratic ballot measure to redraw districts, passing 64%-36%, indicating a backlash against GOP gerrymandering.
Only 7%, 13%, and 16% of voters in California, New Jersey, and Virginia, respectively, said their vote was meant to support Trump, with majority of voters stating their intent was to oppose him.

articles.content:
The most striking stats of the 2025 election 
       
  Analysis by Aaron Blake, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        1:39 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Americans  cast ballots  at polling places across the country on Tuesday, which means we have a bunch of data on voters voting ‚Äî rather than just pre-election polls of a hypothetical electorate.
 

   
  So what did we learn from that data?
 

   
  Here are some of the most striking statistics.
 

   
   68%-31%:  Democratic New Jersey Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill‚Äôs advantage among Latino voters, according to  CNN‚Äôs exit poll , which combines pre-election interviews with those conducted at polling places (Virginia Gov.-elect Abigail Spanberger won this demographic by a similar margin.) President Donald Trump had significantly closed the gap with Latino voters in the 2024 election, winning 46% of them nationally. But Tuesday‚Äôs results ‚Äî albeit in states that Trump lost last year ‚Äî appear much more in line with how this demographic previously voted.
 

   
   17 and 14 points:  Spanberger‚Äôs and Sherrill‚Äôs respective advantages among young men under the age of 30. Trump had also made big gains nationally with this demographic in 2024, when young male voters were close to evenly split.
 

   
   1961:  The last time Democrats won a Virginia governor‚Äôs race by more than Spanberger‚Äôs current 15-point margin.
 

   
   1965:  The last time New Jersey elected the same party to the governor‚Äôs mansion in three straight elections. Sherrill will succeed two-term Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy.
 

   
   78%, 82%:  Spanberger‚Äôs and Sherrill‚Äôs respective vote shares among voters who disliked both major political parties. Some Democrats fear that their party‚Äôs historic unpopularity will hurt their ability to win anti-Trump voters. At least on Tuesday, though, the so-called ‚Äú double-haters ‚Äù swung hard for Democrats.
 

   
   2006:  The last time Democrats won a non-federal statewide race in Georgia, before they  won a pair of Public Service Commission races  on Tuesday.
 

   
   26 points:  The margin by which Democrats won each of those races, defeating a pair of GOP incumbents.
 

   
   41%:  The percentage of Virginia voters who said Democratic Attorney General-elect Jay Jones‚Äô  violent text messages  were ‚Äúdisqualifying.‚Äù
 

   
   9%:  The percentage of those voters who voted for Jones anyway.
 

   
   50%:  The percentage of Virginia voters who agreed that support for transgender rights in society has ‚Äúgone too far.‚Äù Republican gubernatorial nominee Winsome Earle-Sears made trans issues a huge focal point of her attacks on Spanberger.
 

   
   23%:  The percentage of those voters who voted for Spanberger anyway.
 

   
   320,000:  The difference between Spanberger‚Äôs current raw vote total (about 1.92 million) and 2021 Virginia Democratic gubernatorial nominee Terry McAuliffe‚Äôs raw vote total (about 1.6 million). About 20% more people turned out to vote for her than voted for McAuliffe four years ago.
 

   
   50.4%:  New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs current vote share, with about 91% of the vote counted. Getting a majority would put to rest any talk about Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa having been a ‚Äúspoiler‚Äù in the race with former Democratic Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who ran as an independent.
 

   
   73%:  The percentage of GOP voters in that New York race who voted for Cuomo ‚Äî whom Republicans, including Trump, wound up rallying around as a Mamdani alternative.
 

   
   32%:  The percentage of Jewish voters who voted for Mamdani, who will become New York City‚Äôs first Muslim mayor. Trump on Tuesday called any Jewish people who voted for Mamdani ‚Äústupid.‚Äù
 

   
   13%:  The percentage of California  Republican voters  who voted for Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom‚Äôs ballot measure to allow the state government to draw more Democratic congressional districts. Newsom launched the effort to retaliate against Texas Republicans‚Äô move to draw more GOP districts in that state. And his argument that this tit-for-tat move was warranted clearly proved compelling to voters, given it‚Äôs currently passing 64%-36%.
 

   
   7%, 13% and 16%:  The percentages of voters in California, New Jersey and Virginia, respectively, who said their vote was meant to support Trump. In each case, many more voters said their vote was meant to oppose Trump: 52% in California, 41% in New Jersey and 38% in Virginia.
 

   
   This story has been updated with updated exit poll numbers.
