articles.title: Trump Revives False Claim That Americans Must Show ID to Buy Groceries
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has repeatedly revived a false claim that Americans must show identification to buy groceries or fuel, a falsehood that has been debunked by experts and real-world practices. The claim, first made in 2018 and later repeated in 2019 and 2023, is inconsistent with everyday consumer behavior, where grocery and gas purchases typically require no ID. Trump also falsely asserted that mail-in ballots automatically lead to election fraud and misquoted a 2005 report from a commission co-chaired by former President Jimmy Carter, which did not state that mail-in voting guarantees corruption. Oregon's successful mail-only voting system and expert analyses show that fraud is extremely rare, countering the false narrative. These claims are part of a broader pattern of misinformation used to question election legitimacy during a period of Republican electoral losses.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump has repeatedly claimed that Americans must show ID to buy groceries, a false assertion with no basis in reality.
Genuine grocery store purchases typically do not require identification, with exceptions only for alcohol, tobacco, or prescription medications.
Trump‚Äôs claim that mail-in ballots automatically result in election fraud is false; major election experts and historical reports confirm that fraud rates are extremely low and not evidence-based.

Former President Jimmy Carter‚Äôs 2005 commission report did not state that mail-in ballots guarantee corruption; it acknowledged safeguards like signature verification and noted Oregon‚Äôs successful mail-only system.
Trump has misrepresented factual statements from the Carter commission and falsely claimed that mail-in voting leads to certain fraud, undermining public trust in democratic processes.
The repeated revival of these false claims during a period of electoral losses suggests an effort to question the legitimacy of elections, which may be politically motivated.

articles.content:
Fact check: Trump revives his false claim that Americans have to show ID to buy groceries 
       
  By Daniel Dale, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:16 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  President Donald Trump has revived one of the most bizarre false claims from his first presidency and his 2024 campaign: an assertion that Americans are required to show identification to buy groceries.
 

   
  Trump was mocked when he made versions of this claim  in   2018  and  2019  while pushing for stricter voter identification laws. But he said it again  in 2023  as he ran for president, then said it once more on Wednesday morning while baselessly questioning the legitimacy of US elections in the wake of  Republican defeats in various state and local elections  the day prior.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAll we want is voter ID. You go to a grocery store, you have to give ID. You go to a gas station, you give ID,‚Äù Trump  said  Wednesday at a breakfast with Republican senators.
 

   
  Americans obviously do not need to provide identification to buy groceries or gas.
 

   
  Grocery stores generally require identification for purchases of alcohol or tobacco, purchases of  certain medications  and for the small percentage of purchases made by personal check. Stores may occasionally ask for ID under other circumstances.
 

   
  But these are exceptions rather than the rule. Contrary to Trump‚Äôs claims, Americans generally buy groceries without ever having to tell anyone who they are. Similarly, millions of Americans every day buy gas without ever showing identification; many of them do not even interact with a person while paying at the pump.
 

   
  In 2018, when Trump‚Äôs then-White House press secretary Sarah Sanders was asked about Trump‚Äôs initial false claim that photo identification was needed to buy groceries, she  suggested  he was referring specifically to purchases of beer or wine.
 

   
  But he soon made clear he was actually talking about food, specifically mentioning ‚Äúa box of cereal‚Äù in an  interview  three months later. In 2023, he falsely  claimed  identification was needed ‚Äúif you buy a loaf of bread.‚Äù
 

   
    Trump repeats other false claims about elections
 

   
  On Wednesday, Trump  repeated  his false claim that ‚Äúif you have mail-in ballots,‚Äù an election is ‚Äúautomatically corrupt.‚Äù
 

   
  It simply isn‚Äôt. Mail-in voting is a legitimate method used by legitimate voters to cast legitimate ballots. Elections experts  say  the incidence of fraud tends to be marginally higher with mail-in ballots than with in-person ballots ‚Äì but also that fraud rates in major US elections are tiny even with mail-in ballots. There is no evidence that the elections held Tuesday were anything other than free and fair.
 

   
  Trump also repeated his false claim that a commission led by former President Jimmy Carter ‚Äúsaid about mail-in ballots: ‚ÄòIf there is mail-in ballots, there will definitely be corruption.‚Äô‚Äù
 

   
  That‚Äôs not what Carter or the commission said. Trump has  repeatedly misstated  the commission‚Äôs conclusions.
 

   
  It‚Äôs true that the commission Carter co-chaired two decades ago was generally skeptical of voting by mail. Its 2005 report  said  that ‚Äúabsentee ballots remain the largest source of potential voter fraud‚Äù and are ‚Äúvulnerable to abuse in several ways.‚Äù
 

   
  But the report did not say that ‚Äúthere will definitely be corruption‚Äù in elections where mail-in ballots are used. In fact, the report highlighted an example of successful mail-only elections, saying that Oregon, a state that has been conducting elections exclusively by mail-in  voting since the late 1990s , ‚Äúappears to have avoided significant fraud in its vote-by-mail elections by introducing safeguards to protect ballot integrity, including signature verification.‚Äù
 

   
  The report also offered some recommendations for making the use of mail-in ballots more secure and called for ‚Äúfurther research on the pros and cons‚Äù of voting by mail.
 

   
  Carter, who died in 2024,  said  in a 2020 statement: ‚ÄúI approve the use of absentee ballots and have been using them for more than five years.‚Äù

articles.title: Trump Administration Nears Deals with Pharmaceutical Companies to Offer Obesity Drugs for $149 a Month
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration is nearing agreements with pharmaceutical companies Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk to offer obesity drugs such as Wegovy, Zepbound, Mounjaro, and Ozempic at a significantly reduced price of $149 per month. These deals, part of a broader strategy to lower drug costs, would also enable Medicare to cover the drugs for certain beneficiaries, expanding access for millions. The initiative follows years of debate over drug affordability and Medicare coverage, with the Biden administration previously proposing expansion before it was paused. While the deals are not finalized, President Trump has publicly championed the effort, citing a shift from $1,300 to $150 monthly pricing. The negotiations are linked to a CMS pilot program and reflect a growing consumer market for weight-loss drugs, akin to tech product updates. Despite initial skepticism from figures like Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the administration has shown openness to patient access, especially for those who have failed prior treatments.
keyTakeAways: The Trump administration is nearing agreements with Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk to offer obesity drugs like Wegovy, Zepbound, and Mounjaro for as low as $149 per month.
These deals would potentially allow Medicare to cover the drugs for certain beneficiaries, expanding access to expensive weight-loss medications.
The drugs currently cost between $1,000 and $1,350 list price, but consumer prices vary based on insurance and discounts.
The deals are part of a broader White House initiative to lower drug prices through direct negotiations with pharmaceutical companies, including the 'Most Favored Nation' policy.
President Donald Trump has repeatedly referred to GLP-1 drugs as the 'fat-loss drug' and emphasized a target price of $150 instead of $1,300.
The negotiations are tied to a pilot program under CMS to cap obesity drug costs for Medicare beneficiaries.

Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly already offer cash-pay options for their drugs (e.g., $499/month for Ozempic and Wegovy, $349/month for Zepbound), with growing consumer interest driven by new product launches.
The push follows years of debate over Medicare coverage of obesity drugs, with the Biden administration proposing expansion in 2024, which was paused under Trump‚Äôs early administration.
Ozempic and Wegovy were selected for a second round of Medicare drug price negotiations in January 2025, with potential savings for beneficiaries.
Former Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. initially opposed drug accessibility, criticizing Novo Nordisk‚Äôs business model, but has since adopted a more supportive stance.

articles.content:
Trump administration nears deals with pharmaceutical companies to offer obesity drugs for $149 a month 
       
  By Adam Cancryn, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:23 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  The Trump administration is nearing deals with drugmakers Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk to offer some of their obesity drugs to consumers for as low as $149 per month, according to two people familiar with the negotiations.
 

   
  The agreements would also clear the way for Medicare to cover the drugs for certain beneficiaries ‚Äî a move that could broaden the market for medications like Wegovy, Zepbound and Mounjaro that have already proven widely popular despite their steep prices. The list price of the drugs range from roughly $1,000 to $1,350, though the price consumers pay depends on their insurance and on discounts.
 

   
  President Donald Trump is expected to announce the deals as soon as Thursday, though the people familiar with the negotiations cautioned that they are not finalized and that officials are still working through key policy details.
 

   
  In a statement, White House spokesman Kush Desai said that ‚Äúdiscussion about deals that have not been officially announced by the administration should be regarded as speculation.‚Äù Press secretary Karoline Leavitt on Tuesday declined to confirm the planned announcement, but said a deal that cuts the cost of the obesity drugs was ‚Äúsomething that the administration has been engaged and looking into.‚Äù
 

   
  The negotiations over Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk‚Äôs obesity drugs represent perhaps the highest-profile element of a broader White House push to cut drug prices by striking individual deals with pharmaceutical manufacturers.
 

   
  The ‚ÄúMost Favored Nation‚Äù initiative has so far resulted in agreements with Pfizer, AstraZeneca and other companies to sell certain products directly to consumers at a reduced price ‚Äî often in exchange for relief from the threat of targeted tariffs.  Eli Lilly  and  Novo Nordisk  already provide their weight loss drugs at a discount directly to consumers who pay cash.
 

   
  Yet Trump has fixated in particular on striking a deal for GLP-1 medications that have exploded in popularity in recent years for helping with weight loss and a range of chronic conditions. The president has referred to them in both public and private as the ‚Äúfat-loss drug.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to be paying, instead of $1,300, you‚Äôll be paying about $150,‚Äù Trump said of the GLP-1 drugs during a mid-October event highlighting a separate drug price deal, prompting US Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services chief Mehmet Oz to jump in and emphasize that the negotiations were still ongoing.
 

   
  Endpoints News first  reported  that deals were approaching the finish line.
 

   
  It‚Äôs unclear exactly which of the companies‚Äô drugs will be sold for $149 and whether there will be restrictions on consumers‚Äô access to them. The deals are related to a pilot program that CMS is in the final stages of developing aimed at capping the cost of the obesity drugs for some Medicare beneficiaries, one of the people familiar with the negotiations said.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWe have been in dialogue with President Trump‚Äôs administration for a long time now, and our aim is exactly the same: provide affordable access to as many people as possible,‚Äù said Mike Doustdar, Novo Nordisk‚Äôs chief executive, in an interview with CNN Wednesday morning after the company reported quarterly earnings. ‚ÄúHopefully we‚Äôll be able to solve the solution where there is better access than today.‚Äù
 

   
  Doustdar noted the negotiations are ongoing, and didn‚Äôt comment on any specific details. He said the company‚Äôs  cash-pay  option for Ozempic and Wegovy, at $499 a month for patients outside of insurance, is ‚Äúthe channel that‚Äôs right now growing the most.‚Äù Lilly also offers cash-pay  options  for its weight-loss drug Zepbound that start at $349 a month.
 

   
  Weight-loss drugs, Doustdar added, increasingly resemble a consumer market ‚Äì one more driven by new product updates that he compared to iPhones, rather than a more traditional pharmaceutical market like for insulin, where patients find a version that works for them and usually go through insurance.
 

   
  ‚ÄúWithin obesity care, we have seen that patients ‚Äì customers ‚Äì get excited about that next best thing,‚Äù Doustdar said.
 

   
  The expected deals with Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk follow a yearslong debate on both sides of the aisle over whether Medicare and Medicaid should cover the pricey drugs. The Biden administration last year officially proposed expanding coverage of them, though the plan was not finalized before Trump took office. The Trump administration said in April that it was  halting  the proposal but left the door open to consider future policy options for covering the drugs.
 

   
  Also, notably, Ozempic and Wegovy were selected in January for second round of  Medicare drug price negotiations , which is expected to result in savings for the program and, possibly, for enrollees depending on their drug coverage.
 

   
  Trump‚Äôs current health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., vehemently opposed efforts to make the medications more accessible, telling Fox News  ahead of last November‚Äôs election  that Novo Nordisk ‚Äî which makes Ozempic ‚Äî was ‚Äúcounting on selling it to Americans because we are so stupid and so addicted to drugs.‚Äù But since joining the administration, he has struck a far more accommodating tone, expressing openness to patients using them if prior efforts to improve their health have failed.

articles.title: The Dual Nature of Artificial Intelligence: Innovation and Ethical Challenges in Society
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly transforming society, bringing both significant benefits and pressing ethical challenges. In sectors like healthcare, education, and transportation, AI is driving innovation by improving efficiency, personalization, and decision-making. For instance, in healthcare, AI enhances diagnostics and drug development; in education, it personalizes learning; and in transportation, it supports autonomous systems and smart traffic management. However, these advancements come with notable risks, including job displacement in routine tasks, concerns over data privacy, and the potential for algorithmic bias that can lead to unfair outcomes in critical areas such as hiring and law enforcement. To address these challenges, the article calls for the development of comprehensive ethical guidelines and regulations. These guidelines should ensure that AI systems are transparent, fair, and accountable, promoting trust and equitable access to technology. The long-term success of AI in society hinges on balancing innovation with responsible governance.
keyTakeAways: The use of AI in society has led to increased efficiency and innovation in various sectors, such as healthcare, education, and transportation.
However, concerns about job displacement, data privacy, and algorithmic bias remain significant challenges.
There is a growing need for ethical guidelines and regulations to ensure that AI development and deployment are transparent, fair, and accountable.

articles.content:
Should we all start locking up our phones? 
         By Brittany Luse, Corey Antonio Rose, Neena Pathak, Mika Ellison  
        
           Wednesday, November 5, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 3:00 AM EST 
        
        
      

         Does your phone feel like a blessing or a burden? Either way, there's probably a lot you can learn from new phone bans. Many K-12 students are going phone-free ‚Äì but not by choice. In over half the country, there are now restrictions on cellphone possession and use in class. The goal is to increase student focus and enhance learning ... but when you think about school shootings, phones have been a big part of parents' safety plans for their kids. So are phone bans the best solution? And what do these policies teach all of us about the role phones play in our lives? Brittany is joined by  David Figlio , professor of economics at the University of Rochester, and  Kathy Do , assistant project scientist at University of California, Los Angeles. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Episode Highlights Giving grace is a good idea DO: In some cases, this work suggests that unless phones are used as tools for learning, limiting phone use in classrooms can help students build attention and self-regulation skills. But some students are really going to have a harder time adjusting to these new phone rules. And our report is just highlighting why it's so important that schools build these flexible, equitable policies and have support systems in place, not necessarily more suspensions, because the goal should be to help kids access the tools they need to learn and thrive. Better vibes DO: I think one positive that [students reported] is just realizing what phone-free interactions feel like. Really pushing them out of their shell to talk to other people that they might [not] have otherwise. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       LUSE: Really engaging with their classmates who they're actually in the same room with, right? I didn't even think about that. DO: Or they appreciated being distraction-free while learning, like what David was saying. They appreciated having the phones away from their bodies so that they could really focus. So those are some of the benefits that we heard from students. And then from teachers, I think some of those lockable pouches or cubbies that keep phones away from students' person allowed the classroom to be more positive because the teacher wasn't like, the keeper of the phone and enforcer of restrictions anymore. Cell phones could conflict with crises DO: Yeah, there is this tension between kind of family safety expectations, but also on the other side, crisis protocols. Of course, it's important to maintain that line of communication with caregivers. But I think that's one of the nuances, how having phones on you for safety reasons to maintain that line of communication with caregivers can sometimes interfere with crisis protocols that schools are thoughtfully implementing in the case of emergencies. FIGLIO: So often, I and other parents think about one side of this equation. We think about the idea that when something bad is happening, we want the immediate reassurance that our kid is okay. And at the same time, this immediate reassurance we want can actually interfere with the process of ensuring that our kid is okay ‚Ä¶ and I don't have a good answer to that. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       
         
         Transcript 
         BRITTANY LUSE, HOST:   How are classrooms different pre- and post-smartphones? DAVID FIGLIO: Back in the day when I went to school, we communicated with one another by passing notes and hoping the teachers didn't catch us, right? But a lot has changed since then. KATHY DO: You know, a lot of us adults didn't grow up with phones. But for young people, phones are now, like, the main ways that they stay connected, they keep their social lives intact, they learn new information. And so, also, I think it's really important for us to help young people figure out that balance because it's kind of everywhere for them in a way that wasn't as pervasive for us growing up. LUSE: So when I was in school, like, K through 12, I was probably most worried about report card day, finishing my homework before class and who was reading my LiveJournal. One thing I was not worried about was whatever notification was coming up on my phone. I didn't get a cellphone till my freshman year of high school, and it was my dad's old Nokia. I don't even know if it could send or accept text messages, and the only game on it was Snake. So obviously, you could barely do anything with this phone. But classrooms today are a different world than they used to be. FIGLIO: You're constantly getting interrupted. You're constantly getting this feedback. You're constantly getting tempted to be brought into who knows what. LUSE: That's David Figlio. He's a professor of economics at the University of Rochester, and he just coauthored a study on what some educators see as a solution to the great smartphone invasion. FIGLIO: We're seeing school districts, states, countries saying we are not allowing cellphones in school. LUSE: That's right - classroom cellphone bans. FIGLIO: It could be bell to bell from the time kids get to school until the time kids leave school. It could be just during instructional time. All of those things are going on. DO: Yeah. I think, you know, a lot of families and teachers everywhere are raising real concerns about how cellphones are shaping how young people learn and their mental health. LUSE: That's Kathy Do. She's an assistant project scientist at the University of California, Los Angeles. She studied the effects of cellphone bans on students and the communities they live in. DO: We know that cellphones affect students differently. For some, they support connection, communication and learning. But there's also risks around distraction, exclusion and inequity. LUSE: One thing that shocked me when learning about the cellphone bans was how deeply cellphones are already integrated into the classroom. DO: Especially for school districts from lower resource communities, they're having kids use their phones and apps on them in science experiments - so, like, using the speedometers on their phones that are just naturally there to, like, measure how fast, you know, certain objects fall in the classroom. And so it's really aiding a lot of teachers and helping give them the tools to learn, to collaborate in group projects. LUSE: So there's strong arguments for and against cellphones in class. And clearly, educators and lawmakers think the answer is a phone prohibition, a mobile moratorium, a cell block for the cellphones. But is that the only solution? Or are we projecting some of our own adult anxieties about phones onto the next generation? So whether you have kids of your own or you're child-free, what can we all learn about our relationships with our phones through the policies being applied to teenagers? Kathy and David are here to help us understand. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Hello, hello. I'm Brittany Luse, and you're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, a show about what's going on in culture and why it doesn't happen by accident. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: I understand how if there's a technological tool available and you know that kids are going to be using it in their future, I do see a way in which it makes sense to kind of integrate that into the classroom. But I wonder, how have parents or other adults in general responded to smartphones being integrated into, like, the classroom? FIGLIO: Well, this is something I've noticed both at the K-12 level as well as higher ed. Parents these days expect to be in pretty close to constant conversation with their children. LUSE: In college? FIGLIO: Oh, I'm sorry to say yes. That... LUSE: (Laughter). FIGLIO: ...But I'll tell you, there are a number of parents nowadays who feel like, we're going to college. I'm right there along with you. LUSE: What? FIGLIO: So I think there's an awful lot of parents wanting to be connected with their kids all the time. And that's actually one of the things I've heard that is a bit of a parental concern about cellphone bans in school. What if I can't catch up with my kid? How do I know they're doing OK? How do I know they're thriving if I can't hear from them every hour? LUSE: Wow. Wow. Wow. I mean, my parents were on me my entire childhood. They were on me. But even when I went to college, they were like, OK, well (laughter), good luck. You're out there. Like, get on out. That is interesting. That is interesting. OK, so help me to understand the takeaways of your research. Like, what have you been noticing about phone use in schools and how it's affecting students? FIGLIO: Sure. So a lot of people think, oh, my gosh, these phones are absolutely wrecking school. So what my coauthor Umut Ozek at the RAND Corporation and I decided to do was do the first causal study of what happens to kids' academic outcomes when you take away the phones. Florida was among the very first in the country to introduce one of these cellphone bans. And what we did was we looked at one large anonymous school district in Florida - one of the biggest in the country. We were interested in seeing what happened to test scores, what happened to attendance and what happened to discipline when the cellphones were banned from the beginning of the school day to the end of the school day, no exceptions. Here's what we found. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) FIGLIO: We found evidence that the cellphone ban led to modestly improved test scores. (SOUNDBITE OF BELL) FIGLIO: Especially in Year 2, after we got past some of the hiccups at the beginning, we found that the cellphone ban led to improved attendance. (SOUNDBITE OF BELL) FIGLIO: We don't know exactly the reason behind that, but we think it is due to improved school environment, better engagement. But - and there's always a but - we found in the short run, in the first year, the cellphone ban led to increased discipline. (SOUNDBITE OF BUZZER) FIGLIO: And the discipline concentrated disproportionately with Black students. And here, we don't know the answer to that offhand. We don't know. It could be the case that Black students were differentially violating the cellphone ban. It could be the Black students were differentially being targeted by discipline. But we do know that Black students in this school district in Florida were getting disciplined more as a direct consequence of this ban. LUSE: Yeah, I have your research here. And it says that in the first year after the ban, in-school suspensions increased by roughly 30% for Black students, while it had no significant effect for white and Hispanic students. FIGLIO: That lasted a year. By Year 2, it was gone. But in that first year, we saw the discipline. LUSE: That sounds like a multipronged issue. And I wonder how that lines up with other data regarding how Black students are targeted for discipline in classrooms. Kathy, I'd love to hear from you on this. In your experience, how have you seen phone use in schools affecting students? DO: Yeah, I think some of the test score and data that David is highlighting aligns with research showing that, you know, splitting attention between classwork and cellphones can hurt learning and focus and test scores. And this is kind of in part due to, like, the type of learning strategies students use when they're not on their phones. They tend to take more detailed notes and in turn kind of do better on tests. And so, you know, in some cases, you know, this work suggests that unless phones are used as tools for learning, limiting phone use in classrooms can help students build attention and self-regulation skills that boost this achievement. But I think some of the other pieces that David is highlighting is, you know, that some students are really going to have a harder time adjusting to these new phone rules. And our report is just highlighting why it's so important that schools build these flexible, equitable policies and have support systems in place, not necessarily more suspensions, because the goal should be to help kids access the tools they need to learn and thrive. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Coming up... DO: I think one kind of positive that we saw from what students were sharing about the kind of benefits for themselves that they've seen is just realizing what phone-free interactions kind of feel like, like, really pushing them out of their shell. LUSE: Stay with us. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: OK, so David, you touched on this a little bit already. But I'm wondering, I want to ask you both squarely, like, what consequences of cellphone bans should listeners know about? FIGLIO: It varies from place to place. A lot depends on what are the punishments that are associated with these bans. I know that there are some places, not the county school district that I was studying, that had zero tolerance policies where the first violation of a cellphone ban is an automatic suspension. LUSE: Oh. FIGLIO: The place that Umut Ozek and I carried out our study was somewhere in the middle. They had a cooling off period at the beginning of the academic year, a month in which they said the phones are banned but there will be no consequences. And then after that, they started to say, OK, the first couple of offenses, we're just going to remind you. After that, there were going to be escalating sanctions. LUSE: Escalating sanctions like detention or in-school suspension? FIGLIO: They wanted to have suspensions be in school versus out of school. But I will say, one thing that Florida did at the beginning that now they've changed is at the beginning, Florida allowed kids to have their phones on their person - right? - including smart watches. And now, as of this year, Florida requires kids to have the phones fully locked away. LUSE: Yes, elementary and middle school students are under a bell-to-bell policy where they can't use phones at all during the day. And high school students are banned from using them during instructional time. DO: Yeah. Based on our work, we suggest that repeated cellphone violations should prompt something like mental health support rather than suspensions. You know, from the research from neuroscience and psychology, we know that teens' brains and behaviors and self-regulation skills are still developing. And so, you know, youth cellphone overuse might reflect some underlying mental health needs or, you know, challenges with developing self-regulation skills, not simply rule-breaking. So I think we need to be more open-minded about what that might look like for young people. LUSE: Did students ever react positively to these bans? DO: I think one kind of positive that we saw from what students were sharing about the kind of benefits for themselves that they've seen is just realizing what phone-free interactions kind of feel like, like really pushing them out of their shell to talk to other people that they might have otherwise, you know, just... LUSE: Right, like engaging with their classmates who they're actually in the same room with. Right. I didn't even think about that. Yeah. DO: Yeah, or, like, they appreciated being distraction-free while learning, kind of what David was saying, like, they appreciated having the phones away from their bodies so that they could really focus. So those are some of the benefits that we heard from students. And then from teachers, I think some of those, you know, lockable pouches or cubbies that keep phones away from students' kind of person allowed classroom to be more positive because the teacher wasn't, like, the keeper of the phone and enforcer of restrictions anymore. And so there are some benefits as well. FIGLIO: If I can jump in, I think that this is one of the things that's probably behind the fact that we're finding this improvement in attendance that's occurring as a direct consequence of the cellphone bans. Both the narrative evidence that Kathy is describing as well as now some of the early quantitative evidence is suggesting that schools are just more pleasant places to be. People tend to be less interested in skipping school if school's a more pleasant place to be. So that's the flip side of some of these growing pains, I could say. LUSE: One thing I feel like we have to ask about is, like, you know, one aspect of kind of this safety angle that I think is on a lot of parents' minds, maybe even students' as well. You know, as school shootings have become more and more common, many parents want to be able to have contact with their kids at all times. You know, children having cellphones at school is considered a safety measure by many parents. I wonder, is that worth it, even if the phone could be a potential distraction for their kids in class, or even just what do you make of that angle in general? DO: Yeah, there is this tension between kind of family safety expectations, as you were saying, but also on the other side, crisis protocols. LUSE: Right, crisis protocols being like the plans of action schools implement to navigate all kinds of emergency situations, from earthquakes to active shooters. DO: Yeah, I think in some cases, in an emergency, it's really important for students, especially in the K through 12 setting, to be paying attention to the adults giving directions about how to, you know, navigate this emergency instead of texting or not paying attention to what's happening. And so in the moment it can - having access to phones can interfere with some of the crisis protocols that schools have in place. Afterwards, of course, it's important to maintain that line of communication with caregivers. But I think that's one of the nuances as to how, you know, having phones on you for safety reasons to maintain that line of communication with caregivers can sometimes, like, interfere with crisis protocols that schools are thoughtfully implementing in the case of emergencies. FIGLIO: I mean, ditto - right? - to what Kathy just said, right? I can speak as a parent, right? So often I and other parents think about one side of this equation, right? We think about the idea that when something bad is happening, we want the immediate reassurance that our kid is OK. And at the same time, this immediate reassurance we want can actually interfere with the process of ensuring that our kid is OK. And I can tell you myself, I've never - mercifully none of my kids have ever been in a school setting with a real, true instant emergency. And for that, I'm eternally grateful. But I just look at the - sometimes these very real, urgent elemental need that parents may have could be butting up against this very real, urgent elemental need that we also have to help to ensure that a crisis is averted. And I don't know that - I don't have a good answer to that. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: This kind of tension around, like, from a safety perspective, should children have phones in school or not, in some ways, it can be a proxy conversation for what are we really doing about mass shootings and gun violence against children in schools. Thank you both so much for this conversation. I really appreciate it. I learned so much. DO: Yeah, I learned so much too. Thank you. FIGLIO: Thanks for having us on. LUSE: That was David Figlio, professor of economics at University of Rochester, and Kathy Do, assistant project scientist at University of California, Los Angeles. You can find both of their research in our show notes. And I'm going to put on my influencer hat for a second and ask you to please subscribe to this show on Spotify, Apple or wherever you're listening. Click follow so you know the latest in culture while it's still hot. This episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE was produced by... COREY ANTONIO ROSE, BYLINE: Corey Antonio Rose. LUSE: This episode was edited by... NEENA PATHAK, BYLINE: Neena Pathak. LUSE: Our supervising producer is... BARTON GIRDWOOD, BYLINE: Barton Girdwood. LUSE: Our executive producer is... VERALYN WILLIAMS, BYLINE: Veralyn Williams. LUSE: Our VP of programming is... YOLANDA SANGWENI, BYLINE: Yolanda Sangweni. LUSE: All right. That's all for this episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. I'm Brittany Luse. Talk soon.

articles.title: Big media takeaways from Mamdani‚Äôs victory and the Democratic sweep
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs unexpected victory as New York City‚Äôs next mayor, coupled with Democratic sweeps in New Jersey and Virginia, signals a major shift in U.S. political dynamics. The article highlights how progressive media, including The Nation and Jacobin, celebrate Mamdani‚Äôs rise as a potential antidote to Trumpism and a model of inclusive, working-class politics. In contrast, Fox News responded to the defeats with fear-based narratives, framing them as a 'referendum on Trump' and amplifying misinformation. The piece emphasizes a critical gap in traditional media representation, where elite panels often exclude the voices of everyday working people. Instead, journalists like Aditi Sangal are now conducting on-the-ground reporting at community spaces like Kabab King to reflect real voter experiences. Additionally, the article notes that Mamdani‚Äôs campaign success‚Äîmarked by a sharp rise in media attention from March to November‚Äîdemonstrates the power of grassroots messaging and media savvy, especially among younger, progressive voters. This shift not only reflects changing political sentiment but also calls for journalism to evolve toward more inclusive, representative, and community-centered coverage.
keyTakeAways: Zohran Mamdani's victory reflects a shift in political discourse, where working-class New Yorkers are now central to Democratic political narratives.

Media coverage of political events has evolved to include diverse voices, such as those from Jackson Heights and grassroots left-wing commentators like Bhaskar Sunkara and Hasan Piker, challenging the traditional media dominance by conservative talking heads.

articles.content:
Big media takeaways from Mamdani‚Äôs victory and the Democratic sweep 
       
  Analysis by Brian Stelter, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        12:20 PM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
   A version of this article first appeared in the ‚ÄúReliable Sources‚Äù newsletter. You can  sign up for free here . 
 

   
  From time to time, news outlet leaders should look around and ask: Do our stories reflect the current state of political discourse? Do our segments represent the voices of all voters?
 

   
  I found myself thinking about this on Tuesday evening as Zohran Mamdani talked about ‚Äúthe working people of New York,‚Äù whom he credited with his victory. ‚ÄúFingers bruised from lifting boxes on the warehouse floor, palms calloused from delivery bike handlebars, knuckles scarred with kitchen burns: These are not hands that have been allowed to hold power,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd yet, over the last 12 months, you have dared to reach for something greater.‚Äù
 

   
  I love a good TV panel discussion. But it‚Äôs worth asking if the typical one actually includes, or even channels the views of, people like the ones Mamdani described.
 

   
  As David Axelrod acknowledged during one of CNN‚Äôs panels late last night, ‚ÄúEveryone at this table is going to go home to great comfort.‚Äù But ‚Äúthere are a lot of people in this city, there are a lot of people in this country, who have to worry every single day about how they‚Äôre going to meet their bills. And that is a crisis.‚Äù
 

   
  That disconnect ‚Äî between who we invite to talk about politics and who is actually shaping it on the ground ‚Äî is a gap that journalists, especially on TV, constantly have to work hard to close.
 

   
  Thus, my favorite day-after story is by CNN‚Äôs Aditi Sangal, who spent the evening at Kabab King, the mayor-elect‚Äôs go-to biryani spot in Jackson Heights.  Check out what she heard here .
 

   
    Progressive columnists celebrate
 

   
  In the same way that media outlets sought out Trump-supporting talking heads in 2015 and 2016, it‚Äôs crucial to seek out commentators who speak for a new, younger generation of Democratic voters.
 

   
  For example, The Free Press election night live stream last night hosted Bhaskar Sunkara, president of The Nation magazine and founding editor of the socialist magazine Jacobin.
 

   
  ‚ÄúThis wasn‚Äôt supposed to happen,‚Äù Eric Blanc wrote  in an essay  that led Jacobin‚Äôs website last night and this morning. Blanc conveyed the improbability of Mamdani‚Äôs victory, then warned, ‚Äúturning Zohran‚Äôs vision into a reality won‚Äôt be easy. Some of the most powerful people and institutions in the world are going to do everything to stop us. But transforming our city is possible, if large numbers of everyday New Yorkers join the fight. America‚Äôs oligarchs are right to be worried.‚Äù
 

   
  The Nation‚Äôs editor Katrina vanden Heuvel and executive editor John Nichols published a similar  editorial  last night. Mamdani ‚Äúhas no higher responsibility than to be a great mayor of New York City,‚Äù they wrote. In success, he ‚Äúhas the potential to transform not just a city but the politics of a nation that desperately needs a robust antidote to Donald Trump‚Äôs oppressions.‚Äù
 

   
    From fringe to media frenzy
 

   
  Just eight months ago,  in March,  Mamdani held a press conference in Manhattan with barely any journalists in attendance. Now, he is constantly surrounded by cameras. Mamdani comms aide Lekha Sunder  posted  March and November photos side by side with the caption, ‚ÄúHow far we‚Äôve come.‚Äù
 

   
  The campaign received more than 400 press RSVPs for Tuesday night‚Äôs victory party, including some from international media outlets, according to CNN‚Äôs Gloria Pazmino. Many ‚Äúvoices on the left‚Äù were there too, ‚Äúincluding Drop Site News‚Äô Ryan Grim and Democracy Now‚Äôs Amy Goodman,‚Äù along with live-streaming star Hasan Piker, who drew a crowd of his own, TheWrap‚Äôs Michael Calderone  wrote here .
 

   
  Commentators emphasized Mamdani‚Äôs media savvy as well as his message  consistency . Maybe it doesn‚Äôt matter so much ‚Äúhow you use Instagram and TikTok,‚Äù Errol Louis said last night on NY1. ‚ÄúWhat really  does  matter is going to people and saying, ‚ÄòWhat are the issues that most concern you?‚Äô ‚Äî writing down what they say; then making that your program; and not talking about anything else.‚Äù
 

   
  As journalism professor Jay Rosen has argued over the years, this ‚Äú citizens agenda ‚Äù concept also applies well to news coverage.
 

   
    What the polls missed in NJ
 

   
  In New Jersey, the governor‚Äôs race was expected to be a nail-biter. Why? In part because of the polls showing Sherrill with only a slight lead over Jack Ciattarelli. The RCP  average  of recent polls had Sherrill with just a 3.3% edge. But she ultimately won 56% to 42%. Polls ‚Äúsaid it was too close to call, and she just absolutely thumped‚Äù Ciattarelli, Joe Scarborough said on MSNBC this morning.
 

   
  In retrospect, the ‚Äútell‚Äù was that Sherrill was ahead in  every  pre-election poll, even though most of the polls overstated support for her rival.
 

   
    How Fox News handled it all
 

   
  Because the key races were all called before Fox‚Äôs special coverage started at 10 p.m., we got to watch MAGA devotees Jesse Watters and Sean Hannity cope in real time. Both hosts tried to spin away any suggestion that the losses were a repudiation of Trump.
 

   
  After calling Abigail Spanberger‚Äôs victory in Virginia, Watters declared, ‚ÄúThe Democrats are going to spin this: ‚ÄòThis is a referendum on Trump.‚Äô I mean, these are all blue states.‚Äù That particular line continued into Hannity‚Äôs hour. Hannity also said his phone was blowing up with texts from friends in New York who were ‚Äúdepressed and scared.‚Äù Fox‚Äôs shows leaned hard into ‚Äúsocialism‚Äù fears all night long.
 

   
    Taunting the TV president
 

   
  Here‚Äôs an interesting argument  from  conservative writer Sohrab Ahmari: ‚ÄúThe sheer cartoonishness of the Right‚Äôs attacks rendered (Mamdani) more sympathetic.‚Äù (The aforementioned Michael Calderone compiled all the recent NY Post front pages  here .)
 

   
  Mamdani alluded to that ‚Äúprism of misinformation‚Äù last night, and he also presaged the Mamdani-Trump feedback loop that we can expect to see a lot next year. He leaned into Trump‚Äôs TV obsession with a big, headline-generating taunt: ‚ÄúDonald Trump, since I know you‚Äôre watching, I have four words for you: Turn the volume up.‚Äù
 

   
  And Trump likely  was  watching, because Fox News carried Mamdani‚Äôs speech in full. Anchor Trace Gallagher invited Trump to call in immediately afterward, but no such luck.
 

   
  Speaking of feedback loops: During Hannity‚Äôs show, GOP pollster Matt Towery blamed the losses on the shutdown and the fact that Trump‚Äôs name wasn‚Äôt on the ballot. Just eight minutes later, Matt Gertz  noted , Trump posted that same exact argument to Truth Social.

articles.title: Trump administration ordered to restore full SNAP benefits by Friday
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A Rhode Island federal judge, John McConnell Jr., ordered the Trump administration to restore full funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) by Friday, November 6, 2025, after the administration halted payments on November 1. The court ruled that the government failed to consider the harms to individuals relying on food assistance. The administration initially proposed a 50% reduction in benefits, revised to 35%, which still left nearly 5 million people without any payment. The USDA used only a small portion of contingency funds, rejecting requests to use larger emergency reserves. States like Pennsylvania and Minnesota expressed serious concerns over the complexity of the new calculation formulas, which could delay benefit payments by weeks due to outdated administrative systems. A report by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities found that the original plan would have left millions without support, and advocacy groups and state officials urged the USDA to adopt simpler, faster methods‚Äîsuch as paying half benefits‚Äîused during the pandemic. This case highlights a conflict between federal policy, legal obligations, and the practical realities of delivering critical social services.

articles.content:
Trump administration ordered to restore full SNAP benefits by Friday 
         By Jennifer Ludden 
        
           Updated Thursday, November 6, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 5:10 PM EST 
        
        
      

         WASHINGTON ‚Äî  A Rhode Island federal judge has ordered the Trump administration to find enough money to restore full funding for SNAP benefits by Friday. In failing to fully fund the food assistance program that covers 42 million low-income Americans, U.S. District Court Judge John McConnell Jr. said the government "failed to consider the harms individuals who rely on those benefits would suffer."  The Trump administration swiftly appealed the judge's ruling to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The judge's order Thursday afternoon comes in response to a challenge filed by cities and nonprofits after the administration said it would halt funding for the program on Nov. 1. McConnell and another federal judge in Boston ordered the government to use emergency funds to keep SNAP funding flowing, but Trump administration officials said it was only able to partially cover the payments. On Wednesday night, the Trump administration said  it would cut  November's SNAP food benefits by a bit less than it had previously announced. In   revised guidance for states , which are calculating partial payments, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said in a court filing maximum allotments would be reduced by 35% instead of 50%. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Even with the smaller proposed cut, the complex formula for reduced payments would have stayed the same, and still mean steep cuts for those who rely on the country's largest anti-hunger program. USDA's proposed change came after an  analysis by the left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities , which found the agency's original formula for partial payments would not have tapped all of its contingency funds.  Two federal judges  had found the administration is legally bound to spend that money to keep SNAP going. CBPP also estimated the original reduced benefit plan would have left nearly 5 million people with no payment at all this month. USDA did not respond to NPR's request for comment on the center's analysis or its changed plan. But in a court filing late Wednesday related to the revised partial payment formula, the Justice department wrote   the agency "realized this error and worked to issue new guidance and tables as soon as it was discovered." The change will be small in some cases. For example, the minimum allotment for some 1-to-2 person households under  the USDA's revised formula  went from $12 to $16. McConnell ordered the administration to restart the country's largest anti-hunger program after funding lapsed last Saturday, a month into the government shutdown.   USDA rejected the suggestion by that judge, and another federal judge in Boston, that it tap a larger pot of money to fully cover SNAP payments. Instead, it chose to use only a smaller contingency fund that could cover only about half of the program's monthly cost. Implementing the administration's complex  partial funding formula  presents enormous procedural challenges for states, which administer the program that serves 42 million Americans. The USDA itself warned it could take weeks or even months to get the benefits to people. "It requires a  complete recalculation and a complete recoding  of our system," said Tikki Brown, the head of Minnesota's Department of Children, Youth and Families. She said there is no timeline yet for payments in her state. Danny Mintz, who works for the civic technology nonprofit Code for America, said some states have antiquated systems from the 1970s that make it difficult to quickly implement sweeping calculation changes. "There are legitimate concerns that altering the calculations of benefits may break things," he said. "The quickest way for states to get benefits into people's hands is for USDA to fund the full amount of SNAP benefits." Some states already are  warning  it could be weeks before payments can be made. In a bluntly worded letter to USDA ‚Äî  seen by NPR member station WESA  ‚Äî Pennsylvania Human Services Secretary Val Arkoosh said the federal government is "directing states to use the most complex and labor-intensive approach possible." Pennsylvania is asking to use a simpler, faster method that was allowed for pandemic-related aid, and would essentially give everyone half their SNAP payment.

articles.title: Subway sandwich thrower found not guilty in D.C. jury rebuke
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a case that has become a symbol of public frustration with federal law enforcement in Washington, D.C., Sean Charles Dunn, a former Justice Department employee, was found not guilty after throwing a Subway sandwich at U.S. Customs and Border Protection agent Gregory Lairmore in August 2025. The incident occurred during a protest against what Dunn perceived as racist and fascist actions by federal officers, especially at a gay nightclub during Latin Night. Although Lairmore reported the sandwich exploded and smelled of mustard and onions and was not injured, prosecutors initially pursued a felony charge, which was downgraded to a misdemeanor due to a lack of grand jury indictment. Dunn's defense argued the act was a harmless, politically motivated gesture, while the case reflects broader tensions over federal policing and public dissent. The incident also revealed a culture of humor within the agency, as Lairmore admitted to receiving gag gifts like a plush sandwich and a 'Felony Footlong' patch. The jury‚Äôs verdict underscores the ongoing debate over how to balance law enforcement authority with civil liberties in a politically sensitive environment.
keyTakeAways: A man, Sean Charles Dunn, was found not guilty of assaulting a federal officer after throwing a Subway sandwich at U.S. Customs and Border Protection agent Gregory Lairmore.
The case has become a symbol of public sentiment in Washington, D.C., regarding the Trump administration's expansion of federal law enforcement presence.
Dunn claimed he was reacting to perceived racism and fascism by federal officers, asserting he was not targeting the officer personally but expressing opposition to government policy.
Lairmore, wearing a bulletproof vest, reported that the sandwich exploded and smelled of onions and mustard, but suffered no injury.
The U.S. attorney‚Äôs office initially pursued a felony charge, which was dropped due to lack of grand jury indictment, resulting in a misdemeanor charge.
Prosecutors argued that throwing objects at law enforcement is unacceptable, while Dunn‚Äôs legal team emphasized the gesture was harmless and politically motivated.
Lairmore admitted to receiving gag gifts from colleagues, including a plush sandwich and a 'Felony Footlong' patch, suggesting a culture of humor and irony within the agency.
Dunn was previously employed at the Justice Department and was fired following the incident.

Subway sandwich thrower found not guilty in D.C. jury rebuke 
         By Carrie Johnson 
        
           Updated Thursday, November 6, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 3:30 PM EST 
        
        
           Heard on  All Things Considered 
        
      

         Not guilty. That was the finding of a jury on Thursday in the case of a man  charged with assault  for throwing his hoagie at a federal officer in Washington, D.C. The jury's conclusion came after about seven hours of deliberations. The case of the Subway sandwich has come to symbolize how many in the nation's capital feel about the Trump administration's surge of federal law enforcement to the city. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       A bystander's video captured Sean Charles Dunn in August calling federal officers racists and fascists. He thought they were about to do an immigration raid at a gay nightclub on Latin Night. He also threw his Subway sandwich at Gregory Lairmore, an agent with U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Lairmore, who was wearing a bulletproof vest, told jurors the sandwich exploded and he smelled onions and mustard ‚Äî though he wasn't hurt. Dunn was later caught by police and fired from his job at the Justice Department. The U.S. attorney's office in D.C. initially tried to charge Dunn with felony assault. When a grand jury failed to indict him on that charge, the case was downgraded to a misdemeanor charge for assaulting or impeding a federal officer. Prosecutors said Dunn went too far, and people should not be allowed to throw things at law enforcement. Dunn argued that he was being singled out because of his criticism of the Trump administration. His lawyers also teased out the absurdity of the situation, arguing it was a harmless gesture that caused no harm or injury. Lairmore, who was wearing a bulletproof vest, admitted during the trial that he received gag gifts from colleagues, including a plush sandwich and a patch that says "Felony Footlong." "I'm relieved and I'm looking forward to moving on with my life," Sean Charles Dunn said outside the courthouse on Thursday after the jury's verdict.

articles.content:
Tesla shareholders approve Elon Musk's trillion-dollar pay package 
         By Camila Domonoske 
        
           Updated Thursday, November 6, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 5:04 PM EST 
        
        
      

         Tesla shareholders have overwhelmingly approved a pay package of extraordinary proportions for Elon Musk, passing the measure with 75% of the vote, according to preliminary results announced at Tesla's annual shareholder meeting. That package is conditional: Musk would earn no salary, but would unlock Tesla stock worth about a trillion dollars if the company meets certain criteria within the next decade. Among other targets, he would have to raise the company's market capitalization, the value of all its stock put together, from about $1.5 trillion today to above $8.5 trillion. For comparison, the most valuable company in the world, Nvidia ‚Äî the chipmaker boosted by the AI boom ‚Äî is worth $4.83 trillion. (Its CEO, who is seen as pivotal to the company's success, is paid $50 million per year and owns 3.5% of the company.) Musk is already unfathomably wealthy, worth some $460 billion,  according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index . That's thanks in large part to Tesla's soaring stock price, currently worth about $465 per share. (That's more than 400 times more valuable than at the company's IPO in 2010.) 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       A previous pay package that offered Musk a then-unprecedented $55.8 billion has been tied up in  a lengthy court battle  after a judge ruled that the board was too cozy with Musk in designing it. That case is still pending, and  Tesla's board has made sure  that Musk will receive  tens of billions of dollars' worth of stock  for his last few years of work, no matter how it is resolved. But what about pay for his future work? Tesla's board  argues  that they need to incentivize him to "remain at Tesla and focus his unmatched leadership abilities" on the company, and that extraordinary results merit extraordinary pay. Even some of Musk's hard-core fans feel that, over the last few years, he has been  distracted by politics and other projects , to the detriment of  Tesla's efforts to sell cars . Tesla's profits have been  down  from  last year  throughout  2025 . The new package, like the previous one, is entirely based on performance and divided into twelve tranches. If Tesla's stock value grows to hit each of 12 targets, and Tesla also meets separate  earnings or product-specific sales targets , Musk earns a tranche of stock for each pair of targets he hits. He won't be able to sell that stock immediately, to further incentivize him to stick around. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Tesla did not respond to a request for comment, but the board has strongly advocated for this pay package in SEC filings and public comments. Supporters of the pay package emphasize that Musk only gets his big payday if Tesla's value grows enormously, boosting shareholders. Critics note that he could take home hundreds of billions even if he only unlocks a few relatively modest targets. Musk only gets the full trillion-dollar prize if he pulls off the "Mars-shot" of hitting  all  the targets. (Technically, he could take home slightly less, because of some details governing how the restricted stock units would be granted. Of course, it could be  more , if the stock growth beats the top target.) A trillion dollars is hard to wrap your head around, so we did a little number crunching to put this extraordinary pay package in perspective. $8.8 billion per year¬† All-stock compensation packages are tricky to value, because their true worth fluctuates with the company's share price. So what costs the company a small amount to give in 2025 might be worth an enormous amount in 2035, for instance. Based on recent stock prices, Tesla's board values this pay package at around $88 billion, which is a small fraction of what Musk would actually receive if he hits his targets and Tesla stock soars. But even using that very conservative figure, it works out to $8.8 billion a year. Glass Lewis, a proxy advisory firm, analyzes company books and recommends how shareholders should vote on decisions like this. The firm estimates that the entire S&P 500 combined paid  all  its CEOs about $9 billion last year. So Musk would make about as much as every other major corporate CEO combined ‚Äî  before  factoring in stock growth. 28.8% That's how much of Tesla's voting shares Musk would own if he unlocks the full pay package. Musk and Tesla's board have publicly said it's this control ‚Äî not the money ‚Äî that is the real prize. "It's less about compensation and more about the voting influence," board chair Robyn Denholm  told CNBC recently . Critics view it the same way. Tom Dinapoli, the comptroller of New York State, recently called the proposal "pay for unchecked power." One of the pay package targets is for Tesla to sell a million robots. Tesla has been developing a humanoid robot called Optimus, designed to work in factories as well as homes. Musk imagines one for  every person on Earth , all of them running Tesla software. And on  an earnings call last month, he said  he wants to make sure that if he builds what he calls a "robot army," he stays in charge of it. "It's not like I'm going to go spend the money. It's just, if we build this robot army, do I have at least a strong influence over that robot army? Not control, but strong influence," Musk said. "I don't feel comfortable building that robot army if I don't have at least a strong influence." 33x¬† This pay package, by Tesla's own lowball valuation, is more than 33 times larger than the previous biggest-ever package ‚Ä¶ which was Musk's 2018 pay package, then given an equally conservative $2.6 billion valuation. (The value of that 2018 package today is actually above $100 billion, thanks to the rise in Tesla's share price.) That 2018 package, meanwhile, was 33 times larger than the biggest award before that. Which was Elon Musk's 2012 pay package, worth approximately $78 million. $942 billion¬† Glass Lewis has calculated that Musk would actually take home $942 billion once he hits the targets, after some payments he'd be required to make for tax purposes. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Musk has said he won't spend the money. But what could he buy if he did? To give a sense of scale, we pulled the numbers for some of the world's priciest luxury items. Let's say Musk bought every single Rolls Royce sold in a year ‚Äî last year that was 5,712 cars at about $500,000 each. That's $2.85 billion. Let's say he also bought every yacht on offer for a year. Global yacht sales in the  first quarter of this year  were $1 billion, so call it $4 billion for the year. How about a year's worth of jet sales? According to  one estimate , the entire global private jet market will hit $39.84 billion this year. So let's say that Musk buys every new Rolls-Royce, private jet and yacht sold in the entire world. And then does the same thing every year for a decade. He'd still have $475 billion left over. At press time, that's more money than the richest person on Earth possesses, according to the Bloomberg's Billionaires Index. That person is, of course, Elon Musk.

articles.title: Spanberger and Sherrill Make History as First Female Governors of Virginia and New Jersey
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill, former roommates and freshman members of Congress, have made history by becoming the first female governors of Virginia and New Jersey, respectively. Their victories, which occurred in a politically challenging environment marked by a shift in voter support toward President Donald Trump, reflect a strong public demand for pragmatic, issue-focused leadership centered on affordability in healthcare, housing, and utilities. Both candidates ran as centrist Democrats, aligning with the 'Mod Squad' ideology, emphasizing national security and fiscal responsibility. Their personal connection and shared political journey, including their time as roommates on Capitol Hill, underscore a bond rooted in mutual respect and experience. The wins represent a significant milestone for gender representation in American state government and offer Democrats a viable path forward in appealing to voters who prioritize economic and social stability over ideological polarization.
keyTakeAways: Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill, former roommates and fellow members of Congress, made history by becoming the first female governors of Virginia and New Jersey, respectively.
Their victories occurred in a pivotal moment for Democrats, as the party grapples with voter shifts toward President Donald Trump and the need for authentic, pragmatic leadership.

Both candidates campaigned aggressively on affordability issues‚Äîlowering healthcare, housing, and utility costs‚Äîwhich resonated with voters and helped them surpass their predecessors' 2021 vote totals.
Spanberger and Sherrill are part of the 'Mod Squad,' a group of centrist Democrats who emphasize national security and fiscal prudence, contrasting with more progressive factions.

Their personal connection‚Äîhaving been roommates on Capitol Hill‚Äîadds a human element to their political journey, illustrating a shared political philosophy and mutual respect despite different paths.
The win represents a symbolic moment for young women in politics, as seen in the reactions of children who say they want to become governors or presidents.

Both are eldest of three girls with multiple children, and both have deep roots in the Northeast‚ÄîSpanberger from New Jersey, Sherrill from northern Virginia‚Äîhighlighting regional ties and shared community values.

articles.content:
Spanberger and Sherrill were roommates on Capitol Hill. They‚Äôre now making history in their states 
       
  By Arit John, CNN
 

       
Updated: 
        11:23 AM EST, Wed November 5, 2025
     



     
  Source: CNN
 
   
  Six years ago,  Abigail Spanberger  and  Mikie Sherrill  were roommates and freshman members of Congress, part of a record-breaking wave of women who helped Democrats win back the US House.
 

   
  On Tuesday, the two made history once more. CNN projected that Spanberger will be Virginia‚Äôs first female governor and Sherrill will be the first Democratic woman elected as governor of New Jersey.
 

   
  Their wins come at a time when Democrats are navigating difficult questions over who the next leaders of the party should be and what messages will work to win over voters who shifted toward President Donald Trump last year.
 

   
  Spanberger and Sherrill‚Äôs victories offer at least one path forward for Democrats. Both ran aggressively on affordability issues and promises to lower health care, housing and utility costs. It appears to have resonated with voters: Spanberger and Sherrill both surpassed the total number of votes their predecessors won in 2021 before votes were fully tallied in their states.
 

   
  ‚ÄúTonight we sent a message,‚Äù Spanberger told supporters at her election night rally. ‚ÄúWe sent a message to the whole world that in 2025, Virginia chose pragmatism over partisanship.‚Äù
 

   
  Spanberger, a former CIA officer, and Sherrill, a former Navy helicopter pilot, both won Republican-held seats in 2018 by running as national security-minded centrists. In Congress, they ‚Äì along with Rep. Chrissy Houlahan of Pennsylvania, now-Sen. Elissa Slotkin of Michigan and former Rep. Elaine Luria of Virginia ‚Äì formed the Mod Squad, a more centrist version of the progressive Squad.
 

   
  Years after they ran and won their first races, the two newest members of the Democratic Governors Association will enter this next phase of their careers side-by-side as well. Spanberger described the feeling of running in one of this year‚Äôs few competitive races alongside her friend as ‚Äúamusing.‚Äù
 

   
  ‚ÄúBeing able to compare notes has been fun,‚Äù she told CNN recently. ‚ÄúBut I think what I‚Äôm most excited about is just ‚Äî I know what I‚Äôm about to say sounds cheesy, but I mean it sincerely ‚Äî how hardworking she is ‚Ä¶ I think there will be some really interesting value in thinking through different issues or different challenges because we‚Äôre aligned in many places, but we get to the same place from different directions.‚Äù
 

   
  The two attempted to call and congratulate each other Tuesday night, Sherrill told CNN‚Äôs John Berman Wednesday morning.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI actually ended up calling her when she was on the stage giving her acceptance speech,‚Äù Sherrill said. ‚ÄúThen she called me when I happened to be on the stage giving my acceptance speech. So we‚Äôve texted, but we owe each other a good call.‚Äù
 

   
  Spanberger, 46, and Sherrill, 53, moved in with each other after growing tired of living on Capitol Hill on their own. The pair ate dinner off Sherrill‚Äôs gold-rimmed wedding china and sat on a two-decade-old couch Spanberger brought out of storage,  they told the Washington Post last year .
 

   
  They‚Äôre both eldest of three girls. They both have multiple children ‚Äì Spanberger has three kids, Sherrill has four. The Virginia governor-elect was born in New Jersey, while the incoming New Jersey governor grew up in northern Virginia.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think either of us thought we were going to run for office until in 2018 we felt called to serve again and have been in it ever since,‚Äù  Sherrill told CNN last month .
 

   
  During a campaign event this summer, Spanberger told reporters they were both eager to meet voters across their districts when they challenged longtime incumbent Republicans in 2018.
 

   
  ‚ÄúI maintain my friendship with her, so I know a bit about what she‚Äôs been doing across the campaign trail, and she‚Äôs been traveling everywhere in New Jersey,‚Äù Spanberger said. ‚ÄúThe common thread is that we‚Äôre relentlessly focused on the issues that people across our communities bring to us.‚Äù
 

   
  After their races were called, the two governors-elect also reflected on the historic nature of their wins. Sherrill mentioned ‚Äúthe little girls who come up to me and say they‚Äôre going to be a governor, or they‚Äôre going to be a president.‚Äù
 

   
  Spanberger noted that her husband had told their three daughters minutes earlier that their mother would be the state‚Äôs next governor.
 

   
  ‚ÄúAnd I can guarantee that those words have never been spoken in Virginia ever before,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe history Virginia is making tonight is yours.‚Äù
 

   
   CNN‚Äôs Edward-Isaac Dovere and Arlette Saenz contributed to this report.  
 

   
   This story has been updated with additional information.

articles.title: Supreme Court Allows Trump to Require Sex at Birth on Passports
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court, in a 6-3 decision, allowed President Trump to implement a policy requiring passport applicants to list their sex based on birth certificate designation, overturning a lower court order that had permitted gender identity selection. This decision, which emphasizes that displaying sex at birth is merely attesting to a historical fact and not discriminatory, was criticized by Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson and other liberal justices as a 'pointless but painful perversion of equitable discretion' due to its potential to harm transgender and non-binary individuals. The policy, previously introduced under President Biden with the option of an 'X' for non-binary identities, represents a significant policy reversal. The ruling is not final, and litigation continues in lower courts, leaving the long-term implications for transgender rights and identity documentation in flux.
keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court allowed President Trump to enforce a policy requiring passport applicants to list their sex based on birth certificate designation, overturning a lower court order that had allowed gender identity selection.
The policy, which allows applicants to choose M, F, or X on passports, was previously permitted under President Biden, with the X option introduced in 2021.
Ashton Orr, a transgender man, led a legal challenge arguing that the policy harms transgender and non-binary individuals and constitutes unconstitutional transphobia under the Fourteenth Amendment.
The government claimed the injunction harms foreign policy by forcing inconsistent statements to foreign governments about citizen identities.
The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that displaying sex at birth does not violate equal protection principles, stating it merely reflects a historical fact.
Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson dissented, calling the decision a 'pointless but painful perversion of our equitable discretion' and criticizing the lack of justification for immediate harm.
The decision is not final; litigation continues in lower courts, meaning the policy remains in effect temporarily.

articles.content:
Supreme Court allows Trump to prohibit gender election on passports 
         By Nina Totenberg 
        
           Thursday, November 6, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 3:57 PM EST 
        
        
      

         The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday allowed President Trump to proceed with his plan to require that passport applicants list their sex as what was designated on their birth certificate. The court's decision overturns a lower court order pausing Trump's policy and allowing applicants to choose for themselves whether they would like to identify with an M for male, F for female, or an X for neither. ¬† Male and female sex markers began to be listed on passports in 1976. The government has allowed citizens for over 30 years to request a passport that reflects their gender identity instead of the sex listed on a birth certificate. The choice to use an "X", however, only began in 2021 under President Biden. Led by Ashton Orr, a transgender man who was falsely accused of using a fake passport by airport security when traveling with a passport that had a female sex marker, a nationwide group of plaintiffs argued that Trump's policy would hurt transgender and non-binary individuals, would harm the government's ability to identify citizens, and was motivated by unconstitutional transphobia in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment guarantee to equal protection of the law. ¬† "The challenged policy undermines the very purpose of passports as identity documents that officials check against the bearer's appearance," Orr's attorneys said in their briefs. "It is aimed at the rejection of the identity of an entire group ‚Äî transgender Americans ‚Äî who have always existed." The government, Orr's counsel points out, acknowledged that the "outing of transgender, intersex, and nonbinary individuals" was "core to the Policy." ¬† The government submitted its emergency filing to the Supreme Court after the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit refused to block the lower court order that paused Trump's policy.¬†The government argued that the "injunction injures the United States by compelling it to speak to foreign governments in contravention of both the President's foreign policy and scientific reality." ¬† With its decision on Thursday,¬†the Supreme Court signaled that it likely agrees with the administration. The court's decision is not a final ruling, however; it just permits Trump's biological sex passport policy to go into effect while litigation continues in the lower courts. The vote was 6-3 along ideological lines. "Displaying passport holders' sex at birth no more offends equal protection principles than displaying their country of birth," the court said in the unsigned order, "in both cases, the Government is merely attesting to a historical fact without subjecting anyone to differential treatment." ¬† Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson wrote the dissent, which was joined by the court's two other liberals. She called the order a "pointless but painful perversion of our equitable discretion." "This Court has once again paved the way for the immediate infliction of injury without adequate (or, really, any) justification," she wrote.

articles.title: Shein to be suspended in France following uproar over sales of ‚Äòchildlike‚Äô sex dolls
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: France has suspended Shein‚Äôs online access in the country following revelations that the Chinese fast-fashion giant allowed the sale of ‚Äòchildlike‚Äô sex dolls on its platform, sparking widespread public outrage. The government launched investigations into Shein and other platforms like Temu and AliExpress for allegedly spreading child-pornographic content. In response, Shein suspended all third-party product sales, including sex dolls, and maintained its physical store launch in Paris at BHV, which faced protests and backlash from traditional French brands like Figaret and Armor Lux, as well as Disney. Paris officials, including Deputy Mayor Nicolas Bonnet-Oulaldj and Senator Ian Brossat, criticized Shein for promoting disposable fashion contrary to Paris‚Äôs values of sustainability and ethical design. SGM, the parent company of BHV and Galeries Lafayette, rebranded five Galeries Lafayette stores as BHV, symbolizing resistance to the Shein partnership. Critics argue that Shein‚Äôs arrival contradicts France‚Äôs climate and fashion commitments, especially as Paris aims to uphold its green image in preparation for the 2024 Olympics. The controversy underscores a deeper conflict between global fast-fashion models and national cultural and environmental values.

Shein independently suspended sales of third-party products in France to comply with French consumer protection laws, including banning sex dolls.

The backlash led to 12 French brands, including Figaret and Armor Lux, withdrawing from BHV; Disney also canceled its Christmas window displays at BHV.
Paris Deputy Mayor Nicolas Bonnet-Oulaldj and French Senator Ian Brossat criticized Shein, calling it incompatible with Paris‚Äôs values of ethical fashion and environmental responsibility.
SGM (Soci√©t√© des Grands Magasins) faced criticism for partnering with Shein, prompting internal rebranding of five Galeries Lafayette malls to BHV as a symbolic move.
French authorities launched investigations into Shein, Temu, AliExpress, and Wish for content involving minors, including pornographic depictions and violent messages.
Shein responded by banning sex doll sales and enhancing internal controls, while asserting that physical stores are safe from such content.
