articles.content:
White House strikes deals for lower prices on obesity drugs 
         By Sydney Lupkin 
        
           Thursday, November 6, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 2:00 PM EST 
        
        
           Heard on  All Things Considered 
        
      

         People who rely on Medicare for their health insurance will soon be able to get blockbuster obesity and Type 2 diabetes drugs with $50 monthly copays under two new deals the Trump administration announced Thursday. President Trump and his team announced the deals with Novo Nordisk, which makes Ozempic and Wegovy, and Eli Lilly, which makes Mounjaro and Zepbound, from the Oval Office.  The deals are part of a broader initiative the administration calls most-favored-nation drug pricing, which is an attempt to lower American drug prices, and get the same or lower prices as other developed countries. "We believe these deals, within two years ‚Ä¶ based on our health improvements, we will be budget neutral," said Dr. Mehmet Oz, who leads the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, during the press conference. While access to the drugs would increase, their use would lower spending on other health services. "These drugs will not cost us money," Oz said. "The American taxpayers will be getting their money back."  The companies pledged to offer their blockbuster obesity and Type 2 diabetes drugs to Medicare and Medicaid programs for $245 a month, with copays for Medicare beneficiaries set at $50 a month starting in April. State Medicaid programs will have to opt in separately. The programs already cover the companies' drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration for Type 2 diabetes, but under the deals they will also be covered for some patients who are overweight or obese.  There are some restrictions, according to senior officials who spoke to reporters on condition of anonymity before the White House announcement. The medicines will only be covered if patients have: a body mass index over 27 and established  prediabetes  or cardiovascular disease;¬† a body mass index over 30 and uncontrolled hypertension, kidney disease or heart failure; or¬† a body mass index over 35. "This is not about losing weight," a senior administration official said during the briefing call. "It is about making America healthier. This is about preventing a stroke. This is about preventing heart attacks and disease. About preventing  end stage renal disease ." "Reducing the cost and leveraging the scale of Medicare and Medicaid to boost access to game-changing weight loss drugs is a transformative step in the battle against chronic disease and obesity," said Dr. Bobby Mukkamala, president of the American Medical Association.  Like previous deals with Pfizer and AstraZeneca, the agreements with Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly include lower prices in Medicaid, a pledge to launch new drugs in the U.S. at prices on par with other developed countries and discounted drugs for patients paying for them without insurance, which will be available through  TrumpRx.gov . The deals with Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly also include a promise to offer starting doses of their upcoming obesity pills ‚Äî if they receive FDA approval ‚Äî at $149 a month for people on Medicare, Medicaid and using TrumpRx. Eli Lilly said in a press release that it had also applied for a voucher with the FDA, which could speed its review and approval. The current medicines, given by injection, will be available through TrumpRx without insurance at an average of $350 a month ‚Äî down from around $500, which is what the companies offer patients buying directly today. Those prices will drop to $245 over the next 24 months, the officials said. Specifically, Eli Lilly says it will knock $50 dollars off its existing direct-to-consumer price for Zepbound, making it $299 a month for the starting dose and $449 for higher doses. "I think the manufacturers were open to this partly for political reasons, but also it was just going to expand their patient population dramatically," said Geoffrey Joyce, a health economist and director of health policy at the USC Schaeffer Center. Also, in return for these commitments, the Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk will get a three-year exemption from certain tariffs. The White House unveiled its plan for TrumpRx and the first  deal with Pfizer on Sept. 30 . It also announced a deal with AstraZeneca on Oct. 10, and with EMD Serono on Oct. 16, though that deal only included EMD Serono's fertility drugs, and not its cancer or multiple sclerosis drugs. All the deals follow an executive order in May, and letters sent to 17 pharmaceutical companies over the summer to push them to lower prices voluntarily. The TrumpRx website is expected to launch sometime in 2026, and would take consumers to pharmaceutical companies' direct-to-consumer websites to fulfill orders.

articles.title: UPS Cargo Plane Crashes in Louisville, Kentucky, Killing at Least 12, Sparking National Investigation
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A UPS cargo plane, operating as Flight 2976, experienced a fire and lost its left engine during takeoff from Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on November 4, 2025. The plane crashed just outside the airport, killing at least 12 people, including a child at a nearby auto parts business. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is leading an investigation into the cause of the fire and engine failure, noting similarities to a 1979 American Airlines crash involving improper maintenance. The aircraft, a 1991 McDonnell Douglas MD-11, had previously been grounded in San Antonio, and the exact maintenance history remains unclear. The crash triggered secondary explosions at nearby businesses, causing widespread damage and injuries. While no survivors were found, two people were in critical condition at the University of Louisville Hospital. The event has prompted national attention due to its tragic scale, potential safety flaws, and historical parallels in aviation disaster patterns.
keyTakeAways: A UPS cargo plane experienced a fire and engine detachment during takeoff at Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on November 4, 2025.
The crash killed at least 12 people, including a child, with the death toll potentially rising as search efforts continue.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is investigating the cause of the fire and engine failure, noting similarities to a 1979 American Airlines crash involving improper maintenance.
The plane, a 1991 McDonnell Douglas MD-11, was operating from UPS Worldport, the company‚Äôs largest facility, which employs over 20,000 people and handles hundreds of thousands of packages daily.
The crash triggered a chain reaction, causing secondary explosions at nearby businesses such as Kentucky Petroleum Recycling and Grade A Auto Parts, where a child died.
Debris fields and survivors were difficult to locate; first responders reported no living survivors, though two people were hospitalized in critical condition.
The incident occurred just before the plane cleared the runway fence, and the engine detached during the takeoff roll, as captured in airport security video.
Investigations are expected to take more than a year, with potential causes including fuel leaks or improper maintenance during the prior months of operation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) ‚Äî A UPS cargo plane‚Äôs left wing caught fire and an engine fell off just before it crashed and exploded after takeoff in Kentucky, a federal official said Wednesday, offering the first investigative details about a disaster that killed at least 12 people, including a child. Finding survivors seemed unlikely as first responders searched the charred area of the crash at UPS Worldport, the company‚Äôs global aviation hub in Louisville , Gov. Andy Beshear said. The inferno consumed the enormous aircraft and spread to nearby businesses. After being cleared for takeoff, a large fire developed in the left wing, said Todd Inman, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, which is leading the investigation. The NTSB will now try to determine what caused the fire and why the engine fell off. It will likely take investigators more than a year to answer those questions. The plane gained enough altitude to clear the fence at the end of the runway before crashing just outside Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport, Inman told reporters. Airport security video ‚Äúshows the left engine detaching from the wing during the takeoff roll,‚Äù he said. Related Stories States sue Trump administration over restrictions put on FEMA emergency grants 3 MIN READ What to know about the deadly UPS plane crash in Louisville, Kentucky 2 MIN READ At least 7 dead, 11 injured in UPS plane crash and explosion at Kentucky airport 3 MIN READ The cockpit voice recorder and data recorder were recovered, and the engine was discovered on the airfield, Inman said. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of different parts of this airplane in a lot of different places,‚Äù he said, describing a debris field that stretched for half a mile. A chain reaction The plane with three people aboard crashed about 5:15 p.m. Tuesday as it was departing for Honolulu from UPS Worldport at the Louisville airport. The crash had a devastating ripple effect, striking and causing smaller explosions at Kentucky Petroleum Recycling and hitting an auto salvage yard, Grade A Auto Parts. Beshear said the child who died was with a parent at the parts business. Beshear earlier said it was a ‚Äúblessing‚Äù that the plane did not hit a nearby Ford Motor factory or the convention center. Stooges Bar and Grill bartender Kyla Kenady said lights suddenly flickered as she took a beer to a customer on the patio. ‚ÄúI saw a plane in the sky coming down over top of our volleyball courts in flames,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIn that moment, I panicked. I turned around, ran through the bar screaming, telling everyone that a plane was crashing.‚Äù Manager Lynn Cason said explosions, only about 100 yards (90 meters) away, shook the building three times ‚Äî ‚Äúlike somebody was bombing us‚Äù ‚Äî but no one there was injured. ‚ÄúGod was definitely with us,‚Äù Cason said. The number of victims is unclear Louisville Mayor Craig Greenberg announced on the social platform X on Wednesday evening that the death toll had risen to 12, saying, ‚ÄúPlease take a moment to hug your loved ones and check on your neighbors.‚Äù The governor predicted that the death toll would rise, saying authorities were looking for a ‚Äúhandful of other people‚Äù but ‚Äúwe do not expect to find anyone else alive.‚Äù Mark Little, chief of the Okolona Fire District in Louisville, said debris would have to be moved and searched, adding: ‚ÄúIt will take us quite a while.‚Äù University of Louisville Hospital said two people were in critical condition in the burn unit. Eighteen people were treated and discharged at that hospital or other health care centers. The airport is 7 miles (11 kilometers) from downtown Louisville, close to the Indiana state line, residential areas, a water park and museums. The airport resumed operations on Wednesday, with at least one runway open. Beshear said he did not know the status of the three UPS crew members aboard the McDonnell Douglas MD-11 made in 1991. It was not clear if they were being counted among the dead. UPS said it was ‚Äúterribly saddened.‚Äù The Louisville package handling facility is the company‚Äôs largest. Or it could have been a fuel leak igniting and then burning the engine off. It‚Äôs just too soon to tell,‚Äù Guzzetti said. He said the crash bears a lot of similarities to one in 1979 when the left engine fell off an American Airlines jet as it was departing Chicago‚Äôs O‚ÄôHare International Airport, killing 273 people. Guzzetti said this UPS plane and the American plane were equipped with the same General Electric engines and both planes underwent heavy maintenance in the month before they crashed. articles.title: Nancy Pelosi Announces Retirement from U.S. Congress, Ending Historic Political Career
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Nancy Pelosi, the first woman to serve as Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives and a dominant figure in American politics for nearly four decades, has announced she will not seek re-election to Congress. Her decision, made in a video address, marks the end of a historic career that included passing landmark legislation such as the Affordable Care Act and Dodd-Frank financial reforms, leading impeachment efforts against President Donald Trump, and establishing the Jan. 6 Capitol attack investigation committee. Though her departure is not entirely surprising, it has triggered a leadership vacuum within the Democratic Party, particularly in California, where political newcomers like Saikat Chakrabarti and Scott Wiener are mounting challenges to her influence. Pelosi‚Äôs legacy is also shaped by personal adversity, including a fall during a European visit and a violent home invasion that injured her husband, Paul Pelosi. The broader significance lies in her role as a symbol of women's political power and a pivotal force in shaping democratic governance during a period of intense political polarization.
keyTakeAways: Nancy Pelosi, the first woman to serve as Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, will not seek re-election, ending a 38-year career in Congress.
Pelosi's leadership was instrumental in passing major legislation, including the Affordable Care Act and Dodd-Frank financial reforms.
She played a key role in impeaching President Donald Trump twice and led the formation of the Jan. 6 committee to investigate the Capitol attack.
Pelosi‚Äôs decision comes amid a generational shift in political leadership, with younger Democrats and new political figures challenging her influence.
Her departure opens a leadership vacuum within the Democratic Party, particularly in California and nationally, triggering succession battles and uncertainty.
Pelosi remains a powerful political figure even in retirement, with a long-standing legacy of advocacy, fundraising, and party leadership.
Her decision is also influenced by personal events, including a fall in Europe and the 2022 home invasion that injured her husband, Paul Pelosi.

articles.title: D.C. National Guard Deployment Extended to End of February Amid Legal and Political Debate
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Washington D.C. National Guard is set to remain deployed through the end of February 2025 under a formal order issued on November 4, 2025, extending an August 2025 emergency declaration by President Donald Trump. The deployment, authorized by the Secretary of War, involves approximately 2,375 troops, with the D.C. National Guard being the largest contributor (949 soldiers) and West Virginia the next largest (416). Troops have carried out both security duties and beautification tasks such as trash removal, road cleaning, and landscaping. However, the deployment is under legal scrutiny, with D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb filing a lawsuit in September 2025 arguing that the federal use of the National Guard in a democratic city is unconstitutional. The lawsuit has prompted responses from 45 states, with 23 supporting the Trump administration and 22 backing the D.C. government. U.S. District Judge Jia Cobb heard arguments on October 24 but has not issued a ruling. The duration of deployments from other states, including Louisiana, Mississippi, Ohio, South Carolina, Georgia, and Alabama, remains uncertain, with most planning to withdraw by November 30 unless further orders are issued.
keyTakeAways: The D.C. National Guard is being deployed through the end of February 2025 under a formal order from the U.S. government, continuing an emergency response initiated in August 2025.

The deployment is justified by President Donald Trump as a response to an emergency declaration and under the authority of the Secretary of War to protect federal property and functions in Washington, D.C.
The D.C. National Guard is the largest contributor, with 949 troops, followed by West Virginia with 416, and other states including Louisiana, Mississippi, Ohio, South Carolina, Georgia, and Alabama.

Troops have been involved in both security and beautification efforts, such as trash removal, landscaping, road clearing, and tree pruning, with reports indicating over 1,150 bags of trash cleared and 7.9 miles of roadway cleaned.

The deployment is the subject of an ongoing legal challenge by D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb, who argues that the use of the National Guard in a heavily Democratic city violates constitutional and administrative principles.
45 states have filed legal responses to the lawsuit, with 23 supporting the Trump administration and 22 aligning with D.C. officials, indicating a nationwide debate over federal overreach.
The U.S. District Judge Jia Cobb has heard arguments but has not issued a decision, leaving the legality and duration of the deployment unresolved.
Some state deployments are scheduled to end by November 30, but depend on whether further orders extend them, and the final orders do not specify the duration for non-D.C. states.

Published: 2025-11-06T04:36:04+00:00

WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî The Washington D.C. National Guard will be deployed to the nation‚Äôs capital through the end of February, according to formal orders reviewed by The Associated Press. The formal order, dated Nov. 4, extends the original order from Aug. 11 and says the Guard members will be in the city at least through Feb. 28. The order states the additional duty is in response to the emergency declared in August by President Donald Trump and under directions from the ‚ÄúSecretary of War to protect federal property and functions in the District of Columbia and to support federal and District law enforcement.‚Äù Hundreds of National Guard troops have been in Washington since August, which launched what Trump said was a crime-fighting mission that also included the federal takeover of the local police department. That order expired in September, but the roughly 2,000 National Guard troops from D.C. and at at least eight states remain in the city, with most contingents saying they plan to withdraw by the end of November. The D.C. National Guard is the single largest contributor of troops with 949 soldiers that make up the task force that totals 2,375 troops. West Virginia is the next largest state to contribute troops to the task force with 416 guardsmen. Related Stories New Mexico lawmakers propose a Jeffrey Epstein probe of activity at secluded desert ranch 3 MIN READ Republican Rep Elise Stefanik to announce run for New York governor 1 MIN READ Brazil stumps up billions of dollars for its ambitious rainforest fund at UN climate summit 3 MIN READ Some have been armed and providing a military presence in public spaces, especially in the federal parks around the city and at subway stations as well as the Amtrak train station. The National Guard task force appears to have spent a large portion of its time on yardwork and landscaping efforts around the nation‚Äôs capital. In an update provided in early October, task force officials boasted that troops cleared 1,150 bags of trash, spread 1,045 cubic yards of mulch, removed 50 truckloads of plant waste, cleared 7.9 miles of roadway, painted 270 feet of fencing and pruned 400 trees. Since then, most daily updates from the task force only offered new troop figures and no summaries of beautification efforts. One segment of the D.C. Guard has worked with various neighborhoods on beautification efforts at the request of local neighborhood officials and residents. The presence of guard members in the city is the subject of an ongoing lawsuit , filed Sept. 4 by D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb challenging the Trump administration‚Äôs use of the National Guard in the heavily Democratic city. That lawsuit sparked filings by 45 states with 23 supporting the Trump administration and 22 aligning with Washington. The Trump administration has argued that he has full authority to deploy guard troops in Washington because he is the designated commander of the D.C. Guard. In court papers filed by Schwalb seeking to have the guard removed from the city, the documents indicated that there were plans for the D.C. Guard to potentially remain in the city at least through next summer. U.S. District Judge Jia Cobb, an appointee of former President Joe Biden, heard arguments Oct. 24 on Schwalb‚Äôs request but reached no decision. It‚Äôs unclear how long the other states, which currently include Louisiana, Mississippi, Ohio, South Carolina, West Virginia, Georgia and Alabama, will keep their troops deployed to the task force in Washington. Several of the states told the AP they planned to end their deployments by Nov. 30 but indicated that also depended on whether orders were issued extending their deployments. The order does not mention the other states.

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Marshawn Kneeland, a 24-year-old Dallas Cowboys defensive end and a 2024 second-round draft pick from Western Michigan, was found dead of an apparent suicide after evading police during a traffic chase following a crash in Frisco, Texas. Authorities reported that Kneeland failed to stop for DPS troopers and fled on foot, prompting a search and the discovery of a group text from him saying 'goodbye.' His girlfriend expressed concern about his mental health and stated he had a history of suicidal tendencies. Kneeland‚Äôs mother died suddenly during draft preparations, and he wore her ashes in a necklace, indicating deep personal grief. The incident has prompted widespread tributes from teammates, coaches, and NFL figures, emphasizing the importance of mental health awareness and suicide prevention. The Dallas Cowboys, NFL, and players like Dak Prescott and Solomon Thomas, who have personal experience with suicide loss, have responded with condolences and calls for greater support systems in sports.

Published: 2025-11-06T15:11:38+00:00

Police in a Dallas suburb say 24-year-old Dallas Cowboys defensive end Marshawn Kneeland was found dead of an apparent suicide after evading authorities in his vehicle and fleeing the scene of an accident on foot. Frisco police said Thursday they are investigating the suicide. They said Kneeland didn‚Äôt stop for Texas Department of Public Safety troopers over a traffic violation in a chase that was joined by Frisco police on Wednesday night. Authorities lost sight of the vehicle before locating it crashed minutes later. During the search after Kneeland fled the crash site on foot, officers said they received word that Kneeland might be suicidal. As authorities were looking for Kneeland, a dispatcher told officers that people who knew him had received a group text from Kneeland ‚Äúsaying goodbye. They‚Äôre concerned for his welfare,‚Äù according to recordings from Broadcastify, which archives public safety radio feeds. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre talking to the girlfriend. She‚Äôs trying to call his agent. But we‚Äôre trying to get her to call him first. But she‚Äôs saying he is armed and has a history of mental illness. And her quote was, ‚ÄòHe will end it all,‚Äô‚Äù another dispatcher told officers. Related Stories Seahawks eager to make life difficult for another Cardinals QB in veteran Jacoby Brissett 3 MIN READ Packers to face off with Eagles in rematch of playoff game from last season 3 MIN READ Rebuilding Titans center hope on Cam Ward, more cap space and draft picks as they reach bye week 3 MIN READ He was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound early Thursday morning, about three hours after the crash, police said without specifying where Kneeland‚Äôs body was found. In the recordings from Broadcastify, officers said they had tried to get in contact with Kneeland by calling and texting him and had used a drone to try and locate him after the crash. ___ EDITOR‚ÄôS NOTE ‚Äî This story includes discussion of suicide. If you or someone you know needs help, the national suicide and crisis lifeline in the U.S. is available by calling or texting 988. There is also an online chat at 988lifeline.org . Helplines outside the U.S. can be found at www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts . ___ Kneeland‚Äôs death came just days after he recovered a blocked punt in the end zone for a touchdown in a 27-17 loss to the Arizona Cardinals . AP AUDIO: Cowboys‚Äô Marshawn Kneeland found dead of apparent suicide at 24 after evading officers, police say A young Dallas Cowboys player was found dead in a suspected suicide after evading police. Correspondent Gethin Coolbaugh reports. Kneeland was in his second season with the Cowboys. He was a 2024 second-round draft pick out of Western Michigan. ‚ÄúI am shattered to confirm that my client and dearest friend Marshawn Kneeland passed away last night,‚Äù Kneeland‚Äôs agent, Jonathan Perzley, said in a statement that asked for privacy. ‚ÄúMarshawn poured his heart into every snap, every practice and every moment on the field. To lose someone with his talent, spirit and goodness is a pain I can hardly put into words.‚Äù Kneeland‚Äôs rookie season was off to a promising start before he was sidelined for five games by a knee injury. Kneeland had his first career sack in the season opener this year against Philadelphia . He played in seven games this season, missing two with an ankle injury. ‚ÄúMarshawn was a beloved teammate and member of our organization,‚Äù the Cowboys said. ‚ÄúOur thoughts and prayers regarding Marshawn are with his girlfriend Catalina and his family.‚Äù The Cowboys have frequently sought pass rushers and other defensive linemen in the first two rounds of the draft. Kneeland was drafted a year after defensive end Sam Williams was taken by Dallas in the second round. Williams blocked the punt that Kneeland recovered against the Cardinals. Kneeland‚Äôs mother, Wendy Kneeland, died suddenly while he was preparing for the draft. He had his mother‚Äôs ashes in a necklace he wore after joining the Cowboys, according to The Dallas Morning News. ‚ÄúWe are deeply saddened by the tragic news of the passing of Cowboys‚Äô Marshawn Kneeland,‚Äù the NFL said. ‚ÄúWe have been in contact with the Cowboys and have offered support and counseling resources.‚Äù Miami Dolphins receivers coach Robert Prince, who had the same position with the Cowboys when Kneeland was a rookie last year, had tears in his eyes as he met with reporters Thursday. ‚ÄúWe spent a lot of time (together) when he was injured and working out in the weight room,‚Äù Prince said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd shoot the breeze. He was a Western Michigan kid and I coached with the Lions for a while so we had some Michigan-type stories. Good kid. I‚Äôm sorry to hear that about him.‚Äù Kneeland had a career-high 57 tackles along with 4 1/2 sacks in nine games as a senior at Western Michigan. ‚ÄúMy heart is absolutely broken over the loss of Marshawn Kneeland,‚Äù Western Michigan coach Lance Taylor said. ‚ÄúHis leadership, energy and smile were infectious, and he left a lasting impact on everyone in our program. Having coached him during my first season here, we developed a special bond that went far beyond football.‚Äù Tributes poured in from around the NFL, including Tennessee Titans defensive tackle Jeffery Simmons, who raised the topic of suicide awareness with a reporter during training camp this year. ‚ÄúIt sucks seeing the news of our NFL brother!‚Äù Simmons wrote on X. ‚ÄúEven when someone is carrying the biggest smile, make sure to just check in on them. You just never know man. Don‚Äôt be afraid to ask for help, we all go through things that we sometimes hide!‚Äù Two of Kneeland‚Äôs Dallas teammates, quarterback Dak Prescott and defensive lineman Solomon Thomas, had siblings who died by suicide and have foundations supporting suicide awareness and prevention. articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court on November 6, 2025, ruled in favor of President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration, allowing the enforcement of a policy that restricts transgender and nonbinary individuals from selecting gender markers on passports that align with their gender identity. This decision follows an executive order from January 2025 declaring that the U.S. recognizes only two sexes based on birth certificates. The majority opinion claims that displaying sex at birth is not discriminatory, comparing it to recording country of birth. However, three liberal justices, including Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, dissented, arguing that the policy increases risks of violence, harassment, and discrimination, citing real-world harms such as sexual assault and strip searches at airports. The ruling is part of a broader pattern of the Supreme Court siding with the executive branch on emergency docket cases during Trump‚Äôs second term. Individuals like Hunter Schafer have reported receiving passports with mismatched gender markers, raising concerns about safety and self-determination. The decision has drawn criticism from civil rights groups like the ACLU, who say it undermines LGBTQ+ rights and freedom of self-identification, and is seen as a setback for transgender rights in the U.S. government.
keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the Trump administration's policy that blocks transgender and nonbinary individuals from choosing gender markers on passports that align with their gender identity, allowing the use of sex at birth.

The decision is part of a broader pattern of the Supreme Court siding with the executive branch in emergency rulings favoring Trump‚Äôs policies, including those banning transgender service in the military.
The majority opinion cites that displaying sex at birth is no more discriminatory than displaying country of birth, as both are factual records without differential treatment.
Three liberal justices dissented, arguing the policy increases vulnerability to violence, harassment, and discrimination, citing real-world harm such as sexual assault and strip searches at airports.
The policy originated from a January 2025 executive order by President Trump declaring that the U.S. would recognize only two sexes based on birth certificates and biological classification.
Transgender individuals like Hunter Schafer have reported receiving passports with gender markers inconsistent with their identity, raising safety and privacy concerns.
The Biden administration previously allowed nonbinary individuals to select an X gender marker in passports in 2021, removing documentation requirements after years of litigation.
Legal advocates, including the ACLU, argue that the policy infringes on the right to self-identification and increases the risk of discrimination and violence.
The decision is seen as a setback for LGBTQ+ rights and a reinforcement of conservative political narratives about gender identity.
The State Department previously changed its passport rules in response to Trump‚Äôs executive order, and the policy remains under legal challenge.

articles.content:
Published: 2025-11-06T20:23:19+00:00

WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî The Supreme Court on Thursday allowed President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration to enforce a policy blocking transgender and nonbinary people from choosing passport sex markers that align with their gender identity. The decision is Trump‚Äôs latest win on the court‚Äôs emergency docket, and allows the administration to enforce the policy while a lawsuit over it plays out. It halts a lower-court order requiring the government to keep letting people choose male, female or X on their passport to correspond with their gender identity on new or renewed passports. The court‚Äôs three liberal justices dissented. The high court has sided with the government in nearly two dozen short-term orders on a range of policies since the start of Trump‚Äôs second term, including another case barring transgender people from serving in the military. In a brief, unsigned order, the conservative-majority court said the policy isn‚Äôt discriminatory. ‚ÄúDisplaying passport holders‚Äô sex at birth no more offends equal protection principles than displaying their country of birth,‚Äù it said. ‚ÄúIn both cases, the Government is merely attesting to a historical fact without subjecting anyone to differential treatment.‚Äù Related Stories Trump‚Äôs not going to the Supreme Court hearing on tariffs. But his treasury secretary will be there 1 MIN READ A major question for the Supreme Court: Will it treat Trump as it did Biden? 4 MIN READ Tariffs are Trump‚Äôs favorite foreign policy tool. The Supreme Court could change how he uses them 6 MIN READ The court‚Äôs three liberal justices disagreed, saying in a dissent that those passports make transgender people vulnerable to ‚Äúincreased violence, harassment, and discrimination.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis Court has once again paved the way for the immediate infliction of injury without adequate (or, really, any) justification,‚Äù Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson wrote, saying the policy stemmed directly from Trump‚Äôs executive order that described transgender identity as ‚Äúfalse‚Äù and ‚Äúcorrosive.‚Äù Transgender and nonbinary people who sued over the policy have reported being sexually assaulted, strip-searched and accused of presenting fake documents at airport security checks, she wrote. The Supreme Court majority said being unable to enforce the policy harms the government because passports are part of foreign affairs, an area of executive branch control. The dissenters, though, said it‚Äôs not clear exactly how individual identification documents affect the nation‚Äôs foreign policy. The State Department changed its passport rules after Trump, a Republican, handed down an executive order in January declaring the United States would ‚Äúrecognize two sexes, male and female,‚Äù based on birth certificates and ‚Äúbiological classification.‚Äù Transgender actor Hunter Schafer , for example, said in February that her new passport had been issued with a male gender marker, even though she‚Äôs marked female on her driver‚Äôs license and passport for years. The plaintiffs argue those passports aren‚Äôt accurate, and can be unsafe for those whose gender expression doesn‚Äôt match what‚Äôs on the documents. ‚ÄúForcing transgender people to carry passports that out them against their will increases the risk that they will face harassment and violence,‚Äù said Jon Davidson, senior counsel for the ACLU‚Äôs LGBTQ & HIV Project. ‚ÄúThis is a heartbreaking setback for the freedom of all people to be themselves, and fuel on the fire the Trump administration is stoking against transgender people and their constitutional rights.‚Äù Sex markers began appearing on passports in the mid-1970s and the federal government started allowing them to be changed with medical documentation in the early 1990s, the plaintiffs said in court documents. A 2021 change under President Joe Biden, a Democrat, removed documentation requirements and allowed nonbinary people to choose an X gender marker after years of litigation. A judge blocked the Trump administration policy in June after a lawsuit from nonbinary and transgender people, some of whom said they were afraid to submit applications. An appeals court left the judge‚Äôs order in place. Solicitor General D. John Sauer then turned to the Supreme Court, pointing to its recent ruling upholding a ban on transition-related health care for transgender minors and calling the Biden-era policy inaccurate. White House spokeswoman Anna Kelly applauded Thursday‚Äôs order. ‚ÄúThis decision is a victory for common sense and President Trump, who was resoundingly elected to eliminate woke gender ideology from our federal government,‚Äù she said. Attorney General Pam Bondi also celebrated the order, saying there are two sexes and Justice Department attorneys would continue to fight for that ‚Äúsimple truth.‚Äù ___ Follow the AP‚Äôs coverage of the U.S. Supreme Court at https://apnews.com/hub/us-supreme-court .

articles.title: FAA Orders 10% Flight Cuts at 40 U.S. Airports Amid Government Shutdown
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has ordered a 10% reduction in flights at 40 of the nation‚Äôs busiest airports to relieve pressure on air traffic controllers during the ongoing government shutdown. The cuts, effective starting Friday, November 7, 2025, affect major international and domestic hubs including Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta, Dallas/Fort Worth, Los Angeles, Chicago O'Hare, JFK in New York, and others across all 50 states. This decision is a safety measure to maintain air traffic control stability under staffing shortages caused by the shutdown. Travelers are urged to verify flight status directly with their airlines, as cancellations may occur. The widespread nature of the cuts underscores the systemic strain on civil aviation infrastructure during periods of governmental inaction.
keyTakeAways: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is mandating a 10% reduction in flights at 40 of the busiest U.S. airports to alleviate pressure on air traffic controllers during the government shutdown.
The flight cuts are effective starting Friday, November 7, 2025.
Affected airports include major hubs such as Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta, Dallas/Fort Worth, Los Angeles, Chicago O'Hare, JFK in New York, and others across all 50 states.
The reduction is a safety measure to ensure continued safe air traffic management under strained staffing conditions during the shutdown.
Travelers are advised to check directly with their airlines to confirm whether their flight has been canceled or rescheduled.

Title: Thousands evacuated as Typhoon Kalmaegi approaches the Philippines

Thousands of people have been ordered to evacuate from coastal areas in the eastern Philippines before Typhoon Kalmaegi‚Äôs expected landfall.

Forecasters have warned of torrential rains, storm surges of up to 3 metres (10ft) and wind gusts of up to 150km/h (93mph) as the centre of the storm was expected to come ashore on Monday.

More than 70,000 people in the coastal towns of Guiuan and Salcedo on Samar Island and Mercedes in Camarines Norte province were ordered to move to evacuation centres or buildings certified as sturdy enough to withstand the impact of the typhoon. Authorities also prohibited fishermen from venturing out to sea in the east-central region.

The storm is predicted to make landfall in either Guiuan or nearby municipalities.

Guiuan is no stranger to typhoons. It was badly hit in November 2013 when one of the most powerful tropical cyclones on record smashed into the Philippines. The storm left more than 7,300 people dead or missing and displaced over four million people.

Kalmaegi is forecast to travel westwards overnight before hitting central island provinces on Tuesday. This includes Cebu, which is still recovering from a  magnitude 6.9 earthquake in September.

The Philippines is battered by about 20 typhoons and storms annually, and scientists are warning that they are becoming more powerful due to human-driven climate change.

The archipelago was hit by two major storms in September, including  Super Typhoon Ragasa,  which toppled trees, tore the roofs off buildings and killed 14 people in neighbouring Taiwan.

The Philippines is also regularly shaken by earthquakes and has more than a dozen active volcanoes, making it one of the world‚Äôs most disaster-prone countries.

articles.title: Has climate change brought mosquitoes to Iceland?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: For the first time, mosquitoes have been confirmed in Iceland, breaking a long-standing ecological record. The detection occurred in October 2025 in the glacial valley of Kjos, near Reykjavik, following record-breaking summer heat and rapid glacial melting. Scientists at the Natural Science Institute of Iceland identified the species as Culiseta annulata, a cold-adapted, non-disease-carrying mosquito native to the Palearctic region. Experts attribute the emergence to climate change, warming temperatures, and increased global transportation. While the species is not dangerous to humans, its presence signals a broader shift in ecosystems and a growing threat of vector-borne diseases in previously unaffected regions. Similar cases have been observed in the UK and across Europe, where rising temperatures are enabling mosquitoes like Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus to establish. The event underscores how climate change is altering biological boundaries and increases the global risk of disease transmission, with insect species serving as key indicators of environmental change.
keyTakeAways: Mosquitoes have been detected in Iceland for the first time, breaking its long-standing status as one of the world‚Äôs few mosquito-free regions.
The detection is linked to record-breaking summer heat and rapid glacial melting, indicating that climate change is altering ecosystems even in cold regions.
The mosquito species identified, Culiseta annulata, is cold-adapted and not known to carry disease, but its presence raises ecological and public health concerns.
The spread of mosquitoes into colder regions is attributed to warming temperatures and increased transportation, such as international freight.
Mosquitoes breed in stagnant water, which is abundant in Iceland, and their presence is now possible due to milder winters and thawing conditions.
The World Health Organization identifies an increase in insect-borne diseases as a major climate change-related health threat.
Warmer temperatures allow disease-carrying mosquitoes to survive and reproduce in regions previously considered safe.
Insects like mosquitoes serve as key indicators of climate change and ecosystem shifts, offering valuable insight into environmental trends.
While the current species is not dangerous to humans, the potential for future disease expansion and ecosystem disruption remains a concern.

Title: Has climate change brought mosquitoes to Iceland?

Mosquitoes were detected in Iceland for the first time this month, resulting in the country losing its status as one of the only places in the world without them. The findings were confirmed by the country‚Äôs national science institute on Monday.

This follows record-breaking heat this past summer, which has sped up glacial melting in the country.

On October 16, insect enthusiast Bjorn Hjaltason posted on a Facebook group  Skord√Ωr og Nytjad√Ωr √Å √çslandi  (Insects in Iceland) that he had spotted mosquitoes in Kjos at dusk that day.

He said he had caught some using a red wine ribbon, a trap using sweetened wine as bait to attract insects. Kjos is a glacial valley 52km (32 miles) northeast of the Icelandic capital, Reykjavik.

Hjaltason sent the mosquitoes to the Natural Science Institute of Iceland, where entomologist Matthias Alfredsson confirmed they were indeed mosquitoes.

Alfredsson identified the mosquitoes as belonging to the Culiseta annulata species. This cold-resistant species is native to the Palearctic, which refers to Europe, North Africa and most of Asia north of the Himalayas. The Culiseta annulata are not known to carry disease but are generally considered a nuisance.

‚ÄúIt has adapted to a rather cold climate, surviving the winter as an adult and then staying in shelter, such as outbuildings and basements. The fly stings but is not considered dangerous to humans as it does not carry any known infections in these areas,‚Äù a news release published by the Natural Science Institute on Tuesday stated.

Mosquito species that are well adapted to cooler conditions and can survive winters as eggs or larvae do not tend to carry disease.

‚ÄúTheir development is slower, their active season shorter and most tropical diseases cannot complete their life cycle before cold weather sets in,‚Äù British entomologist Luke‚ÄØTilley from the Royal‚ÄØEntomological‚ÄØ Society told Al Jazeera. ‚ÄúCooler regions, therefore, tend to have mosquitoes but with lower disease risk.‚Äù

There are more than 3,500 species of mosquitoes around the globe, and they can be found in most parts of the world, bar a very few, including Antarctica.

Mosquitoes breed in shallow, stagnant bodies of water, which Iceland has in abundance. Despite having many marshes and ponds, however, it has never had a native mosquito population.

This is because mosquitoes are cold-blooded, which means they thrive in warmer environments. Male mosquitoes also feed on flowers, which thrive in warmer temperatures.

‚ÄúWarmer air and water speed up their growth, feeding and reproduction and also allow disease‚Äëcausing organisms inside them to develop more quickly. Longer warm seasons mean more generations of mosquitoes each year, and changes in rainfall can create new pools and puddles for breeding,‚Äù Tilley said.

Iceland is generally cold throughout the year. Its average temperature varies from minus 1 degree Celsius (30 degrees Fahrenheit) in the winter to 11C (52F) in the warmest months.

Mosquitoes lay their eggs during cold weather, and when the water thaws, the larvae hatch from the eggs. In Iceland, however, water typically freezes and thaws several times a year, making the landscape generally inhospitable for mosquitoes.

Before mosquitoes were spotted this month, the closest they had come to Iceland was in the 1980s when biologist Gisli Mar Gislason spotted one inside his aeroplane that had arrived at Keflav√≠k International Airport from Greenland. The mosquito is preserved at the Icelandic Institute of Natural History.

Gislason told Al Jazeera that more mosquito species are in warm climates than cold, and the greatest diversity of mosquitoes is seen in tropical areas.

‚ÄúThere is one species in Greenland, Aedes nigripes. It is a high Arctic species, and their density is controlled by the abundance of hosts, [such as] muskoxen, Arctic foxes, reindeers, polar bears and humans.‚Äù

In a statement, the Natural Science Institute said it is unclear how this particular mosquito species came to be in Iceland. However, it added: ‚ÄúIt is likely that it was transported by freight. It is uncertain whether it has settled here permanently, but everything indicates that it can survive in Icelandic conditions.‚Äù

A growing number of new insect species are being observed in Iceland due to a warming climate and increased transportation, the institute said.

The country is warming at an unprecedented rate. In May, Iceland and neighbouring Greenland experienced record-breaking heat due to a persistent weather pattern that brought unusually warm air from the south. In May, temperatures recorded in Iceland were 13 degrees Celsius (23.4 degrees Fahrenheit) warmer than the 1990-2020 average ‚Äì 10 times higher than the average warming of 1.3 degrees Celsius (2.3 degrees Fahrenheit) across the world as a whole.

The country‚Äôs glaciers have been rapidly melting and are projected to lose about half their volume by 2100, the country‚Äôs Vatnajokull National Park website said.

Increasingly, ‚Äúcooler climates can support mosquito development and survival. They can adapt to cooler temperatures up to a certain temperature below which they cannot survive. It depends which mosquito species,‚Äù Yaw Afrane, a professor of Medical Microbiology at the University of Ghana, told Al Jazeera.

Yes. Warming temperatures are changing how mosquitoes behave in many parts of the world.

As the planet warms, ‚Äúvector-borne diseases will move to areas that have been free of them as the climate will be more permissive to disease vectors,‚Äù Afrane said.

The World Health Organization has identified an increase in insect-borne disease as one of the biggest health threats to humans associated with climate change.

‚ÄúWarmer conditions can allow mosquitoes and the pathogens they carry to survive in new regions, extending the potential range of diseases such as dengue, chikungunya and West‚ÄØNile virus,‚Äù Tilley said.

‚ÄúInternational travel, trade and changes in land use also play a part. The key is careful monitoring and preparedness to prevent local transmission.‚Äù

In September 2023, the United Kingdom found the eggs of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes in the country for the first time near Heathrow Airport. Then in August 2024, four Aedes albopictus eggs were found at a motorway service station in Kent. No further specimens were found on investigation.

The Aedes aegypti is responsible for the spread of diseases such as dengue, chikungunya and Zika. Aedes albopictus can also transmit diseases such as dengue and chikungunya.

European countries have reported increasing cases of mosquito-borne illnesses recently. Last year, Italy had more than 200 local dengue cases. France and Spain also reported cases of the disease. This year, France has recorded 500 cases of chikungunya.

Warmer countries that already have high rates of mosquito-borne illnesses are seeing a surge in numbers. In September, Bangladesh recorded the largest single-day rise in both deaths and hospital admissions from dengue fever when 12 people died and 740 new people were hospitalised in just 24 hours.

Besides increasing temperatures, heavy rainfall can also allow mosquitoes to thrive. The rain flushes mosquito eggs, larvae and pupae from areas where they breed to new areas. If rainwater does not drain away properly, it leaves pools of shallow, stagnant water, the ideal breeding grounds for mosquitoes.

Tilley explained that besides the spread of disease, changing mosquito populations can also create shifts in the ecosystem. ‚ÄúMore mosquitoes can benefit their predators such as bats, dragonflies and birds, but disease in wildlife may also rise,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúA mosquito in a new area will be a prey for predators like fish, waterfowl and insect-eating insects. There is, therefore, more diversity of food for these predators,‚Äù Gislason told Al Jazeera, adding that it is difficult to predict accurately what will happen if a mosquito enters a new area. He said, however, that major changes in aquatic ecosystems in Iceland have not been observed yet.

Tilley said these shifts in mosquito behaviour also allow insect scientists to study climate change patterns, noting, ‚ÄúInsects like mosquitoes are valuable indicators of environmental change, helping insect scientists track how ecosystems respond to a warming climate.‚Äù

articles.title: Scientists watch flare with 10 trillion suns‚Äô light from massive black hole
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Scientists have recorded the most powerful flare ever observed from a supermassive black hole, which briefly emitted light equivalent to 10 trillion suns. The flare originated when a massive star‚Äîbetween 30 and 200 times the mass of the Sun‚Äîwas shredded by gravity as it approached a black hole with a mass of 300 million solar masses, located 11 billion light years away in a distant galaxy. Detected first in 2018 by the Palomar Observatory, the event peaked after three months and is still ongoing, expected to last about 11 years. The research, led by Matthew Graham of Caltech with KE Saavik Ford as a co-author, was published in Nature Astronomy and offers a rare opportunity to study the early universe and the formation mechanisms of supermassive black holes, which are central to nearly all large galaxies including our own.
keyTakeAways: Scientists observed the most energetic flare ever recorded from a supermassive black hole, emitting light equivalent to 10 trillion suns.
The flare was triggered when a massive star (30 to 200 times the mass of the Sun) was torn apart by gravity as it approached a supermassive black hole.
The event, occurring in a distant galaxy 11 billion light years from Earth, provides a rare window into the early universe.
The black hole has a mass of about 300 million times that of the Sun and is located in a faraway galaxy.
The star was 'spaghettified' by intense gravity, forming a stream of hot gas that spiraled into the black hole and produced intense light.
The flare reached peak brightness about three months after initial detection and is still ongoing, though diminishing in luminosity.
The study is led by Matthew Graham of Caltech and includes KE Saavik Ford as a co-author.
The event contributes to understanding how supermassive black holes form and interact with their surrounding stellar environments.

Title: Scientists watch flare with 10 trillion suns‚Äô light from massive black hole

Scientists have documented the most energetic flare ever observed emanating from a supermassive black hole, a cataclysmic event that briefly shone with the light of 10 trillion suns.

The new findings were published on Tuesday in the journal Nature Astronomy, with astronomer Matthew Graham of the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) leading the study.

The phenomenal burst of energy was likely triggered when an unusually large star wandered too close to the black hole and was violently shredded and swallowed.

‚ÄúHowever it happened, the star wandered close enough to the supermassive black hole that it was ‚Äòspaghettified‚Äô ‚Äì that is, stretched out to become long and thin, due to the gravity of the supermassive black hole strengthening as you get very close to it. That material then spiralled around the supermassive black hole as it fell in,‚Äù said astronomer and study co-author KE Saavik Ford.

The supermassive black hole was unleashed by a black hole roughly 300 million times the mass of the sun residing inside a faraway galaxy, about 11 billion light years from Earth. A light year is the distance light travels in a year, 5.9 trillion miles (9.5 trillion km).

The star, estimated to be between 30 and 200 times the mass of the sun, was turned into a stream of gas that heated up and shined intensely as it spiralled into oblivion.

Almost every large galaxy, including our Milky Way, has a supermassive black hole at its centre. But scientists still aren‚Äôt sure how they form.

First spotted in 2018 by the Palomar Observatory, operated by the Caltech, the flare took about three months to reach its peak brightness, becoming roughly 30 times more luminous than any previously recorded event of its kind. It is still ongoing, but diminishing in luminosity, with the entire process expected to take about 11 years to complete.

Because of how far away the black hole is located, observing the flash gives scientists a rare glimpse into the universe‚Äôs early epoch. Studying these immense, distant black holes helps researchers better understand how they form, how they influence their local stellar neighbourhoods, and the fundamental interactions that shaped the cosmos we know today.

articles.title: Why has Pakistan‚Äôs HPV vaccine campaign faced a backlash?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan launched its first national HPV vaccine campaign in September 2025 to vaccinate over 13 million girls aged 9 to 14, aiming to combat cervical cancer ‚Äî the leading cause of cancer death in women, with more than 5,000 new cases annually in the country. The campaign, led by the federal health minister Syed Mustafa Kamal and supported by the WHO and GAVI, used a single-dose Chinese vaccine (Cecolin) that contains recombinant proteins and no live virus. Despite strong scientific backing and global goals to eradicate cervical cancer by 2030, the campaign faced significant public resistance due to misinformation, including conspiracy theories linking the vaccine to infertility, foreign espionage (especially from the CIA‚Äôs Abbottabad operation), and sexual activity. Initial refusal rates were high, with some schools refusing to allow health workers in. The campaign was extended by four days to address this, and public acceptance improved after Kamal publicly vaccinated his daughter. While 9.2 million girls were vaccinated (78% of the target), the campaign has not fully reached its goal, reflecting broader societal vaccine hesitancy. The rollout will continue to other provinces by 2026 and 2027, with future plans to include boys and men. Experts emphasize that the vaccine is a crucial preventive measure, not only for sexual health but also as a safeguard against non-consensual sexual violence in a society where pre-marital sex is culturally and legally restricted.
keyTakeAways: The HPV vaccine campaign in Pakistan has faced significant public resistance due to misinformation and conspiracy theories, despite being scientifically proven safe and effective.
The campaign targets girls aged 9‚Äì14, based on WHO recommendations, as this age group shows the strongest and longest-lasting immune response.
A single-dose vaccine (Cecolin, developed in China) is being used, which contains recombinant L1 capsid proteins and does not contain live HPV virus or viral DNA.
Over 9.2 million girls (78% of the target) have been vaccinated in the first phase, with 66% of the Sindh target met, indicating partial success despite lower-than-expected participation.
The campaign has been extended by four days due to initial high refusal rates, especially in schools, which were initially unwilling to allow health workers in.

Misinformation, including claims that the vaccine causes infertility or is linked to foreign espionage, has been fueled by online content and lingering mistrust from past covert operations like the CIA‚Äôs Abbottabad hepatitis B campaign.
Experts emphasize that cervical cancer is not a rare disease in Pakistan, with more than 5,000 new cases reported annually, and that the vaccine is a preventive measure against a preventable cause.
The campaign includes training of 49,000 government health workers (all women) by the WHO and is supported by GAVI, highlighting international cooperation and capacity-building.
Parents and healthcare professionals are encouraging the vaccine not just for sexual health, but as a preventive measure against non-consensual sexual violence.
The government plans to eventually vaccinate boys and men as well, expanding the campaign‚Äôs scope beyond girls and women.

Title: Why has Pakistan‚Äôs HPV vaccine campaign faced a backlash?

In September, Pakistan launched its first-ever national human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine campaign, aiming to immunise more than 13 million girls aged nine to 14 in its first phase.

HPV is the most common cause of cervical cancer, which kills eight Pakistani women every day, according to Dr Dapeng Luo, the head of the World Health Organization (WHO) in Pakistan. The United Nations health agency has set a goal of  eradicating cervical cancer  globally by 2030.

But the vaccine has met resistance in Pakistan, as conspiracy theories about inoculations have circulated.

Here is more about what HPV is, how it causes cervical cancer, and why the vaccine rollout in Pakistan has faced a backlash.

HPV is a common group of viruses that enter the body via skin-to-skin contact, typically through a cut or abrasion.

There are more than 100 types of HPV, and they are often spread through sexual contact.¬† Infection can be hard to identify because many people who have contracted an HPV have no symptoms at all, and it can take many years for cancer to develop.

Some types of the virus eventually cause warts on the genitals or other parts of the body. These may appear flat or bumpy.

More than 95 percent of the 660,000 cervical cancer cases recorded each year worldwide are caused by HPV, according to the WHO. In Pakistan, more than 5,000 new cases of cervical cancer are reported every year, it said.

Some strains of HPV can cause different types of cancer, such as cervical cancer, vulvar cancer or vaginal cancer. However, cervical cancer typically develops 20 years after the onset of the HPV infection.

While the body‚Äôs immune system can clear away many strains of HPV within two years of infection, certain strains are more persistent. When the body‚Äôs immune system is unable to fight off the more persistent HPV strains, the virus interferes with normal cell growth, causing cells to become abnormal and potentially leading to a pre-cancerous state. If this is left untreated, cancer can develop.

Sufferers of cervical cancer do not experience symptoms in its early stages. Hence, women aged 30 to 65 are advised to have a pap smear every three years, according to the Mayo Clinic.

Pakistan‚Äôs HPV vaccine campaign began on September 15. While the first phase was scheduled to run until September 27, it was later extended to October 1.

Some 49,000 government health workers ‚Äì all women ‚Äì have been trained by the WHO to administer the vaccines across the country. The WHO and Pakistan‚Äôs government partnered to conduct this training with funding support from GAVI, the Vaccine Alliance, a public-private partnership that works to improve access to immunisations.

In advance of the first phase, vaccine centres were set up in public buildings such as schools. Health workers also went door-to-door to administer the HPV vaccine.

A single dose of Cecolin, an HPV vaccine developed in China, was administered free of charge. While most HPV vaccines require either two or three doses, WHO confirmed in October last year that Cecolin could be used as a single dose.

In the first phase of the rollout in Pakistan, girls between the ages of nine and 14 from Sindh, Punjab, Pakistan-administered Kashmir and the Islamabad Capital Territory received the single-dose vaccine.

Pakistan‚Äôs federal health minister, Syed Mustafa Kamal, said at a launch ceremony for the vaccine on September 16 in Islamabad, ‚ÄúI urge all parents to ensure their daughters and sisters are vaccinated. Do not fall prey to negative campaigns. This vaccine is safe, effective and essential for protecting our girls.‚Äù

Kamal told Al Jazeera that when the vaccine campaign started, there was a lot of criticism and scepticism towards it. ‚ÄúA few unknown people had spread some fake videos and fake information.‚Äù

He said that during the first four days of the campaign, the response to the vaccine was negative. ‚ÄúThe refusals were very high, so much so that there are schools which had committed before [to serve as vaccination centres], but refused our workers entry into the school.‚Äù

On the fifth day, Kamal got his own daughter publicly vaccinated during a ceremony at the Drug Regulatory Authority of Pakistan (DRAP) office in Karachi. During the event, Kamal told journalists: ‚ÄúI have never brought my family into the public eye in my 30-year political career. But to put an end to these baseless rumours, I have taken this step.‚Äù

He said that after this, the refusals went down and acceptances went up. He added that this upward trend of acceptance and vaccine administration continued till the end of the campaign.

‚ÄúIt was noticed that after clarifying rumours, people started to get vaccine. Especially, schools were requesting to send teams as parents were agreeing to get their daughters vaccinated,‚Äù Dr Azra Fazal Pechuho, the health minister of Sindh province, told Al Jazeera in a written statement.

The initial reluctance is why, she said, the vaccination campaign was extended by four days.

The Cecolin vaccine does not contain the live HPV virus. Instead, it contains recombinant L1 capsid proteins, laboratory-made proteins that mimic the outer shell of the virus but do not have any viral DNA and therefore cannot cause infection.

Other countries have used the US-manufactured Gardasil HPV vaccine, which also does not contain the live HPV virus and contains recombinant L1 capsid proteins.

The government says that this particular age group of girls was selected per the recommendations of the WHO‚Äôs National Immunisation Technical Advisory Groups (NITAGs), responsible for providing evidence-based recommendations for immunisation.

‚ÄúAs per WHO, the immune response generated by the body after the vaccine jab is maximum at this age of 9-14 years, and the child gets the best and long-term protection. Hence, this particular age group,‚Äù Pechuho said.

‚ÄúCurrently, the vaccine is available free of cost for 9-14-year-old girls only. There have been talks at the federal ministry level to make this vaccine available commercially so others [boys, women and teenage girls, etc] can benefit, as well.‚Äù

In September, Sana Ali Manzoor and her husband ‚Äì who say they are strongly in favour of vaccinations for their children ‚Äì took their 11-year-old daughter to be vaccinated at her private school campus in Karachi after school hours. The whole process took about 20 minutes.

Manzoor said she heard about the vaccine rollout via a mobile application operated by her daughter‚Äôs school, Haque Academy, which is located in the upmarket neighbourhood of Defence Housing Authority. Parents were invited to register on the mobile app and accompany their children for the vaccination.

Manzoor, a lactation specialist who supports new mothers, said approximately 30-40 other children were also present when her daughter received her vaccination.

‚ÄúSo we went to school, and there were two or three tables set up. The health workers were there. They first checked if our name was on the list. After that, we went and got the vaccination done. And then right after that, there was a manual card entry filling that was done, then they gave us the card.‚Äù

She described the process as ‚Äúvery organised‚Äù. Manzoor says she was encouraged by friends, including a paediatrician and a gynaecologist, to get the HPV vaccine for her daughter. She has also had her children vaccinated against chickenpox, which she travelled to Dubai to get.

The rollout has not hit its target, authorities say ‚Äî though they insist that despite this, the campaign counts as a success.

‚ÄúAround 13 million girls were supposed to be vaccinated in the first phase of the HPV vaccine campaign. So far, 9.2 million have been vaccinated, which is 78 percent of the total target,‚Äù Pechuho said.

In the southern province of Sindh, the estimated target for the HPV campaign was 4,081,279 girls. Sixty-six percent of the total target was reached, with 2,674,210 girls vaccinated.

The low take-up is down to a general hesitancy towards vaccines in Pakistani society, experts say. Compounding this, specific concerns about the HPV vaccine have been fuelled by misinformation, particularly online.

The vaccine will eventually roll out to other provinces, including Khyber Pakhtunkhwa in 2026, and Balochistan and Gilgit-Baltistan in 2027. The government has not yet announced when the next phase will begin.

‚ÄúEvery age girl will be vaccinated periodically,‚Äù Kamal, the federal minister, said. He added that the government hopes to vaccinate boys and men against HPV once girls and women have been vaccinated.

While vaccine hesitancy is a global phenomenon, in Pakistan it was aggravated by the CIA‚Äôs use of a fake hepatitis B vaccination campaign in Pakistan‚Äôs Abbottabad as cover for a manhunt for fugitive al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden.

The vaccine campaign, carried out in collaboration with a local doctor, was used to covertly collect blood samples to find links to bin Laden and his family. The plan was to compare the DNA of any of bin Laden‚Äôs children to that of his sister, who had died in Boston in 2010. The al-Qaeda leader was eventually killed in a military operation in Abbottabad by US Marines in 2011.

It was never revealed whether the CIA obtained any DNA from bin Laden‚Äôs family. However, news outlets at the time said that one source suggested the operation had not succeeded.¬†In 2014, the White House promised that the CIA would never again use a false vaccination campaign for espionage. However, mistrust towards vaccines persisted.

This was apparent during the COVID-19 pandemic, when vaccines were free, but according to a recent study, 30 percent of people in Pakistan did not want to get vaccinated. An opinion piece, co-written by a Pakistani doctor and published on the website of GAVI, said: ‚ÄúMisconceptions that the [COVID] vaccine could lead to infertility, death or be tied into shadowy foreign agendas circulated rapidly through social media and community gossip.‚Äù

Manzoor said she has herself noticed ‚Äúanti-vaxxer‚Äù sentiment among some of her clients. She recalled advising a young mother not to bring her unvaccinated newborn into her house, explaining that it is not a sterile environment. The young mother responded, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine, we don‚Äôt believe in such things.‚Äù

The HPV vaccine has faced especially heated pushback in Pakistan.

Some argue that, as HPV is a sexually transmitted infection, it is not required in Pakistan, where consensual sex before marriage is not only culturally frowned upon, but is also illegal.

A Pakistani user wrote on X, ‚ÄúCerv. Cancer is spread via Sexual contact which is NOT IN PAKISTAN for 9-14 year old ‚Äì only in west.‚Äù

Another user wrote, referring to the vaccine, ‚Äúits common in societies where women has multiple sex partners!‚Äù

Manzoor said that she had her daughter vaccinated because, to her, it made sense to ensure that her daughter remains safe from the virus.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not even about being sexually active, it‚Äôs even about, God forbid, molestation. It‚Äôs not always consensual,‚Äù Manzoor said.

In 2023, Islamabad-based NGO Sahil reported that, on average, one child was sexually abused every two hours in Pakistan. According to the  World Population Review , 5,867 rape cases were reported in Pakistan in 2023.

Another conspiracy theory circulating online is that the HPV vaccine causes infertility. There is no evidence to support this claim. Pakistan, with a population in excess of 250 million, is the fifth most populous country in the world, according to World Population Review. While  birthrates  in the country have declined, much like the rest of the world, Pakistan‚Äôs current birthrate is 3.32, well above the replacement rate of 2.1 required to maintain current populations.

In May 2020, a peer-reviewed US study found no evidence of increased infertility among women who received the HPV vaccine. However, this study was conducted in the US, and the sample was inoculated with a different vaccine ‚Äì Gardasil.

Other rumours, along with pictures and videos, have spread online. A video which attracted more than 340,000 views on X this year shows girls in school uniforms collapsing, with the caption asserting that these girls became sick after ‚Äúforced vaccinations‚Äù.

In fact, the video was filmed last year and shows a scene in which police are clashing with protesters over electricity taxes in Pakistan-administered Kashmir. Tear gas shells fired by the police are what caused the girls at the school to collapse.

‚ÄúThe vaccine has an excellent safety profile. It has been around for almost two decades now. It doesn‚Äôt contain any virus, but the active component is the HPV L1 protein,‚Äù Pechuho said.

In an assessment of Cecolin published last year, the WHO said that ‚Äúthe vaccine was safe and showed a good immunogenicity‚Äù.

It can cause a few mild side effects, Pechucho said. ‚ÄúMost common side effects are related to any other vaccine, like fever, pain at the injection site and, rarely, allergic reactions,‚Äù he said.

Kamal too insisted that the most common side effect is a fever, which subsides in a day or two with the help of over-the-counter medicines.

‚ÄúPeople used to die of diseases like polio and tuberculosis. They‚Äôre not dying today because we now have vaccines. People are not dying of COVID because we have vaccines. The world has moved to prevention,‚Äù Kamal said.

‚ÄúThe point of an effective healthcare system is to prevent people from becoming patients. And people will be safe from becoming patients when they take preventative measures and get their children vaccinated.‚Äù

articles.title: At least 66 killed as Typhoon Kalmaegi batters the Philippines
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Typhoon Kalmaegi, locally known as Tino, struck the Philippines with heavy rainfall and extreme flooding, resulting in at least 66 deaths, including six on a military helicopter that crashed during the storm. The worst-hit area was Cebu, where 49 of the fatalities occurred and entire towns were submerged due to unprecedented floodwaters. The storm brought over 183mm of rain in a 24-hour period, exceeding the monthly average, and triggered massive evacuations across the Visayas and surrounding regions. Authorities report that floodwaters have subsided, but debris clearance remains a major challenge. The typhoon maintained typhoon strength despite terrain interaction and is forecast to move into Vietnam, where it may worsen existing flood damage. This event underscores the Philippines' recurring vulnerability to typhoons and the broader regional risks associated with climate-induced disasters.
keyTakeAways: At least 66 people were killed in the Philippines due to Typhoon Kalmaegi (locally named Tino), including six on a military helicopter that crashed during the storm.
Floodwaters described as 'unprecedented' submerged homes, cars, and entire towns in Cebu, with 49 of the deaths occurring in Cebu City.
The typhoon brought 183mm (7 inches) of rainfall‚Äîexceeding the monthly average‚Äîleading to catastrophic flooding in the central Visayas region.
The Philippine military reported a Huey helicopter crash in Agusan del Sur, Mindanao, with six crew members killed and an investigation underway.
Tens of thousands of residents were evacuated across Visayas, southern Luzon, and northern Mindanao as the storm moved through the region.
Despite weakening slightly due to terrain interaction, the typhoon maintained typhoon intensity and continued to produce winds up to 165km/h (102.5mph) through Tuesday.
The Philippines is regularly affected by typhoons, with an average of 20 storms annually, often impacting poor, disaster-prone communities.
The Philippines experienced two major storms in September, including Super Typhoon Ragasa, highlighting ongoing vulnerability to extreme weather.
Typhoon Kalmaegi is forecast to make landfall in Vietnam on Thursday night, where it may exacerbate existing flood damage after killing at least 40 people and leaving six missing in previous weeks.
