Title: At least 66 killed as Typhoon Kalmaegi batters the Philippines

The death toll from Typhoon Kalmaegi in the Philippines has climbed to 66, including six people on a military helicopter that crashed during the powerful storm, which unleashed heavy rains and floods across the central region of the country.

Floodwaters described as ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù trapped many people on the roofs of their homes and submerged cars on Tuesday, with entire towns inundated on the island of Cebu.

Cebu accounted for 49 of the deaths, the civil defence agency‚Äôs deputy administrator, Rafaelito Alejandro, said in an interview with local radio outlet DZMM on Wednesday, as he confirmed the overall death toll of 66.

‚ÄúIt was the major cities that got hit [with floods], highly urbanised areas,‚Äù Alejandro said, adding that 26 people are still missing.

‚ÄúAll the floods have subsided. Our challenge now is the clearing of this debris that is blocking our roads,‚Äù he said.

In the 24 hours before Typhoon Kalmaegi, locally named Tino,  made landfall  shortly before midnight on Monday, the area around the provincial capital, Cebu City, was deluged with 183mm (7 inches) of rainfall, well in excess of its 131mm monthly average (5.2 inches), state weather specialist Charmagne Varilla told the AFP news agency.

In Agusan del Sur, on the island of Mindanao, a Huey helicopter went down while conducting a humanitarian disaster response mission, the military said. Six bodies of the crew were recovered, and an investigation is under way, the military said.

In a Facebook post on Tuesday, provincial Governor Pamela Baricuatro called the situation in Cebu ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù.

‚ÄúWe were expecting the winds to be the dangerous part, but ‚Ä¶ the water is what‚Äôs truly putting our people at risk,‚Äù Baricuatro said on Facebook. ‚ÄúThe floodwaters are just devastating.‚Äù

Although the typhoon gradually lost strength on Tuesday, it continued to lash the country with winds of 120km/h (74.5mph) and gusts of 165km/h (102.5mph) as it swept across the Visayas islands, headed for northern Palawan and towards the South China Sea.

Tens of thousands of residents were evacuated across the Visayas region, including parts of southern Luzon and northern Mindanao, authorities said. The typhoon was expected to leave the Philippines late on Wednesday or early Thursday.

‚ÄúDue to interaction with the terrain, Tino may slightly weaken while crossing Visayas. However, it is expected to remain at typhoon intensity throughout its passage over the country,‚Äù the Philippine weather agency PAGASA said in a morning bulletin.

The Philippines is hit by an average of 20 storms and typhoons each year, routinely striking disaster-prone areas where millions of people live in poverty.

The Philippines was hit by two major storms in September, including  Super Typhoon Ragasa , which killed at least three people and forced thousands to evacuate from villages and schools in the north of the country.

Kalmaegi is forecast to make landfall on Thursday night in Vietnam‚Äôs central region, which has already suffered heavy floods that killed at least 40 people and left six others missing over the past week.

articles.title: Cheyenne and Arapaho Children Repatriated from Carlisle Indian School Cemetery After Decades of Search
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details the long-term efforts of the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma to repatriate the remains of 16 of their children exhumed from the Carlisle Indian Industrial School cemetery in Pennsylvania, where they were taken in 1879 and died due to disease and poor conditions. The children, including Matavito Horse, Leah Road Traveler, and Elsie Davis, were subjected to forced assimilation, including haircuts, military uniforms, English language instruction, and harsh labor. Many died from diseases like tuberculosis and meningitis, and records are often incomplete or contradictory. The repatriation process, supported by tribal leadership and historical research, is described as a vital step toward justice and healing. However, systemic obstacles such as the U.S. Army‚Äôs refusal to hand over remains, poor documentation, and cases where remains do not match expected identities, continue to hinder full recovery. Advocates, including historians and tribal leaders, emphasize that these events represent a federal atrocity and call for moral and financial accountability from institutions that benefited from or enabled the boarding school era.
keyTakeAways: The Carlisle Indian Industrial School was a key site in the U.S. government's campaign to erase Native American identities through forced assimilation, beginning with the enrollment of Matavito Horse and Leah Road Traveler in October 1879.

Native children were subjected to harsh conditions including forced haircuts, military-style uniforms, separation from families, and mandatory English language instruction, with many experiencing physical, emotional, and sexual abuse.
Multiple children died of diseases such as tuberculosis, meningitis, and typhoid fever, and the records often contain errors, missing data, or contradictory information.

The repatriation of 16 Cheyenne and Arapaho children from a Pennsylvania cemetery to Concho, Oklahoma, and Wallace Perryman to the Seminole Nation in Wewoka, represents a significant step toward justice and healing for Native communities.

The U.S. Army's refusal to hand over remains without tribal consent, and poor documentation, has led to cases where remains do not match expected identities, requiring reburial and further investigation.

The 2024 Interior Department review revealed at least 973 Native children died in federally funded schools, indicating a systemic failure to protect Native lives, which has spurred national and tribal calls for accountability.
Tribal members and advocates have emphasized that burial ceremonies are essential for healing and cultural continuity, especially in the context of historical trauma and systemic erasure.

articles.content: Published: 2025-11-06T05:02:30+00:00 CARLISLE, Pa. (AP) ‚Äî The Carlisle Indian Industrial School had not yet held its first class when Matavito Horse and Leah Road Traveler were taken there in October 1879, drafted into the U.S. government‚Äôs campaign to erase Native American tribes by wiping their children‚Äôs identities. A few years later, Matavito, a Cheyenne boy, and Leah, an Arapaho girl, were dead. Persistent efforts by their tribes have finally brought them home. The Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma received 16 of its children, exhumed from a Pennsylvania cemetery, and reburied their small wooden coffins last month in a tribal cemetery in Concho, Oklahoma. A 17th student, Wallace Perryman, was repatriated to the Seminole Nation of Oklahoma in Wewoka. Burial ceremonies are ‚Äúan important step toward justice and healing for the families and Tribal Nations impacted by the boarding school era,‚Äù the Cheyenne and Arapaho government said. Seminole communications director Mark Williams said Perryman‚Äôs family wanted no public statements. Most details are lost to history, but records in the National Archives and documents assembled by a team at Dickinson College offer glimpses into experiences at Carlisle, where 7,800 students from more than 100 tribes were sent as the U.S. government systematically and violently evicted Native Americans from their lands to seize them for white settlers. Among the 17 were children who tended fires, raised pigs and learned how to make clothes. Some were baptized as Christians. One earned 66 cents over four days at the school shoe shop. Another was praised for finishing three pairs of pants in one week ‚Äî when he wasn‚Äôt making bricks. This illustration shows a combination of images provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center. (AP/Dario Lopez-Mills) This illustration shows a combination of images provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center. (AP/Dario Lopez-Mills) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook Copy Link copied Print Email X LinkedIn Bluesky Flipboard Pinterest Reddit Read More Who were the children? Their causes of death, if mentioned in school records, include tuberculosis, spinal meningitis and typhoid fever. Perryman died after abdominal surgery. The records are often contradictory, obviously wrong about names and ages or lacking basic information about their families. ‚ÄúSometimes the only evidence of a child‚Äôs existence is a scrap of paper with a hastily scribbled note,‚Äù said Preston McBride, a Pomona College historian who has examined boarding school death records. Upon arrival in Carlisle, their long hair was cut. They were issued military-style uniforms and often housed apart from any relatives, forced to speak English. In addition to lessons in reading, writing, math, science and other subjects, they were sent to work in ‚Äúoutings‚Äù at farms and homes. Several of the 17 were closely related to tribal leaders, reflecting how the U.S. government used the boarding system to control Native people. Each one was somewhere between a hostage, prisoner of war and student being forced to assimilate, Harvard University historian Philip Deloria said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs undoubtedly true if you have someone‚Äôs kids you have a certain amount of leverage against them,‚Äù Deloria said. In this photo provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center, male students in the Carlisle Indian Industrial School pose for a photo in the tin shop with their instructor Richard Henry Pratt. From left are Charles Oheltoint, Richard Henry Pratt, Henry Roman Nose, Paul Black Bear, instructor J.H. Curtain, Ernest, and Koba. (John N. Choate/Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) In this photo provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center, male students in the Carlisle Indian Industrial School pose for a photo in the tin shop with their instructor Richard Henry Pratt. From left are Charles Oheltoint, Richard Henry Pratt, Henry Roman Nose, Paul Black Bear, instructor J.H. Curtain, Ernest, and Koba. (John N. Choate/Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook Copy Link copied Print Email X LinkedIn Bluesky Flipboard Pinterest Reddit Read More The Cheyenne and Arapaho had been debilitated by decades of battles for their very existence by the time classes began at Carlisle. Some of their children had lost relatives in the 1864 Sand Creek Massacre in Colorado and the 1868 attack on Black Kettle‚Äôs camp along the Washita River in present-day Oklahoma. ‚ÄúEvery tribe has slightly different sorts of experiences, but in the aggregate, especially in the western parts in the 1860s on, it‚Äôs just violence all the time,‚Äù Deloria said. A promising artist This photo provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center shows the student card of Elsie Davis, a member of the Cheyenne Nation, who entered the Carlisle Indian Industrial School on May 21, 1890, and died on July 16, 1893. (Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) This photo provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center shows the student card of Elsie Davis, a member of the Cheyenne Nation, who entered the Carlisle Indian Industrial School on May 21, 1890, and died on July 16, 1893. (Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook Copy Link copied Print Email X LinkedIn Bluesky Flipboard Pinterest Reddit Read More Matavito and Leah‚Äôs journey was recounted by federal Indian Agent Charles Campbell, who wrote that care had been ‚Äútaken to accept the most promising.‚Äù He also noted that Matavito‚Äôs father, a brother of famed Cheyenne leader Black Kettle, ‚Äúforced me to accept his boy.‚Äù Matavito became the first typhoid fever victim at Carlisle. Why Leah died is unclear. Also repatriated was Elsie Davis, whose father, Cheyenne Chief Bull Bear, was a leader of the Dog Men Society of warriors and a signatory to the 1867 Medicine Lodge Treaty . Called Vah-stah by her family, she was about 13 when enrolled, according to her great grand-niece, Cheyenne citizen and Native American rights advocate Suzan Shown Harjo. Vah-stah‚Äôs family remembers her as kind and a promising artist. She died at the school at 18 of tuberculosis in July 1893, while her etching was exhibited at the Chicago World‚Äôs Fair. Her headstone, like many others, contained an error ‚Äî in her case, the year of death. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not even clear if they had a service to bury her or if they just buried her without much of a funeral or ceremony,‚Äù Harjo said. ‚ÄúIt must have been just quite awful.‚Äù A published eulogy attributed to the brother of one of the 17 students, William Sammers, said his death of meningitis in May 1888 at age 19 ‚Äúhappened in these glorious and grandest days of our school lives.‚Äù But records also show Sammers had at one point escaped and traveled 70 miles (113 kilometers) away before he was arrested and returned. Shattering experiences This photo provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center shows nine male students and six female students posed on the steps of the bandstand on the Carlisle Indian Industrial School grounds in Carlisle, Pa., in March 1891, wearing the clothing they arrived in. (John N. Choate/Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) This photo provided by the Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center shows nine male students and six female students posed on the steps of the bandstand on the Carlisle Indian Industrial School grounds in Carlisle, Pa., in March 1891, wearing the clothing they arrived in. (John N. Choate/Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook Copy Link copied Print Email X LinkedIn Bluesky Flipboard Pinterest Reddit Read More Many reports of sexual, physical and emotional abuse of children at boarding and residential schools across the U.S. and Canada have come to light, with much more undoubtedly having been unreported, ignored or covered up. In 1913, 276 Carlisle students petitioned the U.S. Department of the Interior to investigate its conditions, including harsh punishments for minor infractions. A 2024 Interior Department review found at least 973 Native American children died at 400 federally funded schools. McBride said the true number is likely in the thousands. The shattering experiences factored into President Joe Biden‚Äôs apology last year. The Pennsylvania school‚Äôs legacy remains complex, said Amanda Cheromiah of Laguna Pueblo, who directs the Center for the Futures of Native Peoples at Dickinson College in Carlisle. ‚ÄúThere were such diverse experiences, some were good and some were bad ‚Äî and everywhere in between,‚Äù Cheromiah said. Six of her relatives attended Carlisle. Cheromiah said several hundred people attended services in early October for the 16 Cheyenne and Arapaho children. She called it ‚Äúone of the most memorable moments that I‚Äôve ever heard other people share.‚Äù Some tribes are not interested in opening their children‚Äôs graves. Because of poor documentation, others may never be returned. A grave thought to contain a 15-year-old Wichita boy was found to hold someone else‚Äôs remains last year. Expecting a 13- or 14-year-old boy from the Catawba Indian Nation of South Carolina in 2022, the team instead found a female teenager. Their remains were reburied, the graves marked unknown. Norene Starr, a Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes projects coordinator who led their repatriation, called it a ‚Äúfederal atrocity‚Äù that the exhumed remains of two more students didn‚Äôt match their gravestones and had to be reburied. She‚Äôs working with forensic experts to identify them. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs gonna be a long, long journey,‚Äù Starr said. Since repatriations began at Carlisle in 2017, the bodies of 58 students have been returned, leaving 118 graves with Native American or Alaska Native names. About 20 more contain unidentified Native children. Costly undertakings Five image composite showing, top left, a studio portrait of brothers Charles (at right) and Mark Whiteshield. Center, Wash E. He. Top right, Reuben Tanpeds. Bottom right, a studio portrait of Lydia Gardner, Nannie Little Robe (at center), and Ethel Black Wolf. Bottom left, Henry Morning. (Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) Five image composite showing, top left, a studio portrait of brothers Charles (at right) and Mark Whiteshield. Center, Wash E. He. Top right, Reuben Tanpeds. Bottom right, a studio portrait of Lydia Gardner, Nannie Little Robe (at center), and Ethel Black Wolf. Bottom left, Henry Morning. (Carlisle Indian School Digital Resource Center via AP) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook Copy Link copied Print Email X LinkedIn Bluesky Flipboard Pinterest Reddit Read More Exhumations are complicated and costly. The federal government and the Christian churches involved have a moral imperative to fund the work at many more boarding school graveyards, said Samuel Torres with the National Native American Boarding School Healing Coalition. ‚ÄúFor those tribes that are interested in identifying where their children are and to bring them home, there‚Äôs an opportunity for complicit entities to step up and fund these initiatives,‚Äù said Torres, who is Mexica/Nahua. To approve repatriation, the U.S. Army requires a notarized affidavit from the closest living relative, but defers to families and tribes to determine who that might be. Starr said in cases where the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes weren‚Äôt able to locate lineal descendants, the tribal governor‚Äôs office adopted the children to effectuate their return. A flower rests in front of a headstone marked as ‚ÄúUnknown‚Äù at the Carlisle Barracks Post Cemetery in Carlisle, Pa., on Thursday, Sept. 4, 2025. (AP Photo/Mingson Lau) A flower rests in front of a headstone marked as ‚ÄúUnknown‚Äù at the Carlisle Barracks Post Cemetery in Carlisle, Pa., on Thursday, Sept. 4, 2025. (AP Photo/Mingson Lau) Add AP News on Google Add AP News as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. Share Share Facebook Copy Link copied Print Email X LinkedIn Bluesky Flipboard Pinterest Reddit Read More Tribes seeking their ancestors‚Äô return under the 1990 Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act have run into a U.S. Army policy that it is not required to turn over bodies in cemeteries to tribal nations. A court ruling against The Winnebago Tribe of Nebraska , which seeks the return of two of its former Carlisle students, is under appeal. At oral argument, held during the exhumation process in September, federal appellate judges pressed the U.S. Army to justify its position. ‚ÄúThese were burials without consent. There was no Native American burial. These kids are kidnapped, dumped in a grave after they die at the government‚Äôs hands, and then moved so that they can pave over the graves,‚Äù said 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Pamela Harris. ‚ÄúDo you think Congress‚Äô point was like, we really need to preserve that setup?‚Äù Dotted Line with Center Square Associated Press reporter Graham Lee Brewer in Oklahoma City contributed.

articles.title: What caused Amazon‚Äôs AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage at Amazon Web Services (AWS) on October 20, 2025, began at 07:11 GMT in Virginia‚Äôs primary data center due to a flawed technical update to DynamoDB‚Äôs API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS) and prevented apps from connecting to servers. This cascading failure impacted over 113 AWS services, including Snapchat, Pinterest, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Starbucks, Venmo, Duolingo, Canva, and major media outlets like The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal. The outage highlighted the deep reliance of modern digital services‚Äîspanning finance, entertainment, communication, and smart home devices‚Äîon cloud infrastructure. AWS confirmed the issue was due to human error, not a cyberattack, and restored services by 10:11 GMT, though some message processing delays remained. Experts noted that while the incident was widespread, AWS‚Äôs market dominance and user loyalty mean the impact is relatively contained.
keyTakeAways: The AWS outage was caused by a technical error during an API update to DynamoDB, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS), preventing apps from finding server addresses.
The root cause was a DNS failure due to a flawed update affecting DynamoDB's API, leading to a cascading failure across 113 AWS services.

The outage affected major services including Snapchat, Pinterest, Apple TV, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Starbucks, Venmo, Duolingo, Canva, and major news outlets like The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal.

Financial institutions including banks and Coinbase, airlines Delta and United, and AI firms like Perplexity were also impacted, showing how deeply dependent modern businesses are on cloud infrastructure.
The outage was not due to a cyberattack or malicious activity, but rather to human error in a technical update, a common cause of cloud outages.
AWS acknowledged the issue, deployed multiple recovery paths, and stated that services were fully restored by 10:11 GMT, though some message processing delays remained.
The incident underscores the critical role AWS plays in global digital operations and the fragility of internet-dependent systems when core cloud services fail.

Title: What caused Amazon‚Äôs AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?

A  major outage  at the Amazon Web Services (AWS) on Monday disrupted a large portion of the internet, taking down apps, websites and online tools used by millions of people around the world, before services were eventually restored.

The hours-long  breakdown  of the cloud system that supports a portion of the internet revealed just how much of modern-life depends on the infrastructure ‚Äì from banking apps and airlines to smart home devices and gaming platforms.

Here is what we know:

At about 07:11 GMT, Amazon‚Äôs cloud service experienced a major outage, meaning some of its systems stopped working, which disrupted many popular apps and websites, including banks, gaming platforms and entertainment services.

The problem started in one of AWS‚Äôs main data centres in Virginia, its oldest and biggest site, after a technical update to the API ‚Äì a connection between different computer programmes ‚Äì of DynamoDB, a key cloud database service that stores user information and other important data for many online platforms.

The root cause appears to have been an error in the update that affected the Domain Name System (DNS), which helps apps find the correct server addresses. A DNS works like the internet‚Äôs phone book, turning website names into the numeric IP addresses that computers use to connect to servers.

Because of the DNS issue, apps could not find the IP address for DynamoDB‚Äôs API and were unable to connect.

As DynamoDB went down, other AWS services also began to fail. In total, 113 services were affected by the outage. By 10:11 GMT, Amazon said that all AWS returned to normal operations, but there was a backlog ‚Äúof messages that they will finish processing over the next few hours‚Äù.

At the time of publication, Downdetector, a website that tracks internet outages based on user reports, was still showing problems with platforms such as OpenAI, ESPN and Apple Music.

Updated look at the total impact of the AWS Outage up to this point! https://t.co/Bgpm1fFGtf   pic.twitter.com/TAAxjagNl6

‚Äî Downdetector (@downdetector)  October 20, 2025

A cloud is a way of storing and using data or programmes over the internet instead of on your computer or other physical storage devices.

When people say something is ‚Äúin the cloud‚Äù, it means the files, apps or systems are running on powerful computers (called servers) in data centres owned by companies like Amazon (AWS), Google or Microsoft, not on your personal device.

In this case, AWS allows companies to rent computing power and storage. It supplies the technology that runs websites, apps and many online services behind the scenes.

One of AWS‚Äôs core services is DynamoDB, a database that stores important information for companies, such as customer records. On Monday, Amazon reported that customers were unable to access their DynamoDB data.

AWS is the biggest cloud service provider in the world.

Cloud outages are not rare, but they have become more noticeable as more companies rely on these services every day.

‚ÄúThe fallout impacted people across a number of different spheres,‚Äù Joshua Mahony, the chief market analyst at Scope Markets, told Al Jazeera. [But] of course this kind of comes with the territory with tech companies; the key is they can resolve it quickly, and it doesn‚Äôt cost them a lot of money.‚Äù

He said Amazon would likely weather the storm from the incident.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre looking at something that is relatively contained,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAmazon Web Services has cornered 30 percent of the market alone. Their users are not going to suddenly jump ship. Their businesses are deeply ingrained.‚Äù

The outage affected dozens of websites, including Snapchat, Pinterest and Apple TV, according to Downdetector.

Other communication apps were also affected including: WhatsApp, Signal, Zoom and Slack; gaming services such as Roblox, Fortnite and Xbox; and places like Starbucks. Etsy also experienced issues.

In the United States, people were having issues with financial apps too, including Venmo.

Some users said their Ring doorbells and Alexa speakers stopped working, while others could not access the Amazon website or download books on their Kindles.

The language app Duolingo and creative tool Canva were among those reporting errors on their websites, and several media organisations were hit, including the Associated Press news agency, The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal.

Banks, the cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase, and AI firm Perplexity also reported issues, along with US airlines Delta and United.

When AWS had its outage, it was not just Amazon‚Äôs tools that were affected. Thousands of other companies that use AWS for storage, databases or web hosting were also hit. These companies include many major apps that rely on AWS to run key parts of their systems.

‚ÄúWhenever we see these headlines, the first thought that goes through everybody‚Äôs mind, that sends a shiver up the spine, is, ‚ÄòIs this one of those cyberattacks? Is this a military or intelligence-led thing that has led to this disruption?‚Äô And in this case, it‚Äôs not,‚Äù Bryson Bort chief executive of the cybersecurity company Scythe told Al Jazeera.

‚ÄúIn fact, most of the time, it isn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs usually human error.‚Äù

AWS  acknowledged  the outage and said engineers were ‚Äúimmediately engaged‚Äù to fix the problem.

AWS said it worked on ‚Äúmultiple parallel paths to accelerate recovery‚Äù. It also reported that the main issue had been fully resolved, though some users continued to face minor delays as systems recovered.

The company also said it would publish a detailed post-event summary explaining what happened.

articles.title: Avalanche hits Nepal‚Äôs Mount Yalung Ri, killing seven climbers
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: An avalanche on Mount Yalung Ri in northeastern Nepal killed at least seven climbers, including five foreigners‚Äîthree French, one Canadian, one Italian, and two Nepalis‚Äîduring a climb on a 5,630-meter peak amid poor weather and snowfall. Four Nepali climbers were injured and evacuated, while four remain missing. Rescue efforts were delayed due to heavy snow and clouds, with helicopters only reaching the site on Monday evening. The incident occurred in a region known for dangerous terrain and rock, ice, and snow, and coincides with ongoing weather-related hazards such as Cyclone Montha. The event underscores the risks of mountaineering in Nepal, especially during autumn expeditions when conditions are harsh and weather is unstable.
keyTakeAways: An avalanche on Mount Yalung Ri in eastern Nepal killed at least seven climbers, including five foreigners.
The victims included three French climbers, one Canadian, one Italian, and two Nepalis.
Four Nepali climbers were injured and evacuated; four others remain missing.
The avalanche occurred during a climb on a 5,630-metre mountain in the Rolwaling Valley, where rock, ice, and snow are common.
Poor weather and continuous snowfall for several days prior to the incident contributed to the disaster.
Rescue operations were delayed due to heavy snowfall and clouds, with helicopters unable to operate until Monday evening.
A foot-based search team was dispatched, and operations resumed on Tuesday morning.
This incident adds to previous weather-related disasters in Nepal, such as Cyclone Montha which stranded tourists last week.
Nepal, home to eight of the world‚Äôs 14 highest peaks, faces ongoing risks during autumn expeditions due to harsh weather conditions.

Title: Avalanche hits Nepal‚Äôs Mount Yalung Ri, killing seven climbers

At least seven people, including five foreigners, have been killed in eastern Nepal after an avalanche swept through a camp on Mount Yalung Ri, according to media reports.

The Kathmandu Post, citing local officials, reported on Tuesday that the avalanche hit the team of 15 people as they were ascending the 5,630-metre (18,471-foot) mountain of Yalung Ri, and that four members of the expedition remain remaining.

‚ÄúThe avalanche buried everyone on the slope,‚Äù Deputy Superintendent of Police Gyan Kumar Mahato told the Kathmandu Post. ‚ÄúWe got the information late, and the difficult weather delayed immediate response.‚Äù

Mahato said that three French climbers, one Canadian, one Italian and two Nepalis were killed in the incident.

Four Nepali climbers who were injured have been evacuated, while four others, also from Nepal, remain missing, the Kathmandu Post reported.

One of the injured climbers told the newspaper that the climbers had called for help but got no response for hours.

‚ÄúWe shouted and cried for help, but no one could reach us,‚Äù the unnamed climber said. ‚ÄúWe were told that a helicopter would come after four hours, but by then, several of our friends were gone.‚Äù

Yalung Ri is located in the Rolwaling Valley of northeastern Nepal, and climbers there encounter a mix of rock, ice and snow.

Before Monday‚Äôs tragedy, the valley had experienced continuous snow and poor weather conditions for several days, according to the Kathmandu Post.

Mahato, the police officer, said helicopters could not be flown in the area due to heavy snowfall and clouds but an aircraft finally reached the area on Monday evening.

He added that rescue teams on foot have also been dispatched to the area, and that the search operation would resume on Tuesday morning.

Nepal is home to eight of the world‚Äôs 14 highest peaks, including  Mount Everest , and welcomes hundreds of climbers and trekkers every year.

Autumn expeditions on the Himalayan mountains in October and November are less popular because of the shorter, colder days, snowy terrain and a narrow summit window compared with the busy spring season, which runs from April to May.

Last week,  Cyclone Montha  triggered heavy rain and snowfall across Nepal, leaving trekkers and tourists stranded on popular Himalayan trekking routes.

Separately, two Italian climbers have also gone missing while scaling a remote peak in western Nepal, tourism officials said on Monday.

articles.title: How will ‚Äòlimited‚Äô US nuclear tests avoid any explosions?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Following claims by President Donald Trump that the U.S. should resume nuclear weapon testing due to China‚Äôs growing arsenal, U.S. Energy Secretary Chris Wright clarified that the planned tests are noncritical and do not involve nuclear explosions. These tests will focus on component functionality and system performance using subcritical experiments and advanced simulations, not full detonations. Experts, including Georgia Cole of Chatham House and the National Nuclear Security Administration, emphasize that such noncritical testing is both scientifically valid and legally consistent with the global nuclear testing moratorium. The article highlights that no credible evidence exists of active nuclear testing by China, Russia, or Pakistan, and that resuming full explosive testing would dangerously escalate global nuclear tensions, with Russia and others likely to respond. The U.S. has not conducted a nuclear explosion since 1992, and the scientific consensus remains that existing simulations and stockpile stewardship are sufficient to ensure safety and reliability.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. is conducting 'noncritical' or 'subcritical' nuclear tests, not full nuclear explosions, clarifying that no actual nuclear detonations are planned.
President Donald Trump has publicly advocated for resuming nuclear weapon testing, citing China‚Äôs nuclear buildup and global testing by other countries as justification.

Experts and agencies like the National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) and the Arms Control Association affirm that full nuclear explosions are unnecessary, relying on computer simulations and component testing.
Noncritical tests, such as subcritical experiments and system testing of delivery components, are allowed under current international norms and scientific protocols.

If the U.S. were to resume full explosive nuclear tests, it would trigger a global escalation, with Russia, China, and North Korea likely to respond, undermining the 30-year nuclear testing moratorium.
The U.S. has not conducted a full nuclear test since 1992, and the last such test was in 1992, with over 1,000 prior tests conducted in history.

Despite Trump‚Äôs claims, there is no credible evidence that China, Russia, or Pakistan are currently conducting nuclear explosions; the only recent nuclear test in the 21st century was by North Korea (since 2018).

Title: How will ‚Äòlimited‚Äô US nuclear tests avoid any explosions?

United States Energy Secretary Chris Wright says planned nuclear tests will be ‚Äúnoncritical‚Äù and will not feature any nuclear explosions for now.

This clarification on Sunday came three days after President Donald Trump announced he had instructed the Department of Defense to ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù restart  testing of US nuclear weapons .

‚ÄúI think the tests we‚Äôre talking about right now are system tests,‚Äù Wright said on the Fox News show The Sunday Briefing.

‚ÄúThese are not nuclear explosions. These are what we call noncritical explosions.‚Äù

Wright explained that for now, only the components of nuclear weapons will be tested to ensure they work properly and can trigger a nuclear explosion. He said these tests will be conducted on new systems to ensure that replacement nuclear weapons are improvements on earlier models.

‚ÄúWith our science and our computation power, we can simulate incredibly accurately exactly what will happen in a nuclear explosion,‚Äù Wright said. ‚ÄúNow, we simulate what were the conditions that delivered that and, as we change bomb designs, what will they deliver.‚Äù

According to the website of the Washington, DC-based nonpartisan organisation Arms Control Association, several nonnuclear explosive techniques can be used for nuclear weapon development, monitoring and maintenance. These can also include ‚Äúsubcritical‚Äù experiments, which use plutonium but avoid nuclear chain reactions.

‚ÄúIn this context, ‚Äònoncritical‚Äô nuclear tests involve testing of nuclear weapons delivery systems or components but not the detonation of a nuclear warhead,‚Äù Georgia Cole, a research analyst at the International Security Programme at Chatham House, told Al Jazeera.

‚ÄúNoncritical tests typically take place in laboratories or testing facilities, often using advanced computer simulations to assess the safety and reliability of nuclear warheads without detonation. There are also ‚Äòsubcritical‚Äô tests, which are nonnuclear explosions carried out underground, often in former nuclear test sites.‚Äù

On Thursday, Trump wrote in a post on his Truth Social platform: ‚ÄúBecause of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis.‚Äù Trump signed an executive order in September to rename the Department of Defense the Department of War.

Trump added in his post that while the US has ‚Äúmore Nuclear Weapons than any other country‚Äù, China ‚Äúwill be even within 5 years‚Äù.

Trump justified his testing decision by citing China‚Äôs rapid build-up of its nuclear arsenal. The announcement came minutes before Trump‚Äôs  meeting  with Chinese President Xi Jinping which resulted in a truce on tariffs and some Chinese export restrictions of rare earth metals.

On Sunday, during an appearance on the CBS News programme 60 Minutes, Trump said in reference to nuclear weapons: ‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs testing, and China‚Äôs testing, but they don‚Äôt talk about it. You know, we‚Äôre an open society. We‚Äôre different. We talk about it. We have to talk about it.‚Äù

Trump added: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gonna test because they test and others test. And certainly North Korea‚Äôs been testing. Pakistan‚Äôs been testing.‚Äù

However, none of the countries Trump mentioned has openly conducted nuclear weapons tests in recent years, and he did not provide any evidence to support his claims. It is also unclear why he believes China could catch up with the far larger US arsenal of nuclear warheads in just five years.

‚ÄúThere is no credible evidence that Russia, China or Pakistan are conducting explosive nuclear tests. The only country to have tested a nuclear weapon in the 21st century is North Korea, which has observed a self-declared moratorium since 2018,‚Äù Cole said.

‚ÄúWhile all nuclear-armed states routinely test their delivery systems, such as missiles, there is no indication that any have resumed nuclear detonations.‚Äù

Nine states have nuclear arms: the US, Russia, the United Kingdom, France, China, India, Pakistan, North Korea and Israel.

According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) yearbook report published in January, Russia has the highest number of total warheads at 4,309.

Russia is followed by the US, which has 3,700 warheads. China has 600. France has 290. The UK has 225. India has 180. Pakistan has 170. Israel has 90, and North Korea has 50.

A SIPRI report from June stated that China‚Äôs nuclear arsenal has been growing more rapidly than any other country‚Äôs, increasing by about 100 warheads every year since 2023. A report published by the Pentagon in December estimated that China would likely have 1,000 nuclear weapons by 2030.

The US has retired 1,477 nuclear warheads while Russia has retired 1,150. A retired warhead is one that has been removed from a country‚Äôs military arsenal and is awaiting dismantlement. According to a report published in March by the Federation of American Scientists, a US-based think tank, the retired warheads ‚Äúare still relatively intact‚Äù, however.

‚ÄúIn some cases, retired warheads could technically be restored, depending on how far they are through the dismantlement process. However, this can be a lengthy and resource-intensive process. More commonly, states may reuse components from older warheads in the production or refurbishment of a new weapon,‚Äù Cole said.

The US  began testing nuclear weapons  in 1945 with the first detonation taking place over New Mexico‚Äôs desert. The last time it tested nuclear weapons was more than 30 years ago in 1992. In total, the US has conducted 1,032 nuclear tests, according to the United Nations.

The Soviet Union conducted 715 nuclear tests ‚Äì the last one in 1990. Russia, which inherited the Soviet nuclear arsenal, has not conducted any nuclear tests.

China has conducted 45 tests and last tested nuclear weapons in 1996.

France last tested nuclear weapons in 1996. It conducted 210 tests from 1945 to 1996. The UK conducted 45 nuclear tests from 1952 with the last one conducted in 1991.

Most countries  have ceased nuclear weapons testing after signing the global Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT), which was introduced in 1996.

Since then, 10 nuclear tests have taken place: two by India and two by Pakistan in 1998 and six by North Korea in 2006, 2009, 2013, 2016 (twice) and 2017, according to the UN. India, Pakistan and North Korea have not signed the CTBT.

The US did sign the CTBT in 1996 but did not ratify it. Russia signed the CTBT in 1996 and ratified it in 2000, but in 2023, President Vladimir Putin withdrew Russia‚Äôs ratification of the treaty.

When a country signs a treaty, it signals its general agreement with the treaty‚Äôs terms and its intention to adhere to it in the future. Only upon ratification does the treaty become legally binding for that country under international law.

Political and scientific authorities in the US have asserted that the US does not need to conduct new nuclear tests.

The National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) is a semiautonomous agency within the US Department of Energy. The agency oversees nuclear weapons security, maintenance and stockpile stewardship. The NNSA has repeatedly made it clear that the US does not need new tests.

The agency‚Äôs new administrator, Brandon Williams, said during his Senate confirmation hearing in April: ‚ÄúThe United States continues to observe its 1992 nuclear test moratorium and since 1992 has assessed that the deployed nuclear stockpile remains safe, secure and effective without nuclear explosive testing.‚Äù

Williams added that every year, national security lab directors and the commander of the US Strategic Command review the nuclear stockpile to decide if underground nuclear testing is necessary. Previous NNSA Administrator Jill Hruby also stated that new testing was not necessary, according to a 2023 interview with the Arms Control Association.

If the US breaks this moratorium on testing nuclear weapons ‚Äì rather than just their components ‚Äì other countries are likely to follow suit, experts said.

‚ÄúIf the US were to resume explosive nuclear testing, other powers would almost certainly respond in kind. Russia has already stated that it would mirror any US tests, and such moves could prompt China and North Korea to follow. The result would be the collapse of a 30-year moratorium on nuclear testing, undoing decades of restraint and sharply increasing global nuclear risks,‚Äù Cole said.

She added that Wright‚Äôs clarification about the tests being noncritical is an important one. ‚ÄúHad [Trump] been referring to explosive tests, as many initially assumed, that would represent a dramatic policy shift and a serious escalation in nuclear tensions.‚Äù

articles.title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration‚Äôs claims linking Tylenol and autism
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary, has partially retracted his earlier claim that Tylenol use during pregnancy causes autism, acknowledging the link is 'suggested' but not proven. While some studies have raised questions, the World Health Organization and other health experts state there is no consistent evidence of a causal relationship. The claims originated from political figures including Donald Trump and Kennedy, who made unsubstantiated assertions without medical backing. These claims prompted a lawsuit in Texas by Attorney General Ken Paxton, accusing Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue of deceptive marketing of Tylenol as safe for pregnant women. Kenvue and global health bodies continue to affirm that acetaminophen is the safest pain reliever during pregnancy, emphasizing that untreated pain or fevers pose greater risks. This episode highlights the dangers of scientific misinformation from political leaders and the importance of medical evidence in public health messaging.
keyTakeAways: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has partially retracted his claim that Tylenol during pregnancy causes autism, acknowledging that while there is a suggestive association, it is not sufficient to conclude causation.
The World Health Organization and other reputable health bodies have consistently stated there is no consistent association between Tylenol and autism, despite extensive research.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed a lawsuit against Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, accusing them of deceptive marketing of Tylenol as the only safe painkiller for pregnant women, citing misinformation by Trump and Kennedy.
President Donald Trump previously claimed in September 2025 that Tylenol use during pregnancy is linked to increased autism risk, without scientific backing.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has no professional medical background and has made scientifically unsupported claims about Tylenol and male circumcision, contributing to public health misinformation.
Kenvue and other health experts emphasize that acetaminophen (Tylenol) is the safest pain reliever for pregnant women and that untreated fevers or pain pose greater risks to pregnancy.

Title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration‚Äôs claims linking Tylenol and autism

United States Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr has partially walked back his  warning  that taking Tylenol during pregnancy is directly linked to autism in children.

In a news conference on Wednesday, Kennedy struck a more moderate tone than he generally has in his past public appearances.

‚ÄúThe causative association between Tylenol given in pregnancy and the perinatal periods is not sufficient to say it definitely causes autism,‚Äù Kennedy told reporters. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs very suggestive.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere should be a cautious approach to it,‚Äù he added. ‚Äú‚ÄäThat‚Äôs why our message to patients, to mothers, to people who are pregnant and to the mothers of young children is: Consult your physician.‚Äù

Wednesday‚Äôs statement is closer in line with the guidance of  reputable health agencies .

While some studies have raised the possibility of a link between Tylenol and autism, there have been no conclusive findings. Pregnant women are advised to consult a doctor before taking the medication.

The World Health Organization reiterated the point in September, noting that ‚Äúno consistent association has been established‚Äù between the medication and autism, despite ‚Äúextensive research‚Äù.

But claims to the contrary have already prompted efforts to limit the availability of Tylenol, a popular brand of acetaminophen, a fever- and pain-reducing medication.

On Tuesday, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton launched a lawsuit accusing Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, the companies behind the over-the-counter pain reliever, of deceptive practices.

In doing so, he reiterated misinformation shared by President Donald Trump and government officials like Kennedy.

‚ÄúBy holding Big Pharma accountable for poisoning our people, we will help Make America Healthy Again,‚Äù Paxton said in a statement, giving a nod to Kennedy‚Äôs MAHA slogan.

The suit alleges that Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue violated Texas consumer protection laws by having ‚Äúdeceptively marketed Tylenol as the only safe painkiller for pregnant women‚Äù.

It was the latest instance of scientific misinformation being perpetuated by top officials. Both Trump and Kennedy have repeatedly spread scientific misinformation throughout their political careers.

Trump linked autism and the painkiller during a news conference in September, without providing reputable scientific findings to back the claim.

‚Äú[Using] acetaminophen ‚Äì is that OK? ‚Äì which is basically, commonly known as Tylenol, during pregnancy can be associated with a very increased risk of autism,‚Äù Trump said on September 22. ‚ÄúSo taking Tylenol is not good. I‚Äôll say it. It‚Äôs not good.‚Äù

Kennedy has offered his own sweeping statements about Tylenol and its alleged risks, despite having no professional medical background.

‚ÄúAnyone who takes this stuff during pregnancy, unless they have to, is irresponsible,‚Äù he said in a cabinet meeting on October 9.

Kennedy also mischaracterised studies on male circumcision earlier this month. He  falsely  said the studies showed an increase in autism among children who were ‚Äúcircumcised early‚Äù.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs highly likely because they‚Äôre given Tylenol,‚Äù he added.

Kenvue stressed in a statement on Tuesday that acetaminophen is the safest pain reliever option for pregnant women, noting that high fevers and pain are potential risks to pregnancies if left untreated.

‚ÄúWe stand firmly with the global medical community that acknowledges the safety of acetaminophen and believe we will continue to be successful in litigation as these claims lack legal merit and scientific support,‚Äù Kenvue said.

articles.title: EU waters down climate target in last-ditch deal before COP30 in Brazil
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The European Union has compromised on its climate target by allowing up to 10% of its 90% emissions reduction goal by 2040 to be offset through foreign carbon credits, delaying the launch of its carbon market to 2028, and agreeing to reassess its 2040 target every two years. This decision, driven by industrial competitiveness concerns from countries like Poland, Slovakia, and Hungary, weakens the bloc‚Äôs climate ambition and draws criticism from environmental groups. The deal is a prelude to the UN COP30 climate summit in Brazil, where it is expected to influence global climate negotiations amid rising opposition from climate skeptics such as former U.S. President Donald Trump, and where climate justice, reparations, and historical accountability are being pushed as central issues.
keyTakeAways: The European Union has watered down its climate target by allowing up to 10% of emissions reductions to be offset through foreign carbon credits, weakening its commitment to domestic action.

The compromise allows countries to buy international carbon credits to cover up to 5% of their 90% emissions reduction goal by 2040, with a further 5% under consideration, effectively offloading responsibility to foreign nations.
The EU agreed to reassess the 2040 climate target every two years, introducing a mechanism for periodic evaluation that may reduce long-term consistency and ambition.
The launch of the EU carbon market has been delayed from 2027 to 2028, reducing the immediate environmental enforcement of climate policies.
Several member states, including Poland, Slovakia, and Hungary, opposed the target on grounds of industrial competitiveness, but the deal passed due to support from 15 out of 27 member states.
Environmental groups criticized the deal as undermining the EU‚Äôs climate leadership, arguing it introduces loopholes and weakens global climate ambition.
The deal is significant as it directly influences the European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen‚Äôs position at the upcoming COP30 climate summit in Brazil.
The compromise reflects broader global tensions where climate action is being challenged by economic and political interests, especially in the face of opposition from leaders like Donald Trump.

Title: EU waters down climate target in last-ditch deal before COP30 in Brazil

European Union climate ministers have struck a watered-down deal on emission-reduction goals as they have scrambled to win over member states before the United Nations  COP30 summit  in the Amazon.

Ministers approved a compromise early on Wednesday after marathon talks on how the bloc will go about slashing its greenhouse gas emissions by 90 percent by 2040, introducing flexibilities that will essentially offload some of the task onto foreign countries.

Under the compromise, countries will be allowed to buy foreign carbon credits to cover up to 5 percent of their overall target of cutting emissions by 90 percent compared with 1990 levels. In a further concession, the bloc also agreed to consider the option of using international carbon credits to meet a further 5 percent of its goal.

‚ÄúSetting a climate target is not just picking a number. It is a political decision with far-reaching consequences for the continent,‚Äù Danish Climate Minister Lars Aagaard said, adding that he and his colleagues had worked to provide ‚Äúcomfort‚Äù that would preserve ‚Äúcompetitiveness, social balance and security‚Äù.

In a further effort to win over sceptical members, EU countries agreed for the overall 2040 objective to be reassessed every two years. They also agreed to weaken other politically sensitive climate policies, delaying the launch of an upcoming EU carbon market from 2027 to 2028.

A handful of countries including Poland, Slovakia and Hungary opposed the 2040 climate target on the grounds it would hit industrial competitiveness, but they could not block the deal, which needed backing from only 15 of the EU‚Äôs 27 member states.

The UN had asked all governments worldwide to submit 2035 climate plans before the COP30 climate summit opens on Monday in Brazil. The deal means European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen will not go empty-handed to the meeting.

The talks will test the will of major economies to keep fighting climate change in the face of opposition from sceptics like United States President Donald Trump.

The EU, in particular, has prided itself on leading international efforts to curb climate change at past COPs, but climate concerns have recently taken a backseat to defence and competitiveness.

Environmental groups accused countries of undermining the bloc‚Äôs climate ambitions by pushing for loopholes.

Hundreds of environmental and human rights groups and activists penned a letter in late September urging COP30 to place justice and reparations for people unfairly affected by the climate crisis, colonialism and slavery at the centre of the talks.

articles.title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Australia is expanding its social media ban for children under 16 to include Reddit and Kick, alongside Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Threads, TikTok, X, and YouTube. The ban, set to take effect on December 10, 2025, aims to protect minors from harmful design features like opaque algorithms and endless scrolling. The government has met with platforms to enforce compliance, with non-compliance punishable by fines up to 49.5 million AUD. Critics argue the ban may limit children‚Äôs learning and development, and eSafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant will assess impacts such as changes in sleep and activity levels. The policy is being closely watched globally, and France has launched a criminal investigation into TikTok‚Äôs role in potentially pushing minors toward suicide due to its algorithmic content loops.
keyTakeAways: Australia is implementing a social media ban for children under 16 that includes Reddit, Kick, Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Threads, TikTok, X, and YouTube.

The ban is intended to protect children from harmful design features such as opaque algorithms and endless scrolling, with government officials stating it allows parents peace of mind and helps children have a safer childhood.

The ban is part of Australia's landmark online safety legislation passed in November 2024, and failure to comply with the rules could result in civil fines of up to 49.5 million AUD (approximately $32.1 million USD).

Critics argue that delaying children's access to social media hinders their learning and development, and eSafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant will evaluate potential unintended consequences such as changes in sleep patterns, physical activity, and social interaction.
The ban is being closely watched by other countries with similar concerns about the impact of social media on youth, especially due to the rise of harmful content and algorithmic design features.
France has opened a criminal investigation into TikTok‚Äôs role in potentially pushing young users toward suicide, citing concerns about the platform‚Äôs algorithm and ease of access by minors.
TikTok, owned by China-based ByteDance, has faced international scrutiny over content promoting self-harm, unhealthy body images, and foreign political interference.

Title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16

Australia‚Äôs upcoming  social media ban  for children under 16 years old will include the online forum Reddit and livestreaming platform Kick in addition to seven other well-known sites, according to the country‚Äôs online safety commissioner.

The social media ban will go into effect on December 10 and will also restrict access to Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Threads, TikTok, X and YouTube, Communications Minister Anika Wells said on Wednesday.

‚ÄúOnline platforms use technology to target children with chilling control. We are merely asking that they use that same technology to keep children safe online,‚Äù Wells said.

‚ÄúWe have met with several of the social media platforms in the past month so that they understand there is no excuse for failure to implement this law,‚Äù Wells told reporters in Canberra.

‚ÄúWe want children to have a childhood, and we want parents to have peace of mind,‚Äù she said.

Social media platforms have had 12 months to prepare for the ban since  Australia passed its landmark  online safety legislation in November last year.

Initial discussions focused primarily around Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, X and YouTube, but the list was later expanded, and Wells said the list could continue to change.

While more than 140 Australian and international academics signed an open letter to Prime Minister Anthony Albanese last year opposing the age limit ban as a ‚Äúblunt‚Äù instrument,  Canberra‚Äôs move  is being closely watched by countries that share concerns about the impacts of online platforms on children.

‚ÄúDelaying children‚Äôs access to social media accounts gives them valuable time to learn and grow, free of the powerful, unseen forces of harmful and deceptive design features such as opaque algorithms and endless scroll,‚Äù eSafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant said.

Inman Grant said she would work with academics to evaluate the impact of the ban, including whether children sleep or interact more or become more physically active as a result of the restrictions on using social media.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll also look for unintended consequences, and we‚Äôll be gathering evidence‚Äù so others can learn from Australia‚Äôs ban, Inman Grant said.

Critics have questioned how the restrictions will be enforced because users cannot be ‚Äúcompelled‚Äù to submit government IDs for an age check, according to a government fact sheet.

Discussions are under way with platforms about how to comply with the new rules, the commissioner said, while failure to comply could lead to civil fines of up to 49.5 million Australian dollars (US$32.1m).

News that Australia would add more names to the list of banned platforms came as French authorities said they had opened an investigation into the social media platform TikTok and the risks of its algorithms pushing young people into suicide.

Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau said the probe was in response to a parliamentary committee‚Äôs request to open a criminal inquiry into TikTok‚Äôs possible responsibility for endangering the lives of its young users.

Beccuau said a report by the committee had noted ‚Äúinsufficient moderation of TikTok, its ease of access by minors and its sophisticated algorithm, which could push vulnerable individuals towards suicide by quickly trapping them in a loop of dedicated content‚Äù.

TikTok did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The Paris police cybercrime unit will look into the offence of providing a platform for ‚Äúpropaganda in favour of products, objects, or methods recommended as means of committing suicide‚Äù, which is punishable by three years in prison.

The unit will also look into the offence of enabling ‚Äúillegal transactions by an organised gang‚Äù, punishable by 10 years in prison and a fine of 1 million euros ($1.2m).

With more than 1.5 billion users worldwide, TikTok, owned by China-based ByteDance, has come under fire from governments in Europe and the United States in recent years.

Concerns raised over the platform have included content encouraging suicide, self-harm or an unhealthy body image as well as its potential use for foreign political interference.

A TikTok spokesman told the French news agency AFP in September that the company ‚Äúcategorically rejects the deceptive presentation‚Äù by French MPs, saying it was being made a ‚Äúscapegoat‚Äù for broader societal issues.

articles.title: Kazakhstan, which already recognises Israel, to join ‚ÄòAbraham Accords‚Äô
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Kazakhstan, which has maintained diplomatic relations with Israel since 1992, has announced its formal participation in the Abraham Accords, a diplomatic initiative that normalizes ties between Israel and several Arab countries. The move follows a broader U.S. foreign policy push under former President Donald Trump, who brokered the original accords and continues to advocate for further normalization, including with Saudi Arabia. The announcement comes during a pivotal time in geopolitics, with Trump preparing to meet Central Asian leaders and as the global community grapples with unresolved conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon. Kazakhstan's decision is framed as a continuation of its foreign policy principles‚Äîdialogue, mutual respect, and regional stability‚Äîand coincides with a new U.S.-Kazakhstan cooperation deal on critical minerals. Despite the accords' success in fostering bilateral ties, they have not resolved the core Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and critics argue that they bypass the Palestinian issue, which remains central to the region's peace process.
keyTakeAways: Kazakhstan, which has already established diplomatic relations with Israel since 1992, is now formally joining the Abraham Accords, signaling a broader shift in Central Asian foreign policy toward engagement with Israel.
The announcement comes ahead of a key U.S.-Central Asian summit involving President Donald Trump and Central Asian leaders, highlighting geopolitical alignment between the U.S. and Kazakhstan.
The Abraham Accords represent a significant diplomatic shift in Middle Eastern geopolitics, normalizing relations between Israel and several Arab states, despite ongoing conflict with Palestinians.
Kazakhstan's decision to join the accords is framed as a continuation of its foreign policy principles: dialogue, mutual respect, and regional stability.
The move appears to strengthen Kazakhstan‚Äôs strategic alliance with the United States, especially as the two countries recently signed a cooperation deal on critical minerals.

The Abraham Accords, originally brokered by Trump, have continued under Biden, but have not resolved the Israeli-Palestinian conflict or the occupation of Palestinian territories, which human rights groups describe as apartheid-like.

Despite the accords' success in fostering bilateral ties, they have not resolved core issues of justice or peace in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and the Gaza war saw massive Palestinian casualties and destruction.

Trump has expressed a desire for Saudi Arabia to join the accords, but Saudi officials remain committed to the Arab Peace Initiative, which requires a Palestinian state as a precondition for normalization.

Title: Kazakhstan, which already recognises Israel, to join ‚ÄòAbraham Accords‚Äô

More than 33 years after establishing official diplomatic ties with Israel, Kazakhstan says it will join the so-called  Abraham Accords , which formalised ties between Israel and several Arab countries.

The announcement came on Thursday ahead of a meeting between United States President Donald Trump and the leaders of Central Asian countries.

‚ÄúOur anticipated accession to the Abraham Accords represents a natural and logical continuation of Kazakhstan‚Äôs foreign policy course ‚Äì grounded in dialogue, mutual respect, and regional stability,‚Äù Kazakhstan‚Äôs government said in a statement, according to the AFP news agency.

Earlier in the day, US envoy for the Middle East Steve Witkoff had announced that another country would join the normalisation deals without identifying it.

‚ÄúAbraham Accords are big. I‚Äôm flying back to Washington tonight because we‚Äôre going to announce, tonight, another country coming into the Abraham Accords,‚Äù Witkoff said.

It is not clear how joining the accords will affect the already established Kazakh-Israeli ties. The countries established diplomatic relations in 1992, shortly after Kazakhstan gained independence from the Soviet Union.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited Kazakhstan in 2016, and the two countries have several bilateral agreements.

The announcement comes at a time when Trump is promoting himself as a peacemaker after brokering the tenuous ceasefire in Gaza, despite the daily deadly Israeli violence against Palestinians and the escalation of Israeli  attacks in Lebanon .

Kazakhstan appears to be pushing to deepen its ties with the US as its President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev visits Washington. On Thursday, the two countries signed a cooperation deal over critical minerals.

During his first term, Trump brokered the Abraham Accords, a series of deals that formalised ties between Arab countries ‚Äì the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Morocco ‚Äì and Israel.

The push shattered Arab states‚Äô consensus over the 2002 Arab Peace Initiative, which conditioned recognition of Israel on the establishment of a viable Palestinian state.

Netanyahu has categorically rejected that ‚Äúland for peace‚Äù framework, pushing instead for deals with Arab countries that  bypass Palestinians .

Former President Joe Biden, who succeeded Trump, made expanding the deals a priority in his approach to the Middle East early on.

But the agreements ‚Äì brokered between countries that were never at war ‚Äì did little to resolve the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians and the decades-long occupation that leading rights groups say amounts to a  system of apartheid .

Still, the normalisation deals withstood the two-year war in Gaza, which saw Israel flatten much of the territory and kill more than 68,800 Palestinians.

The UAE and other countries involved in the agreements have maintained their trade and security ties with Israel.

In recent months, Trump has repeatedly said he hopes that Saudi Arabia will join the accords. But Saudi officials have stressed their commitment to the Arab Peace Initiative.

Title: Drinking water in Tehran could run dry in two weeks, Iranian official says

The main source of drinking water for residents of the Iranian capital Tehran is at risk of running dry within two weeks, according to state media, due to a historic drought plaguing the country.

The Amir Kabir Dam, one of five that provide drinking water for Tehran, ‚Äúholds just 14 million cubic metres of water, which is eight percent of its capacity‚Äù, the director of the capital‚Äôs water company, Behzad Parsa, was quoted as saying by the IRNA news agency on Sunday.

At that level, it can only continue to supply Tehran with water ‚Äúfor two weeks‚Äù, he warned.

The announcement comes as the country experiences its worst drought in decades. The level of rainfall in Tehran province was ‚Äúnearly without precedent for a century‚Äù, a local official declared last month.

The megacity of more than 10 million people is nestled against the southern slopes of the often snow-capped Alborz Mountains, which soar as high as 5,600 metres (18,370 feet) and whose rivers feed multiple reservoirs.

A year ago, the Amir Kabir dam held back 86 million cubic metres of water, Parsa said, but there had been a ‚Äú100 percent drop in precipitation‚Äù in the Tehran region.

Parsa did not provide details on the status of the other reservoirs in the system.

According to Iranian media, the population of Tehran consumes around three million cubic metres of water each day.

As a water-saving measure, supplies have reportedly been cut off to several neighbourhoods in recent days, while outages were frequent this summer.

In July and August, two public holidays were declared to save water and energy, with power cuts an almost daily occurrence amid  a heatwave  that saw temperatures rise beyond 40 Celsius (104 Fahrenheit) in Tehran and exceed 50C (122F) in some areas.

‚ÄúThe water crisis is more serious than what is being discussed today,‚Äù Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian warned at the time.

Water scarcity is a major issue throughout Iran, particularly in arid provinces in the country‚Äôs south, with shortages blamed on mismanagement and overexploitation of underground resources, as well as the growing impact of climate change.

Iran‚Äôs neighbour Iraq is  experiencing its driest year on record  since 1993, as the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, which flow into the Persian Gulf from West Asia, have seen their levels drop by up to 27 percent due to poor rainfall and upstream water restrictions, leading to a severe humanitarian crisis in the country‚Äôs south.

articles.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan exchange fire as ceasefire talks resume in Turkiye
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan and Afghanistan resumed ceasefire talks in Istanbul, Turkey, following deadly cross-border clashes that began on October 9, 2025, resulting in over 50 deaths and hundreds of injuries. Despite a ceasefire agreement brokered in Qatar on October 19, tensions remain high due to accusations each side makes about the other harboring militant groups, particularly the Pakistan Taliban. A brief exchange of fire occurred at the Spin Boldak and Chaman border areas, with Afghan officials blaming Pakistan and Pakistan countering that Afghanistan initiated the firing. The conflict remains unresolved, with both nations warning of renewed hostilities if the ceasefire fails. All major border crossings remain closed to civilians and trade, and although a monitoring and verification mechanism was agreed upon, implementation has been challenged by mutual distrust and ongoing hostilities.
keyTakeAways: Pakistan and Afghanistan are engaged in ongoing cross-border fighting despite a ceasefire agreement finalized in Qatar on October 19.
The conflict stems from security disputes, particularly over allegations that Afghanistan harbors the Pakistan Taliban (TTP), which Pakistan blames for attacks in its territory.
Afghanistan denies harboring such groups, and both sides accuse each other of violating the ceasefire, with recent incidents of fire along the border prompting renewed tensions.
The city of Spin Boldak in Kandahar was targeted in a brief exchange of fire, with Afghan officials claiming Pakistani forces opened fire, and Pakistan rejecting this, blaming Afghanistan.
Despite the ceasefire, all major border crossings remain closed to civilian and commercial traffic, affecting trade, movement, and humanitarian access.
A monitoring and verification mechanism was agreed upon during earlier talks in Turkey to ensure compliance and penalize violations.
The clashes resulted in over 50 civilian deaths and more than 400 injuries on the Afghan side, and 23 Pakistani soldiers killed and 29 wounded, indicating significant human cost.
Both nations warned of a resumption of hostilities if the ceasefire fails to be implemented effectively.

Title: Afghanistan and Pakistan exchange fire as ceasefire talks resume in Turkiye

Pakistan and Afghanistan have traded blame for brief cross-border fighting, as delegations from both countries met in Turkiye for talks aimed at securing a ceasefire following deadly clashes last month.

Thursday‚Äôs talks in Istanbul are intended to finalise  a truce approved on October 19 in Qatar  that ended a week of deadly clashes between the South Asian neighbours, which killed dozens of people, including soldiers and civilians, and wounded hundreds of others.

Security issues are at the heart of their dispute, with Islamabad accusing Kabul of harbouring groups such as the Pakistan Taliban (TTP), which is accused of launching attacks in Pakistan. The Taliban government in Afghanistan denies¬†these allegations.

‚ÄúWhile the third round of negotiations with the Pakistani side has begun in Istanbul, unfortunately, this afternoon Pakistani forces once again opened fire on Spin Boldak, causing concern among the local population,‚Äù Afghan government spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid said on Thursday.

The city of Spin Boldak is located in the southern Afghan province of Kandahar.

‚ÄúThe Islamic Emirate‚Äôs forces, out of respect for the negotiation team and to prevent civilian casualties, have so far shown no reaction,‚Äù Mujahid said on X.

Pakistan denied the accusation, pinning the blame on Afghanistan.

‚ÄúWe strongly reject claims circulated by the Afghan side regarding today‚Äôs incident at the Pak-Afghan border at Chaman,‚Äù Pakistan‚Äôs Ministry of Information & Broadcasting posted on X. ‚ÄúFiring was initiated from the Afghan side, to which our security forces responded immediately in a measured and responsible manner.‚Äù

Hamdullah Fitrat, deputy spokesman for the Taliban authorities, told the AFP news agency that ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt know the reason‚Äù for the Pakistani fire.

Ali Mohammed Haqmal, head of Kandahar‚Äôs information department, said the firing was brief. Residents told AFP it lasted 10-15 minutes.

Pakistan confirmed that calm had been restored.

Negotiations in Istanbul  reached an impasse  last week when it came to finalising ceasefire details, with each side accusing the other of not being willing to cooperate.

Both sides also warned of a resumption of hostilities in case of failure.

Despite the ceasefire, all important border crossings between Pakistan and Afghanistan remain closed to trade and civilian movement. The crossings were shut on October 12, though Pakistan has partially reopened two of those to allow Afghan refugees to return home.

Host Turkiye said at the conclusion of last week‚Äôs talks that the parties had agreed to establish a monitoring and verification mechanism to maintain peace and penalise violators.

Fifty civilians were killed and 447 others wounded on the Afghan side of the border during clashes that began on October 9, according to the United Nations. At least five people died in explosions in Kabul that the  Taliban government blamed on Pakistan .

The Pakistani army reported 23 of its soldiers were killed and 29 others wounded, without mentioning civilian casualties.

articles.title: Dutch court rejects bid to halt arms exports to Israel over Gaza war
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A Dutch appeals court has dismissed a lawsuit by ten pro-Palestinian NGOs seeking to halt all arms exports and economic ties to Israel, citing a 'grave risk' of genocide in Gaza but asserting that the Dutch government has 'considerable discretion' in foreign policy and national security. The NGOs, citing an International Court of Justice order from January 2024, argued that the Netherlands, as a signatory to the 1948 Genocide Convention, has a duty to prevent such acts. The court acknowledged the risk of genocide but ruled that the plaintiffs failed to prove the government routinely disregarded potential human rights violations. It also found that the Dutch state already took steps by halting most arms exports and allowing only defense system parts, such as the Iron Dome. The decision reaffirms the limits of judicial intervention in sovereign foreign policy, even in high-stakes humanitarian and legal contexts.
keyTakeAways: A Dutch appeals court dismissed a lawsuit by ten pro-Palestinian NGOs seeking to halt all arms exports and economic ties to Israel over alleged genocide in Gaza.

The NGOs argued that the Dutch state, as a signatory to the 1948 Genocide Convention, has a duty to prevent genocide and that exports of weapons and military dogs contributed to human rights violations.

The court acknowledged a 'grave risk' of genocide but ruled that the Dutch government has 'considerable discretion' in foreign policy and national security matters and cannot be compelled to impose a blanket ban.
The court found that the plaintiffs failed to prove the government routinely failed to assess whether exported goods would be used to violate human rights.
The Dutch government maintains it has already taken steps, such as halting most arms exports and only allowing parts for defense systems like the Iron Dome.
The ruling reinforces the principle that courts should not override sovereign foreign policy decisions, even in cases involving serious human rights concerns.

At least 68,875 Palestinians and 170,679 injured since October 2023, with over 1,100 deaths in Israel following Hamas attacks on October 7, 2023, and 236 Palestinians killed and 600 wounded in Gaza since the ceasefire.
The case underscores tensions between international human rights law and national sovereignty in foreign policy decisions.
