# Sexual Assault of the President Exposes Mexico‚Äôs Endemic Machismo

Published: 2025-11-06T16:00:32-05:00

When Claudia Sheinbaum was elected as Mexico‚Äôs first female president, many voters hoped that historic moment would represent the beginning of the end of the male-dominated, machismo culture that has long permeated Mexican society.

Thirteen months later, Ms. Sheinbaum was groped on the street by a constituent, a stark reminder that ‚Äî despite her efforts ‚Äî Mexico still has far to go in its attempts to ensure equality and safety for women.

Just how far is now the subject of a national conversation ‚Äî set off by the assault on Tuesday ‚Äî about the harassment, abuse and violence that women still face in Mexico. Online, on television and in their homes, women this week expressed indignation that not even the president was safe and resignation that nothing would ever change.

Ms. Sheinbaum herself said on Wednesday what many were wondering, asking, ‚ÄúIf this can happen to the president, what‚Äôs going to happen to all the young women and women across our country?‚Äù

For many women in Mexico, the crime against the president, during which a man tried to kiss her and put his hands on her chest, was a sad fact of life. Mexico has a long history of machismo, a culture that teaches men they are entitled to control women, according to Mexican activists and female politicians, as well as a system of norms that reinforce inequality and violence.

On the streets of Mexico City this week, many women could quickly recall frightening personal incidents ‚Äî men following them on the street or groping them on a crowded train. Many said they did not believe they could count on the police to pursue such cases, whether sexual harassment was a punishable crime or not.

In the capital, where sexual harassment and abuse are crimes, many women said the police would file a complaint only if a victim knew her abuser‚Äôs name. Going to the authorities was widely seen as a waste of time, they said; even if a complaint was filed, it would be unlikely to result in a full investigation or arrest, as it did in President Sheinbaum‚Äôs case.

This is true around Mexico, they said. ‚ÄúThere was no one to defend me,‚Äù said Ivett Jijon, 27, recounting when a man put his hand in her blouse at a bus stop in Cuernavaca when she was 18. ‚ÄúI felt afraid ‚Äî and helpless. It bothered me that there was nothing I could do.‚Äù

Ms. Sheinbaum entered office promising to make the country safer and more equal for women. Earlier this year, she said that her political movement was ‚Äúthe only one‚Äù that could improve women‚Äôs rights in Mexico. And from a policy standpoint, she has made clear progress.

She created a new pension program for women. She successfully pushed Congress to pass an amendment that now makes it unconstitutional to pay women less than men. And her administration has started to design an ambitious national system to care for children, older citizens and the disabled, with the intention of taking the burden off women who fall into caretaker roles.

She also forced all security and justice institutions to recognize that gender can be a factor in a crime. And she required every state to have a specialized prosecutor‚Äôs office for so-called femicides, which Mexico defines as murders in which the authorities can prove a woman was killed because of her gender.

‚ÄúNo more violence against women,‚Äù Ms. Sheinbaum said in March. ‚ÄúNo more femicide, no more beatings, no more abuse, no more violent words against Mexican women.‚Äù

On Thursday, in response to her assault, Ms. Sheinbaum unveiled a new national initiative against sexual abuse. The plan includes a push to make sexual abuse a punishable crime in every state in Mexico, education for prosecutors and judges on crimes against women, a new public campaign to encourage women to report sexual abuse, and a streamlined process to do so.

But changing the social dynamic in Mexico has been a challenge, data shows.

While Mexican women are still killed at higher rates than the global average, femicides, as they are defined by Mexican officials, are on track to hit a three-year low this year, with 513 reports through September.

Yet nonlethal violence against women has hardly budged. In September, there were 45,500 emergency calls for domestic violence, almost identical to a year prior. And reported crimes against women dropped only 2 percent in September from a year ago, to 23,100 reports.

Part of the problem, the data suggests, is that so many of the crimes go unpunished.

In the first nine months of this year, the authorities reported nearly 219,000 emergency calls for violence against women. But in that same period, only about 5,000 formal investigations were opened for gender-based violence.

That 44-to-1 gap reflects a broader reality in the country. Last year, 93 percent of all crimes were either not reported or not investigated, a national survey found. Among the reasons Mexican women said they don‚Äôt report crimes: They consider it a waste of time, they mistrust the authorities, and they are scared of their assailants.

‚ÄúWe want to strengthen the entire justice system, which I would argue is not up to the task of protecting women,‚Äù Citlalli Hern√°ndez Mora, whom Ms. Sheinbaum appointed as Mexico‚Äôs first minister for women, said in an interview. But, she added, that will not make a dent in the problem if Mexican society does not reject sexual harassment.

‚ÄúEven if we improve assistance, even if there are more reports,‚Äù Ms. Hern√°ndez Mora said, ‚Äúthe best way to engage with prevention and move toward eradication is through cultural change.‚Äù

To many, that the president of the nation was groped in broad daylight is proof that Mexico is far from the change Ms. Sheinbaum wants.

‚ÄúEven if she is the most powerful woman in this country, she is subject to being sexualized and victimized,‚Äù said M√≥nica Tapia, an expert on social policy who leads a group that trains women for political leadership in Mexico. ‚ÄúA citizen, with no respect for her presidential status or anything else, can see her as a woman he is entitled to touch and defy.‚Äù

Cyntia Barrera D√≠az contributed reporting.

articles.title: Anti-Defamation League Creates Antisemitism Tip Line Focused on Mamdani
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Anti-Defamation League (A.D.L.) has launched a website and tip line to monitor Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani's administration for potential antisemitic actions, following a campaign period marked by accusations of antisemitism. While the A.D.L. claims the initiative is a data-driven, fact-based approach not intended to criticize Mamdani, critics including J Street and the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations have accused the organization of unwarranted hostility and selective outrage, especially given President Trump‚Äôs long history of antisemitic rhetoric. keyTakeAways: The Anti-Defamation League (A.D.L.) launched a website and tip line to monitor Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani's administration for potential antisemitic actions.

articles.content:
# Anti-Defamation League Creates Antisemitism Tip Line Focused on Mamdani

Published: 2025-11-06T19:31:04-05:00

The Anti-Defamation League is facing backlash over what its critics have called unwarranted hostility toward Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, after the organization publicized a website and related tip line to monitor his administration for actions that could be construed as antisemitic.

The announcement of the initiative came after a closing stretch of the mayoral campaign during which Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs detractors, including Jonathan Greenblatt, the chief executive of the A.D.L., repeatedly accused him of antisemitism, a charge he has strongly rejected.

It is the latest in a series of controversial moves by the organization, which was founded in 1913 to fight antisemitism and other forms of prejudice, but which has adopted an increasingly antagonistic stance toward critics of Israel, including Mr. Mamdani.

On Wednesday, J Street, a liberal pro-Israel Jewish advocacy group, called the A.D.L. tracker ‚Äúalarming‚Äù and criticized a statement by the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, a coalition of dozens of Jewish leaders, that referred to Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs election as ‚Äúa grim milestone.‚Äù J Street argued that the groups taking aim at Mr. Mamdani had not applied the same scrutiny to President Trump, ‚Äúdespite his long record of using antisemitism and bigotry for political gain.‚Äù

J Street called on Jewish organizations to ‚Äúengage constructively with the mayor-elect, not sow panic or demonize him,‚Äù adding, ‚ÄúWe urge organizations such as the A.D.L. to lead with consistency and integrity, not selective outrage.‚Äù

In an interview, Mr. Greenblatt said the A.D.L.‚Äôs website and tip line were ‚Äúnot designed to criticize the mayor‚Äù but were instead ‚Äúa data-driven approach that simply looks at the facts.‚Äù

articles.title: Supreme Court Clears Way for Trump Transgender Passport Policy
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in favor of the Trump administration‚Äôs policy to stop issuing passports with gender identity markers selected by applicants, effectively reversing the inclusive policy introduced under the Biden administration. The decision, which was part of a broader effort by the administration to limit recognition of transgender identities, was upheld despite strong opposition from the A.C.L.U. and three conservative justices who dissented, arguing that the policy causes real-world harm and violates constitutional rights to privacy, equal protection, and freedom of expression. The case, Trump v. Orr, originated from a directive signed during President Trump‚Äôs second term, which rescinded prior policies allowing transgender individuals to self-identify on passports. The policy reversal is part of a larger pattern of executive actions targeting transgender rights, including in the military and prisons. The State Department had previously evolved its policy from requiring surgical transitions to allowing gender-affirming medical treatment, and eventually to offering gender-neutral 'x' markers. The legal challenge, initiated by the A.C.L.U. on behalf of transgender individuals, was initially blocked by a federal court in Massachusetts, which was later upheld by an appeals court. The Supreme Court's ruling, while not citing a vote count, marks a significant step in the ongoing national debate over transgender rights, government recognition, and constitutional protections.

The decision permits the administration to revert to using sex assigned at birth as the only basis for gender markers on passports.
The ruling was supported by a majority of the Supreme Court justices, with Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, Elena Kagan, and Sonia Sotomayor dissenting.
The American Civil Liberties Union (A.C.L.U.) argued that the policy violates constitutional rights to privacy, equal protection, and freedom of expression.
The case, Trump v. Orr, originated from a directive issued by President Trump during his second term to end gender-affirming gender marker updates on passports.
The policy reversal is part of a broader pattern of executive actions aimed at limiting government recognition of transgender identity.
The State Department‚Äôs policy has evolved from 1971 to allow self-identification, with a 2021 gender-neutral 'x' marker and a 2022 policy allowing any gender marker under the Biden administration.
The federal court in Massachusetts previously blocked the policy, and the appeals court upheld that decision in September 2025.

articles.content:
# Supreme Court Clears Way for Trump Transgender Passport Policy

Published: 2025-11-06T16:46:18-05:00

The Supreme Court cleared the way on Thursday for the Trump administration to stop issuing passports that include gender identity markings selected by applicants.

The emergency order, which will remain in place as the case makes its way through the lower courts, marked the latest victory for President Trump before the Supreme Court.

The case, Trump v. Orr, stems from a Trump administration policy to change gender requirements for passport holders. The policy has been blocked since June, when a federal court temporarily stopped the administration from enforcing it while the court case continued.

No vote count was given, as is typical in such cases, but the majority offered four paragraphs of reasoning for granting the administration‚Äôs request.

‚ÄúDisplaying passport holders‚Äô sex at birth no more offends equal protection principles than displaying their country of birth ‚Äî in both cases, the government is merely attesting to a historical fact without subjecting anyone to differential treatment,‚Äù the justices who sided with the Trump administration wrote in an unsigned order.

Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson wrote a dissent, and she was joined by the court‚Äôs two other liberals, Justices Elena Kagan and Sonia Sotomayor.

Justice Jackson wrote that it had become ‚Äúroutine‚Äù for the Trump administration to seek emergency relief from the justices after lower courts block its policies, adding: ‚ÄúAs is also becoming routine, this court misunderstands the assignment.‚Äù

She said that the government had found ‚Äúan obliging audience‚Äù for its efforts to change the passport rules among the Supreme Court justices.

Justice Jackson explained that she would have rejected the government‚Äôs request because ‚Äúthe documented real-world harms to these plaintiffs obviously outweigh the government‚Äôs unexplained (and inexplicable) interest in immediate implementation of the passport policy.‚Äù

Jon Davidson, senior counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union‚Äôs LGBTQ & HIV Project, which challenged the Trump administration policy, said in a statement that the court ruling was ‚Äúa heartbreaking setback for the freedom of all people to be themselves, and fuel on the fire the Trump administration is stoking against transgender people and their constitutional rights.‚Äù

The case arose in the early days of Mr. Trump‚Äôs second term as a legal challenge to an executive order signed by the president on his first day back in office. That order prompted the State Department to rescind longstanding policies allowing transgender people to update gender markers on their travel documents.

The mandate from the president was one of several intended to limit government recognition of transgender status, including orders barring transgender soldiers from the military, requiring the Bureau of Prisons to house female transgender prisoners in men‚Äôs prisons, and ending transgender medical treatments for federal inmates.

The State Department‚Äôs passport policies have grown more permissive since the agency issued its first directive on the subject in 1971. At the time, passports did not include a sex marker. In the late 1970s, the department began to include them on passports, a move that the government then attributed to the rise of unisex fashion and hair styles.

The State Department began allowing transgender people to obtain passports with updated sex markers in the 1990s, so long as they provided evidence of having undergone gender transition surgery. That requirement was rescinded in 2010, under then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, and the department began asking only that transgender passport applicants provide a doctor‚Äôs letter affirming that they had received ‚Äúappropriate clinical treatment for gender transition.‚Äù

In 2021, the State Department issued the first passport with a gender-neutral marker ‚Äî an ‚Äúx.‚Äù The following year, the Biden administration announced a policy allowing passport applicants to select any gender marker.

The A.C.L.U. challenged the Trump administration‚Äôs reversal of the passport policy, bringing a lawsuit in federal court in Massachusetts on behalf of seven people who claimed they had not been able to obtain passports that matched their gender identity because of the new policy, or that they would be harmed by the policy when renewing their passports.

In the lawsuit, the A.C.L.U. argued that the policy violated the Constitution‚Äôs right to travel and right to privacy, as well as the equal protection clause that requires that people be treated the same under the law. The group also claimed that the policy violated the passport holders‚Äô First Amendment rights, compelling transgender, nonbinary and intersex passport holders to go along with the government‚Äôs ‚Äúideologically-infused message that their sex is what the executive order defines it to be.‚Äù

In June, a federal judge in Massachusetts ordered the State Department to allow people whose gender identity is different from their sex assigned at birth to self-identify on their passports while the legal case proceeded.

On Sept. 4, a panel of appeals court judges unanimously upheld the lower court‚Äôs decision.

Weeks later, the Trump administration filed an emergency request with the Supreme Court, asking it to step in and clear the way for the new State Department policy to take effect.

In the emergency application, D. John Sauer, the solicitor general, argued that ‚Äúprivate citizens cannot force the government to use inaccurate sex designations on identification documents that fail to reflect the person‚Äôs biological sex ‚Äî especially not on identification documents that are government property and an exercise of the president‚Äôs constitutional and statutory power to communicate with foreign governments.‚Äù

Lawyers from the A.C.L.U., which represents the plaintiffs, responded that ‚Äúclassifying people based on sex assigned at birth and exclusively issuing sex markers on passports based on that sex classification‚Äù would deprive people of ‚Äúa usable identification document and the ability to travel safely.‚Äù

In a brief to the court, the A.C.L.U. lawyers asserted that their clients sought ‚Äúthe same thing millions of Americans take for granted: passports that allow them to travel without fear of misidentification, harassment or violence.‚Äù

articles.title: Mamdani Allies Create a Nonprofit to Push His Affordability Agenda

The initiative underscores a broader political struggle between grassroots advocacy and state-level resistance over the future of affordability policy in New York City.

# Mamdani Allies Create a Nonprofit to Push His Affordability Agenda

Published: 2025-11-06T18:28:59-05:00

Allies of Zohran Mamdani, girding for a fight to implement the incoming mayor‚Äôs ambitious economic agenda, unveiled a new advocacy group on Thursday designed to build pressure to pass it in New York City and Albany.

The group, Our Time for an Affordable NYC, will raise money to try to harness the energy of an army of volunteers that helped drive the huge turnout behind the mayor-elect‚Äôs win on Tuesday.

‚ÄúOur victory was historic, but the campaign for an affordable New York City is just beginning,‚Äù the group wrote on its website.

Our Time is legally distinct from Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs campaign or transition, but it is aligned with his specific vision. It says on its website that its mission is to ‚Äúwin and defend the agenda that resonated with voters: free child care, fast and free buses, freezing the rent and building affordable homes and more.‚Äù

The challenge ahead for Mr. Mamdani, a 34-year-old state lawmaker and democratic socialist, is immense. To finance his proposals, he has proposed securing billions of dollars in new income and corporate taxes.

That kind of revenue will require cooperation from the state government in Albany, where forces are already lining up to try to temper or kill aspects of Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs plans after he takes office in January.

# Justice Dept. Is Said to Be Investigating D.C. Mayor Over Foreign Trip

Published: 2025-11-06T17:13:15-05:00

Federal prosecutors have opened a corruption investigation into Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington, examining a foreign trip she took with members of her staff that was paid for by Qatar, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

The investigation, which is being handled by the U.S. attorney‚Äôs office in Washington, has been underway for months, but could face significant hurdles because of the known facts of the case and recent turmoil inside the Justice Department.

This week, the F.B.I. agent who was leading the investigation was fired by the Trump administration for having taken part in a criminal inquiry into President Trump‚Äôs attempts to overturn the 2020 election.

The public corruption unit inside the prosecutors‚Äô office that would typically be responsible for pushing the case forward has also been badly damaged by a series of dismissals and resignations stemming from Mr. Trump‚Äôs efforts to seek revenge against Justice Department officials and his perceived enemies.

It remains unclear how far the investigation into Ms. Bowser, a Democrat who has served as Washington‚Äôs mayor since 2015, has advanced since it was opened. But the people familiar with the inquiry said it was based on potential violations of bribery or campaign finance laws. A spokesman for the U.S. attorney‚Äôs office declined to comment.

There are also questions about the strength of the case. It is unclear whether the mayor‚Äôs office did anything for the Qatari government, which would be a critical element of any possible bribery accusation. And any criminal case involving campaign finance law would have to show that wrongdoing or misstatements were intentional rather than mistakes in paperwork.

The mayor‚Äôs office said in a written statement that it had not been notified of any investigation.

‚ÄúThis was a business trip,‚Äù the statement said. ‚ÄúD.C. representatives regularly travel to promote Washington as a destination for investment and growth,‚Äù and those efforts have brought business to the city, it continued. ‚ÄúAll proper paperwork for this standard donation is on file.‚Äù

The inquiry began in the wake of an April report by a local TV station, WJLA, over a trip Ms. Bowser and four members of her staff took to Dubai in 2023 for a United Nations conference on climate change. When questioned by reporters about the trip, the mayor‚Äôs office initially said it was paid for by the D.C. Chamber of Commerce. The mayor‚Äôs office then claimed the trip had been covered by the U.S. Conference of Mayors, a nonpartisan organization of leaders of relatively large cities. But it later emerged that the conference group had paid only a portion of the cost.

After that report, a nonprofit group called the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust filed an ethics complaint. Matthew G. Whitaker, who held the position of acting attorney general during Mr. Trump‚Äôs first term and now serves as the U.S. ambassador to NATO, once led the organization.

A March letter from Qatari officials to the mayor‚Äôs office shows that Qatar had paid more than $61,000 to bring Ms. Bowser and her team to Doha just before the conference. The mayor and her staff members traveled from there to Dubai, according to the TV station and the ethics complaint.

It would not be the first time a politician‚Äôs dealings with Qatar have invited scrutiny. In May, the Trump administration formally accepted a 747 jetliner from Qatar. Valued at about $200 million, the plane is meant to be upgraded to serve as Air Force One, making it one of the biggest foreign gifts received by the government. A political firestorm ensued, but no criminal investigation was known to have been opened.

The investigation into Ms. Bowser comes as the president has publicly demanded the Justice Department prosecute his perceived enemies, and fired prosecutors unwilling to obey those orders.

Charges have already been filed against two of them: James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and Letitia James, the New York attorney general, both of whom are being prosecuted in Virginia by an inexperienced U.S. attorney handpicked by Mr. Trump.

Ms. Bowser has clashed with Mr. Trump in the past. But the opening of the corruption investigation appears to have preceded their most serious conflict. That erupted over the summer when Mr. Trump, claiming he was rescuing the city from a violent crime wave, placed the Metropolitan Police Department under the control of the federal government and flooded city streets with hundreds of federal agents and National Guard troops.

After initially opposing the takeover, Ms. Bowser softened her stance somewhat, saying she wanted to work with the federal government to decrease crime. In August, she called his move to assert direct control over the city‚Äôs police force ‚Äúunsettling and unprecedented,‚Äù but appeared resigned to cooperate, stressing at a news conference that there was little she could do to block the effort.

In its broad contours, the investigation into Ms. Bowser recalls a similar inquiry into Eric Adams, the Democratic mayor of New York, who was charged last year by federal prosecutors in Manhattan in the waning months of the Biden administration.

Mr. Adams was accused of abusing his office to obtain free and discounted travel and illegal foreign campaign contributions, largely through his dealings with Turkish officials and wealthy foreign businesspeople.

The Trump administration ultimately moved to drop the charges, prompting a series of resignations by top officials in the U.S. attorney‚Äôs office in Manhattan, who claimed the Justice Department was seeking to curry favor with Mr. Adams to win his support for the president‚Äôs aggressive immigration agenda.

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: As the U.S. government shutdown continues, the Federal Aviation Administration (F.A.A.) is implementing planned reductions in air traffic, starting with a 4% cut on Friday and rising to 10% by the weekend. The cuts target the F.A.A.'s Core 30 list of busiest airports ‚Äî including major hubs like Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, and Atlanta ‚Äî as well as midsize airports with high cargo and private jet activity. The reductions are driven by severe staffing shortages, with air traffic controllers working overtime without pay. The Trump administration has not released a public list of affected airports, creating uncertainty for airlines and travelers. This situation highlights a systemic failure in aviation infrastructure management amid ongoing federal operations disruptions.
keyTakeAways: The Federal Aviation Administration (F.A.A.) has not publicly released a definitive list of 40 airports affected by planned air traffic reductions.
The reductions are expected to start on Friday at approximately 4% and increase to 10% by the weekend.
Affected airports are primarily from the F.A.A.'s Core 30 list ‚Äî the nation's busiest commercial airports ‚Äî and include major cargo hubs and private jet airfields.
The cuts are being driven by staffing shortages and controller absences, with many air traffic controllers working overtime without pay.
The core issue is a systemic strain on air traffic control infrastructure due to insufficient staffing, exacerbated by the ongoing government shutdown.

# Here Are Airports That Could Be Affected by the Air Traffic Slowdown

Published: 2025-11-06T14:56:48-05:00

With less than 24 hours to go before the Federal Aviation Administration‚Äôs planned air traffic reductions are set to take effect, the Trump administration has not publicly shared a list of the 40 airports that will be affected, or told many of the airports bracing for cuts how flights may be canceled.

The Federal Aviation Administration has shared a preliminary list of affected airports with airlines, according to three airline officials who declined to be named because they were not authorized to share that information. Although not finalized, the list shows the scope of the plans being discussed. Government officials have already said the locations with the most air traffic would be the focus of the cuts.

The cuts to flights will begin on Friday, when the affected airports are expected to see about a 4 percent reduction to their air traffic over the course of the day. Those cuts would deepen over the weekend until they reach the 10 percent level that Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy and F.A.A. Administrator Bryan Bedford announced on Wednesday.

The airports under discussion, according to government officials and airline industry executives familiar with the planning process, include those on the F.A.A.‚Äôs Core 30 list ‚Äî a roster of the nation‚Äôs busiest airports for commercial traffic ‚Äî as well as several high-traffic cargo hubs and airfields favored by private jets.

Other potential factors the government may consider include traffic, location and the strain on the local force of air traffic controllers ‚Äî most were already pulling overtime shifts to make up for severe staffing shortages even before the shutdown, and now they are forced to work throughout it without pay.

articles.title: The Colorful, Sequined Life of Judy Garland‚Äôs ‚ÄòLucky Jacket‚Äô
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article chronicles the journey of Judy Garland‚Äôs iconic 'lucky jacket' from its origin at her 1961 Carnegie Hall debut to its eventual return to the venue as a cultural artifact. Designed by Norman Norell, the jacket became a symbol of Garland‚Äôs personal triumph after a medical crisis and was later sold at auction in 1978. It passed through the hands of collectors, fans, and LGBTQ+ individuals, including Bob Cancellare and Michael Benson, who helped elevate its cultural significance. After decades of private ownership, the jacket was acquired by John Thomas, who proposed its transfer to Carnegie Hall for long-term preservation. The institution, with a modest annual budget, launched a $300,000 fundraising campaign to acquire and conserve it, reflecting public and cultural interest in preserving pop culture history. Ultimately, the jacket‚Äôs return to Carnegie Hall represents a symbolic reconciliation of personal legacy and public heritage, with both fans and institutions recognizing its value as a piece of American cultural history.
keyTakeAways: The Judy Garland 'lucky jacket' is a symbol of both personal and cultural significance, representing a major career resurgence and a turning point in her life after illness.

The jacket‚Äôs journey reflects broader social changes, especially in LGBTQ+ history, as it passed through hands of fans, collectors, and men in love with Judy Garland, showing how personal devotion can intersect with cultural memory.

The jacket‚Äôs value has evolved from a personal heirloom to a cultural artifact, with its value increasing from $3,000 at auction in 1978 to $250,000 in 2024, reflecting its growing recognition in the arts and heritage sectors.

Carnegie Hall‚Äôs acquisition of the jacket represents a reconciliation of personal history and public cultural legacy, with the jacket now being seen as part of the institution‚Äôs permanent collection.
The fundraising campaign, which reached $300,000, underscores public interest in preserving pop culture artifacts and the role of institutions in safeguarding historical narratives.

# The Colorful, Sequined Life of Judy Garland‚Äôs ‚ÄòLucky Jacket‚Äô

Published: 2025-11-06T11:00:18-05:00

Carnegie Hall is happy to flaunt its treasures. Benny Goodman‚Äôs clarinet is prominently displayed in its in-house museum, as are conductor‚Äôs batons once waved by Leonard Bernstein and Arturo Toscanini. But hidden away on the seventh floor is an acid-free paperboard box that the hall‚Äôs archivist, Kathleen Sabogal, keeps unlabeled.

‚ÄúI kind of put it like ‚ÄòRaiders of the Lost Ark,‚Äô‚Äù Ms. Sabogal said as she pulled the box off its shelf in the fire-resistant Archives Storage room. Inside: a silk evening jacket worn by Judy Garland during her Carnegie Hall debut, perhaps the most storied performance in the venue‚Äôs 134-year history.

In a review of the April 23, 1961, concert, The New York Times compared it to a ‚Äúreligious ritual,‚Äù referring to Garland as ‚Äúthe goddess‚Äù and noting the ‚Äúfrenzies of exaltation‚Äù and ‚Äúpandemonium‚Äù that greeted her renditions of ‚ÄúThe Trolley Song‚Äù and ‚ÄúOver the Rainbow.‚Äù

Discussions of that night tend to elicit a certain amount of breathlessness (see above), but facts are facts: The performance was attended by a number of stars, including Julie Andrews, Lauren Bacall, Richard Burton, Henry Fonda and Rock Hudson. A live recording of the show spent 13 weeks on the top of the Billboard album chart and earned Garland the Grammy for album of the year.

Whether or not the two-and-a-half-hour performance was, as Capitol Records crowed at the time, ‚Äúthe greatest evening in show-business history,‚Äù it symbolized a turning point in Garland‚Äôs career. Only a year earlier, she was discharged from Doctors Hospital in Manhattan, where she had received a diagnosis of acute hepatitis and had been told she might never work again.

In a career rife with comebacks, Carnegie Hall was perhaps the biggest of them all. And, if her family‚Äôs accounts are to be believed, the singer credited at least some of her good fortune to her ‚Äúlucky jacket.‚Äù

Because Garland wore it during the second half of the show, it has become known as the Act II jacket. It was the work of the Seventh Avenue studio of Norman Norell, a designer described as the ‚ÄúAmerican Balenciaga‚Äù for his couture-level craftsmanship.

A fringe of glass bugle beads trims the hem, giving the garment a dash of swish. Thousands of sequins, layered like disks of squash in a ratatouille, form the petals of blossoms that bloom across the chest, shoulders and sleeves. Some have suggested that the flowers may be poppies ‚Äî a reference to Garland‚Äôs most famous role, Dorothy Gale, a windswept Kansan who traipses through a poppy field on her way to meet the Wizard of Oz.

Over the decades, the jacket has passed through the hands of a succession of men. Some were Judy People ‚Äî fans who made honoring the star‚Äôs life and work a big part of their own life‚Äôs work. Others were simply men who loved men who loved Judy. The jacket‚Äôs unlikely journey tells a story of gay life in America, and how love and devotion can intersect with sequins.

Ms. Sabogal, 60, who started at the archives department in 1989, never imagined the jacket would wind up back at Carnegie Hall. ‚ÄúI just never thought that anyone would part with it,‚Äù she said. But last year she received an email that was as unexpected as it was businesslike: ‚ÄúI am offering the jacket for sale and would like to know if your museum would be interested in obtaining it,‚Äù the owner wrote. ‚ÄúPlease advise.‚Äù

The asking price was $250,000 ‚Äî 50 times the department‚Äôs total acquisition budget for the year.

When Judy Garland died, at 47, from an accidental barbiturate overdose, she was living in London with her fifth husband, whom she had married three months earlier.

Most of her belongings, including the jacket, were still in Los Angeles, the site of the last home she had owned. Her third husband, the producer Sid Luft, was the one keeping up the storage payments, and many of her things went to him by default.

The jacket‚Äôs travels began in the late ‚Äô70s, when Liza Minnelli, Garland‚Äôs firstborn daughter, was the toast of New York. Andy Warhol painted her portrait, Broadway gave her a third Tony Award, and she was a regular at Studio 54. So there were plenty of things she would rather have been doing than submitting paperwork to a trial judge 3,000 miles away.

The reason for the unpleasant chore: an auction of more than 400 of her mother‚Äôs belongings that had been organized by Luft. He had been hyping the sale for weeks, selling reserved seats for $25 apiece to the likes of Liberace and Debbie Reynolds. Ms. Minnelli filed for an injunction to stop it, to no avail.

‚ÄúOh, darling, I was just devastated ‚Äî both when I first heard about it and again when the judge decided to allow it,‚Äù Ms. Minnelli, 79, recently told The New York Times.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a lot of wonderful things to say about Sid,‚Äù she continued, ‚Äúwhich is awkward, because he‚Äôs the father of my sister, Lorna, and my brother, Joey. But he didn‚Äôt have the right to decide what items of Mama‚Äôs would be sold and what would stay with our family.‚Äù

On Nov. 27, 1978, Hollywood had its paddles at the ready to bid on pieces of history from one of its own. False eyelashes, golf clubs, copper cookware, musical arrangements: All went before the gavel in a ballroom of the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Beverly Hills.

This was when the mystique around the jacket ‚Äî listed as Lot No. 388, ‚ÄúBlack Silk Jacket With Mandarin Collar‚Äù ‚Äî started to take shape. ‚ÄúMiss Garland felt this was her lucky jacket,‚Äù a description in the catalog said. And when Joey Luft, Garland‚Äôs son, was asked if there was a particular item that held special significance for him, he singled it out. ‚ÄúThat was her lucky jacket, and she loved that very much,‚Äù the soft-spoken Mr. Luft, then 23, said in an appearance on ‚ÄúGood Morning America.‚Äù

Ms. Minnelli agreed it was special, saying her mother had ‚Äúalways felt the most like herself when she wore pieces like this.‚Äù Her only quibble was with the description. ‚ÄúI think calling it the ‚Äòlucky jacket‚Äô was more of Sid‚Äôs thing than Mama‚Äôs,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut, to be honest, I try not to remember a lot of what Sid said.‚Äù

On the big day, with Lily Tomlin vacuuming up scripts and ephemera in absentia, few noticed the Minneapolis man who made off with the Act II jacket for $3,000. The man, a collector and dealer named Gerald E. Czulewicz, couldn‚Äôt believe his luck. ‚ÄúI could sell the jacket within 72 hours for $5,000,‚Äù he said.

Mr. Czulewicz, a collector who specialized in Uncle Sam memorabilia, was the steward of the jacket from 1978 to 1992. What happened to it next is, in many ways, a love story.

The jacket found its way into Bob Cancellare‚Äôs life and living room through Michael Benson, a Judy Garland superfan.

‚ÄúHe had a great smile and an infectious manner,‚Äù Mr. Cancellare, 89, said. ‚ÄúI thought he was beautiful.‚Äù

They met each other in the mid-1980s at a Gay Men‚Äôs Health Crisis support group. At the time, Mr. Cancellare had recently lost his partner to AIDS, and Mr. Benson‚Äôs lover was dying.

Mr. Cancellare, who had his own real estate business in Manhattan, was then in his 40s; Mr. Benson, a charming man about town, was in his 20s. Not long after their first encounter, Mr. Benson moved into Mr. Cancellare‚Äôs walk-up apartment in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.

They never saw eye to eye on art and culture. Mr. Cancellare was a lover of classical music and opera who collected African sculpture, Japanese porcelains and the odd Indonesian sword, and he never quite shared Mr. Benson‚Äôs passion for all things Judy. But he was happy to help his partner buy Garland memorabilia during their years together.

For all his encouragement, though, there was one thing he couldn‚Äôt provide: the enthusiasm of a true fan.

In 1990, Mr. Benson reached out to John Fricke, a leading Garland expert, to compare collections, Judy Person to Judy Person. Soon, the two were hatching a plan for an exhibition at Lincoln Center to celebrate the 70th anniversary of Garland‚Äôs birth.

Both men knew they wanted the Carnegie Hall jacket on display, and they knew who had it. So they approached Mr. Czulewicz about a loan.

They ended up with more than 20 costumes, including the jacket, and they squeezed them into a gallery of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. In a review, a Times critic called the display ‚Äúintense,‚Äù adding that it was ‚Äúslightly over the rainbow, or at least over the top.‚Äù

Mr. Czulewicz visited the show, and Mr. Benson ‚Äúcharmed the guy into selling him the jacket,‚Äù Mr. Cancellare said. Mr. Benson made the purchase with underwriting from Mr. Cancellare and Larry Zimmermann, an early visitor to the exhibition. Mr. Zimmermann and Mr. Cancellare declined to reveal the purchase price.

Love doesn‚Äôt always follow the smoothest path: Mr. Benson soon started a relationship with Mr. Zimmermann, and they were the keepers of the Judy jacket for a few years. They placed it in ‚Äúseveral fashion shows,‚Äù Mr. Zimmermann said, as well as in an exhibition at the Museum of the Moving Image in London.

Once Mr. Benson and Mr. Cancellare were reunited, the jacket took up residence in the Chelsea apartment, where it remained well into the 21st century. Encased in a fiberglass vitrine, it was displayed against a wall hung with many of the African masks from Mr. Cancellare‚Äôs collection.

Mr. Benson died, from AIDS, in 2001. Mr. Cancellare held on to the jacket for another two decades. As the years went by, what had once been an engaging conversation piece at the couple‚Äôs New Year‚Äôs parties became ‚Äúpart of the furniture.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter 20 years, what difference does it make?‚Äù Mr. Cancellare said. ‚ÄúWhen we first got it, it was like a treasured object. But after a while, it just got ‚Ä¶ It was time for it to move on.‚Äù

On June 10, 2022, what would have been Judy Garland‚Äôs 100th birthday, the jacket was back in Los Angeles.

It was one of several costumes on display in an anniversary exhibition that doubled as a release party for ‚ÄúJudy ‚Äî A Garland Fragrance,‚Äù a unisex perfume with notes of orchid, pepper and tonka bean. (‚ÄúIt smells like Mama!‚Äù Ms. Minnelli, a partner in the venture, raved at the time.)

The spectacle was the work of the jacket‚Äôs new owner, John Thomas, 66, a veteran of the Hollywood memorabilia trade. He was most definitely not a Judy Person (‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt even seen ‚ÄòWicked,‚Äô‚Äù he said), but he knew a good investment when he saw one.

He had reached out to Mr. Cancellare when he was in the early stages of putting together the centennial exhibition. After dinner one night at an Italian restaurant in Chelsea, Mr. Thomas got a close-up look at the garment in Mr. Cancellare‚Äôs apartment. His opening offer was $8,000.

Mr. Cancellare didn‚Äôt go for it.

Mr. Thomas tried a different tack. ‚ÄúI went in with, ‚ÄòOh, all the young kids today, they don‚Äôt know who Judy is, it‚Äôs so important that we share this with them‚Äô ‚Äî almost tears,‚Äù he said of his performance.

They ultimately reached an agreement: $75,000, to be split between Mr. Cancellare and Mr. Zimmermann.

Mr. Thomas had big plans for a traveling exhibition of Garland movie costumes and ephemera. But apart from the weekend of the fragrance launch, he had trouble lining up dates. The jacket‚Äôs only other outing that year was an engagement at the site of its greatest triumph.

‚ÄúJudy Garland‚Äôs sequined jacket has entered the building!‚Äù Carnegie Hall announced in an Instagram post on Dec. 9, 2022. Three nights later, it was displayed in the venue‚Äôs second-floor Rose Museum, where fans were invited to look it over before taking their seats for a Garland tribute performance.

After the show, Ms. Sabogal, the Carnegie Hall archivist, extended an offer to Mr. Thomas: If he ever wanted to put the jacket on long-term display, the Rose Museum would be ready to receive it. When she heard from him 16 months later, it wasn‚Äôt to propose a loan.

Mr. Thomas‚Äôs $250,000 asking price hadn‚Äôt come out of nowhere. It was the same amount he had identified as the jacket‚Äôs value for insurance purposes. Still, for an archives department with an acquisition budget in the range of $5,000 a year, $250,000 was a lot of money.

Mr. Thomas wasn‚Äôt so sure about that. ‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòLook, if Carnegie doesn‚Äôt have 25 people who can pony up $10,000 each, what are you telling me?‚Äô‚Äù he recalled. He knocked $10,000 off the price, framing the discount as his personal contribution.

So began an unusual fund-raising effort, with one of the world‚Äôs most famous arts institutions rattling a virtual tin cup in hopes of ‚Äúbringing the lucky jacket back home to Carnegie Hall!‚Äù

To make sure it will be able to properly care for and display the jacket, Ms. Sabogal‚Äôs archives department is seeking an additional $60,000 for conservation-related expenses and a renovation of the Rose Museum.

Which is how Carnegie Hall came to set a goal of $300,000 for its fund-raising push ‚Äî 100 times what Mr. Czulewicz had paid for it at the auction nearly half a century ago.

When Mr. Thomas delivered the jacket to Carnegie Hall in August 2024, it was folded neatly and wrapped in tissue paper. ‚ÄúIt was pretty low-key,‚Äù Ms. Sabogal said of the handoff. It will remain with the archives department until the sale is complete.

Nicole Bloomfield, a textile conservator, has given it a thorough examination and proposed a course of treatment. With the exception of ‚Äúscattered areas of loss‚Äù ‚Äî Ms. Bloomfield‚Äôs rather poetic description of missing rhinestones, sequins and beads ‚Äî the jacket is in good condition.

When Carnegie Hall formally takes ownership, as it hopes to do by spring, the jacket will become as much the property of the Judy People as the non-Judy People. Practically everyone agrees that‚Äôs for the best.

‚ÄúThere are only two places in the world where that jacket could possibly belong,‚Äù Ms. Minnelli said. ‚ÄúWith my family or at Carnegie Hall. So I‚Äôm glad it will finally be there, where Mama made it a part of her legacy.‚Äù

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: As Nancy Pelosi retires from her role as House speaker, Republicans are shifting their attack strategy from targeting her to focusing on Zohran Mamdani, the newly elected democratic socialist mayor of New York City. They see him as a symbol of the Democratic Party‚Äôs leftward shift and are launching a digital ad campaign to vilify him as a radical, socialist threat. While some Republicans believe this new narrative will energize their base, Democrats are divided: some celebrate Mamdani as a generational, youth-driven progressive leader, while others caution that his local success does not represent national trends. Critics argue that such messaging is reductive, misleading, and ineffective in a non-presidential election year, especially given the geographic and political distance between New York City and other battlegrounds. Nonetheless, political analysts and strategists expect Mamdani‚Äôs image and policies to remain central in political discourse through 2026.

Mamdani, a 34-year-old democratic socialist and Muslim New Yorker, won the NYC mayoral election and is seen by Republicans as a symbol of radical socialism and Democratic ideological extremism.

Democrats are divided: some celebrate Mamdani as a generational talent and youth-driven representative of progressive values, while others caution that his local success does not necessarily reflect broader national trends.

The strategy of targeting a single figure (like Mamdani) is criticized as reductive and potentially misleading, especially in non-presidential years where national leaders like Trump are not on the ballot.

There is skepticism among both Republicans and Democrats about the effectiveness of a city-level political figure influencing national political discourse, particularly in battleground districts outside New York.
Mamdani‚Äôs affordability agenda has gained popularity, even with Republicans echoing it, indicating bipartisan appeal to economic issues.
Some Democrats argue that the focus should remain on statewide winners like Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill, who represent more tangible electoral strategies.

articles.content:
# As Republicans Retire Pelosi From Attack Ads, They Eye a New Villain

Published: 2025-11-06T15:16:20-05:00

Nancy Pelosi is out, and Zohran Mamdani is in. Or so Republicans hope.

After spending years ‚Äî and tens of millions of dollars ‚Äî pillorying Ms. Pelosi and seeking to tie her to seemingly every Democrat in America, Republicans are betting that their next boogeyman has arrived, just in time for Thursday‚Äôs retirement announcement by Ms. Pelosi, the former House speaker.

‚ÄúRadical socialist Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs win is the Democrat Party‚Äôs blueprint for America,‚Äù declared a statement from the House Republican campaign arm, as the committee began a digital ad campaign denouncing the new mayor-elect of New York City.

For Republicans facing a newly re-energized Democratic base and a potentially challenging midterms environment, a fresh foil couldn‚Äôt come soon enough.

In part, they hope to turn Mr. Mamdani into the next national-level villain because they think the 34-year-old democratic socialist vividly illustrates their argument that the Democratic Party has swung hard to the left.

But in a nonpresidential year, with President Trump in Washington and off the ballot, Republicans are also straining to galvanize their base. Some concede that it‚Äôs hard to rile up the party‚Äôs voters by pointing to current members of Democratic leadership, like Senator Chuck Schumer and Representative Hakeem Jeffries.

‚ÄúNancy Pelosi has been in more than one thousand Republican TV ads over the years ‚Äî and that‚Äôs not like an exaggeration, that‚Äôs a vast understatement ‚Äî but that‚Äôs kind of getting old,‚Äù said Curt Anderson, a veteran Republican strategist. ‚ÄúSchumer is not very useful, people don‚Äôt know him. Jeffries is kind of lackluster.‚Äù

Mr. Mamdani, he predicted, ‚Äúwill take over now in a lot of ways, as the sort of Republican example of, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt let this happen here.‚Äô‚Äù

Mr. Mamdani is a Muslim New Yorker who has already faced Islamophobic attacks, and demonizing him as the frightening new face of the Democratic Party could quickly get ugly.

Politically speaking, there are also evident limitations of such an approach.

While candidates running in battleground districts will certainly be asked about him, they are likely to dismiss such questions as hypotheticals ‚Äî or to use them to signal distance from the unpopular national party. They do not have to take a vote on Mr. Mamdani.

It was a different story in 2018, when Democratic House candidates were pushed on whether they would support Ms. Pelosi as speaker if their party reclaimed the majority.

Plenty of Democrats running in competitive races at the time said they would not back her.

That list included the moderate Democratic candidates Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey and Abigail Spanberger of Virginia, who won congressional seats that year as Democrats took back the House. Both won governor‚Äôs races this week.

‚ÄúRepublicans get a lot of mileage out of vilifying Democrats and trying to tie us all to the politics of one person, but they‚Äôre never afraid to take this to extremes,‚Äù said Representative Seth Moulton, a Massachusetts Democrat and Senate candidate, who tried unsuccessfully to block Ms. Pelosi from becoming speaker but praised her tenure on Thursday.

‚ÄúThey do it because they believe it‚Äôs an effective strategy, and I do think there‚Äôs some evidence that it works,‚Äù he went on. ‚ÄúBut will it be effective enough,‚Äù he added, to overcome Mr. Trump‚Äôs unpopularity? ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

There are also signs of skepticism among Republicans about the power of messaging about a mayor of a city hundreds or thousands of miles away from voters, even if the New York City mayor has an exceptionally large platform. It will depend in part, some say, on how he governs.

Brinker Harding, a Republican city councilman in Omaha who is running for Congress, alluded to Mr. Mamdani and New York in his announcement video. But even he conceded in an interview this fall that ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know that necessarily Nebraskans know who Mamdani is.‚Äù

Democrats, for their part, are divided over what Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs stunning ascent represents for their party more broadly.

To plenty, the answer is obvious.

Mr. Mamdani, they say, is a generational talent who should be elevated, emulated and included as part of the party‚Äôs efforts to reconstitute itself and push back against Mr. Trump‚Äôs Republican Party.

Dora Pekec, a spokeswoman for Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs transition, said his campaign ‚Äúbrought thousands of young and first-time voters into the political process ‚Äî and his affordability agenda is so popular that even Republicans are parroting it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that our party needs to have one face ‚Äî our country does not have one face,‚Äù Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, another favorite Republican boogeyman, said in an interview with MSNBC. ‚ÄúOur assignment everywhere is to send the strongest fighters for the working class wherever possible. In some places, like Virginia for the gubernatorial seat, that‚Äôs going to look like Abigail Spanberger. In New York City, unequivocally, it is Zohran Mamdani.‚Äù

It is a more complicated question for other Democratic leaders and strategists who want to harness Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs social media savvy, youthful appeal and compelling message on affordability ‚Äî but have reservations about how much to embrace the messenger himself.

Some would prefer to keep the focus on the statewide victories of Ms. Spanberger and Ms. Sherrill, arguing that those are far more instructive in understanding how to win competitive general elections.

Several Democrats running in competitive House districts, especially in the New York media market, have been quick to distance themselves from Mr. Mamdani.

‚ÄúIf he governs responsibly and focuses on what‚Äôs happening in the Midtown Tunnel instead of the Mideast, then I don‚Äôt think he is at all a challenge for Democrats in battleground districts across the country,‚Äù said former Representative Steve Israel of New York, a former chair of the House Democratic campaign arm. ‚ÄúThis midterm will be a referendum on Donald Trump and his handling of the economy.‚Äù

But it was possible, he said, that Mr. Mamdani could be a greater factor in Long Island and Hudson Valley-area battleground House districts, where residents absorb New York City news coverage and in many cases commute to the city.

‚ÄúI do not think that what happens in New York City represents where the country is writ large,‚Äù said Representative Laura Gillen, a Long Island Democrat and Mamdani critic, urging her party to ‚Äúlead from the middle‚Äù in a September interview.

‚ÄúThat is the path forward for Democrats, and I do not think that that is representative of what Mr. Mamdani stands for,‚Äù she said.

In one sign of the strong feelings the New York mayor‚Äôs race inspired beyond the five boroughs, several attendees at the election-night watch party for Andrew M. Cuomo, Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs chief opponent, said they were from Long Island, Westchester or New Jersey.

‚ÄúThere is high likelihood that Mamdani, his likeness and image, will appear in many ads in 2026,‚Äù said John Brabender, a longtime Republican strategist who was a media consultant to Mr. Trump‚Äôs campaign. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how he‚Äôs not part of the discussion.‚Äù

# Stefanik to Launch Campaign to Challenge Gov. Hochul in New York

Published: 2025-11-06T19:12:24-05:00

Representative Elise Stefanik, a conservative upstate New York Republican with close ties to the White House, is preparing to announce as early as Friday that she will run for governor next year, according to three people briefed on her plans.

The move, which is expected to be announced in a video, sets up a ferocious political battle between one of President Trump‚Äôs fiercest allies and Gov. Kathy Hochul, a moderate Democrat. The contest is likely to be one of the key races in next year‚Äôs crucial midterm elections.

A spokesman for Ms. Stefanik would not comment about her plans. The people familiar with her intentions were not authorized to discuss them and cautioned the timing could still change.

Ms. Stefanik, 41, began her career as a Harvard-educated moderate, working in the White House of former President George W. Bush and for Paul Ryan, the 2012 Republican vice-presidential nominee.

But since Mr. Trump‚Äôs first election, she has moved ever closer to the center of his orbit. She was a visible defender during his impeachments and amplified his lies about the 2020 election. Later, her viral showdowns with Ivy League university presidents about antisemitism on campuses helped push several to resign.

Those qualities have brought her enormous fund-raising numbers and a national reputation among Republicans, but have also saddled her with baggage that could encumber her in a state that Democrats have governed for decades.

Ms. Stefanik has made no secret about her eagerness to challenge Ms. Hochul, 67, who has faced middling poll numbers for much of her tenure. Many of the congresswoman‚Äôs recent moves could be seen as a preview of her campaign strategy: conflating Ms. Hochul with Zohran Mamdani, now the mayor-elect of New York City, and running as their foil.

Ms. Stefanik, a political pugilist, has aggressively criticized Mr. Mamdani, a democratic socialist, calling him an ‚Äúantisemite communist‚Äù and a ‚Äújihadist terrorist sympathizer,‚Äù and has sought to tie him to Ms. Hochul, who endorsed him, at every opportunity.

She frequently calls Ms. Hochul the ‚Äúworst governor in America.‚Äù

By formally beginning her campaign just days after the New York City mayoral election, Ms. Stefanik could use Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs victory to amplify her appeals to donors.

As the news broke Thursday night, Ms. Hochul was more than 1,600 miles away in San Juan, P.R., where Democrats hosted an annual post-election political conference. She stood onstage beside the ocean and celebrated Democratic victories on Tuesday, including Mr. Mamdani‚Äôs.

She did not immediately address Ms. Stefanik‚Äôs expected entry into the race, and a spokeswoman for Ms. Hochul‚Äôs campaign declined to comment.

Addison Dick, the spokesman for the state Democratic Party that Ms. Hochul controls, called Ms. Stefanik a ‚Äúrubber stamp in Washington for Trump‚Äôs deeply unpopular agenda that is raising costs, gutting health care and defunding New York schools, hospitals and police.

‚ÄúVoters in New York and across the country rejected Trump and his enablers earlier this week, and Stefanik will face the same fate when she launches her campaign to put Trump ahead of New Yorkers,‚Äù he added.

Ms. Hochul has been governor since 2021, when she stepped in following the resignation of former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. She was elected the following year in a close contest with Lee Zeldin, a Republican who now leads the Environmental Protection Agency.

Ms. Stefanik is expected to have considerable support from leading New York Republicans. But her decision to announce now may have something to do with getting ahead of another Republican and Trump ally who has signaled he might run. On Wednesday, Bruce Blakeman, the Nassau County executive, told The New York Post that he was weighing jumping in after winning re-election.

A spokesman for Mr. Blakeman declined to comment.

A third Republican, Representative Michael Lawler, had also explored a run for months, but decided against it as Ms. Stefanik began telegraphing her intent. He was said to have analyzed the race and determined it would be difficult for a Republican to win.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of support in the Conservative Party for Elise Stefanik,‚Äù said Gerard Kassar, the chairman of the New York State Conservative Party. ‚ÄúBlakeman, as far as I can tell, is in a very real exploratory process, but he hasn‚Äôt made any decisions."

It is not clear how favorable the electoral landscape will be for New York Republicans next year. Tuesday‚Äôs elections saw a national swing against Republicans, with Democrats handily winning gubernatorial elections in Virginia and New Jersey and the anti-Trump candidate, Mr. Mamdani, winning the mayoral election in New York City.

Ms. Stefanik could also face criticism for her association with several of the members of the New York State Young Republicans, which was disbanded after its racist and antisemitic chat was leaked. Ms. Stefanik condemned the messages, but also criticized the reporting in Politico which brought them to light, calling it a ‚Äúhit piece.‚Äù

When she won her North Country seat in 2014, Ms. Stefanik was the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. In the intervening years her loyalty to Mr. Trump helped her to ascend to the position of No. 3 House Republican, following the ouster of Representative Liz Cheney.

Shortly after his election, Mr. Trump nominated Ms. Stefanik to serve as ambassador to the United Nations, a post she accepted. But months later he rescinded the invitation, fearing the loss of her House seat in a special election.

She has since made it clear to colleagues that she does not want to stay in Congress.

Ms. Stefanik has spent much of 2025 elevating her statewide profile, in part by situating herself as the leader of the MAGA wing of the Republican Party in New York.

Her entry into the governor‚Äôs race means it is likely to pit two women from far outside New York City against each other in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans and where the population is concentrated in and around the five boroughs, many of whose voters dislike Mr. Trump.

The president vowed to withhold more federal funds from the city if Mr. Mamdani won ‚Äî a dynamic that could prove tricky for Ms. Stefanik, who has shown no willingness to criticize Mr. Trump.

‚ÄúI think Elise Stefanik typifies the exact type of politics that has created so much despair across this city, across this state and across this country,‚Äù Mr. Mamdani said on Thursday.

Asked if he would support Ms. Hochul‚Äôs campaign, Mr. Mamdani said she had yet to ask for his endorsement but he looked forward to working together.

# Obesity Drugs May Drop to as Little as $149 a Month

Published: 2025-11-06T18:27:50-05:00

President Trump on Thursday announced a deal that could significantly expand access for millions of Americans to hugely popular obesity drugs by reducing the price to as little as $149 a month.

The Trump administration‚Äôs agreements with the drugmakers Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly would save consumers and the government considerable money on Wegovy, Zepbound and two obesity pills that are expected to win regulatory approval in the coming months.

The lowest price, of $149 a month, will be available only for the lowest doses of the pill form of the drugs. When those drugs reach the market, Medicare and Medicaid will pay that price, as will Americans using their own money to buy the pills directly from manufacturers.

Mr. Trump, top U.S. health officials and drug company executives at the White House outlined broader coverage of the injectable drugs for people on Medicare and Medicaid, the federal insurance programs for older people; many who have disabilities; and those with lower incomes. The deal also lowers the prices the government programs will pay.

Those measures are likely to expand access but still will stop far short of covering all of the millions of people with obesity under the federal programs.

Officials said that within the next few months, Americans would be able to use their own money to buy Novo Nordisk‚Äôs Wegovy and Eli Lilly‚Äôs Zepbound ‚Äî which are each taken as weekly shots ‚Äî directly from manufacturers for an average of $350 a month, depending on the dose. The officials said they expected the average cost to fall to $245 over the next two years.

articles.title: Republicans Block Measure to Bar Military Strike on Venezuela
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: On November 7, 2025, Republicans blocked a Senate resolution aimed at preventing President Donald Trump from conducting military strikes in Venezuela without congressional authorization, highlighting growing internal dissent within the party over the administration's expanding military campaign against drug cartels. While the resolution was rooted in the 1973 War Powers Act, it faced little chance of passage in the Republican-led House and could have been vetoed by the President. Only two Republicans‚ÄîRand Paul and Lisa Murkowski‚Äîsupported it, signaling concern over executive overreach and the potential for regime change in Venezuela. Critics, including Democrats and some GOP senators, argue that the military actions‚Äîsuch as 16 airstrikes on drug-run boats and a buildup of military forces‚Äîlack clear legal justification and may be aimed at destabilizing Maduro‚Äôs government. The White House provided a classified memo justifying the strikes, but it is seen by lawmakers as vague and lacking specific authority for land-based attacks. Key figures like Senator Todd Young and Thom Tillis voiced concern over the expansion of executive war-making, emphasizing the need for congressional oversight and transparency.
keyTakeAways: Republicans blocked a resolution that would have required congressional authorization before President Trump could launch a military strike on Venezuela.
The vote reflects internal Republican concern over the expansion of executive war-making and lack of transparency in the administration's 'war on drugs' campaign.
The resolution was based on the 1973 War Powers Act, which requires Congress to act swiftly to end unauthorized overseas hostilities.
Only two Republicans‚ÄîSenators Rand Paul and Lisa Murkowski‚Äîsupported the resolution, indicating limited bipartisan concern over the military actions.
The Trump administration has conducted 16 airstrikes on drug-run boats, killing at least 67 people, with no clear legal justification for land-based military action against Venezuela.

Critics, including Democrats and some Republicans, argue that the military buildup and strikes are part of a broader strategy to destabilize Venezuela‚Äôs government, potentially leading to regime change.
The White House provided a classified memo justifying the strikes, but lawmakers say it lacks specific legal authority and does not support land-based attacks on Venezuela.
Several GOP senators expressed reservations about the actions, emphasizing that current strikes do not constitute a full-scale war and calling for a more focused discussion on war powers.
Senators like Todd Young and Thom Tillis stressed concerns over executive overreach and the risk of entangling the U.S. military in international conflicts without congressional oversight.

# Republicans Block Measure to Bar Military Strike on Venezuela

Published: 2025-11-07T00:25:22.903Z

Republicans on Thursday blocked a resolution that would prevent President Trump from attacking Venezuela without explicit congressional authorization, turning back an effort to ensure that Congress has a say in his escalating military campaign against drug cartels.

The 51-to-49 vote against bringing up the resolution came as the president was weighing possible military action against President Nicol√°s Maduro of Venezuela, with some senior aides advising Mr. Trump to oust Mr. Maduro from power.

Democrats and a small number of Republicans have grown increasingly alarmed about Mr. Trump‚Äôs expanding war, carried out without consultation with or authorization by Congress. They have pressed for more information and involvement in a campaign whose legal basis remains murky.

Those concerns have grown as the Trump administration has built up military force in the Caribbean ‚Äî including the movement of the Pentagon‚Äôs newest and largest aircraft carrier to the region ‚Äî and continued airstrikes on boats that officials say are ferrying drugs to the United States. Lawmakers have been left largely in the dark about the scope of, or endgame for, the operations.

But on Thursday, even Republicans who voiced serious concern about the strikes and the administration‚Äôs lack of consultation or transparency on them voted against the effort to insist on a definitive role for Congress.

Senator Todd Young, Republican of Indiana, said in a statement that his vote should not be read as an endorsement of the administration‚Äôs ‚Äúcurrent course‚Äù in the Caribbean and the Pacific.

‚ÄúAs a matter of policy, I am troubled by many aspects and assumptions of this operation and believe it is at odds with the majority of Americans who want the U.S. military less entangled in international conflicts,‚Äù Mr. Young said. ‚ÄúThe strategic objective of militarizing a ‚Äòwar on drugs‚Äô is unclear at best,‚Äù he added, and lamented ‚Äúthe creeping expansion of executive war-making ‚Äî under presidents of both parties ‚Äî without congressional input or oversight,‚Äù calling it ‚Äúdangerous.‚Äù

Only two Republicans, Senators Rand Paul of Kentucky and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, joined Democrats on Thursday in voting for the measure.

Senators Tim Kaine of Virginia and Adam B. Schiff of California, both Democrats, and Mr. Paul brought up the resolution under the 1973 War Powers Act, a law that requires swift action on a measure to put an end to unauthorized overseas hostilities.

The resolution had no real path to enactment; even if the Senate had passed it, it was all but certain to fail in the Republican-led House, which has been exceedingly deferential to Mr. Trump. And if the measure had passed both chambers, Mr. Trump could have vetoed it.

But Mr. Paul, a libertarian who routinely opposes U.S. military intervention overseas, said before the vote that Republican support for the measure would signal that some within the president‚Äôs own party were increasingly uncomfortable with his policies abroad.

Last week, the Senate voted three times to end Mr. Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariffs, and the Venezuela vote was just one more sign, Mr. Paul said, of ‚Äúgrowing discontent.‚Äù

Last month, Republicans voted to block a resolution that would halt Mr. Trump‚Äôs boat strikes. Since that vote, the Pentagon has carried out another dozen attacks, bringing the total to 16 and the number of people killed to at least 67.

Ms. Murkowski was the only Republican to join Mr. Paul in voting for that measure.

Mr. Schiff said it ‚Äústrains credulity‚Äù that the Trump administration would deploy dozens of military aircraft and ships and around 10,000 troops to the region to counter small drug-running boats.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs really an open secret that this is much more about potential regime change, and if that‚Äôs where the administration is headed, if that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre risking and along with a war, then Congress needs to be heard on this,‚Äù he said.

Given the military buildup in the region, Mr. Paul said, the ‚Äúrisk of imminent involvement in hostilities is evident.‚Äù

Mr. Paul said the U.S. had learned from conflicts in Iraq and Libya that ‚Äúforeign military interventions often ends up making things worse.‚Äù

The White House in recent days gave Congress access to the classified memo outlining its legal justification for the strikes at sea. Some top lawmakers have also received classified briefings.

But Democrats said that memo is thin and overly general, and does not cite any specific legal authority for direct military action on land to counter narcotics trafficking.

‚ÄúIt makes no effort to claim that there‚Äôs a legal rationale for invading the sovereign nation. No effort to claim that it‚Äôs about Venezuela or could be used with respect to Venezuela,‚Äù said Mr. Kaine.

Many G.O.P. senators voiced full-throated support for the president‚Äôs decision to engage in armed conflict with cartels carrying drugs across the U.S. border.

‚ÄúWhatever power that President Trump would like to use to stop that, I think he has the authority under the Constitution,‚Äù said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina.

Republicans who voted against the resolution said the president‚Äôs strikes so far did not constitute wartime action, but that if the Senate was going to attempt to enforce the War Powers Act, it should focus on the boat strikes, not on a land strike that had yet to unfold.

‚ÄúIf you want to have a serious conversation about war powers, I‚Äôm ready to have it. But I don‚Äôt think this is that,‚Äù said Senator John Curtis, Republican of Utah.

Senator Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, voted against the resolution but said that if the strikes continued, Congress might need to act.

‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre having the same discussion and the same things are going on a few months from now, and it‚Äôs not a dozen or so, but 50 or so, then we have to have a real discussion about whether or not we‚Äôre engaging in some sort of a hybrid war,‚Äù Mr. Tillis said.

# U.S. Sends Attack Aircraft to El Salvador Amid Regional Troop Buildup

Published: 2025-11-07T00:57:23.466Z

At least three U.S. military aircraft, including a heavily armed attack plane, have begun flying missions out of El Salvador‚Äôs main international airport in an expansion of the extraordinary U.S. troop buildup in the Caribbean, according to an analysis of satellite images, air traffic control communications and flight tracking data.

The attack plane, an AC-130J Ghostrider, is designed to destroy targets on the ground or at sea using missiles or barrages from its cannons and machine guns. It is operated by the Air Force Special Operations Command, a unit that carries out sensitive missions for the military. The New York Times also identified a Navy reconnaissance plane and a rarely seen, unmarked Air Force jet at the airport.

The influx of forces into the region started in late August, just before the Trump administration began launching what it said were counternarcotics missions while also planning for possible military action in Venezuela. The buildup has included about 10,000 U.S. troops along with drones, bombers and nearly a dozen Navy warships, soon to be bolstered by the arrival of the aircraft carrier Gerald R. Ford. So far, the Department of Defense has reported 16 lethal strikes on boats it says were involved in drug smuggling.

The deployment to El Salvador is likely to be the first time a foreign country has hosted U.S. planes that may be involved in military strikes in the region. And it further reflects the warm ties between the Trump administration and El Salvador‚Äôs president, Nayib Bukele, who has aided President Trump‚Äôs immigration strategy by jailing deportees from the United States at a notorious maximum-security prison.

The New York Times

‚ÄúIn this sphere, they seem so well aligned,‚Äù said John Walsh, director for drug policy and the Andes at the Washington Office on Latin America, a human rights organization.

Neither Mr. Bukele‚Äôs office nor El Salvador‚Äôs Embassy in the United States responded to a request for comment about the planes‚Äô deployment. Two U.S. military officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters, confirmed to The Times that the presence of these aircraft is related to the increase in counternarcotics missions in the region.

The Times first identified the U.S. planes through satellite images of Cooperative Security Location Comalapa, a small American military outpost at El Salvador‚Äôs main airport.

El Salvador

International

C-40 Clipper

P-8A Poseidon

AC-130J Ghostrider

El Salvador

International Airport

Source: Satellite image captured by Planet Labs on Nov. 5.

By Lazaro Gamio

The outpost, which was established in 2000 to support counternarcotics missions, hosted Navy surveillance aircraft until 2022. Since then, satellite imagery shows, the base has been used little, with only occasional Department of Homeland Security aircraft visible there.

Along with the Ghostrider gunship, there is also a Navy P-8A reconnaissance plane, which is equipped with cameras that can collect intelligence from thousands of feet in the air. The P-8A is also capable of launching torpedoes and anti-ship missiles.

A third military aircraft, the unmarked C-40 Clipper, has been at the base since mid-October. Little is known about its purpose, but flight-tracking data has shown it occasionally flying with surveillance aircraft. It is rarely spotted in public and its deployment to El Salvador, especially alongside an attack plane, is highly unusual.

It‚Äôs unclear if the aircraft are participating in airstrikes, but their deployment to the outpost coincided with an increase in attacks on targets in the eastern Pacific Ocean, which borders El Salvador. The Trump administration has provided little legal justification for the strikes, and Democrats in Congress and experts on the laws of war have called them unlawful.

Adm. James Stavridis, a former head of Southern Command, which includes El Salvador in its area of operations, said the outpost was used in the past for disaster relief, and humanitarian and counternarcotics operations.

‚ÄúThe base is very, very important for soft power,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúbut is clearly being used for hard power today.‚Äù

A Times analysis of publicly available radio messages between military aircraft and air traffic controllers found that the P-8A reconnaissance aircraft had flown at least six missions out of El Salvador. The attack aircraft and the Air Force jet have each flown at least one mission, the radio communications show.

The military planes typically broadcast their locations and directions of flight before cutting off contact with air traffic controllers somewhere over the Pacific.

In one message, the pilot of the P-8A reconnaissance plane hinted at its destination, saying the plane was ‚Äúproceeding operational due regard in international airspace at this time.‚Äù

‚ÄúDue regard‚Äù is a phrase that military pilots use when they are embarking on a mission and will stop communicating with air traffic control.

Eric Schmitt and Annie Correal contributed reporting.

articles.title: AR-15 Ammunition at a Crime Scene? Good Odds This Army Plant Made It
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article reveals that the Lake City Army Ammunition Plant, located near Kansas City, Missouri, produces a significant volume of 5.56-millimeter and .223-caliber ammunition used in AR-15-style rifles. From 2017 to 2024, law enforcement agencies reported spent casings from Lake City ammunition at more than twice the rate of any other manufacturer, indicating a strong link to criminal activity. This includes major incidents such as the 2022 Uvalde school shooting and a 2022 St. Louis high school attack. The data, obtained through public records requests by The New York Times and the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, highlights how widely available and frequently used these rounds are in mass shootings, raising concerns about the role of U.S. military ammunition facilities in civilian firearm violence.
keyTakeAways: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant, located just outside Kansas City, Missouri, manufactures ammunition widely used in AR-15-style rifles, which are common in mass shootings.
The AR-15 rifle, known as 'America‚Äôs rifle,' has become a symbol of civilian firearm access and has been central to several high-profile mass shootings, including the Uvalde and St. Louis attacks.

From 2017 to 2024, over 7,400 law enforcement agencies reported spent casings from Lake City ammunition at more than twice the rate of any other manufacturer, indicating frequent use in criminal incidents.

Lake City-produced rounds, especially 5.56-millimeter and .223-caliber, are common in crimes due to their widespread availability through online and retail channels.
